Paragraph: In 1818, Mary Shelley's ''Frankenstein'' raised the specter of machines running amok. But in keeping with Isaac Asimov's Three Laws of Robotics, written as part of a short story in 1942, many literary robots are designed to avoid harming humans; consider the lovable odd couple R2-D2 and C-3PO in George Lucas's ''Star Wars'' movies. Still, given the rise of military drone aircraft that use artificial intelligence software in staging attacks, it seems unlikely that the next generation of humanoid robots will prove so benevolent.    JOHN MARKOFF
Title: Statues to Golems to R2-D2

Paragraph: Some golfer. Fortunately, you'll never have to meet him in the finals of the club championship. He's a robot. This really isn't the 9th hole at Kittansett. This is inside a theater-like room in New Bedford, Mass., at a laboratory of the Acushnet Company, one of the dominant makers of golf balls. The robot - known as ''Iron Byron,'' since its swing mimicks the classic motion of the stellar professional, Byron Nelson - is firing balls at a net, behind which is a slide projection of Kittansett's 9th hole. Infrared cameras connected to a computer reveal precisely where - and how far -the balls went. The researchers have been studying the aerodynamics of a golf ball, in particular what happens when you change the little circular indentations known as dimples.
Title: IN PURSUIT OF THE PERFECT GOLF BALL

Paragraph: Robots are still used primarily in the auto industry, but electronics and drug companies are expected to increase their use of the machines during the next five years. Paragraph: AN industry of the future - artificial intelligence - needs philosophers. ''Programmers for computers are a dime a dozen, but what is needed are people who can take vaguely formed problems and find ways to make them precise enough to be programmed,'' Dr. Glymour added. ''This is what philosophers can do and they are planning a major role in artificial intelligence.'' ''For the past 40 years,'' he continued, ''American philosophy has been closely tied to the logical and mathematical study of knowledge and inference. The theories produced in these areas have been precise enough to be used in the design of artificial intelligence programs.'' As a result, Carnegie-Mellon six months ago began a program for a major called ''Logic and Computation,'' which involves studying the technical and theoretical issues in artificial intelligence.'' He pointed out that many leaders in the field of artificial intelligence have backgrounds in philosophy, with emphasis on logical thought. One is Dr. Herbert Simon of the Carnege Mellon faculty, who is a Nobel Prize winner. ''He took lots of philosophy,'' Dr. Glymour said last week. The major also requires a few courses in mathematics, including calculus, statistics, philosophy, linguistics, and psychology. Specialties can be pursued in depth, such as in computer science, artificial intelligence and computational linguistics. Professional career opportunities open for such majors in the new program include research programming, artificial intelligence, program development, industrial applications of computational linguistics, and teaching in the field.
Title: Careers; Philosophy Majors in Demand
Other (positive): promising careers in AI

Paragraph: Raymond Kurzweil, known throughout the field for his inventions using artificial intelligence, said he was always on the lookout for employees with backgrounds in three fields: psychoacoustics, the study of subjective response to sound; signal processing, the conversion of sound waves into digitized form, and phonemics, the study of phonetically similar but slightly different sounds in language. ''A lot of these areas were once considered obscure academic disciplines,'' he said. ''But now these people are very much in demand and, unfortunately, in short supply.''
Title: TEACHING COMPUTERS TO HEAR

Paragraph: WOODS HOLE, Mass., July 15                     An undersea robot entered the sunken luxury liner Titanic today through a skylight, worked its way down the grand stairway and descended four levels for the first view of the great wreck's deep interior. The self-propelled vehicle loaded with television and still cameras is called Jason Jr., and this trip, financed by the Navy, is officially a test of its abilities. The robot is scheduled for eight more dives on this mission, one each day, weather permitting, and will explore as much of the ship's interior as it can. The Alvin is carried on the fantail of the research ship Atlantis II, which launches the craft over her stern. The Alvin, which has three small viewing ports, carries the video robot in a basket on its bow.
Title: UNDERSEA ROBOT GETS A LOOK INSIDE STILL-LUXURIOUS TITANIC
Other (positive): exploration  robots go where humans can't, AI advances science

Paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13—                     The International Business Machines Corporation today announced a three-year multimillion-dollar project in artificial intelligence with Carnegie-Mellon University, as part of what the company called ''a major new I.B.M. initiative'' in advanced software. ''There is something of an awakening under way at I.B.M.,'' said Raj Reddy, head of Carnegie-Mellon's robotics institute and a leading authority in artificial intelligence. ''Four or five years ago, when you mentioned artificial intelligence, I.B.M. shrugged its shoulders.'' Under the agreement announced today, I.B.M. will provide Carnegie-Mellon with about $5.5 million in computer equipment and will negotiate contracts for individual studies in artificial intelligence. The equipment is primarily the PC/RT, an engineeering and scientific computer introduced earlier this year.

Paragraph: And yet, for all its virtues, ''Death of the Soul'' leaves one uneasy. For one thing, Mr. Barrett never makes clear just why he wants to defend the human soul. The virtue of doing so may be self-evident, but one can still imagine any number of different explanations, ranging from religious to practical. A defendant might be justifying his belief in God and the immortality of the human soul, or he might be trying to save technology the pointless bother of building a computer that can think like a human. Mr. Barrett never really declares himself, yet it is hard to shake the feeling that he has some ulterior purpose and that it has less to do with disinterestedly addressing the problem of artificial intelligence and more to do with his unarticulated religious faith.
Title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES

Paragraph: ''The Mystical Machine: Issues and Ideas in Computing,'' by John E. Savage et al. ($21.95 from Addison Wesley, Reading, Mass,), is a textbook, and might be expected to have little general appeal. However, it is also one of the best introductions to computing - for those who realize that it will take a little effort to work their way through it - that I have seen in some time. Starting out with what has become an almost mandatory capsule recapitulation of early computer history, from the abacus right up through binary logic, it then moves with rather more enlightenment through computer architecture, operating systems, problem solving, basic programming concepts, computer languages and the latest electronic evolution in the realms of artificial intelligence and factory automation.
Title: THE SOFTWARE WRITER AS ARTIST

Paragraph: Having a robot in the house may sound like science fiction, but it's not. Meet the Dustbot. This small, battery-operated robot will roam over your dinner table vacuuming up crumbs. It needs no supervision -when it reaches the edge of a table, it automatically turns around and continues its work. The Dustbot, which stands five inches tall, comes in red or white and costs $25 at Robot & Son in the Fulton Market building at the South Street Seaport. Disco Belt: The ''Palladium belt'' is for carefree dancing at the discotheque. Made of buttery soft Italian leather, it has a built-in zippered pocketbook and wraps around the waist. Paragraph: Indeed, the French have become increasingly passionate about prehistory. The tourism department of the Aquitaine region, to which the Dordogne belongs, plans to build within three years, a Prehistoland park of 988 acres with hotels and amusement centers and robot dinosaurs and other prehistoric beings programmed by computer. Bookstores overflow with works on prehistory. Small museums across the nation display treasures dug from sites, perhaps the best being the Musee des Antiquites Nationales in St.-Germain-en-Laye, near Paris, which has a small copy of Lascaux. (The museum is open from 9:45 A.M. to noon and from 1:30 to 5:15 every day except Tuesdays and holidays. Adult admission is $1.60.) In the Dordogne, people dig in fields for prehistoric flints. A student selling sandwiches on a Dordogne train sees a visitor reading a book on prehistory and stops to expound on the subject. A woman harvesting walnuts near Les Eyzies puts down her basket to show a visitor her collection of flints.
Title: PREHISTORY'S UNDERGROUND MUSEUMS

Paragraph: A.I., for artificial intelligence, is nothing more than a bit of electronic legerdemain. Going by the normal definition of the word ''intelligent,'' there is no such thing as intelligent software, nor is there likely to be in this millennium. There are, however, ways of designing software so that it becomes reasonably easy for the intelligent person to use it. This is, in effect, what Q & A strives for.  It is disheartening, then, to find that the first message to greet the would-be user trying to enter the world of Q & A through its interactive tutorial is the on-screen communication, ''WARNING: Other program(s) currently installed may be incompatible with AutoMentor. If any problems occur, please try again after removing the other program(s). This may require a change to Autoexec.bat and/or Config.sys files.''
Title: A BUILT-IN ELECTRONIC BUDDY SYSTEM
Other (negative): no such thing as intelligent software

Paragraph: ''As he's coming out, the robot is there,'' the lieutenant continued. ''The operator is 50 feet away, in another room. And we have personnel in strategic locations.'' Just as the man stepped through the doorway, a beam from a high-intensity light atop the robot blasted into his eyes. ''It provided distraction for our people to move in and grab him,'' the lieutenant said. ''It gave us milliseconds.'' ''There's a clear distinction between this robot and the ones used by the bomb squad,'' Lieutenant Baker said. ''It's the application that's different. Our machine's purpose is to investigate hostile environments in place of a human. It's to take the senses of a police officer - eyes, ears, touch, even speech - and bring them into a dangerous situation. That keeps the police officer safe. You blow away a bucket of bolts, not the cop.'' The robot is connected to its control cart by a 360-yard cable. Besides the television monitor, the cart carries one end of the two-way audio system used for communicating with suspects.

Paragraph: Now, however, for all its strengths, there is no denying the weaknesses of both the shuttles and the policy that relied almost totally on a single launching system. In these bleak, uncertain times for the American space program, the current inactivity at Canaveral becomes all the more painful, even a little embarrassing, in the light of recent developments in the Soviet Union, Western Europe and Japan. Any assessment of the magnitude of the shuttle disaster must take into account the following: The world's scientists gather this month not in Pasadena or Houston, but in Moscow and Darmstadt, West Germany, to receive the first closeup images of Halley's comet. Two Soviet spacecraft, Vega 1 and Vega 2, make the first encounters with the comet, followed by the European Space Agency's Giotto craft and two smaller Japanese probes. American scientists have instruments aboard the Soviet craft, and American antennae are helping to track the robot travelers, but this is hardly the leading role that has come to be expected of American science in the realm of interplanetary exploration. Money for an ambitious American Halley's mission was diverted to meet shuttle development costs. On Feb. 20, the Soviet Union took another big step in its drive to establish a permanent human presence in space. A new-generation space station, named Mir, for ''peace,'' was launched into orbit to serve as the core facility in a proposed complex containing living quarters and a variety of research, manufacturing and observation stations. By contrast, the United States is just starting its own space station project, scheduled to be deployed in the mid-1990's.
Title: AMERICA'S FUTURE IN SPACE AFTER THE CHALLENGER

Paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich.                     A TECHNICIAN confronted a cranky ASEA robot that was refusing to start. Once again, he went through the starting routine, pressing the buttons on the front of the robot's free-standing control cabinet in the correct sequence. Still a warning light glowed red and the big orange robot arm refused to budge. The program that the Ford technician, Glenn Jimmerson, used to ''solve'' the safety switch problem contained an expert system, a form of artificial intelligence. An expert system does not simply execute a predetermined set of instructions, as with conventional programs. Instead, it interrogates the operator and uses the responses to decide where the problem lies. Ford calls its system a Maintenance Assistant. Mr. Whitney said Ford would make the program available to robot manufacturers free of charge. And it will demonstrate it next week at the Robots 10 conference in Chicago along with a direct message to robot makers. ''We are going to tell suppliers that this is a feature that we, as a major user, want,'' he said. ''We want to get new equipment up and running as quickly as possible and reduce the number of house calls they have to make for de-bugging.'' Since each robot has its own peculiarities, the Ford system is directly applicable only to the ASEA robots. But Mr. Whitney said the framework softwear was commercially available and each robot company has its own experts to provide the necessary knowledge base.
Title: Technology; A System Aids Use of Robots
Other (positive): business interest and investment in AI, tech supporting AI

Paragraph: Furthermore, those selling the computer revolution - ''the hackers and the hucksters,'' as Mr. Roszak repeatedly calls them - have provided some fat targets. Artificial intelligence has been hyped and oversold, as most computer scientists now realize. Most of what now sells as artificial intelligence is a species known as ''expert systems,'' complicated hierarchies of rules that capture none of the creativity of real thought. Also, Mr. Roszak notes a good deal of confusion about the proper role of computers in education. As he points out, most students really have no need to learn to program a computer, unless acquiring that skill is done for the sake of familiarity and demystification, like learning a little bit of automobile repair. BUT Mr. Roszak goes beyond debunking. His vision of the computerized society becomes astoundingly apocalyptic, and even the most confirmed hater of bits and bytes will find some of his fears hard to take seriously. Is it true that ''some people relish the image of schools where ranks of solitary students in private cubicles sit in motionless attendance upon computer terminals, their repertory of activities scaled down to a fixed stare and the repetitive stroking of a keyboard''? Or that ''the computer makers have a vested interest in the technological unemployment of willing and available teachers''?
Title: FUNKY BITS, FUNKY BITES

Paragraph: The troubles facing the Superspeed Project follow similar reductions in the scale of the project's more ambitious sister program, the much-publicized Fifth Generation effort to develop machines capable of replicating human reasoning. But that exploration into artificial intelligence was expected to be the more difficult task, while the Superspeed Project was expected to play to Japan's strength: improving on existing technologies to increase the raw speed of computers. Some Insist Project Ought to Be Private ''It's very strange,'' said Kazuhiro Fuchi, director of the Fifth Generation project and one of Japan's best-known computer researchers. ''What should be the simpler project is proving the more difficult.'' Now, he said, ''There are some people who think the whole supercomputer development should be done privately rather than as a Government project.''

Paragraph: How does it know which part of the letter provides the address to which the missive is supposed to go? Well, that's where the program's so-called artificial intelligence comes in, although ''automatic abstraction'' might be a more appropriate term for its capabilities. What Q & A does is to search the document for the first line of text beginning at the left margin. It ignores any lines that are indented, like the sender's address. It also ignores any line ending in two or more digits, for instance March 9, 1986, interpreting such an entry as a date.
Title: EXTRA POWER, WITHOUT THE HASSLES

Paragraph: The best political column-readers read newspaper columns the way columnists read each other. They ask: 1. Does this satisfy the hunger of current interest? A pundit, to be helpful, must address Topic A before it becomes Topic Done to Death. An occasional change of pace is nice, but keeping ahead of the pace is what transforms ''night reading'' to first-thing-in-the-morning reading. 2. Does this divide the house? A column should take the fuzziness out of debate and show where a principle is at stake or a policy is wrongheaded or an outrage is being perpetuated or a promise broken. Let politicians temporize and voters agonize; the columnist should crystallize or polarize. 3. Does this put something new on the news agenda? Reporters are usually better reporters than thumbsuckers like to admit, but too often they are dispatched in packs. The column reader looks for the diamond in the trash can, the overlooked story, as well as the story to be alert for in weeks ahead - which pushes reporters to uncover it first, lest the Op-Ed page beat the front page, an embarrassment to all. 4. Where did he get this stuff? Most columnists have been around forever; the good ones use their time-tested sources, the bad ones let their sources use them. By reading a column over time, the shrewd reader spots who gets sent off and who gets sent up, and how often the pundit is mouthpiece or originator. 5. Does this guy have a point of view I can identify with, or at least reject with consistency? If a reader finds a pundit or two whose logic marches, whose premises do not waver, and who is unafraid to make judgments that cost him friends, then the reader can make use of the column in striking a judgment while the issue is hot. 6. Will I ever be surprised? Sometimes consistency is for hobgoblins; the same knee never jerks in exactly the same way. No political column should collapse into dreary expectability, because moods and mindsets change, and the reader is entitled to a little suspense in discovering where the pundit comes out. 7. Is this the product of a committee or a robot - or a flesh-and-blood individual with idiosyncracies and crotchets? In punditry, personality counts. The reader has to trust somebody in the opinion mafia, and an individual with a byline and a style is easier to love or hate than an institution.
Title: In 750 Words

Paragraph: Lady Lovelace also foresaw the continuing controversy about computers' artificial intelligence. Her judgment, included in the ''Notes,'' which were published in Taylor's Scientific Memoirs in 1843, holds good today: ''It can do whatever we know how to order it to perform. It can follow analysis; but it has no power of anticipating any analytical relations or truths. Its province is to assist us in making available what we are already acquainted with.'' Her achievement was all the greater because the Analytical Engine existed only on paper. Unlike Babbage's Difference Engine, it was never built. That her ''Notes'' amounted to a list of instructions to make the Analytical Engine perform and were, therefore, the world's first computer program was discovered by B. V. Bowden in Manchester in 1953. From then Ada Byron's resurrection was swift; her apotheosis came in 1979 when the Department of Defense named its new standardized computer language ADA in her honor.
Title: Byronic, Despite Everything

Paragraph: That is the founding principle of one of the most provocative areas of current research -artificial intelligence. George Johnson's very readable book adeptly sizes up competing technologies, sketches philosophical and procedural debates and gives a primer of computing, an outline history of artificial intelligence research and a fascinating depiction of science when it is conducted with business (and the Defense Department) hovering outside the laboratory door. Mr. Johnson's journalistic approach has drawbacks; he tends to avoid extensive analysis, and his discussion of important topics is sometimes cursory. However, in a field where science fiction and fact are often difficult to distinguish - as one researcher said recently, ''It's a very real challenge to try to separate the essence from the hype, and get a sense of clarity  [ about ]  what the issues are'' - this book should be instrumental in clarifying issues for scientists and laymen alike.
Title: IN SHORT: SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY

Paragraph: IN this vast work-in-progress that we call New York, change is a constant, giving the city's face a quicksilver quality: Vistas are transformed and the landscape is recast. At no time of year, probably, is this so evident as the early fall, when New Yorkers return to their neighborhoods to discover the panoply of new restaurants, museums, clubs, shops, theaters, amusements and a mind-boggling miscellany of other things that have made their debuts during the seemingly lazy days of summer. This year, of course, is no exception. Outdoor artworks have appeared in the most unexpected places. A talking robot has come to midtown and the Bronx Zoo's Himalayan snow leopards finally have a new home. In addition to the six newcomers shown here, eight other recent arrivals are featured on page C28.
Title: 14 REASONS WHY NEW YORK IS NEW

Paragraph: Jurors who favor the death penalty, in sharp contrast to the other jurors, are concerned with the guilt or innocence of the defendants and tend not to side automatically with the prosecution - as you mistakenly contend - but rather to weigh the evidence objectively. A juror who sincerely believes that the death penalty is proper justice for conviction of brutal and deliberate murder, and who believes that it is a deterrent for others who contemplate similar acts, is not a bloodthirsty robot who wishes anyone accused of murder to be found guilty and executed, regardless of the evidence. That is what you imply.
Title: Jurors Who Favor the Death Penalty Are Fairer

Paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21—                     The International Business Machines Corporation said it had entered a joint-development agreement with Intellicorp Inc., a company specializing in artificial intelligence technology. Financial terms were not disclosed. The agreement calls for Intellicorp, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., to develop a version of its flagship product, the KEE System, for use on I.B.M. System/370 mainframe computers. The KEE System, or Knowledge Engineering Environment, is a software product used to develop other artificial intelligence programs and currently runs on technical work stations, such as those produced by Sun Microsystems Inc. and the Digital Equipment Corporation. Under the agreement, the I.B.M. version of KEE will be marketed by both Intellicorp and I.B.M. but will be distributed exclusively by I.B.M. Intellicorp is receiving development funding from I.B.M. and will also receive a royalty on sales.

Paragraph: What one might want at other times is fire. Mr. Bolet's Schumann (the Fantasy) never got red in the face, and his Haydn was unusually pensive and melancholy (but so beautifully phrased!) in the familiar F minor Variations and E-flat Sonata. The G minor Ballade of Grieg was the highlight of the program, brooding and northerly in spirit, stunningly realized on the piano in all sorts of obvious and less-than-obvious ways. (One long passage involves sonorous middle-register chords at moderate volume, each followed by an ''echo'' in the outer registers. It's difficult to balance; to balance about a dozen in a row with the weighting perfectly matched each time, you must really know what you're doing.) Mr. Bolet was filling in for a canceled recital by Martha Argerich, and he zipped in between European engagements to do so. Perhaps that could have something to do with the relatively low temperature of the recital, and perhaps also with a memory slip or two. But those are almost a badge of honor nowadays, since they at least prove that a pianist and not a competition robot is on the stage. And Mr. Bolet's pianism merits honor all around.
Title: MUSIC: JORGE BOLET AT THE PIANO

Paragraph: Hal, movie buffs will recall, was the name of the sinister computer in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' (It was a play on the initials of the biggest computer company around, I.B.M.; go back one letter on each initial and you get H.A.L.) This Hal, too, used artificial intelligence, allowing the astronauts to converse with it in English. Instead of typing long strings of cryptic code into the computer terminal, an astronaut could simply say, ''Open the pod bay doors, Hal.'' And instead of responding with an enigmatic ''fatal error'' message, the computer might purr right back, ''I'm afraid I can't do that, Dave.''
Title: TRANSLATING LOTUS 1-2-3 INTO ENGLISH

Paragraph: Mr. Roland says the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is neglecting unmanned technology. Wrong. More than half the current budget goes to these activities. NASA's new civil space technology initiative, for example, begins this year to replenish the technology ''bank'' on which we have been drawing for two decades and is heavily laden with automation, robotics and artificial intelligence programs. Mr. Roland says that unmanned spacecraft can do any missions better and cheaper. Wrong. Talk to the scientists who learned for the first time with Spacelab just how critically important an on-the-spot human brain and pair of hands can be; it's still by far the best general-purpose computer-manipulator combination. And although the first wave of space exploration was conducted (properly) by robot spacecraft, the goals of the next wave are simply too complicated for fully automated systems. All four of the next-generation ''great space observatories'' - the Hubble space telescope, the gamma-ray observatory, the advanced X-ray astrophysical facility and the space infrared telescope facility - require people to maintain, repair and reprogram them.
Title: Why People in Space Can Outperform Robots
Other (positive): AI aids in space exploration, NASA has faith in and funds AI NASA's new civil space technology initiative

Paragraph: The fact that the most daunting voyages are the most expensive has its positive side, however. The extravagant cost of travel to some destinations helps to protect them from human incursion, thereby safeguarding myths whose existence we relish. We can believe in the possibility that dinosaurs still roam the Congo's jungles only as long as travel in the Congolese interior remains an expensive rarity and large regions remain unexplored. The delicious possibility of finding monsters on Mars won't evaporate completely until we can afford to land there some time in the next century and confirm the negative observations made by the Viking robot spacecraft.
Title: Next Stop: the South Pole
Other (negative): negative observations made by the Viking robot spacecraft on Mars

Paragraph: Agenda classifies the notes the user writes on a personal computer as items. Items are grouped into categories, manually at first but automatically later, if the user wishes, as the structure of the data base develops to the point where artificial intelligence can take over. Categories can be inspected on their own or slices can be taken from various categories in response to a query such as ''What are the items on my agenda for Monday?'' or ''What items involve Peter?'' The idea for Agenda so consumed Mr. Kapor's interest that he stepped down as chairman of Lotus to devote his time to it. He also persuaded two other top industry executives - S. Jerrold Kaplan, co-founder of the artificial intelligence company Teknowledge Inc., and Edward J. Belove, Lotus's director of advanced product development - to join in this two-year obsession. ''I was much stronger on intuition in those days than computer science or AI,'' he said, in reference to artificial intelligence, ''so I couldn't really articulate at all what I thought such a program ought to do.'' So Mr. Kapor called on Mr. Kaplan, who has a Ph.D. in computer and information science and who had invented a data base structure that used features developed in research on artificial intelligence. This data management system became the ''back end'' structure for Agenda.
Title: THE DIFFICULT BIRTH OF THE LOTUS AGENDA

Paragraph: I would like to add to William Safire's collection of ''summative dribble-offs'' such as et cetera, blah, blah, blah and whatever (On Language: ''I am Appalled,'' Dec. 20). Among folks who work in computer science, artificial intelligence and cognitive science, the term mumble has become a mildly self-deprecatory way to terminate a thought that has gotten beyond the control of its thinker. This happens not infrequently at the cutting edge of the information sciences. The user can safely exit to ''mumble'' when he is at risk of flaming - another Silicon Valley locution that means ''getting intellectually outrageous or otherwise losing it.''  ARNOLD S. WASSERMAN  Blue Bell, Pa.
Title: MUMBLING TO THE COMPUTER

Paragraph: My theory is that after some initial flurry of them helping us and them being involved with us, they won't have anything to do with us. Because they won't be able to convey to us what they're doing or why. And the reason is simply that we won't be able to understand. If two of them are talking to each other and you want to know what they're saying - well, in the time it takes you to ask that question, one of them will have said to the other more words than have been uttered by all the people who have ever lived on the planet. So now what does it say to you? It's discussed every subject in such depth that no human could have touched it. So it will say something like, ''Well, you know, things in general.'' What else is it going to say? You have to understand that to it a conversation is like an Encyclopaedia Britannica every picosecond, a Library of Congress every second. Hopefully, if we make AI right it will have a fond spot in its integrated circuits for us.
Title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
Other (negative): after some initial flurry of them helping us and them being involved with us, they won't have anything to do with us.

Paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, May 3—                     The Sony Microsystems Company, Sony's Palo Alto, Calif., unit that markets technical computer work stations, said it had formed a strategic alliance with Symbolics Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., a leading supplier of work stations and software for artificial intelligence applications. Under the agreement, Symbolic will resell Sony's new work stations and act as a service organization. Later, Symbolic will offer systems based on Sony's next generation of work stations.
Title: Sony-Symbolics

Paragraph: ''HOW could solid-seeming brains support such ghostly things as thoughts?'' Marvin Minsky asks in ''The Society of Mind.'' It is not as though the brain were particularly solid. It is more like a blancmange, soggy and quivery - a frail vessel to contain the human mind. Yet the nerve cells of a brain outnumber the human population of the earth and they can communicate with one another in a thousandth of a second. Suppose we look at the brain as a collection of units or agents, ''each mindless by itself.'' If each agent is linked to 30 other agents, it can reach 1,000 agents in two steps and a million others in four steps. How does one try to mimic nature and build an intellect from such small components? How can an artificial intelligence perceive the outside world and react to it? Mr. Minsky explores means of explaining the world to a computer, translating it into language that you and I can understand, providing we accept some new concepts and terms.
Title: IF I ONLY HAD A BRAIN: A COMPUTER'S GUIDE

Paragraph: Users' groups commonly develop around one brand or model of computer. They might consist of two or three people, or two or three thousand. Most charge an annual fee of $10 to $50, and have monthly meetings. The bigger groups are also usually broken down into special interest groups that meet to examine such topics as investing, artificial intelligence or the vagaries of a particular species of software.
Title: TIPS, REVIEWS AND GOSSIP

Paragraph: ''The Tomorrow Makers,'' by Grant Fjermedal ($18.95 from Macmillan) is a volume devoted to the furthest fringes of computer science, where the edges of reality and fantasy, of morality and amorality, of dreams and nightmares merge in a morass of maybes. The framework of the book is a voyage through the leading artificial intelligence and robotics laboratories, from Carnegie-Mellon to the University of Tokyo, where the reader will encounter various fascinating, wild-eyed, brilliant individuals engaged in mapping out the technological avenue to the future for humanity. Many of these researchers seem convinced that within a generation, or two at most, life will ''go on by creating computer copies of our minds and transferring, or downloading, that program into robotic bodies that never die.'' Life in such form, along with electronic protectors for mankind - effectively relieving us of any semblance of adult responsibility - is, according to these merry pranksters of artificial intelligence, humanity's only hope for survival in a supertech world. In their narcissistic search for immortality, these computer scientists seem to have abandoned all considerations of moral boundaries, to say nothing of the basic laws of thermodynamics. Apparently they are oblivious to the fact that we still cannot build even a car to last 10 years and they go on to dismiss the mind/body problem with an elegant amplification of the ''diskcopy'' command, which users of personal computers invoke to duplicate the data they have accumulated. Yet, technologically, the work of these scientists is often dazzling. TO counterbalance the hyperthyroid-propelled vision of ''The Tomorrow Makers,'' I would read Theodore Roszak's ''The Cult of Information'' ($7.95 from Pantheon Books). Mr. Roszak analyzes the folklore that envelops computers and the way in which it has glorified the machines by overstating their potential. Unfortunately, the book is flawed by the promulgation of a conspiracy among manufacturers, the media and the government to force society into the digital mold. Conspiracies are notoriously difficult to prove, and blaming the so-called computer revolution on such a plot makes about as much sense as accusing Bacon, Descartes, Galileo and their cohorts of conspiring to create the Age of Enlightenment. The author's left-leaning political views and technology-bashing bias also taint his thesis with partiality, although certainly they are no more prejudicial than the euphoric pro-technology fusillade fired off in ''The Tomorrow Makers.'' In fact, it is the very opposing nature of the obsessions the two books reveal that may suggest a point of equilibrium somewhere between the extremes. A crucial distinction is made by Mr. Roszak between information, or data, and knowledge, that semantic embarrassment which computer zealots at best ignore and at worst disguise, calling it by such misnomers as ''knowledge systems.'' Computers may excel at processing data. But, unlike humans, they are incapable of the original thought of which knowledge is created. The artificial intelligence community and, in fact, the entire computer cabal are nevertheless trying to mislead us into accepting the notion that the difference between the ''mind'' of the computer and the mind of man is merely a matter of degree, and that not only will this difference be eliminated in short order, but soon people will rank second to computers in their cognitive abilities and responsiveness.
Title: HOW TO AVOID TUNNEL VISION
Other (negative): AI minds are wildly different from human minds but creators do not comprehend this
Other (positive): robotic immortality

Paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, March 3—                     A major retrenchment is occurring in the artificial intelligence industry, dashing the hopes of many companies that thought they would prosper by providing the technology to make computers ''think.'' Some of the setback stems from the failure of artificial intelligence to quickly live up to its promise of making machines that can understand English, recognize objects or reason like a human expert - to be used for such purposes as diagnosing machinery breakdowns or deciding whether to authorize a loan. Despite this, the technology is making slow but steady progress, and now is being subtly incorporated into more conventional computer programs. Weak Business Moves Far more of the artificial intelligence industry's problems result from poor business decisions by companies that were heavily weighted with technologists rather than business minds. Their main mistake was trying to use special computers for artificial intelligence; the machines were too expensive and did not mesh well with those used by potential customers. ''People believed their own hype,'' said S. Jerrold Kaplan, co-founder of one leading artificial intelligence company, Teknowledge Inc., and now president of the Go Corporation, a startup software company in San Francisco. ''Everyone was planning on growth that was unsustainable.'' Hardest hit in the retrenchment so far have been companies that sell special computers for use in artificial intelligence. Symbolics Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., the leader in that market, has had several quarters of heavy losses and recently ousted its chairman. Its archrival, Lisp Machine Inc., declared bankruptcy last year. Texas Instruments Inc. and the Xerox Corporation, the two other vendors in that market, are also experiencing sluggish sales. Meanwhile, Texas Instruments and Apple Computer Inc. announced yesterday that Texas Instruments would sell a version of the Macintosh containing the favored artificial intelligence programming language, Lisp. Still, while companies are suffering, artificial intelligence as a technology continues to make progress. Some companies that have adapted are still doing well. The Aion Corporation, a small, privately held company in Palo Alto, saw its sales triple last year, though from a tiny base. It sells tools that include artificial intelligence technology to help data processing employees develop programs for I.B.M. mainframes. The AI Corporation of Waltham, Mass., has successfully sold programs that allow corporate computer users to use English commands to retrieve information from data bases on I.B.M. mainframes. Use in General Software Artificial intelligence techniques are also being incorporated into general computer programs without necessarily being labeled as artificial intelligence. Symantec Inc. of Cupertino, Calif., sells a data base program for personal computers called Q & A that responds to English queries. A new class of data bases, such as Agenda by the Lotus Development Corporation, also use some artificial intelligence techniques to organize data. ''You're beginning to see the embedding of A.I., sub rosa,'' said Louis G. Robinson, publisher of the Spang Robinson Report, an artificial intelligence newsletter.
Title: Setbacks for Artificial Intelligence
Other (negative): companies not reaping expected financial benefit         AI companies failing AI companies losing money   AI companies failing
Other (positive): optimism about AI progress          AI companies thriving AI to help sort information  to organize data Q & A that responds to English queries organize data   Ai becoming fixture in business

Paragraph: It cannot be said, however, to keep time with what was once taken for granted - the stately round dance of the seasons. It is not, of course, alone in that. When nature herself is out of joint, and winter cuts in on spring, it would take a robot not to miss a beat. Things were different when Virgil was top of the charts in poetry, when Poussin's august fancies held sway in painting and Antonio Vivaldi was at work on his ''Four Seasons.'' In those long-gone days, the round dance of the seasons was pre-set, regular and immutable. As lately as the lifetime of Vincent van Gogh, nature and the calendar went arm in arm.
Title: SEARCHING FOR SIGNS OF SPRING'S PALETTE IN A WHITE-WALLED WORLD OF GALLERIES

Paragraph: Q.What is the status of work on computer chips for applications in artificial intelligence?  A.Computer scientists have been developing such microprocessor chips for several years. These chips are being designed to process a high-level computer programming language known as LISP, short for List Processing. The language is designed to enable a computer to mimic human perception and thinking processes, an application known as artificial intelligence. The new chips would replace the highly expensive artificial intelligence machines that have been designed to run LISP. Last week, Texas Instruments Inc. introduced the first version of a 32-bit microprocessor chip it has developed under a Defense Department contract. The 32-bit chip executes artificial intelligence programs more efficiently than the general-purpose devices. Motorola and Symbolics Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., are also working on similar artificial intelligence chips. The chips promise to lead to computers that are faster and cheaper in performing such tasks as understanding language and in emulating human experts in such tasks as diagnosing diseases and offering investment advice. Such computers could solve problems using word-like symbols that allow them to ''think'' like people. Using such expert systems, the computers could find solutions to complex problems based on a variety of humans experiences found in the programs.  Q.What causes blisters to form on the skin?  A.Blisters are usually caused by friction or burns. In friction, the upper layers (epidermis) of the skin move back and forth over the lower layers (dermis), until a small cleft is produced between the layers of skin. Fluid collects in the cleft. When the skin is burned, serum from damaged blood vessels collects between the epidermis and the dermis. Blisters can also result from insect bites and minor bacterial and viral infections.
Title: Q&A
Other (positive): science supporting AI is progressing  to lead to computers that are faster and cheaper in performing such tasks as understanding language and in emulating human experts in such tasks as diagnosing diseases and offering investment advice

Paragraph: WILLIAM H. CALVIN here takes us on parallel journeys of mind-boggling proportions - a 225-mile raft tour of the Grand Canyon with two dozen river runners, and an expertly guided trip back through time to trace our origins. As Mr. Calvin, a neurobiologist at the University of Washington, explores such natural wonders as fossils, waterfalls, rapids and stars, he visits nearly every popular science topic - from genetic engineering to the aquatic-ape theory to artificial intelligence to sociobiology, the destruction of tropical rain forests and overpopulation. ''The River That Flows Uphill,'' presented as a day-by-day and mile-by-mile diary, offers intriguing glimpses into the physical, natural and social sciences, as well as excursions into history, linguistics and philosophy.
Title: RAFTING THROUGH EVOLUTION

Paragraph: For years Dr. Minsky urged his students to pursue instead a separate effort called artificial intelligence, in which scientists use computer programs to mimic the psychology, not the biology of the brain. Return to Original Idea In the last five years, however, developments in artificial intelligence have been much slower than its champions had hoped. Meanwhile, rapid advances in neurobiology have led many researchers to wonder if the best way to make thinking computers is to return to the original idea of electronically mimicking the brain.
Title: Artificial Brain Again Seen As a Guide To the Mind

Paragraph: HATTERAS, N.C., May 28                     An effort to preserve the remains of one of the most celebrated warships in history began today when a deep-sea robot descended to the murky Atlantic grave where the U.S.S. Monitor has lain for 125 years. But the ship lies upside down, partly buried in the sand and partly broken open. The acoustic and other sensors on the robot are likely to prove at least as important as the cameras in the murky water around the wreck.
Title: SCIENCE BEGINS A SEA SEARCH FOR PIECES OF WORLD'S FIRST ARMORED BATTLESHIP
Other (positive): a robot went under sea to examine a warship sunk in the Atlantic

Paragraph: For most of May, students at the University of Wisconsin Stout, as the Menomonie campus is called, have been eating robot-made burgers for lunch. They are produced by what school officials say is the first industrial robot to work at a burger stand, actually a campus restaurant whose kitchen serves as the fast-food laboratory. The hamburger robot here hits peak speed at three burgers a minute; a busy restaurant needs to produce 20 to 30 burgers a minute, Mr. Schowalter said. In addition, he said: ''Fast-food operations are fighting each other with diversity of product. Sure, you can make a hamburger'' using a robot, he said, but he added: ''What can you do it if suddenly it's the croissant that is moving this year?'' David L. Brenholt, the president of Translab in Menomonie, which designed and built the hamburger-flipping robot at a cost of $20,000, said that although the machine can make only hamburgers, it can be reprogrammed to make various kinds, like ones with multiple patties. The robot looks like a flat oven with conveyor belts running through and an arm attached at the end. A red light indicates when a worker should slide in a patty and bun, which bob along in the heat for 1 minute 52 seconds. When they reach the other side of the machine, photo-optic sensors indicate when they can be assembled. Roland Grant, a senior majoring in hotel and restaurant management, said the robot could be ''the first step toward a totally automated burger.'' But he added: ''It's a touch scary. All through life, you are taught to do it yourself. The danger in the system is when the computer goes down, you can't make the burger yourself.''
Title: ROBOT CHEF'S NEW DISH: HAMBURGERS
Other (positive): making food  commercial applications, business investment and interest in AI    ROBOT CHEF  robot burger flipper

Paragraph: Where Mr. Jackson's dancing is a series of geometric, freeze-frame poses - on his toes, in a robot crouch, miming - Prince is always in motion, undulating, leaping, even crawling on his belly. Mr. Jackson's show, too, seems frozen; his concert on Oct. 3 was a virtual replay of the ones he did in February, down to the few sentences he spoke. The Prince show, despite its fixed routines, has already changed since its Minneapolis opening last month, dumping a ballad medley in favor of a funk workout. And Prince's preaching retains its themes, but varies the script at whim.
Title: Critic's Notebook; They Sing, They Dance, They're Utterly Different

Paragraph: rrMost industrial robots are ungainly looking machines. But the Battelle Memorial Institute in Richland, Wash., is nearing completion on a robot to test clothing for the Army that is so human-like its developers use the word ''spooky'' to describe its movements. It does almost everything but charge into combat. To make the robot sweat, the engineers placed capillary tubes throughout the body. The tubes send liquid at controlled rates and temperatures into a cotton garment that covers the robot and spreads the liquid. The robot was designed to test clothing in temperatures ranging from 30 to 130 degrees Fahrenheit. But there also is talk of extending its range to lower temperatures. ''Manney does have heaters on the skin, so with skin heating we probably could go down farther in temperature extremes,'' Mr. Yount said.
Title: So Give It a Gun and Let It Fight

Paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24—                     Teknowledge Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif., a pioneering company in artificial intelligence and expert systems, said its merger with the American Cimflex Corporation of Pittsburgh had been approved. Cimflex is a privately held company specializing in computer-integrated manufacturing and flexible assembly systems. Under the terms of the deal announced Dec. 1, Teknowledge shareholders will hold 42 percent of the combined company, the Cimplex Tecknowledge Corporation, with Cimflex shareholders holding 58 percent. The new company will have its headquarters in Pittsburgh, but with artificial intelligence operations remaining in Palo Alto. ''The two companies were on parallel courses in different markets,'' said Mike Ayers, a Teknowledge spokesman.
Title: Teknowledge Sets Cimflex Merger

Paragraph: THE PROSECUTORS: Inside the Offices of the Government's Most Powerful Lawyers, by James B. Stewart. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) Charges of insider trading at Morgan Stanley and bribery at McDonnell Douglas are among the cases portrayed in James B. Stewart's book about government prosecutors. ''Each of the stories unfolds with the suspense of a terrific detective novel, but the book is even better than that because the stories are true,'' Seymour Wishman said in The Book Review last year.  THE WORLD AS I FOUND IT, by Bruce Duffy. (Ticknor & Fields, $8.95.) During his early days at Cambridge, arguing logic with Bertrand Russell, it seemed that Ludwig Wittgenstein was the ultimate system builder, attempting in his book ''Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus'' to delineate the geometries of language and life. But somewhere along the way, the philosopher had a change of heart. The ''sweeping arrangement of fact and fancy'' in Bruce Duffy's novel about this enigmatic man ''is vivid, passionate and funny,'' Perry Meisel said here last year. ''Mr. Duffy's is an achievement in both fiction and historiography which deepens Wittgenstein's mythology and should attract a wider audience to it.''  THE TOXIC CLOUD, by Michael H. Brown. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $9.95.) With dioxins, heavy metals, sulfur dioxide and other chemicals filling the air, environmentalists fear that the atmosphere itself is becoming a toxic cloud. Last year, our reviewer, Philip Shabecoff, said this book is ''so compelling it may prod the public to demand that serious attention be paid to this national scandal.''  MURDER IN THE CIA, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $4.95.) President Truman may have been responsible for the creation of the Central Intelligence Agency, Newgate Callendar said here last year, but his daughter, Margaret, takes a dim view of how the organization has changed. Miss Truman, who has also written novels about murder in the White House, the Supreme Court, Georgetown and other Washington locales, ''has become a real pro who can juggle false leads with the best of them.''  THE PHILOSOPHICAL DISENFRANCHISEMENT OF ART, by Arthur C. Danto. (Columbia University, $13.) ''Without theories of art,'' writes the philosopher and art critic Arthur C. Danto, ''black paint is just black paint.'' ''The magnitude of the issues Mr. Danto's books raise is a mark of the books' importance,'' Paul Guyer said in The Book Review in 1987.  FELICITY, by Coral Lansbury. (Ivy, $3.95.) Felicity, a beautiful if slovenly art historian, becomes involved with a gang of adulterous academics in a search for a campus murderer. Last year, our reviewer, Fay Weldon, complimented Coral Lansbury for ''the sheer pleasure she takes in her own intelligence, her own ingenuity, her own wonderfully informed mind.''  THE LOBBY: Jewish Political Power and American Foreign Policy, by Edward Tivnan. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) Edward Tivnan's argument that the American pro-Israel lobby has encouraged the suppression of dissent among American Jews may be overstated, Walter Goodman said in The Times last year. But ''in treating that delicate subject in a not-so-delicate way, 'The Lobby' is in keeping with the scrappy spirit of open controversy found in both America and Israel.''  GREAT SKY RIVER, by Gregory Benford. (Bantam, $4.50.) When artificial intelligence takes over a planet, the dominated human inhabitants are nearly reduced to a breed of biological machines. ''The mutual incomprehension between adversaries gives rise to crisply rendered scenes of suspense and horror as well as some surprising moments of gallows humor,'' Gerald Jonas said here this year.  MANY MASKS: A Life of Frank Lloyd Wright, by Brendan Gill. (Ballantine, $12.95.) Frank Lloyd Wright was as inventive a self-promoter as he was an architect, Brendan Gill writes, ''a virtuoso at bearing false witness.'' ''In giving us a vivid picture of Wright the man, Mr. Gill also succeeds in giving us a practical appreciation of his work,'' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times last year. ''As with the play 'Amadeus,' we end by contemplating the frequent disjunction between temperament and talent, character and genius.''  TENDING TO VIRGINIA, by Jill McCorkle. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A shocking revelation from her husband sends a pregnant young Southern woman fleeing home to Saxapaw, N.C., for a therapeutic conversational marathon with three generations of family. Last year, Alice McDermott said in The Book Review that she admired ''the tremendous exuberance'' of Jill McCorkle's characters.  TOWARDS THE MOUNTAIN: An Autobiography, by Alan Paton. (Scribners, $9.95.) Born in South Africa just after the Boer War, Alan Paton, the author of the novel ''Cry, the Beloved Country,'' spent his life fighting apartheid. ''No one . . . has done more to interpret black and white South Africa to the world outside,'' Thomas Pakenham said here in 1980, ''its terrible wealth and beauty, its frustration and anguish and hope.''  EARLY GRAVES, by Joseph Hansen. (Mysterious Press, $3.95.) When Dave Brandstetter, a homosexual insurance investigator, returns home to Los Angeles and finds a dead man on his patio, he is drawn into a mystery involving a serial killer whose victims are young men suffering from AIDS. Last year, our reviewer, Newgate Callendar, said this ''well plotted and well written'' novel is ''about AIDS and the fear, even hysteria, it creates among otherwise rational people. . . . 'Early Graves' takes a long, sad look at the problem.''
Title: New & Noteworthy

Paragraph: Antinoise systems are said to be effective only against continuous or repetitive sounds that are reducible to formulas; you'll still have to put a muzzle on the guy in the next cubicle with the sudden, braying laugh. Yet while some technocrats are working on antinoise, others are looking for the formulas that underlie musical genres. According to an article by Christopher Yavelow in the June 1987 issue of Music, Computers and Software magazine, computer-music programmers are working with artificial intelligence techniques to create ''style templates'' that can apply a given compositional style to new material - to generate, as Mr. Yavelow suggests, additional volumes of Bach's ''Well-Tempered Clavier.''
Title: A PROPOSAL: SEND OUT THE CLONES

Paragraph: Intensive courses in computer technology for young people will be given at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry starting June 29. Five weekly sessions scheduled from 9:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. Monday through Friday are programmed for various levels of skill including Logo, Basic and Pascal techniques and the more advanced fields of robotics and artificial intelligence.

Paragraph: WASHINGTON—                     WHEN the computer scientist John McCarthy coined the term artificial intelligence in the late 1950's, he did not mean to imply that there would be anything second rate about mechanical minds. However, three decades later computers still do not think. Is this because of the technological failings of the computer industry? Or is artificial intelligence theoretically impossible? Finally, since most of the research is financed by the Pentagon, will smarter computers lead to more efficient ways of killing people? Three reports follow. With awards and contracts to universities, private companies and Government agencies, the project is financing work not only in artificial intelligence, but also in computer vision and speech recognition and in programs that would allow computers to recognize English. The greatest achievement so far has not been in artificial intelligence but in large-scale parallel computing, Dr. Schwartz said. Conventional computers use a single processing chip to solve problems one step at a time. By using numerous processors, a computer can simultaneously work on different parts of a problem, reducing the time it takes to solve it. ''The success of work like this justifies the investment,'' Dr. Schwartz said. ''American companies are ahead in parallel processing, with a number of machines available on the market now. We're getting ready for computers performing at levels 100 times larger than the largest present supercomputer.'' Supercomputers are the powerful machines used for such complex jobs as weather forecasting and aircraft design. Making Weapons 'Brilliant'
Title: IDEAS AND TRENDS: Can Machines Learn to Think?; Pentagon Plan: The Battle to Mechanize the Military Mind
Other (negative): inherent limitations of AI
Other (positive): interest and investment in AI

Paragraph: On that eventful Saturday night, Ms. Chung realized that she was moving out of the camera's frame as she read the Middle East story. She considered scooting her chair, which is on wheels, in pursuit of the robot camera. But she remembered that she was stationed on a platform, ''and if I did move, I might have fallen off,'' she said. Finally, the robot collided with the stage manager, ending its journey but not its mischief. Having stopped, the camera began to pan the anchor desk, turning its lens even farther from the anchorwoman. Ms. Chung tried to lean into the picture, managing to get about half her face into the frame before cutting away to a taped report.
Title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; At Networks, Cheap Is Chic, So Please Pardon the Robots

Paragraph: Both exercise equipment designers and health club owners have become adept manufacturers of fun. Some of the newest gyms could pass for video arcades. Powercise, for instance, is a line of exercise equipment developed by Rick Dyer, who also created Dragon's Lair, the first animated video game. The critical difference between Powercise and Nautilus or Universal machines is artificial intelligence. The Powercise system - now in 200 gyms across the country - works like a personal fitness trainer. Each machine assesses the exerciser's fitness level and ideal workout. It goads the weak-willed to success, chirps a few words of encouragement and flashes a smile on the video screen.
Title: EXERCISING OPTIONS

Paragraph: VOICE OF THE WHIRLWIND by Walter Jon Williams (Tor, $16.95) is a novel in the mode that has come to be known as cyberpunk. It envisions a world of ever-accelerating change in which the dividing line between natural and artificial intelligence grows less and less clear, in which death is not necessarily forever if you are rich and smart enough to buy insurance that includes a cloned ''Beta'' body and a personality recording ready to be activated the moment your ''Alpha'' body meets a natural or unnatural end. Most of Mr. Williams's characters are terminated, if only temporarily, by high-tech weapons that sound no less believable than Ronald Reagan's Star Wars wish list.
Title: SCIENCE FICTION

Paragraph: Another book that is very popular, he said, is ''Artificial Intelligence Enters the Marketplace,'' by Larry R. Harris and Dwight B. Davis ($16.95 from Bantam Books, 666 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10103, 212-765-3535). Dr. Harris is president of the A.I. Corporation and a former professor at Dartmouth, where the history of artificial intelligence began, and Mr. Davis is a senior editor at High Technology magazine. ''These guys get beyond the hype and all the science fiction scenarios about A.I. and expert systems,'' Mr. Girion said. ''They say, 'What are we really talking about here and what can these things really do?' '' The book is popular among executives wondering how artificial intelligence will be used commercially. There is something vaguely heretical about artificial intelligence. Critics say that the quest for machines that can think or reason is absurd, or even impossible, and indeed, as Mr. Girion noted, there have been some rather fanciful science fiction-type scenarios about thinking machines. The most intelligent and readable guide to the realm of artificial intelligence - its history, its fundamentals, its fascinating personalities and its future - is George Johnson's ''Machinery of the Mind'' ($19.95 from Times Books). It's an engrossing look at what promises to be the most exciting application of computing in the decades ahead.
Title: Hot Books for Hot Days
Other (negative): criticism of the concept of AI

Paragraph: The robot is a century behind the times. Its use of >sparingly suggests that it thinks >but can be used at the beginning of a sentence once in a while. Why doesn't the machine check through my column to see whether I've used it elsewhere and, if I did not, just shut up instead of giving me irrelevant advice? That's the sort of fast checking these programs are supposed to be good at. I roared out to my local software peddler to get my own robot for further research. The store did not have ''Grammatik,'' but (the robot would let me use >but here, where it's safe and warm) it did have the competition, ''RightWriter,'' for $80. Must be a swinger: permits a capital letter right in the middle of a proper noun.
Title: Writer vs. Robot

Paragraph: Unlike the relatively simple robot arms that went into automobile plants, the new machines incorporate such advanced technology as vision systems, tactile sensing and voice recognition. These attributes allow a robot to roam the corridors of a hospital or office building without following a predetermined track or bumping into objects. The T.R.C. robot being developed by Mr. Engelberger, called Helpmate, is intended to ease the nurses' workload by performing such low-level duties as delivering medicines and meals. Walter K. Wiesel, whose Prab Robotics specializes in large materials-handling robots, has taken a different approach with a new company, Prab Command Inc. It produces a system that is intended to allow a person without the use of arms or legs to function in an office. The system includes a personal computer, a robot arm and normal office equipment. It is controlled by voice command, a technology that has had limited application in industry. The user controls the system by speaking pre-chosen words into a microphone. A user can dial a telephone, operate the computer or, by using a sequence of spoken commands, have the robot perform mechanical tasks. Ready-Made Market Seen
Title: Ailing Robot Industry Is Turning to Services

Paragraph: What Kay was proposing was a future in which one child on a personal computer could do the kind of animation that now requires a dozen supercomputers, and also create characters that are ''artificially intelligent'' - able to do things without the child's intervention. He was planning to realize that future here, with the kids' help. And he was doing it with funds from Apple and the support of people like Marvin Minsky, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology computer scientist who is regarded as the dean of artificial intelligence. Kay can be quite blunt for a dreamer, and as he talked that day to the assembled technologists, who sat surrounded by the children's crude drawings of cave paintings and tribal masks, he spoke of today's technology as if considering the artifacts of a backward civilization. On the features his team developed at Xerox: ''It's surprising to me that they're even interesting after 15 years.'' On recent progress in artificial intelligence: ''There's nothing that comes close to doing what a fish can do, let alone a cat. The closest thing that artificial intelligence has been able to do so far is a termite.''
Title: PIED PIPER ON THE COMPUTER
Other (negative): AI is not very intelligent

Paragraph: On the applications software fronts, Lotus unveiled a fascinating new program called Agenda, which won't be in the stores until April. Agenda allows users to enter items of text - reminders, memos, notes, outlines, names, etc. - in a natural, unstructured fashion (for example, ''Remind Ron about the meeting next month with Mr. Gorbachev.'') Agenda, using some artificial intelligence techniques, can then arrange, sort and cross-reference the various facets of the item. The resulting data base can be added to, restructured, or manipulated at will. Agenda is a brilliant concept, but whether the average user thinks it will be worth $400 in its present form is a big question.
Title: New Products Fuel Boom in Exhibits at Show

Paragraph: Scientists tried to build brain-like computers in the 1950's and 1960's. Frank Rosenblatt, a Cornell scientist, designed a simple neural computer known as the perceptron. But the neural devices of those days had severe limitations. Marvin Minsky and Seymour Papert of M.I.T., two giants in the field of artificial intelligence, wrote an influential book called ''Perceptrons'' in 1969 that pointed out many of those limitations and helped diminish interest in the field. The quest to make computers ''think'' turned instead to artificial intelligence, which involves programming rules into a computer for performing tasks such as reading aloud or making medical diagnoses. A rule for reading out loud, for instance, might be to pronounce a ''k'' except when it is followed by an ''n,'' in which case it is silent. Devising such rules - and their exceptions - and entering them into a computer can take years.
Title: MORE HUMAN THAN EVER, COMPUTER IS LEARNING TO LEARN

Paragraph: In 10 fast-paced chapters Mr. Forester discusses a broad set of topics, including the design and manufacture of integrated circuits, artificial intelligence, robotics, life in Silicon Valley, work and productivity in computerized offices, the organization of computerized factories, electronic banking, telecommunications, computer-based instruction, computer crime, threats to privacy, and the quality and quantity of jobs in high-tech societies. He places some of these topics in the context of global competition among Japan, the United States and European nations.
Title: SO MANY CHIPS, SO LITTLE TIME
Other (positive): CompSci book overview

Paragraph: Writers, film makers and even animators have been offering their own answers for decades. Aldous Huxley in his 1932 novel, ''Brave New World,'' envisioned rooftop entrances to skyscraper homes, pneumatic sofas and bathroom taps that emitted scent. Fritz Lang's futuristic city in his 1927 film, ''Metropolis,'' included underground housing and robot technology. But perhaps the most fanciful vision came from ''The Jetsons,'' William Hanna and Joseph Barbera's popular 1962 animated television series. In a world in which space was at a premium, houses were suspended on stilts, beds collapsed and disappeared into the floor, doors descended from the ceiling and chairs were moved by conveyor belt to wherever they were needed.
Title: THE SHAPE OF THINGS TO COME
Other (positive): AI for homes - saving space and making human life more comfortable

Pat Choate  Vice president of policy analysis, TRW Inc.

Paragraph: Computer integrated manufacturing - where automated machines are all linked directly to the same computer - is a technology that has been ''just around the corner'' for the past 10 to 15 years. But one of the current problems preventing this technology from being adopted in factories is that it requires significant advances in artificial intelligence. Industrial robots have been a major disappointment and an example of a technological promise that has yet to be fulfilled. After almost 40 years of development, the presently available robot can do very little. The 1990's may be the time when robots will fulfill their promise but it will require gains in computing power.
Title: Develop Those Existing Technologies

Paragraph: The issue, which has sharply divided museum directors, was brought into focus in New York City last week with the opening of a dinosaur exhibition that flies in the face of tradition. Without a single fossil in sight, two dozen robot dinosaurs moving under computer control rip meat from carcasses, browse leaves from high branches, tend nests of babies and crane serpentine necks toward visitors. The new robot exhibit is a commercial venture of the Dinamation International Corporation of San Juan Capistrano, Calif., which lends its robots to museums and collects a share of the museums' admission charges. The latest collection of robot reptiles from the Permian, Jurassic and Cretaceous epochs, was built especially for a temporary display at the World Financial Center. It stands in sharp contrast to such traditional displays as those of the American Museum, which owns the largest collection of dinosaur fossils in the world.
Title: Robots or Bones? Dinosaur Experts Disagree

Three Original Targets The three big applications were meant to demonstrate the potential of artificial intelligence to the armed services, and also to induce the development of underlying technologies, like computer vision for the autonomous vehicle, speech understanding for the pilot's associate and a new generation of faster chips and computers that would be needed to make the applications practical.

Paragraph: Mr. Brinkley has engineered his plot with great care, so that the action flows smoothly from country to country, and he has filled the novel with just the kind of realistic detail about places, weapons, people, combat and Government policies that convinces the reader that he knows what he is writing about. Most of the characters are fully dimensional, especially, for some reason, the minor ones, but Terry Ascher, around whom the story pivots, is too naive and foolish for his position, and Major Paz, a former member of Somoza's National Guard who has become a contra leader and the prime tool of Mendoza and Gustafson, is so mechanical in his unthinking obedience that he seems more like a robot than a man.
Title: A CONSPIRACY SO MONSTROUS

Paragraph: For Voyager 2, the robot spacecraft launched in 1977, the encounter with Neptune will be the culmination of the most far-ranging reconnaissance of the space age. The robot spacecraft flew by and photographed Jupiter in 1979 and Saturn in 1981 and then, continuing to operate after its planned mission had been fulfilled, cruised on to Uranus in 1986 for the first close-up look at that planet. Now, conceding nothing to age and distance, it is racing in at 42,000 miles an hour for the first visit to Neptune. It will make its closest approach on Aug. 24.
Title: New Clues Emerge in Mystery of Planetary Rings
Other (positive): exploration Voyager 2

Paragraph: He thought they had been impressed with a demonstration that morning at a microchip assembly plant in Norwalk, Conn. An Adept robot had placed chips on a printed circuit board within three-thousandths of an inch of specifications. A major source of that challenge has been the failure of robotics to live up to its advance notices in the early 1980's, when it was touted as the industry of the future and the best hope for reviving America's manufacturing sector. Many of the robots - computer-driven machine tools flexible enough to handle a variety of parts and tasks - turned out to be less accurate, less flexible, weaker or slower than promised. And even when they worked, the robots often did not mesh well with the rest of the manufacturing process.  [ See box. ]  While many of the bugs have been ironed out, the legacy is a heavy burden for the scores of men and handful of women who generally put in 50-to-60-hour workweeks looking for new business. Even newer robot makers like Adept, a four-year-old privately held company based in San Jose, Calif., feel it. MR. REPKO, who was recently promoted to director of sales for Adept, has more reason to enjoy the challenge of selling robots than most. Adept was organized in 1983 by key personnel from Unimation's Silicon Valley office after Unimation was acquired by Westinghouse. It has prospered since introducing its first robot in early 1985, thanks to a unique gearless electric drive system. The speed, accuracy, cleanliness and reliability of the system makes it well suited for electronics assembly and lightweight mechanical tasks such as packaging or drilling. It is a market niche where Adept leads the pack. Mr. Repko, who was hired away from Unimation in late 1984, has been the company's most successful salesman.
Title: The Woes of a Robot Peddler
Other (positive): AI does work more accurately

Paragraph: The fact that the software came packaged in a snazzy package the size of jacket for a 33-rpm record jacket whose liner notes stressed its remarkable artificial intelligence made me even more suspicious. To me, artificial intelligence has always been a contradiction in terms. The first time Disk Technician is run, according to the manual, the program ''develops its initial AI history and learns your individual system.'' The software also runs what is called a monthly automatic test, during which ''every single byte and bit on the hard disk, occupied or not, is being tested for reading and writing ability, soft error rate, track alignment and magnetic retentivity - and automatically repaired if necessary.''
Title: Preventing and Repairing Hard Disk Disasters

Paragraph: The big moment in ''Infiltrator'' comes toward the end: a young scientist, trapped in a cloud of poison gas, turns into a robot with a red light in his head. A moment later, he's back in his normal state, looking dreamily at the woman he loves, who is also a young scientist. ''Infiltrator,'' on CBS at 8 o'clock tonight, is a particulary goofy one-hour movie.
Title: 'Infiltrator,' On CBS

Paragraph: This story, like the others in the book, plays on the strange things that happen when the notion of belief is injected into logic. Through a series of increasingly demanding puzzles, Mr. Smullyan introduces the reader to the curious situations that arise when we deal with ''conceited'' reasoners, who believe that they are infallible (even if they are not); ''peculiar'' reasoners, who believe a statement but believe that they don't; ''timid'' reasoners; ''modest'' reasoners, and other similar types. Mr. Smullyan also deals (ever so logically) with the implications of self-awareness - in reasoners who are aware that they are reasonable, and who are aware that they are aware. WITH these self-referential loops, Mr. Smullyan ties readers in Godelian knots. Before he is done he has brought us near the forefront of logic (where, yes, research is still going on). He introduces the strange fields of modal logic and ''possible worlds'' semantics. He examines the notion of self-fulfilling beliefs (''Could this have anything to do with religion?'' he asks). Ultimately what he offers is a painstakingly formal approach to the idea of belief systems. The implications to psychology and artificial intelligence don't escape him though he chooses not to confront them here.
Title: LOGIC AND OTHER IMPERFECT THINGS

Paragraph: Microstep goes beyond this, though. It ''knows'' all the rules for developing proper business software and presents them as choices on a menu. And it uses artificial intelligence techniques to guard against logical or procedural errors. This last feature prevents the programmer from making dumb mistakes at the moment, and it also allows comprehensive testing of the design at any later point.
Title: Do-It-Yourself Customized Software

Paragraph: In theory, switching from paper to electrons makes sense, but in practice it is usually more trouble that it is worth. The most powerful personal productivity managers consist of free-form data bases with elements of artificial intelligence, but for the most part they are hard to use. We have to learn not only a new software package, but a new way of thinking about organization to conform to the software's structure. Too often, the whole process does not conform to life in the real world and makes too many demands for practicality.
Title: Getting Organized The Electronic Way
Other (negative): real-world failure, impractical

Paragraph: The men who claim to be inventing our future at M.I.T. (few women are mentioned in the book) are an eccentric and interesting bunch. Led by Nicholas Negroponte, half supersalesman, half high-tech academic, their ranks include Seymour Papert, champion of the children's computer language Logo; Mr. Minsky, the guru of artificial intelligence; and Danny Hillis, whose 64,000-processor ''Connection Machine'' is the first really big parallel computer. These are genuine mad scientists, with boundless enthusiasm and wild ideas.
Title: GADGETS FOR UTOPIA

Paragraph: But a balanced space program must include activities that go beyond what robot spacecraft sensors can tell us. Space is the next major area for human expansion. And the development of new industries that will generate the increased tax revenues to support our desperately needed social and environmental programs will come from research performed on the space station - that can only be performed by people. We could continue doing no more than we have done so successfully -study the planets with robot spacecraft. But we have explored virtually the entire solar system, and it would be truly myopic to do nothing further than simply refine the first giant step of data that Voyager and its colleagues have given us. What is needed is to move out on the next giant step: using that best decision-making, action-taking general-purpose computer - the human being -to explore and develop space for the benefit of all humankind, not just for the scientists. JERRY GREY  Washington, Aug. 29, 1989  The writer is director of science and technology policy, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics.
Title: Venus May Tell Us How to Escape Its Fate; The Next Giant Step

Paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3—                     Sun Microsystems Inc. has introduced a new work station, the Sun-4/110, which it said would offer users many times the power currently available from competing machines in such applications as artificial intelligence and computer-aided software engineering.
