Paragraph: Consider first some of the advances we may well encounter in the next decades. In closely related essays, Richard Flaste and Peter Lewis discuss the next generation of computers. Work is progressing in two directions: toward faster machines (supercomputers) and toward more versatile and flexible (artificially intelligent) machines. Faster computers have potential military, scientific, industrial and even artistic applications - from nuclear weapons design to analyzing chemical interactions to designing aircraft wings to improving special effects in movies. The current effort concentrates on new designs involving parallel processing, but future advances could even involve bioengineering, according to a third essay by Michael Edelhart, the editor of P.C. Week magazine. The future of artificial intelligence is less clear. Current applications focus on expert systems -computers programmed with the logic of a specialized field like medical diagnosis or interpretation of oil exploration tests. A major research goal, however, is to improve the accessibility of computers, and to enable them to attack a new range of problems defined in terms of words, pictures, symbols and human speech.
Title: THE SHAPE OF THINGS, PERHAPS
Other (positive): AI used in oil exploration tests accessibility

Paragraph: Hospital officials said that the robot had been discussed with the hospital staff and the initial reaction was favorable. Workers in the dietary unit chose the name Roscoe. Paragraph: The lesson is one of many in the recent and rapid demystification of artificial intelligence - both for those who design computers and those who use them. Just a few years ago, the phrase ''expert system'' conjured up images of programs that could make computers reason, converse and learn like the humans whose knowledge they seek to replicate. More than a few struggling software companies nurtured that image: programs that could ''think,'' even in a limited way, were always just a few years away from becoming a commercial product. ''In the future artificial intelligence should simulate easily replaceable people,'' said Roger C. Schank, a professor of computer science and psychology at Yale University who also heads a fledgling artificial-intelligence company, Cognitive Systems. ''For example, there are a lot of people in the customer-service area - bank tellers, travel agents, airline reservation clerks - who don't do their job very well.'' And they are the kind of people who, programmers hope, they will soon learn to simulate. Actually writing such a program, computer experts note, would not be all that difficult. Most of the decisions made by banks are strictly ''rule-based,'' the industry's lingo for actions that follow a closely prescribed set of guidelines. And rules are the lifeblood of any expert system. Usually, they are expressed as a series of ''if-then'' statements: If the patient complains of stomachaches, then what has she eaten? If the robot has stopped operating, then check its power supply. ''A library of cases should be what characterizes the intelligence of a machine,'' contends Professor Schank, who like many in the field questions whether the current generation of expert systems has very much to do with the goal of creating artificial intelligence. ''This concept that rules are where it's at in simulated intelligence is just dead wrong.''
Title: Computer Fails As Job-Killer
Other (negative): fails (in title)
Other (positive): could make computers reason, converse and learn like the humans     commercial applications

Paragraph: There's no missing the point of Christy Rupp's small sculptural caricature ''Workerless Recovery.'' The metal robot is the villain, the simple workingman in overalls that he's kicking skyward is the victim.
Title: ELIZABETH GALASSO FINE ART TAKES A LOOK AT TRAGEDY

Paragraph: The Space Science Board has laid out an exciting, comprehensive and well-planned program for space science over the coming decades, based primarily on the use of robot spacecraft. That program is affordable and necessary, and it could be considerably enhanced by greater cooperation with the Soviets and our longtime European and Japanese partners.
Title: Space Programs Aren't for the Faint of Heart

Paragraph: UNTIL recently the world was more or less divided between those who believed in artificial intelligence and those who considered it a philosophical scam. People were either reductionists, who believed that the brain is a biological machine - a system of neurological gears and pulleys that can be mimicked by a computer - or holists, who insisted that there is some indescribable mind stuff that will slip through the cracks of any simulation. No matter how sophisticated its cogitations, these holists would say, a computer will never have intuition, wisdom or - some have even called it - soul. Like oil and water, the two positions are immiscible; holism and reductionism just don't mix. With both artificial intelligence programs and neural networks the goal is to create intelligence outside the body and learn more about how the mind works. But in artificial intelligence it has been assumed that the brain's psychology can be simulated from the top down without paying much attention to the way neurons work. The neural network people take a bottom-up approach: they assemble a network of artificial neurons and hope that a mind will emerge. The neural net enthusiasts are as far from their goal of making intelligent machines as are their competitors in artificial intelligence. But for some reason people who have reviled the artificial intelligentsia, as they like to call them, are suddenly embracing neural networks. The philosopher Hubert Dreyfus has made his career using obscure arguments from Heidegger and other philosophers to denounce artificial intelligence as theoretically impossible. But he was so impressed by neural nets that he rewrote parts of his 1985 book ''Mind Over Machine'' (written with his brother, Stuart Dreyfus), allowing that thinking machinery might not be so unthinkable after all. It is surprising that as good a science writer as Mr. Campbell would fall into this same confusion, believing that neural nets constitute ''an approach that is radically different from much of the Western philosophical tradition.'' His first book, ''Grammatical Man,'' was an exhilarating meditation on information and entropy, order and chaos - the poles of the dynamo that generates life. ''The Improbable Machine'' elegantly describes the importance of neural networks in studying the brain-mind connection. But in trying to make neural nets seem like an upheaval rather than a variation on a theme, he turns artificial intelligence into a caricature that few of its adherents would recognize. In Mr. Campbell's mythology, the neural net people were clever enough to see through this ruse. Unlike standard digital computers, brains consist of billions of processors - the neurons - that operate in parallel. What is more, people are inherently illogical. We overgeneralize and jump to conclusions. But in our weakness lies our strength. We can tolerate ambiguity and deal with imperfect information. In the 1960's, the neural net researchers were bullied out of the laboratory by the artificial intelligentsia, he argues, but now, two decades later, artificial intelligence has failed and neural nets are making a comeback.
Title: Casting Their Neural Nets
Other (negative): philosophical conflict within AI field, soullessness of AI  philosophical conflict within AI field   AI has bad reputation
Other (positive): AI research       neural nets

Paragraph: The theoretical physicists, having mastered an enormous range of natural phenomena from black holes to nuclear bombs, are talking about developing a so-called superunified theory or theory of everything (T.O.E.), a masterful set of equations that would embrace both quantum mechanics and relativity, the two grand pillars of modern physics. A T.O.E. would bring new depths of understanding to every basic process in nature, from the death of stars to the birth of the universe. It would, however, be a reductionist theory, concerned principally with simple interactions and far removed from such complicated phenomena as life and thought. And yet we find similar optimism at the complex end of the spectrum, too. Many mathematicians working in computer science propose that it will soon be possible to build computers capable of artificial intelligence, machines that could equal or excel the thought processes of the human mind. The proponents of the ''strong A.I.'' strain of artificial intelligence argue that the brain is a computer. Mr. Penrose responds that computers have inherent limits, which, while clearly acknowledged in the foundations of computation theory, are not necessarily imposed on human thought.
Title: HOW THE BRAIN WORKS, MAYBE
Other (positive): AI and the brain work in similar ways, and learning about one can open possibilities about the other.

Paragraph: The idea of turning to a machine for advice on how to deal with other humans may be unsettling to some executives. Yet a program called Performance Mentor ($295, for I.B.M. PC's and compatibles, from Performance Mentor Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif., 415 969-4500), uses expert system technology, a subset of artificial intelligence, to help executives prepare for job evaluations and to advise them on how to conduct the reviews in the most effective way.
Title: The Executive Computer;   'I'm Sorry; My Machine Doesn't Like Your Work'

Paragraph: One of the brightest is Ms. Dyson, an energetic 36-year-old publisher of the newsletter Release 1.0. It dissects the latest products and trends in the industry, although recently it has become more focused on software and artificial intelligence. A kind word from Ms. Dyson can lift an obscure company into prominence; a harsh one can send a product back to the drawing board. Paragraph: In the 1980's, the corporate saga and the personal computer came into their own. Frank Rose's ''West of Eden'' combines the two. Mr. Rose, a journalist and the author of ''Into the Heart of the Mind,'' a book about artificial intelligence, traces Apple Computer Inc. from its origins in 1976 in the garage of Steven P. Jobs through January 1986, not long after Mr. Jobs's ouster as the head of what had become a billion-dollar company.
Title: WHAT THE TECHIES WROUGHT

Paragraph: Symbolics Inc., a struggling technology company in the artificial intelligence business, announced yesterday that it had named Jay Wurts chairman and chief executive. Mr. Wurts, 40, will have the job of reversing these fortunes. The artificial intelligence industry in general has been going through a retrenchment, with setbacks stemming from its failure to live up to its promises of making machines that can recognize objects or reason like a human. Symbolics sells special purpose computers and software for artificial intelligence applications.
Title: A New Chief Executive Is Named at Symbolics

Paragraph: The machine producing the X-rays is an example of the huge impact that computer technology is having on medicine. The system employs computer vision and artificial intelligence techniques to help cardiologists analyze the function of a patient's heart as they perform the angioplasty.
Title: Computer's X-Ray Movies Make Heart Procedure Faster and Safer

Paragraph: Many golfers are willing to hike, but they don't want to lug a golf bag at the same time. Some use human caddies; others golf bag pull carts. But now there are electric motor caddies that will move at your pace. And for those willing to pay the $2,350 price tag, there is a robot that will follow you around like a pet duck.
Title: THE LATEST IN CADDIES

Paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, March 1—                     Apple Computer Inc. and Texas Instruments Inc. will announce on Thursday a specially configured version of the Macintosh II personal computer for artificial intelligence applications, industry sources said today. The machine will include a microprocessor designed to run LISP, a computer language used in artificial intelligence development, and is expected to be sold by Texas Instruments for less than $20,000. LISP applications have typically been run on work stations developed by such companies as Texas Instruments and Symbolics Inc., a company in Cambridge, Mass. The applications typically cost at least $50,000. Analysts say the market for the advanced Mac II will be large by artificial intelligence standards.
Title: Announcement Of Computer Due
Other (positive): personal computer for artificial intelligence applications   Advancements in AI will not costs that much.

Paragraph: The Nynex research center plans to study artificial intelligence, voice recognition and applications software for computerized information systems. Casimir S. Skrzypczak, Nynex's vice president of science and technology, said the center was ''building upon and customizing Bellcore's work, not supplanting it.''
Title: Baby Bells Moving Into the Lab

Paragraph: The science of artificial life resembles that of artificial intelligence, a commercial and scientific discipline that first flourished in the 1960's, in its attempt to mimic or simulate natural processes. But where artificial intelligence focuses on simulating human qualities like vision and speech, work on artificial life is taking on a much broader challenge: the basic behavior of all organisms. ''There is a lot of frustration in the lack of progress in artificial intelligence during the last 40 years,'' said J. Doyne Farmer, an artificial life researcher at the Santa Fe Institute, which studies complex organizations and biological and physical processes. ''They missed something along the way. We'd like to go back to fundamentals.'' Creating more powerful software through evolution rather than by designing it ''is a radical approach to programming,'' said Esther Dyson, a computer industry analyst and publisher of Release 1.0. ''Just as you now find artificial intelligence techniques infiltrating regular programming, in the future you will find artificial life techniques infiltrating the design of operating systems and computer networks.''
Title: A Darwinian Creation of Software
Other (negative): lack of progress in artificial intelligence
Other (positive): AI creates new technology (software)

A snake-like electrical cord guards each room, and in the hallways the sleuth is inevitably accosted by an obnoxious provocateur named ''Telly,'' a robot television set that assaults intruders with various power-sapping tricks. The sleuth must answer Telly's four math problems correctly to regain energy and get another clue to the Master of Mischief's whereabouts.

Paragraph: The swirling action in ''Nightshade'' revolves around a seemingly stock figure, John Shade, an omnicompetent immortal who lurches through the complicated interstices of Martian politics. The plot ramifies, as so many science fiction epics do, preoccupied with skulduggery and power. The action is elevated here by the plain fact that technology is destiny. Shade's allies are humans whose brains have been partly replaced by digitized computer-chip-based elements and an engaging artificial intelligence, Mandrake, who reflects on the amusing traits of our species: ''Nor do I observe that most humans resent the fact that their own lives are played out chiefly in the service of DNA, of a living stuff that is perhaps not aware of humans at all, or aware of them only as carriers, tools, means to an end - peripherals, shall we say?'' He is also interested, in his new novel, in the boundary between the animate and the inanimate. ''None of the characters is strictly human,'' he said. ''The trick is, can you make them real? In part of the book, the narrator asserts that fiction is finding a way to do what artificial intelligence has been trying to do all along - model awareness.''
Title: HOW TO MAKE LOVE LIKE A MARTIAN

Paragraph: The 36-year-old Dr. Baker is also the daughter of the top official of Queens, Borough President Claire Shulman. Taking time out from her duties in New York City government, Mrs. Shulman was at Cape Canaveral, Fla., with other members of her family for yesterday's launching of Atlantis, whose missions include putting the Jupiter-bound robot spacecraft Galileo into orbit. To some who recall the teen-age Ellen Shulman, it is not particularly surprising that the girl from Bayside, Queens, would develop into a space traveler familiar with both the internal systems of the human body and those of a Jupiter-bound robot powered by plutonium-fueled generators.
Title: Queens Recalls Student With Future in Space

Paragraph: Dr. Havel, who holds a doctorate in formal language theory - which deals in part with artificial intelligence - from the University of California at Berkeley, said students, actors, writers and humanists had led the revolution.

Paragraph: Further advances could be expected if proponents of artificial intelligence are correct in arguing that human knowledge can be regularized and predicted on a level beyond spoken or written languages. But it may turn out that knowledge and language are interpenetrating and mutually-generating entities, in which case there may be definite limits to further progress. ALEX GROSS  Chairperson, Computer Translation Committee  New York Circle of Translators  New York, Nov. 19
Title: Beyond Language

Paragraph: Longwall mining is used wherever coal is present in thick, level seams deep under the ground. (Shallow deposits are often exploited by strip mining, in which the surface layers are scraped away and the coal is excavated from an open pit.) Embracing new technologies and sometimes developing technology on its own, Consolidation Coal, a subsidiary of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, last year mined 55 million tons with 9,500 employees. Fifteen years earlier it took 23,000 workers to mine 55 million tons. A big part of the change was installing 22 longwall machines like the robot here.
Title: Robots Transform Coal Mining

Paragraph: More often than not, however, Correctext uses artificial intelligence to sort through the universe of expressions. It is ready to analyze noun, verb and prepositional phrases, jargon, redundancies, colloquial expressions, the use of adverbs, adjectives and articles, relative clauses and other clausal errors. Punctuation, abbreviation, capitalization and foreign phrases are a piece of cake.
Title: Righting English Becomes Easier

Paragraph: An auto mechanic, Mr. Clark runs his own shop in Newtonville, which is recognizable from the sculptures parked outside. But his fame extends beyond Atlantic County, specifically to Newark, where a 15-foot robot of his crowns a junkyard building. There are many such robots here, along with some abstractions and, though less impressive than the dog, they are all tours de force of selection and nearly invisible welding.
Title: Individualism That Promises Fun

Title: In Chess, a Machine Is the Master

Paragraph: WHEN the computer scientist John McCarthy coined the term artificial intelligence in the late 1950's, he did not mean to imply that there would be anything second rate about mechanical minds. However, three decades later computers still do not think. Is this because of the technological failings of the computer industry? Or is artificial intelligence theoretically impossible? Finally, since most of the research is financed by the Pentagon, will smarter computers lead to more efficient ways of killing people? Three reports follow. In the last few years, such optimism has gradually faded. Bringing the visionary technologies of artificial intelligence to the market has proved far more difficult than had been anticipated. Many of the original artificial-intelligence companies - including Teknowledge, Intellicorp, the Carnegie Group and the Inference Corporation - have suffered losses. Several others have gone out of business. Progress in building intelligent machines is also coming from a new group of researchers who are attempting to merge neurobiology and semiconductor manufacturing technology. In the past most developments in artificial intelligence have been in the software rather than in the hardware; whatever intelligence there was existed in the programs not in the machines. Researchers are now trying to use recent theories about how the brain works to make complex, neuron-like chips that might be used for machine vision and speech recognition.
Title: IDEAS AND TRENDS: Can Machines Learn to Think?; The Artificial Intelligence Industry Is Retrenching
Other (negative): AI companies failing
Other (positive): science and technology development support AI

Paragraph: ME AND DIMAGGIO: A Baseball Fan Goes in Search of His Gods, by Christopher Lehmann-Haupt. (Dell, $3.95.) After spending a season observing the big leagues, the New York Times book critic Christopher Lehmann-Haupt contemplated the uneasy relationship between those who play baseball and those who sit in the press box and write about it. ''Seldom is the awkwardness of this situation so freshly and unabashedly reflected as in this book,'' Roy Blount Jr. said in The Times in 1986.  STARING AT THE SUN, by Julian Barnes. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $7.95.) On the eve of her 100th birthday, in 2021, an Englishwoman named Jean Serjeant, who once left a ''second-rate life'' with a boring husband to seek enchantment and the wonders of the world, boards an airplane and flies into the sun. Last year our reviewer, Carlos Fuentes, called the novel ''a marvelous literary epiphany'' and praised Julian Barnes, the author of ''Flaubert's Parrot,'' for using his ''great precision of language, ironical detachment and talent for the incarnation of ideas'' to let his readers ''witness a reality we do not normally see.''  TANIA: A Biography and Memoir of Isak Dinesen, by Parmenia Migel. (McGraw-Hill, $8.95.) Karen Blixen's nom de plume was Isak Dinesen, but to her friends she was Titania - Tania for short. In 1967, when this memoir by Parmenia Migel was first published, our reviewer, William Jay Smith, called it ''a remarkably sensitive book that . . . never for one moment loses sight of  [ Dinesen's ]  magic. . . . Miss Migel has told Tania's own story as she would have wished it told, with accuracy and care, with wit and style.''  WHO KILLED PALOMINO MOLERO? by Mario Vargas Llosa. Translated by Alfred Mac Adam. (Collier/ Macmillan, $6.95.) The Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa uses a detective story about the murder of a young singer to explore the ambiguities of truth, justice and evil. ''Evoking landscape and mores in writing that is spare, rich and cruelly beautiful, he both satisfies the requirements of the genre and demonstrates that it too can resonate like any other form of fiction,'' Richard Lourie said in The Book Review last year.  THE NEW AMERICAN GRANDPARENT: A Place in the Family, a Life Apart, by Andrew J. Cherlin and Frank F. Furstenberg Jr. (Basic Books, $9.95.) Increased longevity and the ever-advancing demographic bulge are creating a country that is top-heavy with grandparents, who are providing their children's children with something halfway between a parental authority figure and an aging friend. In 1986 Maggie Scarf said here that this sociological study is ''a bit dry in places,'' but that it provides a ''comprehensive and intriguing portrait of grandparenting in America today.''  A NIGHT AT THE MOVIES: Or, You Must Remember This, by Robert Coover. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) Written in the form of absurd cinematic parodies, Robert Coover's collection of short fiction shows that the printed page can be more malleable to the imagination than the silver screen. ''The book gives us a long, exhilarating evening at an old-fashioned movie palace,'' Edmund White said here last year. ''Mr. Coover has understood the potential of the movies to persuade and to subvert but also to go out of control.''  THE CAPTIVE PUBLIC: How Mass Opinion Promotes State Power, by Benjamin Ginsberg. (Basic Books, $8.95.) By managing mass opinion, Benjamin Ginsberg writes, governments use democracy as a means of social control. Last year our reviewer, Mark Crispin Miller, said the author's ''quasi-Orwellian vision is oversimple,'' but he found the book ''largely admirable.''  OVERHEAD IN A BALLOON: Twelve Stories of Paris, by Mavis Gallant. (Norton, $7.95.) When these interlocking stories by the Canadian writer were published last year, Phyllis Rose said in these pages that Mavis Gallant ''conjures up  [ Paris ]  more knowingly than any other fiction writer in English. . . . In the taut, high-wire literary performances in this volume,  [ she ]  is at the top of her form.''  A GOOD ENOUGH PARENT: A Book on Child-Rearing, by Bruno Bettelheim. (Vintage, $9.95.) Last year our reviewer, Barbara Ehrenreich, said she wondered how Bruno Bettelheim thought today's two-paycheck families would have time for his leisurely, permissive approach to child raising. But she found the book ''a reassuring corrective to the hubris that leads many parents to think they can mold a child to meet their exact specifications.''  SERENISSIMA, by Erica Jong. (Dell, $4.95.) An intellectual American actress travels to the 16th century and has a lurid affair with William Shakespeare. In 1987 Michael Malone said in The Book Review that he didn't like this novel as much as he did ''Fanny,'' but he praised Erica Jong for ''her careful research, her rich descriptive facility and her deep love of the period.''  THE TOMORROW MAKERS: A Brave New World of Living-Brain Machines, by Grant Fjermedal. (Tempus, $8.95.) If the mind is a program, theoretically it can be ''downloaded,'' or fed, into computerized robots, granting a kind of immortality. Last year one reviewer said this book about computer scientists and robotics is ''a virtual smorgasbord of artificial intelligence.''  MEMOIRS OF MANY IN ONE, by Alex Xenophon Demirjian Gray. Edited by Patrick White. (Penguin, $6.95.) A madwoman's fantasies, cast as a memoir edited by the author, allow Patrick White to write a story about writing stories. In 1986 our reviewer, Jonathan Baumbach, called the novel ''an elegant book, a comic meditation on the nature of art (and putative madness), a minor 'Tempest' in a career of sometimes oversized teapots.''
Title: New & Noteworthy

Paragraph: Increased financing by Darpa would also be significant because the agency has long been the leading backer of research for a competing approach in artificial intelligence that uses conventional computers. Neural networks in the past have been widely considered a part of artificial intelligence, but the approach has not received wide support. Darpa now appears to be hedging its artificial intelligence bets. Darpa is currently sponsoring the Strategic Computing Initiative, a 10-year program involving the expenditure of more than $100 million a year, aimed at applying artificial intelligence to such tasks as developing a tank that can navigate on its own and a computer system that can give instant advice to fighter pilots in battle. Dr. Fields said that the Strategic Computing Initiative, now reaching its midway point, was on target. Paragraph: Eric Davis, the Cincinnati outfielder whose left leg was bruised in a collision Monday night, is expected to return to the lineup in a few days. X-rays were not taken, Starr said, because an examination showed Davis had not suffered damage to his left knee. ''You really could call it a thigh bruise, as opposed to a knee,'' Starr said. Paragraph: ROCHESTER, March 30—                     The Xerox Corporation introduced a new copier that can ''phone home'' for help when it senses a problem developing. The Xerox 5065, a mid-volume copier that produces 62 copies a minute, is the first Xerox copier to offer a built-in ''remote interactive communications'' system, which continuously checks the copier's performance and alerts a central computer when it notices a potential problem, a Xerox spokesman said. The central computer uses an artificial intelligence system to decide whether a service call is needed.
Title: New Xerox Copier

Paragraph: The robot was designed to perform while submerged in the the deuterium, or ''heavy water,'' that flows through the reactor to cool it and to withstand the extreme radioactivity that has developed in the reactors after more than 30 years of operation. If the robot works as planned, crews operating it around the clock will take 52 to 60 days to inspect the 300 to 400 feet of welds in each reactor vessel. The company is building several robots, the first of which is scheduled to be ready in June. In trial operations in a full-scale model of the Savannah River Plant's reactor vessels, the robot has performed well, according to engineers. In a demonstration earlier this month, technicians punched in the commands that caused the robot's long arm to whir into position and then to gently place the delicate ultrasonic grids against cold welds. Flood lights flashed on inside the vessel and the camera moved into position to record the progress. Unanticipated Weakness
Title: New Robot Holds Key To Repair Of Reactors

Paragraph: NORFOLK, Va., April 3                     When the submersible robot Nemo surfaced from the depths of the Atlantic one day last summer, its mechanical arms clutching a gleaming batch of gold coins and bars, the salvagers of the 132-year-old wreck of the S.S. Central America figured their dream of fabulous riches - perhaps a billion dollars or more - had at last come true. The case, which for the most part involves admiralty law, a particularly arcane area, has already broken some new legal ground. Judge Kellam ruled shortly after the wreck was discovered that the Columbus salvage team had the right to bring up the gold, though not necessarily the right to claim it, because its robot had photographed the wreck with television cameras and had mechanically recovered parts of it.
Title: A Treasure From the Seas, but Whose?

Paragraph: WITH nurses in short supply, Danbury Hospital in Connecticut considered an offbeat aid to make its nursing staff more efficient: Roscoe, a three-foot-tall robot designed to do some of the drudge work. Developed by a pioneer in robotics, Joseph Engelberger, Roscoe was to undergo testing and programming at the hospital early this year. If all went well, the robot was expected to start performing in six months such tasks as delivering meal trays and retrieving laboratory samples and medical files. All has not gone well.  Hospital halls, Roscoe has learned, are cluttered, tricky mazes, and ''one thing we don't want to do is bang into things,'' notes Mr. Engelberger, who is chairman of the Transition Research Corporation in Danbury. The robot has been back to the drawing board more than once for enhancement of its vision sensors and computer software. He hopes to have Roscoe working full-time at the 450-bed hospital in Danbury by mid-1989. Then he looks for full production of a robot that will cost about $40,000 and be eligible to work at any hospital with more than 250 beds.
Title: Training a Robot For Hospital Jobs
Other (negative): been back to the drawing board more than once for enhancement of its vision sensors and computer software
Other (positive): delivering meal trays and retrieving laboratory samples and medical files.

Paragraph: If object-oriented programming is so great, why haven't we seen it before? It has been employed to some extent in computer-aided software engineering, or CASE, and in the rarefied realm of artificial intelligence, but until now it has not been practical for the millions of business and recreational programmers. Developed for research and academe, not for business applications, OOPS has until now been too fat and too slow to be useful on personal computers. But two leading makers of personal computer software have developed a relatively sleek version of OOPS that is ready for the mainstream of personal computing. The products come from from Borland International Inc. of Scotts Valley, Calif., and the Microsoft Corporation of Redmond, Wash. Each hopes to set the industry standard, and the initial battlefield is Pascal, by far the most popular language for teaching programming and computer science.
Title: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER

Paragraph: WHY IS MONNETT HANVEY Soldo following a robot down the hall, yelling, ''Straight! Straight!''? Well, naturally, because the robot is trying to swerve into people's offices - for example, into the office of Kaigham J. Gabriel, in the machine perception research department of A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories in New Jersey. Gabriel has enough troubles. He is trying to put across the bewildering idea that in the future, robots tiny enough to clean out your clogged heart arteries from the inside will have special control problems because they won't have any mass or inertia to speak of. Soldo's robot, meanwhile, has solved its own control problem. It reaches the end of the corridor and, without hesitating perceptibly, turns left and coolly trundles off. It is an uninspiring sort of robot, really - just a small cart with wheels. Out the window, a human can see that nature has provided a fine autumn day, sunshine and a brisk wind playing over sculpted green gardens. The robot's television-camera eye reduces this vista to vague white-on-black lines. The robot is not using the camera for navigation anyway. It is using sonar, and, because of all the smooth metal and glass surfaces around, trying to navigate by reflected sound is like trying to figure out where you are in a hall of mirrors. Sometimes the robot gets confused. Who wouldn't? Confused? As the era of robots dawns - and it is dawning with a vengeance - people are finding it all too easy to apply such words to the mental states of inanimate objects. Scientists who make humanlike machines are falling into the obvious anthropomorphic traps, ascribing thoughts and emotions to their creations, if only for the sake of linguistic convenience. Soldo's robot sometimes gets ''confused'' when people walk by. It freezes into a catatonic state or else it nervously hugs the wall and keeps going. Soldo, who is a graduate-student researcher, shouts at her robot, though she knows full well that this model cannot hear her - it is not equipped for voice recognition. Down the hall, Russell Andersson has a robot that plays Ping-Pong. It is more nimble and clever than Soldo's. Andersson says that to solve the Ping-Pong problem he had to endow his robot with a sense of time and a sense of self-awareness. So they are tackling the vision problem, the navigation problem, the manipulation problem. Unlike industrial robots, stuck in their mindless ruts, the robots in these research laboratories look around, clamber over obstacles, pick out objects from piles of junk and manipulate them with fingers covered in plastic skin. Some of the progress is painfully slow. Robot designers admit that their field, like artificial intelligence, is suffering the consequences of the last decade's hype. Even so, some developments are startling: robots play Ping-Pong and billiards. An Australian robot shears sheep quite well (though enthusiasm was tempered by an early ovine fatality). Robot senses now include vision, hearing and touch. Robot hands are getting dexterous: the so-called Stanford-J.P.L. (Jet Propulsion Laboratory) hand can pick up wine glasses with its individually coordinated fingers; the Utah-M.I.T. hand can grasp an egg, crack it, dump its contents into a bowl, and then beat it at high speed with its index finger. The roboticists debate the merits of wheels versus legs. Where first they tried making legged robots with built-in stability, now they are trying to make robots with the controlled instability that comes naturally to walking and running humans.
Title: WHY CAN'T A ROBOT BE MORE LIKE A MAN?
Other (negative): inherent limitations of AI, humans mistakenly blur human and AI false AI hype
Other (positive): information lacking       progress in robotics

Paragraph: Indifference, absence, alienation, indolence - these are Mr. Longo's themes, and he expresses them in many different forms. A creature with, among other things, two densely fanged mouths and a single female breast, it stands against a painted backdrop of opera boxes, holding a flagpole in one hand, a broken guitar in the other and emitting from its naked rump a bunch of thunderbolts. Paragraph: Vasya Surin saw the aliens. In a park in Voronezh, 300 miles southeast of Moscow. Tass, the official Soviet news agency, said so, in a straight-faced report that conveniently, and perhaps not coincidentally, provided the Soviet public last week with plenty to ponder besides bare food shelves and chaotic politics. Tass said the landing had been confirmed ''scientifically'' and through ''biolocation.'' ''One, two or three creatures similar to humans and a small robot came out'' of the ball-shaped spacecraft, Tass said. Vasya, one of several witnesses to the encounter, told another Soviet publication the aliens were nine feet tall, had a hump where their heads should have been and had three eyes apiece. Paragraph: Researchers in the Netherlands are testing a milking robot developed by Gascoigne-Melotte, a Dutch machinery company. The device uses electronic sensors to identify cows approaching the milking box. If a cow is due to be milked, the door swings open and she is automatically presented the particular feed ration programmed for her. While she is feeding, a brush-covered device is automatically inserted between her hind legs to clean the udder. So far, it sounds better than it works, according to Hoard's Dairyman, a trade magazine that reported on the system. A herd manager had to help attach the milking cups during a demonstration early this year. When a cow moved suddenly, the cups came off and the manager had to help the robot reattach itself. And part of one cow's udder remained unmilked when the robot retracted.
Title: A Mechanical Milkmaid: Will Cows Be Content?
Other (positive): cow milking    Milkmaid

Paragraph: WHEN the computer scientist John McCarthy coined the term artificial intelligence in the late 1950's, he did not mean to imply that there would be anything second rate about mechanical minds. However, three decades later computers still do not think. Is this because of the technological failings of the computer industry? Or is artificial intelligence theoretically impossible? Finally, since most of the research is financed by the Pentagon, will smarter computers lead to more efficient ways of killing people? Three reports follow. WHILE many scientists question whether people are smart enough to make machines that think, few of them doubt that artificial intelligence is at least theoretically possible. Hubert Dreyfus, a colleague of Dr. Searle's, argues that artificial intelligence is impossible because reality itself cannot be formalized. Since the days of Plato, he believes, we have been deluded into believing that everything can be modeled by abstract systems. Whether we use mathematics to describe an economy, or quantum theory to describe an atom, something essential will always slip through the cracks of our simulations. By insisting that artificial intelligence is impossible, Dr. Dreyfus, Dr. Searle and a few other philosophers question the premise of Western science: that the world we live in and the world inside our heads can be understood by the human mind.
Title: IDEAS AND TRENDS: Can Machines Learn to Think?; A Parable of Computers And Brains
Other (negative): inherent limitations of AI   AI is not possible.  It will never work.
Other (positive): three decades later computers still do not think

Paragraph: However, I was left feeling curiously unsatisfied on one count. Mr. Moravec's whole thesis presumes that sufficiently advanced computers and robots will possess consciousness in the same sense we do; otherwise, how could they become our heirs? And yet, except to say that consciousness will be ''emergent'' in complex systems, he does little to justify this presumption. In fact, it has been the subject of many a debate among philosophers, psychologists and artificial intelligence researchers: is thought just a form of (very complex) information processing? I happen to believe it is. But there are a lot of deep issues here, and I think ''Mind Children'' would have been stronger with a much better discussion of them. Leaving that issue aside, however, we still have the second basic question: is Mr. Moravec's vision of the future desirable? And here, I think, he falters. Nowhere in ''Mind Children'' does he express the slightest doubt that what can be done will be done. (Indeed, he argues that nations will be forced to develop robots as fast as possible in the name of economic competitiveness.) He says very little about the impact of humanlike robots on human employment - or, more importantly, on humankind's sense of purpose and dignity. Apparently we are simply to fade away, leaving the universe to our heirs and betters. And he gives only passing mention to that ancient human institution, warfare. The fact is that military needs have always been among the major drivers of computer and robotics research, both here and abroad; Mr. Moravec's near-human machines might very well find their first uses as robot soldiers and robot fighter planes.
Title: THE SOULS OF THE NEW MACHINES
Other (negative): inherent limitations of AI

Paragraph: We do not denounce artificial intelligence as ''theoretically impossible,'' as George Johnson states in his review of ''The Improbable Machine'' by Jeremy Campbell (Dec. 24). Rather, we argue in our 1985 book, ''Mind Over Machine,'' that human experts do not rely on reasoning but on pattern discrimination with associated decisions based on what experience has shown to succeed and, furthermore, that artificial intelligence based on reasoning has failed miserably to live up to expectations. And we do not believe, as Mr. Johnson writes, that artificial neural nets make successful artificial intelligence more thinkable. In our book's 1988 preface we give reasons why such nets will probably fail to generalize from experience as human beings do. Most important, what we, and Mr. Campbell, do assert is that neural net research shows that inferential rules for manipulating symbols representing facts about the world are not required for successful learning from experience. Since conventional artificial intelligence is based on the physical symbol system hypothesis, which asserts that symbol manipulation is the source of intelligence, this is a radical rejection of conventional artificial intelligence.
Title: Neural Nets and Human Experts
Other (negative): fail to generalize from experience as human beings do
Other (positive): neural nets

Paragraph: The Lady and the Monk chronicles a year in Kyoto and is arranged, in proper Japanese style, by seasons. Arriving in Kyoto fresh and wide-eyed in the fall of 1987, Mr. Iyer -- an essayist for Time magazine and the author of "Video Night in Kathmandu" -- wanders the city streets and observes the strange and intriguing world around him, where timeless Zen temples coexist side by side with 24-hour convenience stores, vending machines with mechanized robot voices and tinkling Muzak. Unable to speak Japanese, he is thrown back on Western students of Zen, longtime residents of Kyoto, to provide some explanation of what he sees. There are many convincing portraits here of old Japan hands, living out their obsessive love-hate relationship with the place. Mr. Iyer also absorbs translations of Japanese literature, which he discovers to be a very feminine art form. Thus his image of Kyoto is framed in terms of poetry, a sort of idealized romantic Japan.
Title: Zen and the Art of Flirtation

And while his erudite characters are mainly mouthpieces for various cognitive theories, they can be as witty as the droll academic who points out that "the most exciting things the mind does are lie, laugh, and create chaos."

Paragraph: Professor Fredkin hung around with a ragtag band of students, professors and other hangers-on at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology that, working on a machine donated by Digital, came up with software to make the PDP-1 useful. Their software innovations included the first computer graphics systems, the first word processors, the first video games, the first computer music systems and programming tools for the first researchers in artificial intelligence. Among the guests were some who are now among the most famous people in computing. Marvin Minsky, who was and still is a professor at M.I.T., is perhaps the foremost pioneer of research into artificial intelligence, in which computers mimic human functions like vision, speech and decision-making. John McCarthy, a Stanford University professor who was an M.I.T. professor at the time, was an early developer of computer time-sharing systems, which allowed more than one person to use a computer at the same time.
Title: Digital Fetes the 'Germ' That Began a Revolution

Paragraph: They teamed with Ampex, a big supplier of magnetic tape and equipment to broadcasters, on a helical-scan tape drive for the system. Helical scanning, which uses a cylindrical drum rotating at 5,500 revolutions a minute to "write" data onto a tape, allowed E-Systems to produce a tape drive 10 times faster than conventional mass-storage tape drives. A robot stand with four arms, developed with the Odetics Corporation, an Anaheim, Calif., robotics company, files and retrieves the data cartridges. Higher Performance and Price Emass is designed for use with supercomputers made by the Convex Computer Corporation and Cray Research Inc. It uses six tape cassettes -- which are roughly three times the size of a standard videocassette -- to store a trillion bytes of data. That compares with about 5,000 cartridge reels in mass-storage systems made by Storage Technology. The Emass robot selects tapes by using a bar-code scanning device, then loads the cassettes into the computer's tape drive. The process takes about 30 seconds after the user enters the appropriate command. Diagram: "A Tower of Information"    E-Systems' storage system is capable of storing enormous amounts of electronic data while keeping it readily accessible to computers.    A total of 227 tapes are stacked in columns within a tower. A robot can grab as many as 4 tapes at one time and transfer them to drives in the rear of the tower in a matter of seconds.    The tower, which is 6 1/2 feet tall, can store the equivalent of a 150-mile-high stack of pages of typed data. (Source: E-Systems)
Title: A New System for Storing Mountains of Data

Paragraph: Sun also signed a significant pact last week with Texas Instruments. Texas Instruments' chip-manufacturing division, which includes some of the biggest and most sophisticated fabrication facilities in this country, agreed to make SPARC chips for Sun and other customers. Texas Instruments' computer systems group, at the same time, licensed the SPARC chip for use in a new line of Unix-based computer systems that company officials said would incorporate artificial intelligence features now found on the company's more expensive and specialized Explorer platform. ''T.I.'s great failing has been in commercial systems,'' said Richard A. Shaffer, editor and publisher of the Technologic Computer Letter. ''They don't have a part of the microprocessor market. None of their chips has made it, at least not in mainstream microprocessors. This is another shot at the market they lost to Motorola.'' Texas Instruments has also not had a successful business computer. It wants to change that by building a Unix-standard work station around the SPARC chip, customizing it to take advantage of symbolic processing, and thus provide it with special artificial intelligence features. By customizing the SPARC design with its own artificial intelligence techniques in a Unix-based machine, the company hopes to make artificial intelligence and expert systems cost-effective for large-scale operations. TEXAS INSTRUMENTS currently provides such a system, the Explorer, at a cost of $50,000 to $100,000 for each user. Its recently announced Microexplorer system brings some artificial intelligence functions down to about $10,000 a user.But with the SPARC architecture in a standard Unix work station, Texas Instruments hopes to bring such expert-system technology to thousands of users at a cost of perhaps $2,000 a user. Then artificial intelligence might be found in such broad-based operations as factory-floor scheduling, credit card authorization or trading on a stock exchange.
Title: Getting Faster by Getting Simpler
Other (positive): science and technology development for AI AI in a potential large scale computer product   affordability of AI tech, broader applications

Paragraph: The Arris Pharmaceuticals Corporation, in South San Francisco, is using artificial intelligence software originally developed for use in guiding bombs to their targets, applying it to the even more complex task of exploring molecular interactions. "Our goal is to predict with some certainty molecules that have never been made before, and say this one will work, and this one won't," said Michael J. Ross, Arris's chief executive. "Small, specific, potent -- that's the trick to this trade." Photo: A new technique for synthesizing drugs is attracting large numbers of new investors to the biotechnology field. Steve Banville, a lab operator for the Chiron Corporation, monitored a robot as it performed automated peptide synthesis in a company lab in Emeryville, Calif. (Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times) (pg. D1) Diagram: To develop drugs for diseases like cancer or AIDS, researchers need to find ways to target diseased cells but leave healthycells untouched. One method of targeting these cells is by finding the peptide (a specific armino acid sequence) that bonds with the diseased cell. THE PROBLEM    1. Diseased cell amid healthy cells.    2. Each type of cell carries a certain receptor to which a peptide may bind.    3. But there are billions of possible peptides. SELECTIDE PROCESS    1. Create a peptide "library" or millions of beads, each coated with a different peptide.    2. Immerse beads in a solution containing a receptor from the diseased cell. The bead with the right peptide will react invisibly with the receptor.    3. Treat beads with an enzyme system that turns the "positive" bead a different color.    4. Isolate the positive bead under a low-power microscope, and identify its amino acid sequence. (Source: Dr. Kit Lam, Arizona Cancer Center) (pg. D13)
Title: New Drugs by Process of Elimination
Other (positive): predict with some certainty molecules that have never been made before, and say this one will work, and this one won't,

Paragraph: In ''The Age of Intelligent Machines,'' Mr. Kurzweil valiantly attempts to provide an overview of artificial intelligence - the field devoted to the theory, design and construction of computing machines that think, or at least appear to. He discusses its philosophical, mathematical, psychological and technical roots; the outstanding problems in contemporary research on artificial intelligence; the history and current state of the industry; the impact of artificial intelligence on the arts, and the future of the discipline. The volume is an innovative blend of monograph and anthology, for it includes not only Mr. Kurzweil's own writing but a number of essays by philosophers and researchers in artificial intelligence. This structure would have been more successful, however, if the author had included views divergent from his own alongside those that buttress his position. On his own turf Mr. Kurzweil is clear, current and informative. He understands how artificial intelligence can be used in pattern recognition, reading, speech and music synthesis. But when he strays into philosophy, logic and psychology, he is often sloppy and vague. He relies on dated and secondary sources, ignores or misunderstands many of the most important thinkers and distorts the relevant history of philosophy and logic. Mr. Kurzweil also is too quick to draw inferences about human psychology from artificial intelligence models, and he is superficial when he discusses one of the most exciting developments in current artificial intelligence theory - the emergence of connectionism, which explains intelligence as arising from a web of interconnected, individually very simple, processes. Mr. Kurzweil's enthusiasm for the artificial intelligence industry also leads him to disregard his own advice against overly optimistic projection as well as his own remarks on the deep differences between human and machine intelligence. While noting that ''understanding language can . . . require a knowledge of history, myths, literary allusions and references, and many other categories of shared human experience,'' he says on the same page that Terry Winograd's 1970 Shrdlu program (an early attempt, later repudiated by its designer, to model language comprehension) represents progress toward a genuine understanding of natural language, and he asserts that ''we can expect translating telephones with reasonable levels of performance . . . early in the first decade of the next century.'' There is no suggestion of the mammoth difficulties that confront anyone who tries to accomplish such a task. Chess is a leitmotif in the history of artificial intelligence, and in this book. Mr. Kurzweil writes that ''when a computer does become the chess champion . . . before the end of the century, we will either think more of computers, less of ourselves, or less of chess.'' But then he undermines this odd speculation by observing correctly that the methods by which computers play chess differ dramatically from those by which humans play. This difference is evidenced by the fact that even though humans can play go (a Japanese board game) with no greater difficulty than chess, computers, which can play chess extremely well, are embarrassingly weak at go. In other words, the fact that planes and birds fly makes us think neither more nor less of birds, planes or flight. Bird flight and plane flight are simply two quite different feats. Artificial intelligence boosters and critics are often puzzled by one another, and often talk past one another. Mr. Kurzweil has heard the voices on the other side, but he has not quite understood the force of their arguments or the problems they pose. Even sympathetic critics of artificial intelligence look like Luddites to him. But, after all, judicious Luddism may not be such a bad thing.
Title: Machine See, Machine Do
Other (negative): being beaten by computer diminishes humans   references Luddites as wisely cautious
Other (positive): AI's use in arts   can be used in pattern recognition, reading, speech and music synthesis     can play games like chess and go

Paragraph: Well, it's not supposed to be. But "Science Matters" is. In an early chapter, for instance, we learn about the atom. Not until Chapter 9, however, do we find out about the subatomic particles that make up atoms. Biologists and their ilk will no doubt be upset over the book's emphasis on the physical sciences over the life sciences. Mathematics, which serves as the language of science, is dismissed from the outset. And, inexplicably, artificial intelligence is discussed in the chapter on chemical bonding.
Title: Huggies and Isaac Newton

Paragraph: The failure of the cognitive revolution to unravel the mysteries of the workings of the human mind as the creator of meanings is the starting point for Jerome Bruner's "Acts of Meaning." He argues that psychology should return to human concerns, especially the role of culture in shaping our thoughts and the language we use to express them. Mr. Bruner, a professor of psychology at New York University, seems to have read and assimilated everyone else's ideas on the topics he discusses. He can -- and does -- allude to them in context, so that we are constantly rubbing elbows with the giants on whose shoulders he stands. Erudite and recondite, the text glistens with Mr. Bruner's bold style. He dismisses the concept of "artificial intelligence" early on as "an oxymoron (the liveliness of intelligence coupled with the flatness of artificiality)." In defending "folk psychology," he observes that "it is part of our heritage as post-Freudian modern men and women to cock a snoot at what people    say   ." This is a terse but densely written work of scholarship.
Title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION

Paragraph: As much as any one person, Herbert A. Simon has shaped the intellectual agenda of the human and social sciences in the second half of the 20th century. A brilliant polymath, Mr. Simon is a Nobel laureate in economics, a pioneer in political science, psychology and management and a founding father of artificial intelligence, the enterprise of trying to build machines that think. Now he has turned to autobiography and thus provides a window onto the subjective side of scientific achievement. Models of My Life, one of the books in the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation series, offers dramatic examples of science as the product of the whole scientist, of the fit among personality, scientific problems and strategies for their solution. As the work comes out of the life, so the life is shaped by the work. And while readers may come to this book thinking that artificial intelligence is an impersonal product of technological progress, they will come away seeing that it is a deeply personal enterprise -- an expression of the esthetic of the people who work in it and, more than that, a science of self-reflection, a way of thinking about one's own thought. In the mid-1950's, Mr. Simon married his vision of human behavior to the possibilities offered by computer technology. The computer gave powerful expression to Mr. Simon's already-formed intellectual esthetic. His idea that humans solve problems under constraint was easily adapted to the task of programming a computer to solve problems using heuristic search -- a procedure that doesn't involve absolute rules but rules of thumb based on the knowledge of specific and bounded environments. And his idea that observation must be the foundation for abstraction led him to create a research strategy for artificial intelligence that he called "thinking aloud." In "thinking aloud," Mr. Simon and his colleagues asked people to express their thoughts as they solved logical problems, and then they analyzed the transcripts of these sessions. The protocols of human beings playing games and solving puzzles were used to evaluate computer programs made to follow in human footsteps. Whereas some artificial intelligence researchers were content to leave aside the larger question of whether machines that perform intelligent tasks are doing them in the way people might, Mr. Simon took a very different tack. His artificial intelligence was psychology, not engineering. From the first, he says, "we were interested in simulating    human problem solving,    and not simply in demonstrating how computers could solve hard problems." His school of artificial intelligence was committed to the view that human intelligence is the manipulation of symbols and the implementation of rules. "For my money," he writes, "to show that something whose behavior looks very complex and erratic is really built from the combinatorics of very simple components is beautiful, not demeaning."
Title: Dangerous Thoughts . . . And Machines With Big Ideas
Other (positive): This is probably part of an Obit for Herb Simon

Paragraph: But not every path she explores leads to surprising vistas. Most of the computer programs in the book will be familiar to anyone who has read some of the popular literature on artificial intelligence. And though her descriptions are usually crystal clear, in one case her metaphor undermines her exposition. In describing a neural network, consisting of a web of artificial brain cells, she likens it to a classroom of children sitting in rows of desks and shouting at one another. I doubt I would have understood that very well if I hadn't already read Jeremy Campbell's book about neural nets, "The Improbable Machine," and William F. Allman's "Apprentices of Wonder." And while Ms. Boden argues convincingly that brains are computers and computers can create, no one has made the point more eloquently than Douglas R. Hofstadter in "Metamagical Themas" and "Godel, Escher, Bach."

Paragraph: There are personages like Conan the Barbarian, who started life as the hero of a paperback series, and Mr. Delbo's own Transformers, who were originally robot toys. This information was supplied by Mr. Delbo, not the biographies, which, written mainly by the artists themselves, tend to be irritatingly informative about wives (without whom) and children but facetiously offhand about accomplishments. As already indicated, it is a take-it-or-leave-it show.
Title: 'Cartoons Come to Paterson'

Paragraph: WASHINGTON                     A Massachusetts computer scientist patented his ''baby'' this week, a robot called Infant that he says is modeled on the way a human baby learns motor skills. The robot's greatest accomplishment thus far is picking up a cylinder. What makes this seemingly simple task special, the inventor said, is that the robot trained itself to carry out the task and has learned to do it regardless of the cylinder's position. The robot starts out with instructions to try to carry out a particular task within a defined space, like a factory floor. Two video cameras take snapshots of the robot arms in every position relative to an object and, through extensive repetition, the robot begins to associate positions of the arm and the object with the movement it has just made. Over time, it begins to develop its own sense of the motion needed to carry out a particular task in the space that it has explored. The inventor hopes to offer the robot commercially in about 18 months, and he said he believed the potential applications range from the automation of factories to farms. The robots will cost $50,000 to $150,000 apiece. Mr. Kuperstein received patent 4,884,216.
Title: Patents; A Robot Said to Learn Like a Baby

Paragraph: Since the United States is so far behind Japan on high-definition television, not all supporters of national high-tech efforts think it should be developed. But in general, leaders of the computer industry say Pentagon support has been indispensable. Alan Kay, one of Apple Computer's principal researchers, has referred to the early years of Darpa as a renaissance for computer science. The agency supported research into the first personal computers, computer graphics, computer networks and artificial intelligence. Sun Microsystems Inc., the world's fastest-growing maker of computer work stations, was started by researchers at Stanford and the University of California at Berkeley who worked with the agency's money. A Darpa-financed software project at Carnegie-Mellon University known as Mach has become the basis for several companies including Steve Jobs's Next Inc.
Title: Making Industrial Policy at the Pentagon

Paragraph: New computer software products using techniques developed by artificial intelligence researchers are helping a growing number of employers and insurers to audit some of the 1.5 billion doctor and hospital bills submitted each year for insurance payment.
Title: Insurers vs. Doctors: A Software Battleground

Paragraph: Lingo's artificial intelligence grows by leaps and megabytes. He achieves the ability to speak, hear and see. He invades the major computers of the world to give himself space for his growing memory. He orders the construction of a doll that gives him near-human form. He hires a publicity agent who puts him on the cover of People magazine. He gets himself invited to television talk and quiz shows.
Title: Books of The Times; A Computer Program Decides to Take Over

Paragraph: Norman Mack, the head of Robutler, is not concerned with what Omen says. It's Mr. Stewart who is being challenged. ''He signed an agreement when he worked for me which kept the workings of the robot secret,'' Mr. Mack said. ''He has totally disregarded that agreement. I'm filing a suit to prevent him from using that robot.'' ''Anyone who knows anything about the robot business would be able to construct one similar,'' Mr. Stewart countered. ''I signed an agreement not to divulge the secrets about Robutler and I haven't.''
Title: Long Island Journal

Paragraph: For the human exploration program, NASA is proposing to spend $1.3 billion on developing new technology for flights to the Moon and Mars, preliminary studies of an aerospace plane and two robot spacecraft to orbit the Moon and investigate the effects of long-duration flight on biological systems. However, space policy experts point out that only about $300 million of this constitutes new undertakings; the rest consists of existing programs included in the new category.
Title: Budget for the Space Agency Sets a Broader Course in Exploration

Paragraph: Almost everyone knows that the Winter Garden in the granite-and-marble World Financial Center is a haven on gray and gusty weekends, especially in March, when the weather fulminates while babies in strollers resolutely nap inside. This month, Brian Eno's tropical wildlife music floats above the palm fronds, unfraying young and old nerves. This weekend, children can take part in an environmental fair at which, among other things, a robot named Mr. R. E. Cycle will munch aluminum cans fed to it by children.
Title: For Children

Paragraph: Having kept the peace for millions of years by preventing its wards from developing destructive technology, the artificial intelligence known as the Oversoul realizes that it is breaking down, losing control over its own functions and over the human beings on the planet Harmony; to save the people and the planet, it decides to return to Earth to seek help from the artificial intelligence that created it. To assist it in this enterprise the Oversoul recruits members of a large extended family; it communicates with its chosen servants by stimulating visions of one kind or another in their brains. Some sacrifices are necessary; before the world-saving can even begin, a 14-year old boy named Nafai, through whose eyes we follow the story, is asked to kill a man in cold blood.
Title: Science Fiction

Paragraph: WASHINGTON                     BETWEEN the sky above and the earth below lies a place that scientists study only with great difficulty: the critical region of the atmosphere where the highest clouds form and gases interact with radiation from space. This zone, too high for most aircraft to reach and too low for thorough satellite observations from space, is prompting the development of a new class of robot airplanes to monitor ozone depletion and global warming.
Title: Designers Plan Drones To Probe Atmosphere
Other (positive): monitor ozone depletion and global warming

Paragraph: But this is an imperfect world, and that is why Bruce A. Powell, John S. Kendall and David J. Sirag labor for the Otis Elevator Company in the rolling hills of central Connecticut, using various forms of artificial intelligence -- technologies and disciplines with odd names like fuzzy logic and neural networks -- to improve the relationship between humankind and its elevators. With the sophistication of the new artificial intelligence, and with better processors, these elevators can process a lot more information, said Mr. Kendall, director of advanced research at Otis, a division of the United Technologies Corporation. "They're learning." There are plenty of pitfalls in elevator programming. Mr. Sirag, an analyst in the artificial intelligence group at the United Technologies Research Center, where Otis thinks many of its big thoughts about elevators, recalls a simulation that was intended to keep elevator systems from sending cars that are too full to take passengers. The computer was told, in effect, "don't send a car that can't take all the people who are waiting." Photo: At the Otis Elevator Company, the assignment of Bruce A. Powell, left, David J. Sirag, center, and John S. Kendall is to make use of various forms of artificial intelligence to try to improve the relationship between the machines they make and the people who use them. (Carl David LaBianca for The New York Times) Chart: "Fuzzy Elevators"    Two elevator cars serve 12 floors. Both are traveling down. A passenger on the sixth floor calls an elevator.    Using the "CRISP" rule, the computer would send car B, on the ninth floor, since it is closest to the sixth.    But in a FUZZY LOGIC system, the computer assigns values to several variables in a mathematical equation, considering such factors as the number of people in each car and proximity to the desired floor. It then uses the equation to respond to a rule that has been programmed into the system:    If car B is crowded an car A is close, then choose car A.    Car A proceeds to the sixth floor. (Source: Otis Elevator Company) (pg. D9)
Title: Fuzzy Thinking Has Merits When It Comes to Elevators
Other (positive): neural networks improving things in daily life (elevators) better elevators improving things in daily life (elevators) elevator operation     improving things in daily life (elevators)

Paragraph: Mr. Kaplan, who has developed artificial intelligence software at Teknowledge and the Lotus Development Corporation, chides himself for falling into a trap that caught many pioneers in other technologies.
Title: Getting Computers to Accept Poor Penmanship

Paragraph: Restaurants provide Mr. Schank with a comfortable place to introduce the strategies he believes govern how we think, remember and learn. Like many a computer scientist, he has come to a lot of his conclusions about people from his experience with machines. And like many an expert in artificial intelligence, he could have used algorithms to explain certain features of the human mind. Instead, he tells engaging, often witty stories centering on his irrepressible drive to eat and drink well. His assumption is that restaurants and his dining companions around the world are more interesting to the lay reader than laboratories and data -- and he is right.
Title: Strategies of the Head

Paragraph: Dante, the robot volcano explorer thwarted at the edge of success earlier this year, will try to tackle another mountain of fire next summer, say its builders at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh. The team of robotics experts, led by Dr. William L. Whittaker, is redesigning the eight-legged, spidery-walking robot to descend into volatile Mount Spurr in Alaska next June and explore the gaseous, rock-strewn crater floor. Dante, a 990-pound, remote-controlled metal ambler, was to explore Mount Erebus in Antarctica last January when its mission was aborted.  After the robot traveled only 21 feet into the volcano's crater, a fiberoptic communications cable linking the robot to its control station a mile away was severed and could not be repaired.
Title: Into the Volcano
Other (positive): explore

Title: The Nation; Locking the Doors in the Electronic Global Village

It lumbers clunkily, muscularly out of a closet, points its gun at a junior executive who has been given his own weapon so he can serve as a demonstration suspect, and says in a voice full of robotic menace, ''You have 60 seconds to put down your weapon.''
Title: Reporter's Notebook;   Oh, No! They've Created a Monster!

Paragraph: A wedge of hard-driving bodies moves like a robot battalion in precision drill through ''Rhythm Nation,'' the title song of Janet Jackson's current national tour. Legs chop wide open, then close again. They shoot out abruptly to the sides, then kick into jazz spins and bouncing splits to the floor. There are sedate pelvic jerks and a swiveling turn on a toe, trotting runs and purposeful syncopated walks. But essentially these are bodies rooted into the floor, taut yet alive in the way of a boxer edgily biding his time in the ring.
Title: Ballet, Boogie, Rap, Tap and Roll

Paragraph: For robots to operate effectively, they need predictability; the pieces to be moved or welded by the robot must be positioned consistently. Therefore, picking up parts piled randomly inside a bin has long posed a challenge for robot makers. For a robot to identify and determine how to grip an irregular part, it must have a sense of depth as well as knowledge of the part's two-dimensional outline. Perceptron uses a scanner to bounce a laser beam off specific points of a bin's contents. The scanner senses the contours by measuring the varying distances to the parts. This information is then used to guide the robot's gripper to the best place to grasp the part. Diagram shows how 3-D camera and robot arm can be used to eliminate need for precision stacking systems (Source: Perception Inc.)
Title: Tech Notes; Robots to Handle the Random
Other (negative): For robots to operate effectively, they need predictability

Paragraph: Budiansky is right: the horse was not a trained robot and I was not a manipulative exploiter. We were partners in a co-evolutionary deal that suited us both. BERNARD Z. FRIEDLANDER West Hartford, Conn.

Paragraph: Yet the fulfillment of this prospect does not lie a hundred years in the future, Mr. Gelernter says; it is going to happen very soon. In a concluding summary, Mr. Gelernter, who teaches computer science at Yale and is an expert on artificial intelligence, writes: "If we had the luxury of devoting ourselves to full-time mirror-worlding, we'd have a complete prototype in a year or two. One way or another, we or some other research group will almost certainly have produced a full-fledged, large-scale mirror world by the end of the decade." In fact mirror worlds may even embrace artificial intelligence, if, as Mr. Gelernter evidently suspects, mind is based on a vast storehouse of memory and not on "a dense intertwined superstructure of categories, rules and generalizations, with the odd specific, particular    fact hanging from the branches like the occasional bird-pecked apple."
Title: Books of The Times; A Mirror of Reality on a Computer Screen

Paragraph: In the 1970's, NASA sent two robot landing craft, known as Vikings, to Mars to examine its surface for signs of life. They found none.
Title: Can Mars Be Made Hospitable to Humans?

Paragraph: Now Japan wants I.B.M. and A.T.& T., among others, to join the Sixth Generation Project, a major new initiative in parallel processors -- a supercomputer technology that puts thousands of independent processing units to work on a single problem -- and artificial intelligence. Past initiatives of this kind have been closed to foreigners. Dr. Bromley suggested that an American endorsement of the project may be in the offing.
Title: Japan Wary as U.S. Science Comes Begging

Paragraph: The new robot gripper solves the problem with a simple sliding bar, backed by ball bearings, which are attached to one of the two parallel blocks. If, say, the gripper picks up the hexagon bolt along two edges, the bar quickly slides one way or the other and the bolt turns until two of its sides are flush with the block in a more stable position.
Title: Patents; A Simple Method for Robot's Grip

Paragraph: Allen Newell, a founder of the field of artificial intelligence and a leader in the study of human thinking, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 65 years old and lived in Pittsburgh. Dr. Newell, a professor at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, was considered one of the four fathers of artificial intelligence and an expert on how people think. He earned an international reputation for developing programs for complex information processing. He was the founding president of the American Association for Artificial Intelligence and had also headed the Cognitive Science Society. Dr. Newell's interest in artificial intelligence grew from his work in the early 1950's on a Rand Corporation project for the Air Force to simulate an early warning monitoring station with radar screens and a crew. In trying to predict how the crew members would react, he became fascinated with the puzzle of how people think and make decisions. Along with Dr. Newell and Dr. Simon, Marvin Minsky from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and John McCarthy from Stanford University are considered the pioneers in artificial intelligence by experts.
Title: Allen Newell, 65; Scientist Founded A Computing Field
Other (positive): military application early warning system

Paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24                     Telling an enthusiastic group of young people that even in hard times the public must invest in the future, President Bush said today that he would seek additional money for the space station, robot missions to the moon and other aerospace projects.
Title: Bush to Seek More Money for Major Space Missions

Paragraph: Robots have also proved indispensable, for example, in nuclear power plants. "We use them in remote inspection, tank cleaning, looking inside pipes and retrieval of loose parts," said Harry Roman, robotics and artificial intelligence manager for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey. "Our next target is repairs." Mr. Engleberger's first robotics company, Unimation Inc., is generally credited as the pioneer in industrial robotics in the late 1950's. He sold it a decade ago to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which later became one of several multinationals to give up on the business. Others that washed their hands of robot making included I.B.M. and Bendix.

Paragraph: Evidence of the danger, as outlined in the NASA report and interviews with major authors, is extensive, if at times circumstantial. One clue, Dr. Morrison said, is the large number of impact craters found throughout the solar system by robot spacecraft exploring planets. Moreover, he said, geologists have only begun to realize in the past two decades that numerous craters exist on Earth. Some 130 have been discovered, with the list growing by five or six a year. The largest crater, which is in Ontario, is 124 miles from rim to rim.
Title: Asteroid Defense: 'Risk Is Real,' Planners Say

Paragraph: A dozen companies are competing for a Postal Service contract to harness sophisticated optical-scanning technology and computer-based artificial intelligence to one of the post office's most tedious and costly tasks: deciphering handwritten addresses. Paragraph: The Fifth Generation project, started in 1982, aimed to develop computers with reasoning capabilities, rather than the ability to merely perform calculations. Computers imbued with such "artificial intelligence" could be used to diagnose diseases, analyze lawsuits and understand language. With the project drawing to a close, a big conference is under way here this week to assess its results. But these days, few people want specialized computers for artificial intelligence, preferring powerful general-purpose machines like those made by Sun Microsystems Inc., a fast-growing Silicon Valley company that did not exist when the Fifth Generation Project was conceived. And a host of scrappy American companies have sprung up to sell massively parallel computers with tens of thousands of processors, far more than the Fifth Generation machines.
Title: 'Fifth Generation' Became Japan's Lost Generation
Other (negative): lack of interest
Other (positive): analyze lawsuits, understand language
