Paragraph: Mysteriously, the German edge was lost. Although the Nazi regime perfected much innovative war machinery, including robot weapons, jet engines and the first rockets to soar into space, it failed to produce a nuclear weapon or anything close to it. Allied forces sweeping across Europe in 1944 and 1945 discovered only a small, half-hearted German effort to study the possibility of nuclear munitions.
Title: Saboteur Or Savant Of Nazi Drive for A-Bomb?

Paragraph: The Newton, for example, can capture handwritten notes and sketches, sort them and organize them using artificial intelligence techniques, then send the information to facsimile machines, electronic mailboxes or other computers using wireless communications. The difference between a tool and an assistant is that a tool helps you do the work, while an assistant does it for you, explained Esther Dyson, editor of Release 1.0, a newsletter published in New York City. "Newton's soul is an object-oriented operating system imbued with intelligent artificial intelligence." Apple constructed the operating system so it could be trained to "recognize what a user is trying to accomplish and complete much of it for him," she said.
Title: The Executive Computer; A Computer or Not? Apple Readies Its Newton

Paragraph: Leyner's fiction is, by design, indescribable. Befuddled critics have patched together a kind of police composite that presents the suspect as a surreal postmodern comic experimental novelist. Often, against his will, he is lumped in with the science fiction offshoot known as cyberpunk, which proposes a near future transformed by new developments in cybernetic engineering, organ transplants and artificial intelligence research. Leyner himself says, "I just use what's around me in my life."
Title: The Ridiculous Vision of Mark Leyner

Paragraph: JOHN R. SEARLE'S new book, "The Rediscovery of the Mind," could, at a stretch, have been called "The Critique of Cognitive Reason," and indeed one chapter of it is. Just as Kant's "Critique of Pure Reason" attacked the science of speculative metaphysics, which tries to spin a substantial web out of the pure silk of armchair reflection, so Mr. Searle's book takes aim at the dogmas of cognitive science, the ruling philosophy behind much of today's neurophysiology, linguistics, psychology and (above all) artificial intelligence. But such a title would have made it sound ponderous and boring, and Mr. Searle is never that. He likes to tell lively stories about driving, skiing and eating pizzas. His stories often have an explosive polemical point. When he thinks he sees a flaw in what somebody says, he will sidle up behind that person and blow an enormous raspberry.
Title: The Lesson of the Drunkand the Streetlight

Paragraph: Like any good home computing superstar, Mr. Bell has big plans: "My goal by the end of the year is to get rid of all paper -- I want all incoming correspondence automatically filed by the computer. Within three years I want to want to put a videophone on it, so I never have to leave the house." He laughs, "Then maybe a robot of me to look presentable answering the phone so I don't have to do even that."
Title: The Executive Life; Home Is Where the Megabytes Roam

Paragraph: The VCR Voice Programmer lets viewers commune directly with their appliances, liberating them from directions translated from Japanese. WHY ELSE: In a world where men and women cannot communicate, where children ignore their parents and where friends are too busy to chat, it's nice to know that someone -- well, something -- is listening. WHY NOT: The VCR Voice Programmer, which sells for $169, will not take orders from just anyone. You have to "train" it to recognize your voice pattern. Mr. Bissonnette, whose company is in Canoga Park, Calif., said this process should take about 15 minutes, but experience suggests otherwise. And chances are if you can figure out how to train the Voice Programmer, you can figure out how to program a VCR. "It does what it says it does," said Stan Pinkwas, managing editor of Video magazine. "But every solution creates a new problem." HOW IT WORKS: A lot of high-priced science went into teaching a VCR to understand a few words of English. Mr. Bissonnette said the Voice Programmer's patented computer chips use artificial intelligence and "fuzzy logic," a type of programming that allows computers to work with imprecise terms, to convert voice commands into electrical impulses. LEXICON: The Voice Programmer's vocabulary is fairly limited: basic terms like "fast forward," "stop" and "play." To tape, say, "Murphy Brown," in New York, you tell the machine "2" for the channel, then "Monday, 9 P.M." To watch the tape, you tell it "rewind," then "play." To breeze through a commercial break, just say, "Zap it."
Title: Making VCR's Hear
Other (positive): Help pick out the right TV channels.

Paragraph: GREENBELT, Md., Jan. 1                     The robot Dante stepped into the inferno today as it started down into an Antarctic volcano on a mission that could be a prelude to robotic exploration of the Moon and other planets, scientists said. The project is being directed from NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center here. On Thursday, the center accomplished another goal of the project by taking control of the robot through a satellite link and operating its cameras as it sat on the crater rim. Planning for the Planets The Dante mission is seeking not only to give volcanology a valuable new tool but also to prove the concept of robotic exploration of the Moon and Mars. When the robot is under the control of Goddard, there is a lag of 2.5 seconds each way in communicating with the robot, similar to the delay in operating a robot on the Moon from the Earth. Dante, a spider-like contraption weighing almost 1,000 pounds, was built by a team at Carnegie-Mellon University's Robotics Institute in Pittsburgh. The project took less than a year from concept to putting the robot on the mountain because the institute used much existing technology in constructing the machine. The robot, which is 9.8-feet long and 5.6-feet wide with a center mast that makes it 8.2-feet high, moves at a maximum speed of 6.6 feet a minute. Rappelling to the Lava Lake Dante is designed to rappel down the volcano with the help of a tether that is unreeled from its transport vehicle on the rim. At the lava lake, the robot is to take temperature readings, measure the composition of gases escaping from volcanic vents and retrieve samples of aerosols and the powdery mineral substances that build up around vent holes.  The Antarctic research team, including volcano experts from the New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology, wants Dante to spend at least a day near the lake before starting back up the crater. Constructed mainly of aluminum alloy and titanium, Dante is to feel its way down the crater walls with the help of a laser range-finder that has a 350-degree field of view. Developers of the range-finder said it tells the robot where objects are in every direction. In addition, the robot has six video cameras mounted on its center mast, three looking forward and three behind, that combine images to give the three-dimensional views of the surroundings.
Title: On Lonely Mission, Robot Starts Descent Into Volcano
Other (positive): space exploration      does dangerous jobs       exploration, research Where humans cannot tread, the robot is to take temperature readings, measure the composition of gases escaping from volcanic vents and retrieve samples of aerosols and the powdery mineral substances that build up around vent holes.   does dangerous jobs

Paragraph: Now, people seeking commercial applications of artificial intelligence have entered the philosophical debate that was once limited to academic corridors or private meetings. If scientists could never agree, they didn't seem to mind. But business people are pressing to redefine success in artificial intelligence. But even if computers still cannot think, artificial intelligence is making them smarter. Some large companies are using A.I. software that makes decisions by searching data for patterns, following rules of thumb and drawing on experience stored in memory. These programs allow American Express Company computers, for example, to analyze credit status and account activity and then decide whether to authorize a credit card charge. Another large user, Northwest Airlines, can audit millions of tickets and decide whether the right taxes, commissions and fares were paid. Many share the belief of Joe Carter, a partner in Anderson Consulting, one of the nation's largest international management and technology consulting firms, that the development of artificial intelligence is overly dependent on the goal of matching human thinking. Saying as much in his speech, Mr. Carter set the room abuzz with vexation. It's time to recycle the A.I. acronym -- there's nothing artificial about the intelligence in the systems we build, he added. "We don't need any more artificial humans, but we need vast improvements in alternatives to human intelligence." Some of what you say is dangerous to the field of artificial intelligence, said Stuart Shapiro, a professor at the State University of New York at Buffalo, rising to answer Mr. Carter. "A.I. is a science as well as an engineering and technical field. You can't tell people interested in science to pack up and go away because they're really irrelevant to making a business profit." Both business and science are bucking a public whose expectations have been primed by visions of computers like R2D2 in "Star Wars." And among this public are the executives and venture capitalists who might invest in the more limited achievements that the A.I. movement has pioneered. Where do you draw the line? asked Patrick Hayes, the association's president and a professor at the University of Illinois. "Where do you stop saying you won't call it artificial intelligence yet, but next year you will call it artificial intelligence?" Scientists are interested in solving unsolvable problems, said Philip Klahr, a vice president at the Inference Corporation, a leading producer of artificial intelligence software. Mr. Klahr began his career doing scientific research for the Rand Corporation. There is a lot of hype for what artificial intelligence can do, and we're still living with that legacy, Mr. Klahr said. "Maybe it was naive, but it did set an agenda. And there have already been tremendous by-products of that challenge."
Title: A Split in Thinking Among Keepers of Artificial Intelligence
Other (negative): philosophical conflict within AI field

Paragraph: COMPUTER ETHICS: Cautionary Tales and Ethical Dilemmas in Computing. By Tom Forester and Perry Morrison. (MIT, $19.95.) Because computers have made their way into nearly every corner of our lives, the professionals who design computers may unwittingly possess as much control over our future as elected officials. Yet students preparing for careers in computer and software development often receive little - or no - instruction in the ethical problems they will create. Two Australians, Tom Forester, who teaches at the School of Computing and Information Technology at Griffith University in Queensland, and Perry Morrison, a lecturer in computing at the University of New England in New South Wales, offer a provocative look into the moral issues surrounding the world's most powerful machines. ''We argue,'' they write in ''Computer Ethics,'' ''that computer systems by their very nature are insecure, unreliable and unpredictable - and that society has yet to come to terms with the consequences.'' Computer crime could cost each of the top 300 companies in the United States $2 million to $10 million a year, they write, but only 35 percent of I.B.M. mainframes used security software by late 1988. London's computerized air traffic control system failed six times in 12 months. Perhaps even more frightening is the 10-year delay in warnings about ozone depletion; software employed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration called satellite ozone measurements spurious because they were so low. Mr. Forester and Mr. Morrison have chapters on computer crime, software theft, computer hacking and viruses, computer unreliability, invasion of privacy, artificial intelligence and computers in the work place. While their prose occasionally wanders toward flat assertion, the authors' stated goal is to provoke debate in an area too often dominated by dehumanized logic.
Title: IN SHORT/NONFICTION

I also attempt to interface with Al Gore, but get only a robot response to "Dear Friend": "Although the volume of mail prevents the Vice President from personally reviewing each message, be assured that your concerns, ideas, and suggestions have been read carefully, and a detailed report of the mail is provided to the Vice President on a regular basis."

Paragraph: With little more than a company name, Ms. Handler recruited such diverse talents as physicist Richard Feynman, artificial intelligence guru Marvin Minsky and computer scientist Jack Schwartz.

Paragraph: Dante, which went more than 650 feet down into the crater during its explorations last week, had climbed to within 400 feet of the rim at the time of its mishap. A walking robot built by engineers at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, it was struck once by a falling rock while exploring the crater and survived several near-hits. While attempting to leave the crater last Wednesday, the robot lost power because a generator on the rim above malfunctioned. The machine remained stranded for a day until engineers flew to the rim and repaired the electric generator. Officials had said that the robot did not have to survive for the mission to be successful, but engineers said they preferred to retrieve the machine to study how it weathered the harsh environment in the crater and to help design future robots.
Title: Rescue Bid Planned For Robot
Other (negative): robots break down
Other (positive): researching harsh environments

Paragraph: Dr. Bremermann's interests included artificial intelligence, evolution and the limits of computer calculations. He contributed to many areas of mathematics, constructing models of the interactions of parasite and host and of biological processes in general.
Title: Hans-Joachim Bremermann, 69, Professor

Paragraph: Scientists say a high-flying robot airplane developed for the military could revolutionize research into ozone depletion and other atmospheric problems. But they fear that it may be scrapped before it can ever be used.  20  In Baltimore, the debate over Norplant in the schools goes on.  28  The Government will toughen standards on mortgage race bias.  27  Arizona acted to stem gambling on Indian reservations.25  Metro 37-48  FEARING A WAVE OF ANGER
Title: NEWS SUMMARY

Paragraph: Explorers from Woods Hole are sending a seven-foot-long robot named Jason more than a mile down to the bottom of the Gulf of California, between the Mexican mainland and Baja California, to study hot vents in the ocean floor and associated life forms. Jason works on a long tether tied to a surface ship. Almost instantly, by way of satellite and the computer network known as Internet, its data are flashed around the globe to marine scientists at more than a dozen universities and research institutes. Some 3,000 miles eastward, off Bermuda in the Atlantic, another Woods Hole team this week is inaugurating a new robot known as ABE, for Autonomous Benthic Explorer. Unlike Jason, it has no tether. An advanced computer inside the six-foot vehicle guides it through preprogrammed paces. The device is designed to travel to depths of nearly four miles and to stay there, examining a particular site or region for up to a year. It can be called back to the surface by an acoustic signal from a ship.
Title: Into the Abyss: New Robots Probe the Deep
Other (positive): exploration

Paragraph: On the third day of the eight-day mission, Dr. Ellen Ochoa, an electrical engineer who is the first Hispanic woman to go into space, is to use the shuttle's robot arm to place Spartan into a separate orbit. Two days later, the Discovery's crew plans to rendezvous with Spartan and Dr. Ochoa will try to retrieve it with the arm. Tracking Yearly Variations
Title: Shuttle Launched on the Second Try

Paragraph: In ''The Night Is Large,'' Martin Gardner appears to be on a mission to tell the reader everything he knows, no matter how long it takes. His table of contents resembles a college catalogue, with sections on the physical sciences, the social sciences, mathematics, the arts, philosophy and religion. Miraculously, his ambition does not exceed his erudition; the same reasonable, trustworthy voice examines artificial intelligence and ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland,'' pragmatist philosophy and supply-side economics. Mr. Gardner acts as a journalist of ideas, absorbing the most difficult theories of quantum physics and philosophy and restating them for us in jargon-free language. His essays, collected mainly from Scientific American and The New York Review of Books, exhibit a singular love of discovery; he appears impatient to learn what new truths science may uncover. Mr. Gardner sees the world as a puzzle to be solved, the ultimate brain teaser fabricated by God for our (or His) awe and amusement. So he never shies away from the big questions: Why does the universe exist? Do humans possess free will? Is there a God? These essays serve as his own explorations into the subject matter; he does not set out to convince or cajole. He takes special glee in chiding intellectuals who abandon their common sense. While some essays overlap and some arguments recur, ''The Night Is Large'' captures the joys of being a lifelong student.   Douglas A. Sylva
Title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION

Paragraph: Letterman: A Japanese inventor has developed a robot that can simulate five human facial expressions. Now, I know you are saying to yourself: that's three more than Bob Dole can make.
Title: Word for Word/Late-Night Comics;Joking About Bill, Bob and Hillary With Dave, Jay and Conan

Paragraph: The Kaiko consists of two vehicles. A 17-foot-long launch vehicle descends most of the way to the bottom and acts as an underwater base station. It releases a 10-foot-long roving vehicle that is tied to the launcher by a smaller cable. The rover is equipped with television cameras, a still camera and robot arms to take samples from the ocean floor.
Title: On Pacific's Deep Floor, Japanese Find Fish

Paragraph: Is the digital computer merely a simpler version of the human brain, as many theorists contend? If in fact it is, the implications are scary. For then, as Roger Penrose points out in his profound new book, "Shadows of the Mind: A Search for the Missing Science of Consciousness," "all thinking is computation; in particular, feelings of conscious awareness are evoked merely by the carrying out of appropriate computations." And it is only a matter of time before the fabricators of artificial intelligence will be producing minds that make human beings obsolete.
Title: Can Quantum Mechanics Explain Consciousness?
Other (negative): makes humans obsolete

Paragraph: WASHINGTON                     WHEN the Jetsons, the 21st-century cartoon family, were ready to sit down to dinner, Jane Jetson merely announced her menu to a machine that transformed her instructions into space-age delicacies, which were transported by conveyor belt to the family dining room, where Rosie, the robot maid, served the meal. Mr. Gordon has not yet built a prototype of his invention. But in one respect, he acknowledges, the invention would not be as sophisticated as the Jetsons' meal maker or, for that matter, the "food replicator" featured in episodes of "Star Trek: The Next Generation": an ordinary human would have to measure and add the ingredients before the machine could process them, he said. Nor does the patent cover a conveyor belt or a robot maid.
Title: Patents

Paragraph: PITTSBURGH                     The last few months have been heady ones for William L. Whittaker, the Carnegie-Mellon University professor considered one the nation's foremost robot designers. First came the demonstration for Government officials of the Ambler, Dr. Whittaker's 19-foot tall, six-legged robot designed to explore Mars someday. In a rock garden on the Carnegie-Mellon campus here, Ambler stepped over high boulders and avoided holes, a formidable achievement for a robot. "It was one of those holy moments," said Dr. Whittaker, 42, a former Marine whose friends call him Red. "It was mystical to see the Ambler get up and go. My heart was in my throat." The game has changed radically, said Dr. Whittaker. "The service that a robot can deliver today is vastly superior to what one could do 10 years ago." It is probably too early to say if this latest enthusiasm will be the one that endures, spawning start-up robot companies that thrive and throw off hundreds of millions of dollars in earnings, making robots common in the workplace. Roboticists are incurable optimists, and many obstacles must be surmounted before useful robots are common. The computers that guide Ambler, for example, are still too large to be contained on the robot itself.
Title: The Creature That Lives in Pittsburgh

Paragraph: MODELS OF MY LIFE, by Herbert A. Simon. (Basic Books, $26.95.) The Nobel laureate's autobiography shows his scientific activity -- most notably, his work in artificial intelligence -- as a deeply personal enterprise, a product not of irresistible technology but of the esthetic and self-examination of the researcher himself.
Title: BEST SELLERS: March 24, 1991
Other (positive): AI interest rewarding as self-examination

Paragraph: When Harold Katz, the 76ers' owner, chastised Barkley for his remarks about the Philadelphia franchise, Barkley responded by saying that Katz would "rather me be a robot so I can just play and he'll be able to make money." Paragraph: He said rapidly increasing computer processing power and several decades of experience in artificial intelligence research had made this a good time to pose such a challenge. But at the same time he said that the first round of the Turing Test would not be the open-ended challenge that was originally proposed because it is generally acknowledged that today's computers could never pass such a trial. To be successful, a Turing program must not only understand the structure of the English language, but also grasp subtle differences in meaning and cope with ambiguous questions. The programs will also require what artificial intelligence researchers refer to as a "knowledge base," a complete set of facts that a human would be expected to know. Gaps in Comprehension
Title: No Headline
Other (positive): advances in AI enable Turing test/research

Paragraph: That's precisely the picture the inventors of a robot lawn mower hope to see one day. Thomas H. Noonan and two partners, John Fisher and Barry Bryant, have won a patent for an automatic, self-propelled mower that stores a map of terrain and a cutting route in its microprocessor.

Paragraph: Mr. Gawron, who has a doctorate in something called computational linguistics, has no qualms about supplying, as backdrop for his narrative, a new form of theocracy run by computer scientists, new technologies borrowed from mysterious extraterrestrials, and chapter-heading epigrams from such diverse sages as Marcus Aurelius, Northrop Frye, Benito Mussolini and Bob Dylan. He also supplies a cast of characters whose hang-ups make the legitimately confused Alexa Augustine look almost normal. Not least of the oddities are the AI's, computer-based artificial intelligences who, in more ways than one, are central to the story.

Paragraph: Last year the 150,000 people who traveled there discovered at the end of their journey a rainbow, a 2,000-foot-long rainbow that stretched over Heckscher Pond. Paragraph: For now, though, think of them as A-Life artifacts. A-Life bears the same relationship to biology as artificial intelligence does to intelligence. It is the "science" of artificial life, the attempt to "model" life forms on the computer; M.I.T. Press even publishes a journal, Artificial Life. And while Max  Headroom has yet to emerge from a computer monitor, and while no one could really confuse an artificial life form with its creator, A-Life is rapidly reproducing both on the World Wide Web and off. Games like "Creatures" are joining a genre of biological simulations pioneered by Maxis, like "SimAnt" and  "SimLife."
Title: Technology: CONNECTIONS;'Real, silicon life forms' and a 'science' of artificial life: Orwell is not dead.

Paragraph: Kimberly Shelton Stahlman, the public affairs director for New York's Department of City Planning, and Michael Justin Kearns, a researcher on artificial intelligence at AT&T Labs in Murray Hill, N.J., are to be married today in Healdsburg, Calif. Title: Ms. Stahlman And Mr. Kearns

Paragraph: There have also been utopian fantasies about the powers of technology and science, asserting that human consciousness is about to be transformed just because the Internet allows computers to link to each other at 28,800 baud, or that life as we know it will be altered by advances in artificial intelligence or biotechnology. In a provocative new book, ''The End of Science,'' (Addison-Wesley Publishing) John Horgan, a senior writer for Scientific American, sees science fast approaching its conclusion, with lots of depression along the way. Science is usually portrayed as an infinite path to absolute knowledge in which important work is still continuing apace. The physicist Stephen Hawking and the mathematician Roger Penrose have been on the best-seller lists with their speculations about the cosmos and consciousness; theories of artificial life and artificial intelligence attract new generations of researchers; Darwinism continues to inspire controversy.
Title: Science and scientists are facing some rough going as the millennium approaches.

Paragraph: The Impossible Mission force has the latest technology, like the "686 chip with the artificial intelligence module," but the script lacks a module of intelligence when it comes to the concept of networking.
Title: New Movie Stars Often Surprising

Paragraph: The efforts of artificial intelligence research, which once had the futile hope of creating an artificial brain before the end of the century, may have generated other sorts of peculiar relationships between mind and technology. Instead of making demands on the machine, we now ask the machine to make demands on us, to help us create a new mind, allowing us to become smarter, calmer, more subtle, or, in the words of Brainwave Journey, ''to discover new sources of joy, creativity, energy and healing.'' We command it, plead with it, to help us live up to the dreams we have for machines. Technology may never make artificial intelligence possible in a machine, but in the meantime, we are hoping it can create some in ourselves.
Title: Machines should help people become smarter, calmer, more subtle.
Other (positive): to discover new sources of joy, creativity, energy and healing

Paragraph: ''If your boss, wife or jealous lover shows up unannounced,'' says the instructional materials for Girlfriend Tracy, a cutting-edge, interactive CD-ROM for lonely-heart guys, ''just press the ESCape key. . . . A meaningless but serious-looking spreadsheet will appear on your screen.'' Fine, but if you're reduced to this, you may also want to hide from the smirking gods of love. Tracy's creators stress that unlike all other sex-oriented CD-ROM characters, she operates with powerful artificial intelligence -- enough to mimic ''the response of a human female'' when you write sexy commands. To test this, we created two suitors with very different styles. As our cyberboys learned during a visit to Tracy's swank pad, she can react to different approaches, but whatever happens, her startlingly non sequitur personality creates a truly, er, unique dating experience.
Title: Girlfriend Tracy. Guy Pathetic.
Other (negative): poor substitute for human interaction

Paragraph: The novel is set in a world that resembles Hobbes's state of nature. Mr. Dillon excels at creating two-dimensional bad guys animated by greed and vindictiveness -- apparently a common type among cyber-lowlifes in places like Redmond, Wash., where Microsoft is headquartered. He coins clever names for his characters; the spiritual mentor to the start-up's C.E.O. is called Baba RAM DOS. And he writes clearly about technology. Even those who have only recently upgraded from DOS to Windows 95 should have no trouble understanding the book's gadgetry, which includes a keyboard that combusts in the heat of cybersex and an artificial intelligence program that can order in pizza without being asked to do so.
Title: There's Always a Glitch

Paragraph: To be sure, "Galatea," too, is crammed full with philosophical asides, bad puns ("Rhesus pieces" in reference to slices of simian forebrains) and riffs on everything from artificial intelligence to literary criticism. But the novel's strong, straightforward story line is both an armature for Mr. Powers's fecund talents and a magnet that pulls all his themes together and lends them a focus and direction. As a result, the novel has an urgency that is new to the author's work, an urgency that makes the emotions of this story as compelling as its more cerebral components.
Title: Playing Pygmalion to a Hermeneutic Computer

Paragraph: Mr. Clarke was criticized for grossly underestimating the effort necessary to develop a computer with HAL's ability to converse (and lip-read) by the year 2001. In ''3001'' his attitude to consciousness and artificial intelligence appears to have changed; there are marvels aplenty, but the only real agents seem to be people. Amazingly, even the monoliths are not seen as conscious.

Paragraph: America lost the robot wars for the last few decades, said Daniel S. Goldin, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, in a recent discussion with employees. "You can't go into a modern factory in America today and find a robot manufactured in America." But developers' visions go way beyond farming. Carnegie Mellon researchers are working with engineers from Caterpillar Inc. to develop robot trucks for use in open-pit mining and automated excavators for use at hazardous sites.

Paragraph: Photo: Addressing a news conference yesterday, with a rendering of the Martian surface as their backdrop, were, from left, Dr. Wesley T. Huntress Jr., chief of space science at NASA; Daniel S. Goldin, the agency's Administrator, and Dr. Edward C. Stone, director of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. A13)    Chart: ''How to Visit Mars''    WHEN The robot spacecraft Pathfinder is to touch down on Mars at 1:07 P.M. Eastern time today. Because it will be nighttime at the landing site -- the equivalent of 3 in the morning -- the first pictures from Mars will not be transmitted to Earth until after sunup, four to six hours later. The space agency expects to receive detailed pictures between 7 and 8 P.M.    ON TV CNN and MSNBC plan live coverage of the landing, with progress reports through the day. C-Span will cover the NASA briefings at 6:30 and 9:30 P.M. Eastern time, and the Discovery Channel will carry an hourlong special report at 11 P.M.    ON THE WEB A NASA Web site, http://www/jpl.nasa.gov/mpfmir, offers links to 25 Mars Pathfinder home pages. $(Page A13$)
Title: Spacecraft Lands Today On the Planet of Dreams

Paragraph: Mike Weaver's ''Making Music With Computers'' will show that artificial intelligence isn't tone-deaf. ''He will actually write a song with the kids on his computer,'' said Jack W. Batman, vice president for public relations at Chelsea Piers.
Title: For Children
Other (positive): music creation

Paragraph: Anthony Catania got suspicious when his floor started to shake. For weeks, sewer diggers had been tearing up the street in front of his restaurant-supply store in Seattle. Among the deployed tools was a tunnel-digging robot ''mole,'' a $475,000, 18-foot-long device that can chew through 70 feet of soil a day using programmed directional coordinates. The machine has been doing solid yeoman's work for years, but this time somebody programmed it incorrectly. Catania realized this when he saw 11 hard hats peering expectantly into a 30-foot-deep hole in the street, one muttering, ''Our mole is supposed to come out here but we haven't seen it.'' Eventually recovered without damaging Catania's property, the wayward mole left behind a 700-foot hole that will have to be filled with concrete. Cost: $600,000.
Title: BAAAD MOLE

Paragraph: WASHINGTON—                     WAITING for an elevator may seem like nothing more than a matter of standing in line, but in fact sophisticated computers decide the best way to deploy cars in modern office buildings. New artificial intelligence software patented by the Otis Elevator Company could mean more elevators will zoom past a lone person in favor of a large group waiting on a different floor.
Title: Patents; Computer software from Otis uses fuzzy logic to make elevators smarter and more efficient.
Other (positive): elevators

Paragraph: The Material Recovery Facility -- nicknamed Murf -- celebrated its first birthday recently with an official ceremony to open the new center. County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke and other officials cut the ribbon alongside a robot made of soda cans, a mannequin dressed in newspapers and a dummy promoting recycling. A potpourri of bottles, cans and containers dangled from the ceiling over their heads.
Title: Finding Out What Happens To All That Recycled Material

Paragraph: In my M.I.T. course on computer-based fiction, students create complex but construable journeys through imaginary spaces filled with virtual objects and characters who can converse with the reader. I would argue that the finest literary creation in the computer medium is Joseph Weizenbaum's 1966 experiment in artificial intelligence, the comically obtuse interactive therapist Eliza, whose uncomprehending echoing of patients' remarks brilliantly uses the rigidities of the computer for parodic effect.
Title: Novels for the Computer

Paragraph: Movie Select is a database of information about more than 44,000 videos. It can be browsed in like any other database, but its "artificial intelligence" comes into play when it does the hard work itself. Click on the Movie Select Recommends box and select three of your favorite movies, either from the whole list or from one of 10 categories. I selected "2001: A Space Odyssey," "Airplane" and "Back to the Future." The program then presents a list of movies, 16 in this case, and you highlight those you especially liked. I selected "Star Wars," "The Lion in Winter" and "Dead Poets Society."
Title: For Older Children, Electronic Playthings

Paragraph: They are visions of the future, straight out of a science fiction novel or a  "Twilight Zone" episode. The development of human-level artificial intelligence  leads to enormous leaps in robot evolution, which leads in turn to a "post-human" universe presided over by godlike machines. Advances in virtual-reality technology enable individuals to have cybersex with any man, woman or creature of their choosing, while at the same time allowing them to choose the style, color and material of their own bodies. The implantation of miniaturized computers in the body not only helps to correct physical defects but also enhances human capabilities, resulting in beings who are half human, half machine. The ability to download consciousness into a computer finally frees people from their bodies, signifying the next great leap forward in human  evolution.
Title: Don't Hold Your Breath for Later-Model Humans
Other (positive): Have sex with humans. frees people from their bodies, advance the body's capabilities

Paragraph: The joint resources are there: a combination of CNN's global staff, local affiliates and Atlanta studios and SI's network of journalists who can report and analyze from wherever they are, even from the magazine's Manhattan offices,  where a robot camera will be installed.    CNN and SI Television are being chary with details of their estimated $40 million to $50 million launch plan. From their perspective, it makes sense. They can be in most places quickly, but how many places need they be? Sure, it's great to be live at events like Tommy Morrison's announcement that he has the virus that causes AIDS, but how many of those events are there? How many of them aren't already carried by ESPN, Newsport, CNN or local stations?
Title: Up Next, Swimsuits in the Crossfire

Paragraph: Humankind has a seemingly inexhaustible lust for invention. Ten years ago, it was almost impossible to predict that by 1991, fax machines and portable telephones would be the stuff of everyday life. By 2001, according to a new book, they may be joined by voice-activated microwave ovens, floating furniture, robot bartenders and remote-controlled vacuum cleaners. Dr. Myun W. Lee, a human factors engineer and director of the Research Institute of Engineering Science at Seoul National University in South Korea, is convinced that the world will be a better place because of his mushroom-shaped, remote-control vacuum cleaner, now in production. It works like a toy robot and has a snap-off control box attached to its handle.
Title: Inventors in Search Of New Must-Haves
Other (positive): optimism about AI's future vacuum cleaner

Paragraph: Another such collection distributed by Walnut Creek CD-ROM is "The Scientific and Technical Library CD-ROM, Second Edition," a 240-page paperback with the disk in the back cover. The book contains instructions for installing the programs and a catalogue of them. The programs are divided into the categories of artificial intelligence, astronomy, communications, education, electronics, engineering, graphics, ham radio, mathematics, medicine and health, printing utilities, programming, science, security, special needs, technical drawing, utilities and word processing and text editing. Title: A Bountiful Grab Bag of Programs

Paragraph: The bionic cockroach has arrived, alive, kicking and hissing in the artificial intelligence lab at the University of Michigan. There, Dan Koditschek, an associate professor, and his colleagues have attached wires to the backs of live cockroaches from Madagascar. The wires send electrical current to their legs and antennae, and Koditschek manipulates them by varying the current. So far, he has only rough control over them, but his "science fiction dream" is to master cockroachian derring-do well enough to clone it in teeny robots called Biobots. "A cockroach can carry up to 80 times its own body weight," he says. "Two or three could carry a small package of screws." He has no plans, however, to turn them into carpenters' helpers. On the other hand, speaking of artificial intelligence, why not wire them up and send them undercover? True bugging, you could say.
Title: Sunday May 5, 1996: BUG-EYED;The Bionic Cockroach
Other (positive): control live cockroaches   vague

Paragraph: (1) THE DAY THE EARTH STOOD STILL (1951) (2) IT CAME FROM OUTER SPACE (1953) (3) THE WAR OF THE WORLDS (1953) (4) CLOSE ENCOUNTERS OF THE THIRD KIND (1977) (5) E.T.: THE EXTRATERRESTRIAL (1982) (6) SPECIES (1995) (7) THE ARRIVAL (1996) (8) INDEPENDENCE DAY (1996) SIGNS THE ALIENS MIGHT BE BAD (1) A robot starts vaporizing people, not just rifles and tanks.

Paragraph: IN 1981, Matthew Wyse, then a 42-year-old book dealer, came across a wind-up tin robot from the 1950's at a collectibles show. He was so transfixed by the vivid green and orange toy robot, which looked like a blank-eyed Martian, that he willingly paid $12 for it. ''The price seemed high to me at the time,'' he said. ''So I didn't tell my wife, Karen, what I'd paid for it.'' He quickly discovered that the robot, called the Interplanetary Explorer Spaceman, was worth about $1,000. But recently, Mr. Wyse said, dealers and collectors had identified robots that were made exclusively for the Japanese. The one he acquired was a walking robot with sparkling eyes and a cone-shaped head. He paid only $3,000 for it, in part, because it came without its original box. With the box, as with most such toys, the robot would probably have cost twice as much. The rarest of these toys, Machine Man, first attracted collectors in the late 1980's. Only one was known at the time, but since then several others have come to light, including one Mr. Wyse bought last year. While he refused to say how much he paid for it, he said it was the most expensive robot he had ever bought. Mr. Bergin, who sold it to Mr. Wyse, said he knew of several private sales of robots for more than $20,000 each. Sotheby's expects Mr. Wyse's Machine Man, the first ever auctioned, will bring $30,000 to $50,000.
Title: If Robby the Robot Had Little Brothers . . .
Other (positive): AI in the arts, robot items appeal to collectors

Paragraph: But these are small quibbles to set against considerable achievements. Late  in the novel, Edmund tells Anne the story of Albertus Magnus, who after 30 years of labor succeeds in building a robot, only to have it destroyed by his student  Aquinas. The true miracle of this story is not in the creation of the robot but  in the fact that Albertus forgives Aquinas, "the way you would a lover or a son." And that is what this novel so gracefully offers its characters: forgiveness and a second chance.
Title: Transmutations

Paragraph: Wandering in the Colorado desert, you have stumbled upon the Cyberraptor, a robotic dinosaur that has survived significant electronic misfortune. To get back to the past to rescue him, you must first repair the robot and return to the past to rescue its inventor. This turns out to involve restoring its memory banks by surviving incomprehensible blather about virtual reality and successfully completing a series of tasks.
Title: Pursuing Virtual Dinosaurs, Alive on Your Screen

Its system is intended to replace people who spray potassium permanganate onto jeans, particularly the seat, knee and thigh areas, in a technique known as localized abrasion. Paragraph: Nearer on the horizon, and also promising rewards for business, are expert systems. "The Rise of the Expert Company" ($19.95, Times Books, New York City), by the artificial intelligence experts Edward Feigenbaum, Pamela McCorduck and H. Penny Nii, is subtitled "How Visionary Companies Are Using Artificial Intelligence to Achieve Higher Productivity and Profits." Others, then, can extract the intelligence and apply it to problems that range from product development and administration to manufacturing. A new breed of computer experts called knowledge engineers are creating a form of artificial intelligence known as expert systems. This book first appeared in 1988. But the vision it describes is perhaps more important today. Tom Peters, a management consultant and author, writes in the forward, "Any senior manager in any business of almost any size who isn't at least learning about artificial intelligence, and sticking a tentative toe or two into A.I.'s waters, is simply out of step, dangerously so."
Title: The Executive Computer; Hands Off the Keys, Noses Into Books
Other (positive): manufacturing, administration, product development   interest in AI is vital to business

Paragraph: The winner of the $1,500 first prize was a whimsical program called PC Therapist III, a personal triumph in the unusually complex world of artificial intelligence. It was designed not at the Pentagon, in Silicon Valley or in the intellectual citadels of Cambridge, Mass., but by Mr. Weintraub in Woodside, just 200 yards from an entrance ramp to the Brooklyn- Queens Expressway. Celebrity Blooms Turing's view was simple. If a computer could have a conversation that fooled people into thinking it was a person, then it could probably think -- at least in a conventional way. Last week, 5 of the 10 judges thought PC Therapist III was a person. For home practitioners of artificial intelligence, it was a signal achievement. If it's artificial how good could it be? said the proprietor of Guido's Fine Foods, on Queens Boulevard, when informed that one of his neighbors had created a winning computer program that employed artificial intelligence to think. "We don't sell artificial things if we can help it." At nearby Beer Boys Discount Beverage Center, the manager, Alan Kalfin, was equally surprised, but much more excited by the news. Your basic home machine right now is capable of computations that would have been at the forefront of human knowledge 10 years ago, said Chris Langton, a staff scientist in the complex systems group of the theoretical division at Los Alamos National Laboratory, which has long been a leader in exploring artificial intelligence. "We call it garage band science. Personal computers today are reminiscent of the 60's when high school kids could first afford electric guitars and amplifiers. Within the last five years computers have crossed a threshold so that people can do incredible science at home." Stock Phrases
Title: It's Alive! (But Must Be Plugged In.)
Other (positive): optimism about AI progress

Paragraph: Though she sometimes seems too perfect to be real, particularly when she's humiliating her inferiors on the court with a backhand so precise it could cut diamonds, hers is no artificial intelligence. Hingis is a champion for the 21st century. She simply arrived a little early. And so far, nobody has been able to catch up. Nobody except Steffi Graf, very much a 20th century champion, who accumulated a winning record (5-1) against her before Hingis the early bloomer became Hingis the full bloomer. This year, when Graf has been largely dormant because of knee surgery, only Iva Majoli, who took advantage of Hingis's knee surgery to wear her down in their French Open final, and Lindsay Davenport, who exploited the hint of fatigue in Hingis's game in their Manhattan Beach semifinal in California earlier this month, have made the Swiss sensation appear anything less than invincible.
Title: A Calculated Approach Has Put Hingis on Top

Paragraph: In 1982, when the Kirks bought their ramshackle 1870's Carpenter Gothic house (it has been immortalized in an illustration in "Miss Spider's Wedding"), its $29,000 price was almost beyond their reach. To muster the down payment, Mr. Kirk sold much of his precious collection of vintage mechanical robot toys, gathered since 1960, that were the inspiration for his fanciful world. Violet's father built a niche in her bedroom wall to house a wooden robot toy, which overlooks a flea-market dressing table and cabinet with glass doors.  The table overflowed with Violet's favorite rubber bugs, creepy-looking aliens and gaudy plastic jewelry.
Title: Where Spiders Are Welcome

Paragraph: One of the strengths of science fiction is its ability to put flesh on abstract ideas, to conduct, in the guise of well-made narratives, what Albert Einstein called thought experiments. This is the ostensible purpose of "The Turing Option," a novel by Harry Harrison, one of science fiction's most prolific and accomplished craftsmen, and Marvin Minsky, one of the major contributors to the field known as artificial intelligence (AI for short). One can sympathize with Mr. Minsky's frustration after all those discouraging years on the frontiers of artificial intelligence research. But even in the fictional universe of the "techno-thriller," there is more to creating a believable "thinking machine" than wishing it so. Sven, for example, does Brian's bidding unquestioningly, like an obedient slave; there is no hint that Sven might conceive of goals that conflict with those of its maker. Despite their impressive credentials, the authors utterly fail to explore the fascinating implications of a machine that can think for itself -- which is surely the whole point of Turing's deceptively simple little challenge.
Title: Machine Dream
Other (negative): AI in fiction not exploited to potential

Paragraph: * ''FAST, CHEAP AND OUT OF CONTROL,'' directed by Errol Morris (PG, 82 minutes). Brilliant, ruminative documentaries by the director of ''The Thin Blue Line'' and ''A Brief History of Time'' are always worth waiting for. This time, contemplating the mysterious intersection of nature and human design, he interweaves the work of four inspired eccentrics -- a lion tamer, a topiary gardener, a scientist studying social behavior of the naked mole-rat, and a robot designer -- into a haunting and poetic exploration of creative imagination. Always invigorating, never pedantic or dry, Mr. Morris brings wisdom, wit, quirkiness and a metaphysical overview to this eerily beautiful meditation. At Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village (Maslin).
Title: Movie Guide

Paragraph: ''Interdisciplinary'' is a suspect word -- it is too often the grayspeak of campus grandees -- but artificial intelligence and the theory of evolution do seem to be making an interdisciplinary merger. Steven Pinker, a professor of psychology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is one of the clearest writers about this new synthesis. ''How the Mind Works'' examines brain mechanisms -- or rather, computational models of brain mechanisms -- and the evolution of our reasoning abilities, emotions and social and sexual behavior. The marriage is by no means complete; Pinker exaggerates when he says that ''without the computational theory, it is impossible to make sense of the evolution of the mind.'' I suspect the evolutionary insights in the book would have made good sense to that precomputational Victorian Charles Darwin. However, there is still a strong unity in this book. The computational and evolutionary parts, for instance, both reject the idea that the mind begins life, in Locke's phrase, as a sheet of blank paper. Artificial intelligence is a powerful test; it requires you not merely to talk about how a mental task is accomplished, but to write a program to prove it. If you program a robot as initially blank except for a general learning rule or two (I mean something like the psychologist's ''law of association'': the robot should do more of whatever it has associated with pleasurable, or reinforcing, consequences), it will not develop much of a mind. It fails because the environment contains too many stimuli, and each action has too many possible consequences. Unless the robot has been programmed to recognize which stimuli to concentrate on and how to assess them, it is hopeless at human tasks. Indeed, for many tasks, including walking or holding or reading a newspaper, the robot will be hopeless even if it contains state-of-the-art software. Humans find them easy enough in practice, but the rocket scientists are baffled about how we manage them in theory. As for walking, ''no one has yet figured out how we do it.'' When you hold up your arm, your brain is ''solving a near-intractable physics problem.'' When you use your eyes, you solve ''what engineers call an 'ill-posed problem.' It literally has no solution.'' Pinker adds, ''I believe that the discovery by cognitive science and artificial intelligence of the technical challenges overcome by our mundane mental activity is one of the great revelations of science, an awakening of the imagination comparable to learning that the universe is made up of billions of galaxies or that a drop of pond water teems with microscopic life.'' He concludes that the mind must possess a set of specialized, preprogrammed modules that are quite unlike one another, each designed for a task such as perception or social exchange.
Title: The Brain's Software
Other (positive): provides insight into wonder of the brain

Paragraph: GREENBELT, Md., Jan. 2                     Scientists called off the robot Dante's mission of climbing down into an Antarctic volcano today after a crucial communications cable between the machine and its control station broke. Scientists initially thought the problems they experienced were with a computer at the expedition base station 1.4 miles down the mountain. But today they discovered that the fiber optics communications cable to the robot had had kinks in it as it unreeled and that one of them had resulted in a break. The communications cable, through which the robot received its commands and sent back television images and data, was a crucial component in the mission for which there was no backup, they said. When the robot was under Goddard's control, there was a lag time of 2.5 seconds each way in the communications, similar to the delay in operating a robot on the Moon from the Earth.  NASA had hoped that the Dante expedition would give it experience in operating more advanced robots on the Moon and other planets. Mr. Osborn said the attempt to send the 1,000-pound robot into Mount Erebus was canceled when engineers realized the the glass-fiber communications cable could not be repaired at the site or at the nearby American Antarctic base at McMurdo. Any repair or replacement was at least seven days away, he said, and that was too long because the project had to be off the mountain by mid-January.
Title: Scientists Call Off Robot's Mission Into Volcano
Other (negative): robots break down    technical problems      there was a lag time of 2.5 seconds each way in the communications, similar to the delay in operating a robot on the Moon from the Earth. NASA had hoped that the Dante expedition would give it experience in operating more advanced robots on the Moon and other planets.
Other (positive): robots go where humans can't, AI advances scientific exploration

With a 700-foot 3-day trek, NASA is testing the robot in conditions equivalent to spring on Mars before sending the robot to the red planet. (Associated Press)

Title: Robot Named Dante To Explore Inferno Of Antarctic Volcano

Paragraph: Crosshatched with that comparison is a set of transformations Ms. Turkle traces in attitudes to what are known as boundary questions, the criteria we deploy to distinguish ourselves from the machines we interact with. The alleged  division line once lay in the definition of intelligence, but that indisputable  superiority was subtly eroded by developments in artificial intelligence, both the logic-oriented expert systems or chess-playing variety and the connectionist kind modeled more on the brain's own neural net. We then sought differentiation  in the confident claim that human psyches lie beyond the reach of calculation, but that claim too has been destabilized, both by computer programs that plausibly simulate sympathetic psychotherapists and by reluctant recognition that our character and emotional profiles depend on chemical processes a pill can contain.
Title: Only Connected
Other (positive): eroding people's sense of individualism

Paragraph: Moreover, the religious impulse of technology has caused it to aim at transcending mortal concerns (as in ambitions for space travel or artificial intelligence) rather than at improving the condition of mortal life.

Paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 26                     Researchers placed the Dante II robot atop an Alaskan volcano today, beginning an attempt to send the walking machine into an active crater to see if it can do research in a place too dangerous for humans. Army National Guard pilots used Blackhawk helicopters to hoist the 1,700-pound robot to the crater, 7,575 feet above sea level. Then a crew of four engineers from NASA and the Robotics Institute of Carnegie Mellon University were ferried to the site, where they began hooking the equipment together for the expected five-day experiment on Mount Spurr.
Title: Robot on Mountain For Volcano Descent

Paragraph: What does this mean, that everyone on Usenet will have to meet the standards of this Gulbrandsen guy or he will take it upon himself to cancel their messages? Ms. Siegel asked. "If anything is going to bring down the net, it'll be things like robot cancelers and self-styled censors."
Title: No More 'Anything Goes': Cyberspace Gets Censors

Paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 23                     A gangly eight-legged robot called Dante II is preparing to descend into the dark interior of an active Alaskan volcano in an effort to extend the reach of humans into places too dangerous for them to go. Tethered to the rim of the crater, Dante is to pick its way down the snowy, rock-strewn slopes of an active vent and sample the toxic gases spewing from below. Engineers said it should take about two days for the robot to amble and rappel down to the crater floor, about 600 feet below the rim. Once there, it is to spend a day mapping the crater and measuring the temperature and composition of gases before starting an expected two-day climb out. An earlier version of the robot tried a similar feat a year and a half ago on Mount Erebus in Antarctica, but that mission was cut short after the robot had advanced only 28 feet. A fiber-optic communication cable had broken and could not be repaired. Dangers Limit Scientists The $1.8 million Alaskan mission is sponsored primarily by NASA, which is interested in perfecting remote robot operations for use on the moon and other celestial bodies. In addition, scientists from the Robotics Institute of Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, which designed and built the robot, say such machines acting independently or under human guidance could revolutionize the study of volcanoes, caves, deep ocean chasms or other parts of the earth that are risky for humans to enter.
Title: Robot Set to Explore a Volcano That's Too Dangerous for Humans to Enter
Other (negative): robots break down
Other (positive): does dangerous jobs   robots go where humans can't, AI advances scientific exploration    robots go where humans can't, AI advances scientific exploration

Paragraph: For the actual filming, each full-size dinosaur robot was controlled by up to 20 puppeteers, every one of whom was assigned to a part of a four-foot mechanism called a waldo. The waldo doesn't look like a dinosaur, but each of its moving parts corresponds to those of the dinosaur robot -- the neck, the tail, the legs and so on. By manipulating the waldo, the puppeteers control the full-size robot. Electronic signals from the waldo travel along wires to motors concealed inside the dinosaur. The motors involved are powerful, and the lashing tail of a 20-foot-tall tyrannosaur was so dangerous that the area around it had to be marked off with flashing red lights.
Title: Visiting 'Jurassic Park' For Real

Paragraph: ONE of the most impressive of these creatures is a humanoid developed and built by Honda during the last 10 years. Paragraph: I normally start my graduate class in artificial intelligence, or A.I., with a quote from a National Aeronautics and Space Administration report supporting manned space exploration: ''Man is the lowest cost, 150-pound, nonlinear, all-purpose computer system that can be mass produced by unskilled labor.'' I use this to emphasize that we should study A.I. technology and its potential benefits without complicating it with philosophical issues (''Can machines think?''), a nonproductive exercise. Instead, we must remain alert to the consequences of our designs.
Title: Is That Machine After Your Job?; Measure of Man
Other (positive): jobs not necessarily threatened because human labor cheaper

Paragraph: The connection between humans and machines stimulates endless speculation. People anthropomorphize inanimate objects, naming cars and nursing viral computers. Paragraph: Michael Crichton meets Carlos Castaneda meets Danielle Steel in this cheesy New Age thriller-cum-bodice-ripper set in Santa Fe, N. M. The period is vaguely futuristic, yet the plot of Jack Butler's ''Dreamer'' is strictly yesteryear. In the opening pages, a covert Government agent remarks to his talking computer: ''You know that I think artificial intelligence is the key to winning the wars of the future. The key to colonizing the planets. The key to everything.'' The missing ingredient in creating a ''truly conscious computer,'' the agent believes, can be found in the human ability to dream. Closest to making a key discovery in this field is a brilliant young scientist, Jody Nightwood, director of a sleep clinic and a subject of her own research into dreaming. A red-haired shaman-in-training, Jody theorizes that the dream experience is real, occurring in a dimension that can be charted, quantified and simulated. The covert agent and his archrival both attempt to infiltrate her life and steal her findings. Awake, Jody is romanced by a tall, shadowy figure named -- you guessed it -- Shade. Asleep, she romps with a dream lover called Ish. While ''Dreamer'' barely delves into actual theories of sleep science, it provides proof of one phenomenon: in general, dreams are fascinating only to the dreamer.   Bill Hayes
Title: Books in Brief: Fiction
Other (positive): AI can win wars, AI can colonize planets

Paragraph: Deep Space 1, a 1,000-pound craft crammed with miniature instruments and devices, is to test 12 innovative technologies in its first few months in space. Among the technologies aboard are an autonomous navigation system; a miniature integrated camera and imaging spectrometer; an integrated suite of space physics instruments for studying charged particles, or plasma, flowing through space; advanced software with artificial intelligence that lets the spacecraft help run its own mission as situations change, and a variety of new, low-power electronics.
Title: Ion Propulsion of Science Fiction Comes to Life on New Spacecraft

Paragraph: Why? Because the main reason so many people have lost jobs, been forced to change jobs, or been able to upgrade their jobs in the last tumultuous decade is not a lowering of U.S. trade barriers. It's technology. A Mexican working at 75 cents an hour didn't take the job of our office receptionist; a microchip did -- the one that operates the voice mail device in all our office phones. A Chinese making 75 cents an hour didn't take that auto worker's job; a robot did. A Brazilian making 75 cents an hour didn't take your neighbor's grocery job; a supermarket scanner did.
Title: Foreign Affairs; Down With Chips!

Paragraph: Last month when Dante II, the 1,700-pound robot built by engineers at Carnegie Mellon University, misstepped, tumbled and couldn't right itself while returning from exploring the crater of an Alaskan volcano, it provided a fitting metaphor for both the progress and the limits of the three-decade-old science of artificial intelligence. In "Brainmakers: How Scientists Are Moving Beyond Computers to Create a Rival to the Human Brain," a Boston-based science writer, David Freedman, sets out to survey the current state of the art of artificial intelligence. His premise is that the original artificial intelligence researchers, traditionalists as he refers to them, failed because their attempts to codify a logic representing human thought proved bankrupt. Elaborate models written in computer languages such as Lisp and Prolog were incapable of emulating the simplest kinds of human behavior. Mr. Freedman then charts the outlines of a new movement that has emerged to carry the search for artificial intelligence forward by drawing on the biological underpinnings of human intelligence. It is a seductive idea: a new artificial intelligence revolution can be achieved by copying the simplest biological processes and enhancing those processes with immensely powerful supercomputers and arrays of neural circuits made in the laboratory. Indeed, even while Mr. Freedman draws disparaging portraits of such pioneers in artificial intelligence as Marvin Minsky and Seymour Papert, computer scientists at M.I.T., and John McCarthy of Stanford (who is described as looking and acting like a homeless person), his more affectionate portraits of the younger artificial life wizards contain enough ominous signs to warn the reader that this new generation is no closer to the holy grail of a self-conscious machine. But in a brief conclusion Mr. Freedman writes, "The nature-based A.I. movement seems exceptionally well positioned to succeed." Yet in the following paragraph he admits, "On the other hand, conventional A.I. also got off to a breathtaking start . . . It wasn't for nearly two decades that the endeavor began to lose momentum." Mr. Freedman has provided a quick travelogue that offers a glimpse of the work of some leading researchers in artificial intelligence. Ultimately, however, the reader is left wondering why he made the journey.
Title: Making Electronics Mimic Biology
Other (positive): robotics           AI Spring or renaissance in AI

Paragraph: The capabilities that will drive the new computer industry? Such computing devices would have enough machine intelligence to take simple orders, learn the habits of their users well enough to anticipate their commands -- and even help to figure out their future computing needs.

So far, the robot appeared undamaged by the dangerous conditions inside the crater, although engineers controlling Dante said that for the third day, large rocks had tumbled past it, coming within 15 feet. Paragraph: The diving robots, which look something like delivery vans outfitted with titanium claws, can perform all sorts of deep-water maintenance and repair feats, like drilling, cutting and bolting. They can even replace the 90-pound gaskets in blowout preventers that keep wells from spewing oil or natural gas. A robot can do the repair job, which might take a human crew two days, in two hours. Winding and unwinding a tether thousands of feet long, and keeping a bobbing ship or oil platform from jerking the robot around, requires a huge spool or drum that is lowered into the water with the robot. The equipment on the surface includes a crane and winch for lowering and raising the robot and tether spool. A Containerized Workshop Robots are also starting to have a lighter touch. Most of their arms, lacking tactile sense, cannot be trusted with delicate equipment. To turn a valve off without snapping it, the operator has to anticipate the action and program the robot for just enough, but not too much, force.
Title: Superhuman Feats From a Subhuman Diver

Paragraph: After digressions into social commentary and Christian imagery, his message is back to where it was when he made his first album, "For You," in 1978. Researchers expect to let Dante descend up to 200 feet into the crater if it is set up early enough in the day. Paragraph: Dr. Hurd went on to help develop several other I.B.M. computers and served as a consultant to the company for years after leaving in 1962 to become chairman of the board of the Computer Usage Company, the first independent computer software company. He was later appointed chairman of the Picodyne Corporation, which specialized in educational software, and in 1984 he co-founded Quintus Computer Systems, which was devoted to the commercialization of artificial intelligence. Paragraph: In his review of three books on artificial intelligence and machine consciousness (Jan. 3), Colin McGinn is correct to gently chastise certain people for being overly optimistic about the vision of a robotic future. Some advocates of artificial intelligence trumpet the fact that a computer beat Gary Kasparov in chess, signaling a triumph of sorts. I think it says more about the limitations of chess than it does about the success of computers. Yes, computers are practically infallible for high-level, algorithmic work. But everyone knew that already. Can a robot skate? Read a book? Tie shoes? Or know that it is doing any of these things? Robots will never be able to do an infinite number of even the most mundane human tasks. It may be true that the distance between humans and computers is closing, but it's because humans are becoming more robotlike and not the other way around.
Title: Machine Dreams
Other (negative): AI unable to recreate actual human abilities AI is incapable of basic human tasks

Paragraph: Under the agreement, the International Business Machines Corporation's North American technology consulting and services group in Dallas will sell and service a system that combines E-Systems' Emass storage device with I.B.M.'s high-performance RISC System/6000 work station. It would store up to 10,000 trillion bytes of data -- or about five trillion pages -- and use a robot to file and retrieve the data cartridges. The system will sell for a base price of $1.5 million -- about half the cost of a basic supercomputer -- and will be available in several months.
Title: I.B.M. AND E-SYSTEMS TEAM UP ON MASS DATA STORAGE

Paragraph: But Mr. Papert has a vision. Title: Books of The Times; Learning Better How to Link Up Computers and Education

Paragraph: Dr. Dreyfus first drew attention for his views in 1972 with the publication of a defiant book titled ''What Computers Can't Do'' (Harper & Row). It challenged the assumptions of the nascent field of artificial intelligence, saying it was theoretically impossible to build truly intelligent computers. Dr. Dreyfus holds firm to his view. ''Computers have been getting faster and faster at an amazing rate,'' he said, ''but as I predicted, they are not getting more intelligent.'' Most recently, Dr. Dreyfus has criticized Cog, a humanoid robot built by artificial intelligence researchers at M.I.T. ''All I can say for now is that I am ready to go out on a limb and predict Cog won't learn a thing,'' Dr. Dreyfus said. He is joined in his skepticism of artificial intelligence by Dr. Weizenbaum, an M.I.T. computer scientist who is known for having written a program more than 30 years ago called Eliza, which imitated a Rogerian psychologist. His intention in writing Eliza, he wrote later, was not to prove that a computer could understand natural language but to demonstrate that language is understood only in contextual frameworks.
Title: Between Tech Fans And Naysayers, Scholarly Skeptics
Other (negative): won't learn inherent limitations of AI   inherent limitations of AI

Paragraph: Aibo (pronounced eye-BO) is Sony's answer to the 20th-century quest for a relatively intelligent robot that gets around on its own. (Its name is also a quasi-acronym that stands for artificial intelligence robot.) Over the years some companies have actually tried to sell what they call robots, like the remote-controlled Omnibot sold by the Tomy toy manufacturer in the late 1980's. But none have succeeded in producing a usable robot or capturing the consumer's attention. Sony is betting that Aibo will break that cycle, and a few other companies are taking the same gamble this year. Eureka has been showcasing a new robot vacuum cleaner at housewares shows. A few companies are promising to unveil robotic lawn mowers within months. And a wheeled robot called Cye is starting to generate interest among robot enthusiasts after appearing last fall in a Web-based catalog called the Mondo-tronics Robot Store. ''I've painfully watched the slow evolution of robot technology,'' said Mr. Branwyn, who has written several articles on robotics, ''and there still is not a robot that can really clean up the house.''
Title: A Smart Dog With Megabytes

Paragraph: The ship, the Royal Majesty, en route to Boston from Bermuda, went aground on June 10 with 1,509 people on board. The crew thought its autopilot was using the Global Positioning System, a highly accurate technology for determining position using satellite signals. But a cable running to the Global Positioning System antenna on the ship had become disconnected, and the robot reverted to using an on-board system, dead reckoning, which calculates position by keeping track of the ship's speed and heading.

Paragraph: These are thrilling times in the world of robotics and artificial intelligence. Particularly in Japan, which is a leader in the field, robots are stepping creakily into the mainstream. Sony has just unveiled a robot pet dog, Aibo, which sells for $2,500 and comes preprogrammed with six ''emotions'': happiness, sadness, anger, surprise, fear and dislike. And another Japanese electronics giant, Matsushita, has developed a prototype of a $450 robotic cat aimed at keeping elderly widows company. ''Good morning!'' the cat says cheerily each morning as it boots up, and it responds with brief conversation when it is petted or spoken to. When connected to a cell phone, the robot downloads news from the Web and records phone messages.

Paragraph: Grace ponders the mysteries revealed in the Encyclopedia of the Unexplained (a gift from her mother) and sees herself as a detective, keeping lists of words and facts in her notebook. ''I had an idea that someday someone would come to me with a mystery and I would open up the notebook and all the clues would already be there.'' Ordinary communications are fringed with codes, signs, questions and disguises. Grace's eccentric baby sitter, a 16-year-old genius named Edgar, suggests that ''everyone around you might be an ingenious robot and you're the only one that's not.'' Uncle Pete, her father's twin brother, plays Mr. Science on a television show for children. When he runs off with one of the show's writers, Grace's father easily steps into the role, playing his brother playing Mr. Science. Anna is fluent in Annic, her own secret language, invented by her father.

Paragraph: Mr. Pajitnov's approach to computer games is certainly not accidental. By the time he was 14, Mr. Pajitnov, whose mother was a journalist and whose father was a philosopher, writer and political dissident, had fallen into the mind-whirling embrace of advanced mathematics and strategy games. The former he studied hard; the latter he explored gleefully. He earned a master's of science degree in applied mathematics from the Moscow Institute of Aviation and did postgraduate work at the Academy of Science Computer Center in Moscow. All the while he continued to play games, even designing some to test the computers at the center, where he also worked as a programmer in speech recognition, artificial intelligence and computer-assisted design.
Title: Creator of Tetris Looks for New Ways to Dazzle and Beguile

Paragraph: Once the territory of large corporations, research laboratories and the military, advanced artificial intelligence research is now increasingly driven by the consumer electronics and entertainment industries. The push to commercialization of artificial intelligence is just being renewed after numerous disappointments during the 1980's. Today a growing number of researchers and entrepreneurs believes that the explosion of the Internet is paving the way for new artificial intelligence applications. Discussions at the conference  highlighted the fundamental shift that has occurred in the financing of artificial intelligence research. ''What is driving artificial intelligence now is the entertainment industry instead of the defense industry," said Danny Hillis, a vice president and research fellow at the Walt Disney Company. Mr. Hillis, a computer scientist who founded the supercomputer maker Thinking Machines Corporation, said that the shift had led to a sometimes rough cultural adjustment for computer researchers. However, the technology shift in the artificial intelligence field parallels a similar transformation in other areas of the computer industry, where increasingly powerful computing technologies are showing up first in consumer applications. Despite such advances, many computer researchers remain skeptical about the ability of artificial intelligence research to match human reasoning capabilities any time soon. He said that most artificial intelligence programs fall into two broad categories: programs that follow simple if-then-else rules and other programs that try to mystify their activities, but which are also essentially trivial in their capabilities. Ms. Hayes-Roth, who was an artificial intelligence researcher at Stanford University before leaving to found Extempo last year, said that her company's characters functioned much like improvisational actors.
Title: Intelligent Software Finding Niche
Other (negative): inherent limitations of AI
Other (positive): science and technology development support AI

Paragraph: In the movie ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' the director, Stanley Kubrick, made a computer the most human character. Part Aristotle, part English butler, and, in the end, all Captain Queeg, the HAL 9000 computer stood out from his monotonic human counterparts, fascinating not only computer-illiterate filmgoers but also scientists trying to develop artificial intelligence. It is little wonder, then, that admirers of ''2001'' consider yesterday, Jan. 12, 1997, to be important. In the novel ''2001,'' it is the date the science fiction writer Arthur C. Clarke assigns as HAL's birthday, the day it became operational, and admirers of the film take it as a convenient point for measuring hope and dread -- hope that continuing progress in artificial intelligence will lead to vastly more useful computers and dread that someday those computers will do something horrifyingly wrong. How much longer should it take before a computer captains a ship to a distant planet, while winning at chess and bantering with its crew? As any computer researcher will confess, a long time. Before scientists can develop artificial intelligence, they must understand the human variety more fully. The mistake that the first researchers in artificial intelligence made was to underestimate the power of the human brain. ''The writers of '2001' made the same mistake that artificial intelligence researchers made about intelligent machines -- a mistake that dates from the very beginning'' of research on artificial intelligence, wrote Roger C. Schank, a Northwestern University computer scientist, in his essay in Dr. Stork's anthology, ''I'm Sorry, Dave, I'm Afraid I Can't Do That.''
Title: No HAL Yet: Artificial Intelligence Visions Underestimated the Mind

Paragraph: Here is a rundown of some ways real technological advances since 1968 stack up against the predictions of ''2001,'' along with a more searching look at the problems of artificial intelligence.
