Paragraph: Even before the world chess champion Garry Kasparov faced the computer Deep Blue yesterday, pundits were calling the rematch another milestone in the inexorable advance of artificial intelligence, the effort to create machines that mimic human thought. Computers will soon become ''smarter than us,'' the supercomputer designer Danny Hillis asserted in a Newsweek essay. Actually the contest, whatever its outcome, only underscores what a flop artificial intelligence has been, especially relative to its founders' goals. The naivete of Marvin Minsky of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and other pioneers in the field is legendary. In 1966 Professor Minsky gave an undergraduate, Gerald Sussman, the task of building an object-recognition device out of a computer and a television. Object recognition is what you do when you're having lunch with a prospective employer and you suddenly realize that the person at the next table with his back to you is your current employer. Bald spot, blazer, jowls. Yup, it's him. Sure, some programs can ''hear'' a limited number of words. Banks use neural networks to weigh the merits of loan applications. The immigration service plans to test face-recognition software at borders. But these achievements are paltry compared with the dreams of artificial intelligence enthusiasts.
Title: Smarter Than Us? Who's Us?
Other (positive): AI is progressing

Paragraph: It would seem likely that Deep Blue's inventors would be touting their brainchild as a landmark in artificial intelligence, and that Mr. Kasparov would be dismissing Deep Blue as a mere automaton, triumphing when it does mostly because of an inhuman ability to consider 200 million chess positions in the time it takes to furrow an eyebrow. Its ability to do that has enabled it to hold its own against Mr. Kasparov, and after four games they are deadlocked. Each has won once and two games were drawn. The last two games are tomorrow and Sunday.
Title: Ghost in the Chess Machine: A Brain, or Just a Black Box?

Paragraph: Like most Americans I was mesmerized by the sight of the small toylike robot Pathfinder on Mars, going about its business as the eyes of man on Earth. I was moved by the obvious, almost childlike joy on the faces of Pathfinder's handlers. After all, the robot was their toy. They were telling the gadget what to do, where to go. I am quite certain that it was also the object of their individual imaginations. When the robot would stub its toe, the boylike handlers would leap to their feet to proclaim, ''Don't blame the robot -- it was our fault!'' I had quite a collection, which was kept in a shoe box. They were perfectly wonderful vehicles for a young boy's imagination, not unlike the robot in its effect on its handlers. I played with my toy soldiers for hours on end. They would in time show wear and tear. I had momentous battles between the soldiers that had their heads broken off and those that were intact. My side always won.
Title: Metropolitan Diary
Other (positive): exploration, research

Paragraph: * ''FAST, CHEAP AND OUT OF CONTROL,'' directed by Errol Morris (PG, 82 minutes). Brilliant, ruminative documentaries by the director of ''The Thin Blue Line'' and ''A Brief History of Time'' are always worth waiting for. This time, contemplating the mysterious intersection of nature and human design, he interweaves the work of four inspired eccentrics -- a lion tamer, a topiary gardener, a scientist studying social behavior of the naked mole-rat, and a robot designer -- into a haunting and poetic exploration of creative imagination. Always invigorating, never pedantic or dry, Mr. Morris brings wisdom, wit, quirkiness and a metaphysical overview to this eerily beautiful meditation. At the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village (Maslin).
Title: Movie Guide

Paragraph: James Trefil poses a somewhat chilling question: ''Could a computer paint the equivalent of the 'Mona Lisa,' write the equivalent of 'Hamlet' or produce the equivalent of quantum mechanics or the theory of relativity?'' Mr. Trefil, who teaches physics at George Mason University, methodically attempts in ''Are We Unique?'' to prove that the boundaries separating humankind from animals and machines are fundamentally inviolable. He uses cogent examples from evolutionary biology, psychology, computer science, philosophy and the new science of complexity to illustrate his arguments, and he personalizes abstract scientific concepts with deft analogies and anecdotes, like his account of how he courted his wife: ''We were in a restaurant in Chicago, and when I looked at her across the table I knew, with more certainty than I've ever known anything in physics or mathematics, that I was in love with this woman.'' Proponents of artificial intelligence, he continues, ''are going to have to work very hard to convince me that an algorithm running on a Turing machine is ever going to know anything in quite that way.'' Although Mr. Trefil makes a solid scientific case for humanity's uniqueness, it is his insightful, witty, informal -- in a word, human -- style that convinces the reader that no machine could ever succeed in replacing such an author or in duplicating such a book.   Jacqueline Boone
Title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
Other (negative): AI is not dangerous but merely incapable of replicating human experience

Paragraph: The comforting thing about computers is how dumb they often are. When anything goes wrong with today's computers, they either grind to a halt or spew out nonsense. The human brain is far more resourceful, flexible, adaptable. The truth is, the whole decades-long effort to develop ''artificial intelligence'' has been a crashing disappointment, as even its boosters acknowledge.
Title: Mind Over Matter

Paragraph: NEW HAVEN—                     Last year, after Garry Kasparov's chess victory over the I.B.M. computer Deep Blue, I told the students in my Introduction to Artificial Intelligence class that it would be many years before computers could challenge the best humans. Now that I and many others have been proved wrong, a lot of people have been rushing to assure us that Deep Blue is not actually intelligent and that this victory has no bearing on the future of artificial intelligence. Although I agree that the computer is not very intelligent, to say that it shows no intelligence at all demonstrates a basic misunderstanding of what it does and of the goals and methods of artificial intelligence research. Of course, this advance in artificial intelligence does not indicate that any Grand Unified Theory of Thought is on the horizon. As the field has matured, it has focused more and more on incremental progress, while worrying less and less about some magic solution to all the problems of intelligence. There are fascinating questions about why we are unaware of so much that goes on in our brains, and why our awareness is the way it is. But we can answer a lot of questions about thinking before we need to answer questions about awareness.
Title: Yes, Computers Can Think
Other (positive): Ability to play chess chess AI is progressing    AI can help us learn about human brain function

Paragraph: In your May 10 editorial ''Mind Over Matter,'' the statement that the decades-long research in artificial intelligence has been a ''crashing disappointment'' panders to the popular myth that the main goal of artificial intelligence is to replicate human intelligence. With computers becoming ever more powerful, the field of research called artificial intelligence is even more of an intellectual imperative. It's important to know to what extent tasks such as, say, the diagnosis of a suspicious-looking mass in a mammogram as potentially cancerous can be computerized.
Title: Artificial Intelligence

Paragraph: Some forms of information must be pushed, and the intelligence of the pushing can only improve. E-mail is pushed, of course. You might want to let weather forecasts and stock prices flow into small windows on your screen, especially if you are the kind of person who leaves the Weather Channel on in the background or stares at the stock ticker through a brokerage storefront window. News bulletins can be pushed, but if you have ever tried subscribing to a service that clips and filters news to your particular taste, you know that the necessary forms of artificial intelligence do not exist. Do you want news about the Internet or the Clintons or the trade deficit? You are certain to be either overwhelmed or underwhelmed by the mass of material that will be pushed your way.
Title: Pushy, Pushy

Paragraph: Still, Ginsberg believes that success in computer bridge playing, as in so much of artificial intelligence, will come from giving up on trying to imitate humans. We're different. ''We are massively parallel hardware operating on millisecond time scales,'' he says. ''Computers are serial hardware operating on picosecond time scales.'' Let them do what they do best -- in this case, deal and analyze random hands by the millions -- and they may even have contributions to make to the language-building process that is modern bidding theory.
Title: Bidding Wars

Paragraph: Instead of a windswept planet of dust storms and pink skies observed by Viking spacecraft from orbit and on the surface in the 1970's, the robot visitors will find an even colder Mars with a dark blue sky full of white clouds of water ice, scientists said. Paragraph: Dr. Vaughan sets about to prove her contention by describing a series of case histories and using them to illustrate recent findings about the brain from several disciplines. And when they fail to work for us, by producing depression and anxiety, they can be altered through the intervention of psychotherapy. Why it takes so long can be seen from artificial intelligence's new understanding of pattern recognition. Paragraph: LAUREL, Md., May 5                     The formal talks at the meeting were all about planned and proposed spacecraft missions throughout the solar system: stunning descriptions of balloons deployed in the atmosphere of Venus to sample its acrid air or robot vehicles plumbing the moons of Jupiter or blasting holes in asteroids. Most of those attending the conference agreed that flying more budget planetary missions and fewer billion-dollar larger ones had become the norm. There remains a need for some larger, more comprehensive robot craft, like the Galileo probe that has spent years exploring Jupiter and its moons. But teasing out details about numerous planets, moons, asteroids, comets and other bodies requires flying many more missions more often than in the past.
Title: Debating the Real Price of Space Bargains

Paragraph: But these impressions of shared exploration are misleading. When I checked with the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, and with Ballard, they confirmed that Pellegrino was on neither the 1985 expedition, when the Titanic was discovered not by a robot but by a towed imaging sled, nor on Ballard's follow-up trip to the Titanic in 1986. The expedition Ballard allowed Pellegrino to join, at Pellegrino's request, was a trip in the Pacific that was unrelated to the Titanic. In 1996 Pellegrino went to the Titanic site on an expedition, not connected with Ballard, run by a salvage organization called RMS Titanic. (On that expedition's arrival at the surface above the ship, Pellegrino writes: ''Moth to the flame. That's what you can call me. How else did I get here -- again?'' When I first read that I assumed, as most readers will, that he's referring back to a previous Ballard expedition. Only a second reading allows another interpretation: he may be suggesting that his previous life ended in the disaster.)
Title: At Sea With a Sunken Ship

Paragraph: The most talked-about piece of art in this three-part exhibition, which is also on view at the Asia Society and the Grey Art Gallery in Manhattan, is a 21-foot-long, yellow nylon inflated-balloon robot from a piece called ''About Being Irritated: Death of the Robot.'' Who is talking about it so much? Children. The robot is by Choi Jeong-Hwa, an artist based in Seoul, South Korea, who uses a spectrum of media in his work, from plastic molded animals to food. The robot doesn't eat but it does move, which is what makes it so appealing. But it doesn't move far. This inflated fellow lies on its back and tries to rise by pushing itself up with one hand. Its symbolic meaning involves issues -- Korea's political and social problems -- that children don't need to understand to enjoy the piece. The robot continuously tries to rise, as if doing a sit-up, but always fails.
Title: For Children

Paragraph: To operate in such a harsh environment, the robot explorer would not only have to be rugged, but also smart enough to fend for itself without immediate human direction if it ran into the unexpected. Naturally, the place to test such robots would be Antarctica itself. And scientists and engineers from many disciplines have begun thinking about new ways to bring robots and Antarctica together. Under the proposals, Antarctica would serve simultaneously as the subject of robotic exploration and as a place to test robot technology that could operate on the Moon and beyond. Engineers envision a wheeled robot powered by an internal combustion engine that would slowly move an array of sensors in a detailed search pattern across the ice. The eyes of the robot would be high-resolution color cameras, perhaps with an infrared ability for seeing in the dark, that allow operators to move sensors close to objects of interest. Instruments would include a metal detector, a magnetometer for  detecting the magnetic properties of metal-bearing rock and a spectrometer for examining the chemical composition of samples.
Title: Hardier Breed of Antarctic and Lunar Explorers: Robots
Other (positive): robots go where humans can't, AI advances scientific exploration Robots/AI for exploration  robots go where humans can't, AI advances scientific exploration Robots for exploration

Paragraph: Two decades ago, the idea of personal computers appealed to only a relative handful of hobbyists. Today, PC's are a multibillion-dollar industry. If the dreams of some robot developers come true, recent advances in computer science, artificial intelligence and engineering, coupled with a growing consumer acceptance of electronic gizmos, may soon converge to create a personal robotics industry. ''It's kind of like where computers were 20 years ago,'' said Gregory Dudek, an assistant professor of computer science at McGill University in Montreal. ''Today's robots are weird, kludgy things. But then, 20 years ago people bought computers that were also awkward to use. That's the sort of change we're looking for in the robot industry. I don't think it will happen in the next two years, but in the next 5 or 10 years, certainly.'' With whirring motors, flashing lights and occasional beeps, small mobile robots are beginning to show up in schools, toy stores, gift catalogues and even a growing number of robot specialty shops. ''Business has tripled in the last two years,'' said Mary Neitzel, manager of Mondo-tronics, a robotics company based in San Rafael, Calif. The company sponsors a series of popular robot exhibitions on the West Coast and has a Web site at www.robotstore.com. It used to sell expensive items like a solar-powered robot lawn mower -- the first order came from Lichtenstein, of all places -- but now Mondo-tronics sells only robot construction kits.
Title: And Now, R2D2 for You, Too
Other (positive): Advances in AI may create new robotics industry  personal robotics

Paragraph: Meeting Cog for the first time can be an unsettling experience. Cog, the creation of Rodney Brooks, the director of the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is a legless, human-shaped robot that looks like an ungainly ancestor of C3PO. Despite the fact that he directs the world's largest artificial intelligence laboratory, Dr. Brooks is something of a maverick in the field. ''Most of my colleagues here in the lab do very different things and have only contempt for my work,'' he said cheerfully. The majority of artificial intelligence researchers pursue an approach that Dr. Brooks calls, Good Old-Fashioned Artificial Intelligence, or Gofai. According to this approach, the best way to make a computer that is as intelligent as a human is to cram it full of knowledge about the real world and methods to manipulate it. The schism in the artificial intelligence field represented by these two  approaches to building intelligent machines in some ways mirrors the split among educators. Traditional educators, like Dr. Lenat, believe ''that intelligence is intimately tied up with having and being able to use knowledge.'' Dr. Brooks's approach is closer to that of educators like John Dewey, who urged ''a philosophy of education based upon a philosophy of experience.'' As Dr. Lenat puts it, ''We represent the 'it's worth it to go to school' point of view, and  he represents the 'you can learn stuff on your own' point of view.''
Title: A Man, a Plan and a Robot That Makes Eye Contact
Other (negative): philosophical conflict within AI field
Other (positive): Meeting Cog for the first time can be an unsettling experience. Cog, the creation of Rodney Brooks, the director of the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is a legless, human-shaped robot that looks like an ungainly ancestor of C3PO.

Paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 26                     After nine months of cruising through space testing new technology for future missions, a robot spacecraft with a mind of its own is closing in for a very close encounter with a small asteroid. Among the technologies aboard is an autonomous navigation system that lets the spacecraft guide itself, a miniature integrated camera and imaging spectrometer for determining the composition of distant objects, a combination ion and electron spectrometer, advanced software with artificial intelligence that lets the spacecraft manage its own mission as situations change, a new type of solar-power array and a variety of diverse, low-power electronics. One of the last technologies to be tested was artificial intelligence software called Remote Agent, which completed its validation last month by independently operating parts of the spacecraft, and diagnosing and correcting a series of simulated problems, with minimum direction from ground controllers.
Title: Robot Craft To Cozy Up To Asteroid For Study
Other (positive): research   AI in space probe operate spacecraft AI aids in space exploration AI aids in space exploration operate spacecraft

Paragraph: In an effort to fuse entertainment, education and artificial intelligence, a company in Newton, Mass., is starting a Web site of interactive cartoon characters imbued with behavior that mimics human emotion. Zoesis was founded in 1996 by Joseph Bates, a Carnegie Mellon University computer scientist who develops interactive dramas, an area of artificial intelligence research that tries to create fantasy worlds and characters with whom humans can interact. Known as the Oz Project, the research tried to use artificial intelligence techniques to create a new medium by blending characters, presentation and drama. Barbara Hayes-Roth, a Stanford artificial intelligence researcher, has also founded a company, Extempo Systems Inc., to develop interactive software agents. Extempo has developed its agents for Internet customer service applications, in which, for instance, a character might answer questions from computer users.

Paragraph: The simultaneous rise of computer science led to theories of artificial intelligence and computer models of how the mind works, often developed at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, down the hall from Chomsky in the legendary Building 20, a ramshackle wooden structure built originally for the development of radar in World War II. These models of intelligence shared with Chomsky's models of language the use of systems of mathematical rules (symbolic systems) to account for human thought. Behaviorism, which eschewed rules and symbols in favor of simple association, appeared to be dead as a theory of the human mind.
Title: Washington Sleeped Here

Paragraph: But another goal in artificial intelligence research has proved more elusive. For more than 25 years, experts in artificial intelligence in the United States and Western Europe have tried to figure out how to teach computers to think as lawyers do. But those who work in artificial intelligence say that to the extent that law relies upon tightly woven arguments, supporting precedent and well-defined rules, it can be a perfect template for artificial intelligence. That is because the fields best suited for artificial intelligence are the highly mathematical ones that have ''very little subjectivity in them, like chess,'' said Edwina L. Rissland, professor of computer science at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst and president of the International Association for Artificial Intelligence and the Law. The fields that lend themselves least to artificial intelligence, she added, are those ''in which it's very hard to pin down the meanings of the words.'' Professor Rissland said that research into the use of artificial intelligence in legal contexts had divided into two general categories. But even artificial intelligence experts acknowledge its inherent weakness. ''It's hard for a good lawyer to come up with novel, inventive arguments,'' Professor Rissland said, ''and it will be even harder for a machine to do so -- probably.''
Title: A Lawyer Minus the Briefcase
Other (negative): inherent limitations of AI               artificial intelligence experts acknowledge its inherent weakness to come up with novel inventive arguments inherent limitations of AI
Other (positive): template exists in law/rules       AI limitations related to linguistic nuance

Paragraph: One might object that Ms. Turkle is skewing these categories, since modernism, in art at least, is usually associated with the shift in our sense of reality effected by Einstein's discovery of relativity, and involves the sense of instability she associates with postmodernism. But no matter; her point is clear enough. As she sees it, the change in perspective she describes has deep implications for such matters as artificial intelligence, artificial life and, perhaps most important of all, "a fundamental reconsideration of human identity." And these are the subjects that "Life on the Screen" explores so fascinatingly. One therefore pays close attention when she explains how the shift to postmodernism has been reflected in a new outlook on artificial intelligence. No longer are designers striving for an overarching theory of mind. More and more they see hope in computers that can learn, or what she terms "emergent A.I.," which, as she writes about it, accords with the fragmented, "decentered" self posited by postmodernism.
Title: The Self in Cyberspace, Decentered and Opaque
Other (positive): kindergarten for computers

Paragraph: Dr. Dimitrios Apostolopoulos, a systems scientist at the Robotics Institute,  who is project manager for Nomad, said the robot would test its skills under increasingly challenging conditions. Some parts of the test area are flat ice sheets studded with occasional, distinct rocks while others are moraines, dense concentrations of rock and rubble deposited by glaciers. When it sees a good candidate, the robot will move in for detailed examination with instruments on the end of a movable arm, including a close-up mini-camera that will look at it from different angles. Nomad will touch the rock several times with a reflection spectrometer, which shines a light on the object and analyzes the spectrum of the reflected light to tell what elements are present. Then the robot will use a metal detector to sense the presence of iron, a major component of some meteorites, and do computations to classify the sample. If Nomad decides a rock is a meteorite, the robot will radio the object's exact location to the researchers using coordinates calculated by the satellite-based Global Positioning System. Later, people will retrieve the specimen to confirm or refute Nomad's findings. The project, which has so far cost about $3.5 million, is sponsored by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Office of Space Science, which is interested in sending intelligent robot explorers to other planets. On distant worlds, where the simplest, round-trip radio communication can take hours, it would be impossible for humans on Earth to guide a robot. Scientists need robots that can fend for themselves in unknown, hostile environments and that are smart enough to recognize and assess the unexpected.
Title: Hunt for Meteorites In Antarctica Enlists a Novel Recruit
Other (positive): cataloging info   exploration, research

Paragraph: Dr. Myers, whose field was internal medicine, was the chairman of the department of medicine at the University of Pittsburgh from 1950 to 1970 and later developed his software there using the principles of artificial intelligence. When he began work on the program in 1970, Dr. Myers sought help from computer experts with experience in applying artificial intelligence to medicine. Dr. Myers tape-recorded his thoughts as he made a diagnosis and the programmers devised a way for the computer to follow his steps in making decisions and to apply his methods of reasoning. His first program could match 3,550 symptoms with more than 500 diseases that made up about three-quarters of the diagnoses in internal medicine. It was used at a number of hospitals and medical schools.
Title: Dr. Jack Myers, 84, a Pioneer In Computer-Aided Diagnoses

Paragraph: Underground should put developers on notice about what can be achieved with brilliant artificial intelligence and a familiar theme. But it should be one theme among many. Our planet is a fascinating and diverse place, and the human race, ever pushy and inquisitive, has wriggled its way into all sorts of interesting corners and assumed all manner of heroic roles. I'd rather lead a team up the south ridge of Mount Everest than kill another alien. I'd rather troll the blackness of a Pacific trench than swim through another sewer in pursuit of an evildoer. And I'd welcome the challenge of rescuing a sleeping child from a smoky apartment. I've never fought a fire in my life, but I know for a fact that I could fall right into it.
Title: War Game With Intelligent Enemies
Other (negative): AI in gaming shows limited imagination

Paragraph: ''Still a Long Way From Checkmate'' (Dec. 28) -- about how artificial intelligence is affecting, or may affect, consumer appliances -- hinted at some lovely windmills in the sky. But I'd like to pick a bone with Sony, Panasonic, General Electric, et al: Why can't I walk into a consumer electronics store and buy an AM/FM radio with presettable programming, similar to that of a VCR?
Title: Radios Aren't So Smart

Paragraph: Astro Teller's explanation of why people fear artificial intelligence (Op-Ed, March 21) misses an obvious solution: just stop calling it intelligence, because it isn't.

Paragraph: The find was accidental. In early 1999, a robot tethered to a surface ship by a long cable was being directed to hunt the icy darkness of the deep Mediterranean for a lost submarine. Suddenly, it lit up thousands of amphorae -- the clay jugs of antiquity used for storage. The pile of ancient debris also held several anchors, pitchers, a serving bowl and a large metal cooking pot.
Title: In an Ancient Wreck, Clues to Seafaring Lives; Accidental Find Lends New Credence to Greek Tales of Sailing Feats
Other (positive): exploration, research

Paragraph: But where are the German Expressionists of the game world? And the Charlie Chaplins? And can game creators overcome the inherent repetition in their work, perhaps through advances in artificial intelligence?
Title: It's a Video Game, Certainly, but Is It Art?

Paragraph: ''We are really trying to use software agents that are considerably different from those before,'' said Michael Kearns, the department head for artificial intelligence research at AT&T Labs and a co-developer of Cobot. ''Instead of tasks like coordinating calendars, these software agents will step out and take much more initiative, making social introductions, not a task people have traditionally thought of machines as being good for.'' Using that summary, the robot identifies clusters of documents that use the same words. ''Soon you have clumps of word lists that are mostly talking about the same subject,'' Dr. Foner said. For instance, the user's copy of Yenta may find that in a group of 24 documents, all share the same top five keywords, like ''robot,'' ''collaborative,'' ''filter,'' ''Yenta'' and ''results.'' The users can direct their Yentas to eliminate any clusters in which they are not interested.
Title: Find Me A File, Cache Me A Catch
Other (positive): AI performs unexpected jobs well making social introductions interpersonal relationships with humans

Paragraph: All I am doing is watching a $700 robot whose one purpose in life is to mow lawns. It is crisscrossing the grass in tight V-shaped patterns as if it were creating a large, green backgammon board. It is not beeping like R2D2 of ''Star Wars'' or talking like HAL of ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' but its circuit-board brain knows things I do not: which way is north, for example. It figured that out before I was sure I had turned on its electric-powered motor.
Title: Grass Is Greener If the Robot Mows

Paragraph: Both games possess exceptional artificial intelligence that can convincingly animate opponents for single-player modes, but it is Unreal Tournament's that really shines. In single-player mode, Unreal Tournament can create the illusion that a player is playing a team sport. Actually, the game directs the computer to animate and control groups of virtual players, or bots; one group plays with the human player and the other does its digital best to defeat the player and his bots.
Title: New Heights (or Depths) of Blood and Gore

Paragraph: And the business of high-technology  safety is not far behind. Many have been developed at teaching hospitals like LDS. They include Internet links to a doctor's laptop, advice-giving software equipped with artificial intelligence, wireless devices that transmit medical orders and bar-code systems to avoid drug errors.
Title: Corrective Medicine; New Technology Helps Health Care Avoid Mistakes

Paragraph: Once you accept this setup -- and Ms. Wood is very skillful at diverting attention from the less plausible details -- the narrative moves with the ever-accelerating speed of the best techno-thrillers. Spies and counterspies, betrayals and counterbetrayals, artificial intelligence and counterintelligence. Through it all, Kay Bee Sulaiman retains her sense of humor and her sense of self, while her relationship with the fabricant grows deeper and more problematic. As in any relationship, the sticking point is trust. When choices must be made, whose priorities count most? Are Kay Bee's hang-ups less crippling than John Halton's, just because hers are "natural" while his have been "programmed"?

Paragraph: Their field is only a decade old, tracing its origins to 1987 when the early viruses like Brain and Jerusalem began to infect personal computers. Title: Trying to Shore Up the PC's Immune System

Paragraph: David Barstow is the founder and president of Instant Sports Inc., an Austin, Tex., company that runs a sports site on the World Wide Web (http://www.instantsports.com). He also holds a Ph.D. in artificial intelligence from Stanford, but perhaps more important, is a devotee of baseball. In the 1980's, he began designing ways to enjoy baseball games via computer. Early on he compiled an index of 78 possible baseball plays that is now a central element in his patented method of displaying live events via computer. As a game unfolds, each play is entered into a computer using one of the 78 terms in a domain-specific language.
Title: Patents;The owner of a direct-mail company creates a system to send electronic ads to specific viewers.

Paragraph: The Albuquerque Police Department is a case in point. After several years of seeking money for a robot to help disarm explosives, the department spent $160,000 in 1998 for a remote-controlled robot called Andros, built by Remotec, a subsidiary of Northrop Grumman. The Albuquerque department, which responds to bomb threats statewide, had one of only two such robots in New Mexico. Andros and other bomb squad robots are generally slow, traveling no faster than five miles per hour, but their every motion must be controlled by a human operator. And since the Albuquerque bomb squad officers train with the robot only about two hours a month, they have found it hard to master its remote controls. Instead of being completely manually controlled, a robot equipped with Smart could be given sensors that would allow it to make some decisions on its own. The robot could figure out the best path to a point in a room, center itself in a doorway or grip a bomb on its own. That would free security personnel to focus on what steps to take when there was a bomb threat, Mr. Bennett said, rather than focusing on controlling the robot's every move.
Title: Trying to Give Bomb Squad Robots Brains to Match Their Brawn
Other (negative): bomb squad robots are generally slow, their every motion must be controlled by a human operator, they have found it hard to master its remote controls

Title: Dance With Aliens and Save the World

Paragraph: Second, the Information Revolution of the late 20th century was a spectacular but only partial success. Simple information processing became faster and cheaper than anyone had imagined, but the once-confident artificial intelligence movement went from defeat to defeat. As Marvin Minsky, one of the movement's founders, despairingly remarked, ''What people vaguely call common sense is actually more intricate than most of the technical expertise we admire.'' And it takes common sense to deal with the physical world -- which is why, even at the end of the 21st century, there are still no robot plumbers.
Title: White Collars Turn Blue
Other (negative): It has fallen behind other forms of technology inherent limitations of AI

Title: Weighing Demand and Figuring Supply

Paragraph: This is dazzling stuff. But just when we have become intimate with the robot -- who has acquired a gender (male) and the name Orf (short for Orpheus) -- the focus suddenly shifts. We are still on the Olympic Peninsula in the Pacific Northwest, but years have passed, political authority has splintered among antagonistic ''tribal'' units, and we are now inside the head of Jarrod, a ranger of the fiercely independent Park Service whose single-minded dedication to protecting the trees of the Olympic National Forest leaves no room for the joys and burdens of human reproduction.
Title: Science Fiction

Paragraph: We are not encouraged to think of computer science as pure programming knowledge, as the media often depicts it, but as a field that is literally brimming with possibilities, like artificial intelligence, biocomputing and robotics.
Title: The Nerd as Stereotype
Other (positive): AI as an opportunity for people in CompSCi

Paragraph: Mention genetic algorithms or artificial intelligence, common parlance among computer scientists, and eyes may very likely roll among even the most respected new- media executives in New York. In fact, an almost Luddite attitude toward hard technology seems to prevail in Silicon Alley, where Bikini.com, ''the world's biggest beach party,'' is an example of the cutting edge. On the fringes of Silicon Alley, though, can  occasionally be found a company like the Intelligenesis Corporation, which was founded in early 1997 by Ben Goertzel, a mathematician, and Lisa S. Pazer, a former Wall Street economist and analyst. Intelligenesis is trying to change the way people measure business risks or make buying decisions by combining, in a software program called Webmind, elements of the Internet with artificial intelligence technology or ''machine learning,'' by which the software can, for example, ''remember'' who Alan Greenspan is and why he matters. ''For a long time, I had been designing an architecture for artificial intelligence, but didn't have the machine to do it on,'' said Dr. Goertzel,  now 32. ''When I started using the World Wide Web, I realized it was a  metaphor for the brain -- that the Web could be a mind.'' Dr. Goertzel and Ms. Pazer contend that all the really significant predictions and decisions that people make are, in the end, based on human psychology. And Webmind, they say, can use artificial intelligence to translate the multitudinous outpourings of human psychology into valuable data.
Title: Prospectus; Can a computer program figure out the market? A former analyst and a mathematician are betting that theirs can.
Other (negative): Luddite attitude toward hard technology
Other (positive): smarter stock trading translate the multitudinous outpourings of human psychology into valuable data stock market analysis

Paragraph: The spectacle, captured on videotape, evoked cheers from the wheelchair's engineers, robotics experts from the University of Ulm and NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The self-navigating wheelchair, part of a class of smart machines that rely on advances in artificial intelligence and sensor technology, could give the most severely disabled a new degree of autonomy.
Title: Smart Wheelchairs Will Ease Many Paths

Paragraph: Ralph, who is known as a ''media don'' for his frequent television appearances on subjects like artificial intelligence, thinks of the individual human being as ''a machine that's been programmed by culture not to recognize that it's a machine'' and consciousness as a form of information processing. He does not believe in God, does not believe in the concept of the soul; and he has a Darwinian explanation for virtually all human actions and beliefs. He thinks it would be interesting to try to ''discover the mechanism behind laughter'' by getting a computer ''to crunch millions of jokes instead of numbers.''
Title: Seduction and Reduction On a British Campus

Paragraph: But at least one project stops Mr. Brain, 40, from fidgeting: the act of taking something apart. On a recent Thursday he appeared almost serene as he took a power screwdriver in hand, removed the plastic casing from a wheeled toy robot and gazed at the gears and circuit boards inside.
Title: For One Web Site, Some Explaining to Do

Paragraph: Has the invasion already begun? Are the aliens already right under our noses? Are machines, the products of human engineering intelligence, poised to take over the world -- or is this an irrational fear, the latest spasm of the Luddite spirit? Finally, is the whole idea just a clever marketing ploy for the investment-hungry artificial intelligence industry? Here we have three books, all written by experts in computer intelligence, aimed to persuade us that the Age of Machines is nigh. We are to be eclipsed by our own technology, ceding our outdated flesh, blood and neural tissue to integrated circuits and their mechanistic progeny. The future belongs to the robots. All three of these books provide a vivid window on the state of the art in artificial intelligence research, and offer provocative speculations on where we might be heading as the information age advances. Of the three, ''The Age of Spiritual Machines,'' by Ray Kurzweil, is the best: it is more detailed, thoughtful, clearly explained and attractively written than ''Robot: Mere Machine to Transcendent Mind,'' by Hans Moravec, and ''When Things Start to Think,'' by Neil Gershenfeld -- though all three are creditable efforts at popularization.
Title: Hello, HAL

Paragraph: I have seen only two episodes of ''Futurama,'' the new show from Matt Groening, the creator of ''The Simpsons.'' But the year-3000 look of ''Futurama'' is great fun: all the technology we know, hyperextended and activated; all the cultural artifacts we live with, relocated (Earth theme parks on the Moon); and our biochemical systems inverted (the robot that lives on alcohol and gets the D.T.'s when dead sober).
Title: Animated Characters Imitate Life, Even Transcend It

Paragraph: Time to flip some off switches. My 750-square-foot apartment has become a high-tech kennel as I spent the last week living with a litter of robot dogs, looking into what may be the future of pet ownership in places like Manhattan. After Sony's tail-wagging success with its Aibo robo-dog -- it sold out its entire 45,000-unit production run of the $2,500 electric critters last winter -- at least four toy companies are putting their own, less expensive versions on the market this fall. But Poo-chi's got moods. If he feels he's not getting enough attention, he gets surly and barks, beeps and growls. Oh, and he can't walk. Tiger plans a more sophisticated robot dog for later this year, a $150 model called i-Cybie that not only will walk realistically but also will be able to express six different emotions, including surprise and sadness.
Title: Pets or Appliances? Meeting the Purebred Robot Dogs
Other (positive): robots becoming more lifelike and evolving

Paragraph: It's simple enough. You highlight a unit or group of units with the mouse, click the right button and up pops a menu of choices. These depend on the specific unit and the state it is in, but they might range from Hunt to Hide to Button Up (which orders a tank to close its hatches) to Line of Sight (which allows you to determine what a unit can see). To direct a soldier to a new destination, you simply draw a line there. Once you've entered orders for the units, you click on the Go icon, the computer simultaneously implements your instructions and those of the game's artificial intelligence, and you watch the next 60 seconds of action unfold.
Title: Playing War, but With a New Set of Rules

Paragraph: A tale of a perfect child robot programmed to adore his human Mommy, this collaboration between Mr. Spielberg communing with the dead Stanley Kubrick has, with its waxy sentiment, Simonized filmgoers and polarized film critics.
Title: How to Tell a Bad Movie From a Truly Bad Movie

Paragraph: STEVEN SPIELBERG'S latest movie, ''A.I.,'' depicts the futuristic concept of a robot boy with artificial intelligence. The reality of a truly emotive robot seems a long way off (possibly even longer than the movie itself). In the interim, we should focus on some things that are less daunting -- and more easily attainable -- that capitalize on existing technology: EPIPHANY ALARM CLOCK -- This clock with artificial intelligence would demonstrate not so much intellect but intuition. When you hit ''snooze'' in the morning, it would discern whether you really needed more sleep or were just procrastinating. In either case, the clock would call your office and bargain for more sleep time.
Title: Here's to a Really Useful Machine
Other (negative): advances are to far off.

Paragraph: It happened, seemingly, overnight. There is a new energy surging through the league today. C. Webb, V.C. and A.I. are not merely eye candy on Sunday anymore, ratings grabbers who offer little more than first-round exits in the spring.
Title: Youth Movement Has Created New Energy in Playoffs

Paragraph: Even worse, with some E-mail systems, if the writer doesn't fill in the subject line, the occult hand of artificial intelligence will enter ''No Subject.'' Beware such automation.  Someday a software program using so-called fuzzy logic may scan my (or your) carefully composed messages and label them ''No Point.''
Title: Well Versed in E-Mail Subject Lines
Other (positive): summarize email content

Paragraph: The duo's forthcoming single may be its most tongue-in-cheek synthesis to date. The group appropriates the robot beats and voices of Kraftwerk, a German group that has made a career of embracing electronic instruments and detesting rock-and-roll. Only the lyrics in Arling and Cameron's Kraftwerk song consist of a computerized voice saying, ''We love to rock. R-O-C-K, let's rock.''
Title: The Pop Life

Paragraph: It seems counterintuitive that this highly technological medium should lean so heavily on 19th-century dramatic techniques. But when actors aren't sentient, the Method doesn't cut any ice. It's no accident that the most compelling characters in the virtual world are silent or minimally vocal. Mario and Lara Croft are the digital world's Charlie Chaplin and Mary Pickford -- they are operating in a medium that has yet to find its technological feet. And until computer games can muster truly powerful artificial intelligence, natural language capability and digital voice synthesis, their characters will be marionettes attached to strings of gestural instruction code.
Title: New Title on the Cutlass Edge of Software
Other (negative): AI poorly mimics human behavior

Paragraph: ''On line, people mostly gang up on the computer,'' said Mr. Meier, who has only recently turned to science fiction after designing historical simulation games like Gettysburg and Civilization. ''They band together to beat the artificial intelligence. And then when they've beaten the computer, they'll go after each other.
Title: On 2067 Battleground, 1999 Political Passions

Paragraph: Modeled after a contest developed in the 1970's at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, FIRST sends out a kit each year to participating schools which contain parts for building a robot. The schools, with support from local businesses with engineering orientations, then have six weeks to build their robot from the same kit of parts before squaring off in a series of eight regional contests this year, including the one in Hartford. It leads to a nationwide face-off at Walt Disney World on April 22-24. Berlin's team is unusual in that it incorporates middle school students (two team members are in the sixth grade) for what is otherwise a high-school event, and also for its grassroots orientation. No professional engineers worked with the students (teachers helped out instead), and the team has had to scrape for most of the $30,000 needed for entrance fees, robot kits, and expenses.
Title: In This School Tournament The Final Four Were Robots
Other (positive): contest encourages AI advances, academia supports AI education, business interest and investment in AI

Paragraph: He said the new processor had enough power to begin to convey humanlike motions and abilities, ranging from natural movement and facial expressions to artificial intelligence like the ability to learn and to recognize speech.
Title: Silicon Valley's Awesome Look at New Sony Toy
Other (positive): New CPU has power for human like intelligence to learn and to recognize speech speech recognition

Paragraph: Before the monkeys began to reach out to pick up a morsel of food, the robot was able to ''read'' their intentions and carry out the same complex movement. Making a robot move in real time based on the activity of many brain cells in primates is ''an important step'' in developing neural prostheses, said Dr. Richard A. Andersen, a neuroscientist at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena who does similar research. In most previous experiments, Dr. Andersen said, brain signals were fed into machines some time after the signals were obtained from animals. The researchers also sent the monkeys' brain signals over the Internet to another robot arm at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The next step will be to ''close the loop,'' Dr. Andersen said. With visual and perhaps tactile feedback from the robot, the monkey might not bother to reach with its own arm anymore. It would merely think about making the movement and let the robot do the work.
Title: Brain Signals Shown To Move a Robot's Arm
Other (negative): It makes us lazy

Paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.                     Dr. Anne Foerst, 34, a researcher at the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the director of M.I.T.'s God and Computers project, apologized on a recent afternoon that a certain robot named Kismet wouldn't be joining our interview. Cog is a robot built in analogy to a human infant. He has a torso, two arms, a head, ears and eyes. He, it, learns to coordinate those limbs to explore its environment, just as newborn babies do. Kismet is a robot who interacts with humans through her body posture and facial expressions.  The aim of this project is to explore social interactions between humans and robots and also between the humans themselves. A. Well, that moment is 50 years down the road. At least. But it's pretty clear that when it comes, those who built the robot will have to make that decision because they won't be blinded by their fears of the seemingly human qualities of the machines. They'll know what's inside. And if it ever got to the point where the builders felt, Oops, now that has become something, the builders could become the creature's strongest advocates.
Title: Do Androids Dream? M.I.T. Working on It
Other (positive): explore social interactions between humans and robots and also between the humans themselves aim of this project is to explore social interactions between humans and robots and also between the humans themselves

Paragraph: Earlier today, mission managers had the Canadian astronaut Marc Garneau maneuver the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm so cameras on the end could take detailed pictures of the deployed array to see why it was more slack than expected. Each array, which measures 38 feet across, contains 32,800 silicon cells that convert sunlight into electricity.
Title: Astronauts Finish Adding Solar Wing To Station

Paragraph: ''Honey, I Shrunk the Audience,'' which is new, is set up as the occasion when the movie's fictitious Prof. Wayne Szalinski is to receive an award from the Imagination Institute. His invention, of course, malfunctions during the ceremony, shrinking the audience to the size of a shoebox, and great adventures ensue. In Star Tours, a refurbished version of a longtime attraction based on the ''Star Wars'' films, an inexperienced robot pilot takes the audience careening around the universe in a spaceship, into and out of trouble, with a great sense of levity.

Paragraph: DOG IN THE WINDOWS -- It seems that Sony has found an untapped market for robotic dogs. Within 20 minutes of opening on-line sales on Tuesday, the company sold out its 3,000 units of Aibo, a programmable pup, on the Japanese market. Sales of the robot in the United States weren't quite as brisk -- about 1,000 of 2,000 robots on the market were sold by the end of the day. But Tod Freeman, a spokesman for Sony, said that demand was high. ''For the first two and a half hours, our server was so overloaded it was inaccessible,'' Mr. Freeman said. Aibo, which is selling for $2,500, can be purchased only on line.
Title: NEWS WATCH
Other (positive): Aibo

Paragraph: Mr. Goodwin, 36, is a researcher in artificial intelligence at I.B.M.'s Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. He graduated from the University of Waterloo in Ontario and received a Ph.D. in computer science from Carnegie Mellon University.
Title: Jenny Libien, Richard Goodwin

Paragraph: When he defined the actor's craft, Shaw did concede the limits of age and sex. Today we argue fiercely about the limits of race and ethnicity too. But limits shift as suddenly (and sometimes as violently) as the borders between human intelligence and artificial intelligence or reality and virtual reality. Frankly, I'm much more interested in the limits of talent and imagination.
Title: Helping Shakespeare Make an Easy Crossing

Paragraph: INTREPID SEA-AIR-SPACE MUSEUM, Pier 86, West 46th Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 5 p.m., Coast Guard Appreciation weekend, free activities, including search and rescue demonstrations involving an HH-65 Dolphin Helicopter, ship tour of the Coast Guard cutter Reliance, boat safety demonstrations and a presentation by Coastie, the talking robot cutter. Admission: $12; 65+, veterans, reservists and ages 12 to 17, $9; ages 6 to 11, $6; ages 2 to 5, $2; under 2, free; wheelchair patrons, half price. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., with last ticket sold at 4 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m., with last ticket sold at 6 p.m. Information: (212) 245-0072.
