Paragraph: Jehuty's frame runner has disappeared, and Jehuty is an advanced prototype needed for a great battle on Mars. Leo is asked to help get the robot to the red planet. He refuses, but finds himself in the position of so many heroes: He's the only one who can do it, and millions of lives hang in the balance. The most challenging battles are those in which you must fight another robot as powerful as Jehuty. In these fights you are taunted by the enemy frame runners, the nastiest of which is Viola, a bitter, self-destructive killer. When her commander warns Viola that she could wind up dead, she smilingly replies, ''That's what I'm waiting for.''
Title: Gee Whiz. Must I Keep Slaughtering?

Paragraph: A revived Martin is added to the mix. Envious of David, and plain nasty to boot, he splits the family and deepens Monica's feeling that it was a mistake to accept David. If she returns the mecha to the company that made him, he will be destroyed, which she doesn't want. But when Martin and David have an encounter in a swimming pool, she puts the robot in her car and abandons him in the woods.
Title: All He Wants Is His Mother, But She Doesn't Want Him

Paragraph: The power behind Prody -- made by Mindmaker, a company based in San Jose, Calif. -- is artificial intelligence and speech-recognition technology that enables it to accept voice commands and learn the user's preferences. In that regard, Prody is not flying solo: a handful of companies are working with both technologies to create on-screen digital assistants and, in some cases, digital pets.
Title: Watch Your Language Around This Digital Bird
Other (positive): accept voice commands and learn the user's preferences

Paragraph: A robot lander and two piggy-backed microprobes embarked on the second of NASA's water missions to Mars, launched atop an unmanned Boeing Delta 2 rocket. After an 11-month journey, the Mars Polar Lander will parachute gently to the surface of the red planet and start scooping up dirt.   A15
Title: NEWS SUMMARY

Paragraph: The technology for the E-rater dates to the interest in artificial intelligence in World War II, and gathered force in the 1960's with the development of computational linguistics: the merging of computer science with the study of language.
Title: High Tech Comes to the Classroom: Machines That Grade Essays

Paragraph: Made by Mr. Vercesi's son, Paul Vercesi 3d, the robot has been in the window for 13 years, regularly attracting the attention of admirers. Over the years, more than 50 people have offered to buy it for as much as $500, Mr. Vercesi said. For Mr. Vercesi, though, the robot is an ever-present reminder of his son. ''It keeps part of him in the store,'' he said.   MICHAEL GOLDMAN Photo: This photograph of the hardware robot is on exhibit at the Municipal Art Society. (Martha Cooper)
Title: How Much Is That Robot In the Window?

Paragraph: As for HAL, he is another unrealized dream of the 60's, artificial intelligence. Thirty years of computer science have given us machines that can beat us at chess, but cannot do the simple things that a 6-year-old can, like walk, talk, recognize faces, learn languages, dream and laugh.
Title: On the Eve of 2001, the Future Is Not Quite What It Used to Be
Other (negative): AI has failed to meet expectations (Arthur C. Clarke per se)

Paragraph: The screenplay (by Mr. Bird, Tim McCanlies and Andy Brent Forrester), is set in 1950's Maine and is full of pointed, adult-friendly references to the Eisenhower era and its Cold War anxieties. Hogarth is a delightful Everykid, a believable mix of mischief and bravery. His robot pal, nicknamed Diesel, is endearingly childlike. Much of the humor derives from a role reversal in which the boy becomes a parental figure to the monstrously huge metal man. Hogarth protects Diesel, defends him (even against the United States Government), and teaches him about everything from connecting words with thoughts to the meaning of life and death.
Title: A Disney Dissenter Shuns Song and Dance

Paragraph: Deep Space 1 is a barrel-shaped, 1,000-pound craft that was launched on Oct. 24, 1998. The robot vessel, packed with miniature instruments and other devices, was designed to troubleshoot 12 innovative technologies that could be used by future spacecraft. Dr. Marc D. Rayman, chief mission engineer, said the spacecraft had completed more than 95 percent of its mission before the encounter. Technologies aboard include an autonomous navigation system, an unusual solar-powered ion engine, an integrated camera and spectrometer for determining the composition of distant objects, a combination ion and electron spectrometer for studying charged particles, and advanced artificial intelligence software that lets the spacecraft manage its own mission as situations change.
Title: Craft Fails In Bid to Take Asteroid Photo
Other (positive): space exploration  AI aids in space exploration

Paragraph: Tired of mopping? A Virginia company has created a floor-cleaning robot that will do the job for you. The EBot2 from Intellibot is designed to  scrub up to 50,000 square feet on a four-and-a-half-hour charge without any human attention or programming. Unless you have a colossal weekend house outside Microsoft headquarters, you probably don't have anywhere near 50,000 square feet of floor; as might be expected, the machine is geared toward institutions.
Title: It Does Floors (Lots of Them) All by Itself and Doesn't Complain

Paragraph: His set, accompanied by flashy animated films of himself as a robot and a demon with smiley-face eyes, was as robustly fun as always. Bits of hits from the likes of Blondie and Queen mingled with dub reggae, ecstatic house music and Fatboy Slim's patented monster beats. Grinning like a fool, miming along to spliced-in snippets of spoken word, Fatboy Slim was the benign face of democratic good times. His fans reveled during his set, then obediently departed when the pier shut down at the stroke of midnight, proving that at least when it's network-sponsored, electronic music is just a good party, not a threat.
Title: Party Animals And Ravers In a Free And Easy Mood

Paragraph: Now, a small group of researchers say that such intuition can, at least in part, be duplicated by computers. Rules of thumb that are only partially accurate can be combined into precise prediction tools using an artificial intelligence technique called boosting. Boosting, like other aspects of computational learning, raises fundamental questions about the nature of artificial intelligence. Despite the accuracy of boosting, the algorithm does not really ''know'' anything: It does not search for certainty, but merely makes mathematically calibrated predictions based on precedent.
Title: A Computer Program That Plays a Hunch

Paragraph: Remember artificial intelligence? Pen computing? Both were the Next Big Thing -- hot investment targets that became big losers -- in the 1980's. And now it's E-commerce and the Internet and the Web. Obviously the commercial Internet has been exponentially more successful than artificial intelligence or CD-ROM's, but with the exception of a few remarkable companies, products and services that have actually changed the world, it has followed the same general course.
Title: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; Contributing to the bumpy ride for Internet stocks is a familiar overload of eager hangers-on.
Other (negative): investors lose with AI

Paragraph: Photo: The robot giraffe at the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City. (Liberty Science Center)
Title: FAMILY FARE

Paragraph: It's ironic that one of the central characters in Eric Idle's new novel is a robot who has written a dissertation on the nature of comedy. As lovers of the legendary British comedy troupe Monty Python's Flying Circus can attest, Idle is one of the least robotic men ever to wield the unspeakable power of the Comfy Chair, an inspired buffoon whose prissy, leering face and lunatic antics helped drive some of the best comedy of the past three decades. Yet in print he clanks dutifully along like a humanoid who needs a battery recharge. It isn't that Idle isn't smart. ''The Road to Mars,'' an offbeat futuristic thriller- comedy about the misadventures of two small-time comedians and their faithful robot on an interplanetary Catskill circuit, is filled with intelligent observations about comedy and comedians, and enough one-liners to keep a funnyman in gigs past Pluto. And Idle handles plot competently, even displaying some genuine narrative quirkiness. But the whole of the book is less than the sum of its parts: it's neither funny enough to take off as a comic novel nor meaty enough to be particularly provocative. In what may be an occupational hazard for actors turned novelists, this consummate showman doesn't perform as a writer. His terse prose lacks the robust, cunning, luxurious stupidity that comedy needs. (Does he respect the literary medium too much? Big mistake.) You want to laugh more than you actually do: his riffs feel detached, observed rather than realized. ''The Road to Mars'' has its merits, but it reads more like a script than a novel -- and if Idle's in the movie, it'll probably be hilarious.   Gary Kamiya
Title: Books in Brief: Fiction

Paragraph: This time the Church does not have to beg support from temporal powers; its own battle fleet is the biggest, fastest and best armed in space. But despite its galaxy-spanning power, the Church has reason to fear two groups of enemies: the Ousters, gene-altered humans whose idiosyncratic space habitats owe allegiance to no one, and the scattered followers of a young girl named Aenea, who is rumored to be a new messiah and whose most dangerous gift, quite literally, is empathy. While the Pope's battalions wreak havoc on the Ousters, the agents of the Inquisition close in on Aenea. Her most prominent defenders are the good-hearted Endymion, the multitalented narrator of the tale, and the enigmatic Shrike, a half-human killing machine of uncertain provenance but unwavering loyalty. Behind the scenes lurk layer upon layer of shadowy string-pullers, ranging from competing factions of the TechnoCore, the nest of artificial intelligences that long ago wrung independence from their human creators, to even more arcane presences whose purposes can only be guessed at.
Title: Science Fiction
Other (negative): dealing with an independent state of artifiicial intelligence

Paragraph: The form has evolved little since then. But makers represented in the show vary their figures by the features they paint on the faces and the things they add: simulated musical instruments, ersatz vacuum cleaners, robot jetpacks, goggles, clothing and bar stools. Space creatures come with silvery wings made from heat shields, claws of spark plugs and alternator wiring connecting packs on their backs. A minimalist fantasy figure combines two kinds of mufflers: a canlike type for the bright yellow torso and a rod-shaped glass pack muffler for the red sausagelike head, the work of Manuel Rodriguez and Efran Castillo. A different approach is seen in ''Recycle, Re-seen.'' A muffler man, made in 1992 by Jack King of Des Moines, sports a bright red ribbon for a tie with light-bulb eyes in a hubcap face.
Title: There Can Be Art In Car Parts, Too: Take Muffler Men

Paragraph: Once, Internet search sites served as helpful road maps. With advances in artificial intelligence, one day they might be brilliant secretaries. But today, they are in a state of transition, slouching toward the human,  growing more philosophical. Mixing mechanical and personal elements, they have turned into accidental wisefolk, spiritual advisers and drive-by psychoanalysts. If Altavista is in love -- and I imagine Jeeves wouldn't be right for her anyway -- and if she really knew it, artificial intelligence will have reached a new high.
Title: Ideas & Trends; Searching for the Search Engines of Meaning
Other (positive): accidental wisefolk, spiritual advisers, drive-by psychoanalysts  better search engine

Paragraph: So do the women in my artificial intelligence classes. Given the dearth of women in computer science, an article that opens in a way that immediately turns off girls and mothers can do quite a bit of harm.
Title: Girls Like Robots, Too

Paragraph: Today the weather was cooperative; seas were light and winds gentle. But Magnum, a robot deployed from the submarine support vessel Carolyn Chouest, needed repairs and spent much of the day on deck.
Title: EgyptAir Data Shows Engine Shutdown
Other (negative): robots break down

Paragraph: Fleeing the campus gave him a chance to return to an earlier passion: mathematics. ''I always had a mathematic bent,'' he said. ''I dropped it all in Berkeley when I looked around a math class and realized there were no girls. But artificial intelligence? Mathematical models? I love that stuff. Eventually, my dad suggested I might be able to apply it in the business world. I joined the company in 1979.
Title: Growing a Giant in the Vineyard

Paragraph: Although Aibo may be able to read the Circuits section, I am extremely thankful that Chaka, my real-live dog, cannot. I can assure you, I will never replace my dog with an electronic one. I think robot developers have chosen an area in which their product will never be able to compete with the real thing.
Title: Four-Footed Robot

Paragraph: Some 50 years ago, the science fiction writer Isaac Asimov formulated the three laws of robotics. The first is, ''A robot may not injure a human being or, through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm.'' For the moment, there is nothing to worry about from the robot now under consideration. It has a pair of caterpillar treads, bent yellow arms with multiple sockets, touch sensors and two rubber bands. It even follows the second law of robotics: it obeys orders without question -- after a program is fed into its central processor via infrared signals from a desktop computer. And so far, even the third law seems to be holding up: ''A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the first or second law.'' The two touch sensors turn off the power when the robot reaches the edge of the table, preventing destruction on the floor below. But the future may be less certain as these robots evolve. Similar constructions, created out of Lego blocks and the Lego Mindstorms Robotics Invention System, are proliferating. The $219 set, which contains familiar Lego pieces along with light sensors, motors, touch sensors, gears and a minicomputer ''brick,'' has been an immense success since its introduction last year. A Lego machine is made with the brick at its center. Then a program is written on a computer and beamed into an infrared sensor on the robot, which is then set free to follow its prescribed orders. Lego is now introducing a Star Wars Droid kit ($109), in which the robots take on forms resembling the films' quirkiest characters, and a Discovery robot set ($159) for more elementary constructions that don't require a computer to program.
Title: In a Child's Tiny Bricks, The Logic Of Computers

Paragraph: PICTURE the brain of a high school sophomore in the body of a military assault vehicle, and you have Tiny Tank. The hero of a Playstation game by the same name, Tiny is the flagship product of Sentrax, a military contractor in this fictional world. The company thought Tiny would be a good public relations tactic -- something cute and approachable to sell a robot defense program to the American public. Tiny is hostile. He's surly, angst-ridden and appalled by his appearance. In other words, he's a teen-ager with treads. So when the robot army seizes power, drives the human race underground and threatens to remove Earth's atmosphere, Tiny can feel justified in his contempt for authority. And as the sole opponent of a towering corporate war machine, he has plenty of opportunities to channel his aggression. Tiny's Napoleon complex transforms the game into a parody of the standard robot epic. In most ''mech'' games, the player pilots a machine lifted from the pages of a Japanese comic book, and the whole story plays out like an Italian futurist manifesto: huge, imposing machines with terrifying power wreak havoc on the surrounding landscape. Steel behemoths exchange fire in deadly earnest. They're as serious as a heart attack.
Title: A Cute Little Tank Adds Insult to Injury

Paragraph: She has consistently sided with the mayor on major issues since her appointment to the board in July 1998. But Ms. Thomson is not a robot programmed by City Hall, and on Sunday she had the temerity to cross the mayor by casting the deciding vote for Mr. Levy to serve as an interim chancellor until a permanent replacement for Dr. Crew is found.
Title: In America; An Honest Vote

Paragraph: Avoiding classified research, he began by underwriting project MAC at M.I.T., a mammoth undertaking in large-scale time sharing. Long before Apple Computer, MAC stood for both Multi-Access Computer and Machine-Aided Cognition and included Marvin Minsky's artificial intelligence laboratory. He also supported the work of John McCarthy, the inventor of time sharing; programs at the RAND Corporation, and at Carnegie Tech (now Carnegie-Mellon) with Allen Newell and Herbert Simon of ''bounded rationality'' fame; and the kindred spirit Douglas Engelbart of SRI International, who later developed the mouse, hypertext and windows.
Title: The Electric Psychologist

Paragraph: Among the combatants, robots faced each other one on one, in classes from lightweight (made of aluminum or strong plastic) to heavyweight (steel or titanium), with the winner of each round advancing. To win a round, a robot had to render its opponent helpless, often by ramming it into the arena walls or by whacking it with weapons like whirling mini-maces or lawn-mower blades.
Title: In This Coliseum, Robots Fight to the Final Spark

Paragraph: Mir has been aloft for 11 years, but it registered in the popular consciousness only in June, when a robot supply ship collided with the station's science laboratory. The collision punctured and depressurized the laboratory compartment, forcing the crew to cut power cables that had been jury-rigged and strung through an open door that now had to be closed. The accident left Mir with only partial power and its science lab out of commission.
Title: A Valuable Space Jalopy

Paragraph: The subject of chatterbots gets Mr. Leonard into artificial intelligence and the Turing Test, which poses a challenge to the computer to convince a judge communicating with it by teletype that it is human. Mr. Leonard points out that when people don't know that a bot may be talking to them -- as is often the case in, say, chat rooms -- they are much more likely to be fooled. This can be useful if the bot's intentions are benign. But if the bot is programmed to be destructive, it has the potential for great harm.
Title: Bumping Around Cyberspace: The Evolution, Virtual or Otherwise, of Bots
Other (negative): An AI programmed to be destructive can cause great harm

Paragraph: The Discovery astronauts plan to test a new miniature shuttle robot arm designed by Japanese scientists for the international space station, on which construction work in space is to begin next year. The $87 million arm features very fine control and is about five feet long, compared with the 60-foot arm on the space shuttles.
Title: Space Shuttle Blasts Off and Deploys a Scientific Satellite
Other (positive): does dangerous work instead of humans

Paragraph: The mood-squashing robot is not some sort of mechanized Mrs. Grundy. It is a bot -- an artificial intelligence program designed to perform simple chores. This one is specifically a clonebot, rogue software purposely invented to wreak havoc by self-replicating and rudely interrupting live interaction in Internet chat areas. Writing in a blend of English and cyberjargon, Leonard cleverly uses ''Bots'' as a vehicle to explore the psychology and anthropology of popular technology. His relaxed yet knowledgeable tone occasionally borders on a note of cynical whimsy about the whole artificial intelligence phenomenon. ''Any culture that can go mad over pet rocks,'' he dryly observes, ''can certainly fall in love with a computer program.''
Title: Virtual Bedlam
Other (negative): self-replicate, spam trollbot? odd either way

Paragraph: That was the challenge faced by robots created by 330 schools across the country at the National First Robotics Competition in Orlando, Fla., last week, and a robot built by 30 students at Rice High School in Harlem, a Roman Catholic school better known for basketball than academics, came in 11th out of 84 schools in its division. In March, the Rice team, helped by engineers from Consolidated Edison, won the New York City regional competition.
Title: BULLETIN BOARD
Other (positive): contest encourages AI advances, academia supports AI education

Paragraph: The robot was created to fulfill a dream: laying fiber-optic cable within city sewer systems. Owned by CityNet Telecommunications Inc., a new company in Silver Spring, Md., the device, which looks a little like the unlikely offspring of a dachshund and an Electrolux vacuum cleaner, is on its first American mission. If all works as planned, efforts like this promise sweet relief to Americans nationwide who have sacrificed their shock absorbers, wheels and lower backs to streets turned into washboards by companies cutting and repaving streets to lay the ''last mile'' of fiber-optic cable. Robots do not take humans out of the muck entirely, however. Somebody has to get the robot into the manholes, to build in the ''slack boxes'' that allow the connections from the fiber-optic network into buildings, and to take on other tasks, sometimes unpleasant. It's a dirty job, but somebody's got to do it. I put on the boots, a white hard hat, disposable overalls and gloves; a snug harness and cable tether me to the surface world. After workers have laid the robot at the mouth of a pipe that opens onto either side of the shaft, I go down for a look.
Title: Wiring the City: Humans Won't Do
Other (positive): protects cars and people from damage of driving through road construction

Paragraph: Chart: ''NASA''  +1.4% from 2001  Discretionary spending authority, in billions  '01: $14.3  '02: 14.5    Would cancel some programs, including a robot mission to Pluto  Would keep level spending for International Space Station
Title: Who Gets What Slice of the President's First Federal Budget Pie
Other (positive): exploration, research

Paragraph: ''Being hospitalized can be very stressful for children, and we are trying to put them more at ease by using techniques like these,'' said Dr. Akimitsu Yokoyama, a psychiatrist who runs the robot therapy program at Yamato Municipal Hospital, one of several in Japan. ''Children who are repeatedly hospitalized must constantly make new friends. But for them to know that the same Aibo they had befriended during their last visit will be there is very comforting.''
Title: Yamato Journal; Rover's Just a Robot, but a Great Pal for All That
Other (positive): robot surrogate for social connection

Paragraph: Edwards is not a robot who automatically follows archaic thinking. He is new blood, and his deal with his players has paid huge dividends, as was evident last night in a 29-28 victory over the Indianapolis Colts.
Title: Sunny Winter Skies In Edwards's Reign

Paragraph: Mr. Wiprud got into his field of expertise when an engineering firm required footage of sewers. Mr. Wiprud did not do the filming himself. The cinematographer was a robot on treads, with a rotating camera and lights. Mr. Wiprud sat in a mobile TV studio and made certain the robot was getting it right. That led to reading and mapping manhole covers and underground utilities. Often, in addition to studying maps, Mr. Wiprud must climb down a manhole or direct a dig.
Title: Holmes Had His Pipe. This Sleuth Has Thousands.

Paragraph: It may not live up to its predecessors, but George Lucas's STAR WARS EPISODE I - THE PHANTOM MENACE (1999) has a few special effects - like the bigger-and-bigger fish and the robot army - that take even nonfanatics' breath away. The young Eric Lloyd plays the young Anakin Skywalker, who will eventually succumb to the Dark Side. His co-stars include Liam Neeson, Ewan Mc Gregor and Natalie Portman - Sunday at 7 p.m. on Channel 5.
Title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE

Paragraph: Dictionary of the Future, by Faith Popcorn and Adam Hanft (Hyperion, $22.95), is the cheery ''speak preview'' product of a couple of marketing futurists. They create words like geriborg, a robot built to make old age easier for ''baby boomers growing old in the digital age'' with never-hungry electronic dogs wagging their feather tails, ever ready to take out the garbage. Sinister hacktivists flood computer servers with denial-of-service attacks, while old-fashioned spamming is blocked by address munging, ''modifying one's e-mail address in such a way that computers can't read it but humans can.'' My favorite description of a growing annoyance is secondhand speech, ''the cellphone equivalent of secondhand smoke.''
Title: Gifts Of Gab

Paragraph: Some of the cinematic sequences are quite good, notably a jazz-scored appearance by a seemingly supernatural villain named Fortune, who repeatedly screams ''kill me'' as bullets swerve around her, and the first appearance of Metal Solid Ray, a gigantic robot tank that dives into the ocean like a monster from an old Japanese science-fiction movie. The story is confused but fairly interesting, and some of the dialogue is clever, but so much time is spent with the game controller in your lap that you soon come to dread the next plot development. A good editor could have helped this game a lot.
Title: Stealing Cars and Telling Stories

Paragraph: DIGITAL PETS -- Aibo the robot dog by Sony was, and is, a remarkable machine. Useless, but remarkable. It can walk on its own -- seeing with cameras, hearing with microphones, thinking with software. It can even learn new tricks.
Title: Year of Living Geekily: Even the Dogs Evolved
Other (negative): useless machine although remarkable
Other (positive): obot dog by Sony was, and is, a remarkable machine, can entertain on it's own by doing everything itself  Robotic pets

Paragraph: Engineers at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory near Pasadena, Calif., sent a signal to the robot spacecraft at 3:15 p.m. Eastern time, ordering it to shut down its ion propulsion engine and stop communicating with Earth. After executing final orders, the last transmission from the craft ended nine seconds after 4 p.m., while it was 86.5 million miles away, in orbit between Earth and Mars.
Title: Deep Space 1 Ends Mission, But Triumphs Are Clear

Paragraph: A close runner-up is Thierry Mugler's 1995 robot couture cyborg suit, an armored bodysuit made of chrome-plated Fiberglas with clear plastic panels in all the right places. Another strong finisher is right next to it: an anatomically accurate sterling silver bustier by Mr. McQueen for Givenchy Haute Couture. It extends from waistline to jaw line and erupts with silver roses, like something out of a Frida Kahlo painting.
Title: For a Body That Nobody Ever Had

Paragraph: ''I was born a compulsive builder,'' Mr. Tilden said. ''I made my first robot out of sticks and rubber bands when I was 3.''
Title: Toyland Is Tough, Even for Robots

Paragraph: Several companies, including Fisher-Price and Toy Biz, are rolling out computerized canines this spring and fall, following in the path of Sony's Aibo (pronounced EYE-bo), a limited production robot dog that cost $2,500.
Title: Plenty of Barks and Bytes, No Housebreaking Required

Paragraph: The new machine is meant to go where no firefighter has gone, investigating factory floors, for instance, for explosive chemicals and removing them with a remote-controlled grapple before people enter to tackle the blaze. ''You can put a host of attachments on the front of the machine and then control them remotely,'' said Nigel Chell, a spokesman for the manufacturer, J. C. Bamford Excavators in Cheadle, England. ''The robot has the potential to save lives.'' The robot is an adaptation of a skid steer loader -- a small, maneuverable vehicle used for excavating and grading. The machine, built to withstand temperatures up to 800 degrees Celsius, replaces the driver's seat with a high-pressure water system. Cameras on top of the vehicle transmit pictures to a control room, so watchers can spot potential hazards like gas cylinders and remove them.   ANNE EISENBERG
Title: Robot Takes Some Danger Out of Firefighting
Other (positive): Firefighting saves lives by doing dangerous jobs  excavating and grading, takes danger out of firefighting robot helps in warehouse

Paragraph: * ''FAST, CHEAP AND OUT OF CONTROL,'' directed by Errol Morris (PG, 82 minutes). Brilliant, ruminative documentaries by the director of ''The Thin Blue Line'' and ''A Brief History of Time'' are always worth waiting for. This time, contemplating the mysterious intersection of nature and human design, he interweaves the work of four inspired eccentrics -- a lion tamer, a topiary gardener, a scientist studying social behavior of the naked mole-rat, and a robot designer -- into a haunting and poetic exploration of creative imagination. Always invigorating, never pedantic or dry, Mr. Morris brings wisdom, wit, quirkiness and a metaphysical overview to this eerily beautiful meditation. At the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village (Maslin).
Title: Movie Guide
Other (positive): about a documentary

Paragraph: A Short List of Technology I Could Easily Live Without: TV zappers, the VCR, running shoes that look as if they have pool floats for soles, artificial intelligence, morphing, olestra, miracle-fiber shoelaces that come undone even when you double-knot. Recently, every historic place I went in Vienna a man was lurking in the doorway shouting into his cell phone. If these babies are such technological wonders, why do people have to scream into them? The $2 billion Stealth bomber couldn't tell the difference between a mountain and a cloud? The last time I checked, a pilot could.
Title: Lives; Technology Makes Me Mad
Other (negative): Ai is irritating

Paragraph: The Smithsonian Institution is creating a robot that not only is user-friendly but also looks user-friendly too: it can smile and even offer candy to strangers. In addition to refining the robot itself, the scientists also hope Minerva will help children feel comfortable with technology and familiarize them with robots. To prepare children for the new technology, they are relying on an old-fashioned trick: a box of candy will be placed on board the robot to encourage youngsters to approach.
Title: Smithsonian Robot to Have A Kid-Friendly Sweet Touch
Other (positive): robot greeter at Smithsonian

Paragraph: When Dogz are thirsty, their tongues hang out and their eyes sort of plead. The dialogue bar flashes ''Quench your Petz' thirst with some cool, refreshing water.'' So you set the water bowl down, and the little fella runs over to it. The computer executes the ''dog lapping water'' sound file. And the pup looks happy and licks your cursor, and you feel swell. Dogz know how to deliver the emotional payoff that motivates users -- behind those adorable little muzzles is some rather sophisticated artificial intelligence code. And it's training you.
Title: Putting a Virtual Doggy in Your Window

Paragraph: Matthew L. Ginsberg, a University of Oregon professor who does research in artificial intelligence, is the creator of the GIB, which stands for Ginsberg Intelligent Bridge Player (www.gibware.com). Professor Ginsberg plans to start shipping the software commercially on Oct. 1 with a price tag of about $80.
Title: Artificial Intelligence Program Tries Its Hand at Cards

Paragraph: DR. MARVIN MINSKY, 71, a rumpled-looking man who wears shirts mended with masking tape, is Toshiba professor of media arts and sciences and professor of electrical engineering and computer sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and one of the world's leading theorists of artificial intelligence. In the late 1950's, Dr. Minsky and John McCarthy, a professor of computer science at Stanford University, founded a research program that would evolve into the MIT Artificial Intelligence Laboratory. In addition to inventing and building thinking machines, Dr. Minsky wrote the classic ''The Society of Mind,'' (Simon & Schuster, 1986) in which he tries to show how intelligence works ''by the particular way the agents in the brain have evolved to interact.'' ''The Turing Option,'' (Warner Books, 1992) a novel by Dr. Minsky and Harry Harrison, is about superintelligence in not-too-far-off 2023. Q. In the 1960's, science students, particularly those at M.I.T., talked of artificial intelligence, or A.I., as if it would create world revolution. Were they too optimistic? A. Well, it got stuck. A.I. was able to produce all kinds of wonderful things . . . programs that did better than the average stockbroker or portfolio manager, programs that could fix some piece of equipment. Around 1980, progress stopped in some ways and people went off in a number of other directions to try to find some way to get back. It stopped because we'd done the easy things. In the eye of eternity, it got stuck for a moment. Photo: Dr. Marvin Minsky, one of the leading theorists of artificial intelligence, at his home in Brookline, Mass. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)
Title: A CONVERSATION: With Dr. Marvin Minsky; Why Isn't Artificial Intelligence More Like the Real Thing?
Other (positive): AI would create world revolution

Paragraph: The United States fielded remote-controlled, pilotless aircraft in the Persian Gulf War and in Bosnia. The smallest such operational craft available today in the military inventory is an electric-powered, 10-pound craft called Sender. The robot aircraft, with a four-foot wing span and the ability to fly up to 100 miles, can carry a 2.5-pound payload.
Title: Tiny Spies to Take Off for War and Rescue

Paragraph: The new paper, she said, would be a 50-50 joint venture of Distribution Systems of America, a Newsday subsidiary, and AI Holding Corporation, of Union City, N.J., whose principals publish El Especial, the regional Spanish-language weekly. El Especial's publisher, Antonio Ibarria, would be Hoy's publisher, Ms. Scovel said. He could not be reached at El Especial's Union City offices yesterday.
Title: Newsday to Start Publishing A Spanish-Language Paper

Paragraph: The Spartan, being carried by Discovery, is a 3,000-pound, battery-powered satellite that has been flown on four previous shuttle missions. The satellite, which is deployed from the shuttle's cargo bay by an astronaut using the orbiter's 50-foot robot arm, flies free of the shuttle at a distance of 70 to 100 miles to conduct its operations. At the end of two days, the shuttle retrieves the satellite using the arm and returns it to Earth so that scientists can retrieve its data from tape recorders. A NASA inquiry found that the fourth Spartan flight failed because astronauts aboard the shuttle did not send a crucial command to activate the craft's control system and then accidentally struck the satellite with the robot arm, sending it tumbling out of control. Two astronauts made an emergency space walk three days later and caught the satellite.
Title: Two Satellites to Study Sun During Discovery Mission

Paragraph: If Nebraska does win big, B.C.S. officials are in for a tense Saturday night wondering whether artificial intelligence will override the votes and wisdom of the coaches and news media polls -- also components of the formula -- both of which say Virginia Tech is the No. 2 team.
Title: Polls and Pundits Hold Answers

Paragraph: For those wondering when artificial intelligence will truly take root, here's a bulletin: it already has. But Mr. Pollack knows better than most that although yesterday's release of the futuristic film ''A.I.'' is likely to stir up such fears, artificial intelligence has already seeped into many corners of daily life. Just how much of a living is anybody's guess. ''I haven't seen an estimate of the market value of A.I. products in years because it's become part of the landscape,'' said Curt Hall, a software analyst with the Cutter Consortium, a research firm in Arlington, Mass., who has followed the technology since the 1980's. The numbers are elusive in part because artificial intelligence is spread across a variety of disciplines that overlap and, in some cases, start from conflicting premises about how humans think. They include the ability to understand and manipulate language; make sense of what can be seen, heard or felt; find useful patterns in data; and draw conclusions based on rules and experience. Other attributes include an ability to respond to environmental changes without human intervention or evolve through selecting the best results from random mutation. Most computer experts expect public fascination with artificial intelligence to surge with the fanfare surrounding the release of ''A.I.: Artificial Intelligence,'' the sci-fi film vision of Stanley Kubrick and Steven Spielberg that some have described as Pinocchio meets robotics. Some suspect the impact will be comparable to 1968, when Kubrick's ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' made HAL the world-famous symbol of deadly thinking machines. Today's theatergoers will emerge with a reality check all around them, in the form of numerous university programs that teach artificial intelligence and the many businesses that embed such concepts in their products. But the artificial-intelligence world is so fragmented that some experts fear the film will leave many people with mistaken notions that could slow development. Similarly, some vendors of intelligent software fear that an explosion of interest could produce a flood of shaky business schemes and products dressed up as artificial intelligence. ''When you get the circus, you get the clowns,'' said Konrad Feldman, head of American operations of Searchspace, a British vendor of multimillion-dollar software agents that continually examine databases and online activity. Others are more hopeful, suggesting that ''A.I.'' might awaken venture capitalists to the commercial potential of research projects in controversial areas like the emotional dimensions of machine intelligence. The film asks what would become of a childlike robot programmed to love a human mother. As unnerving as the results depicted are for both the robots and humans, researchers said ''A.I.'' could build support for today's more mundane goals of using programmed emotional capabilities to make Web sites, tutorial software and products like cars more responsive and engaging.
Title: Artificial Intelligence For the New Millennium; A Revolution More Bland Than Kubrick's '2001'
Other (negative): philosophical conflict within AI field    AI depicted on film creates false impression Mistaken notions that will slow development   humans using it for nefarious purposes
Other (positive): Business should increase  an ability to respond to environmental changes without human intervention, understand and manipulate language; make sense of what can be seen, heard or felt, find useful patterns in data, draw conclusions based on rules and experience           emotional capabilities

Paragraph: /features/?feature_id=16381) for ''A.I.,'' a Steven Spielberg film about artificial intelligence that will be released on June 29. Watch the trailer carefully. Watch it again. One more time. See anything? Look harder. Using an Internet search engine, you can locate a site where you'll learn that Dr. Salla is a professor in the artificial intelligence department of a university founded in 2028. She specializes in robot intelligence. After visiting the Web site of Dr. Salla's university, you will find other connected Web sites, all painting a disturbing picture of the future. A robot emancipation site bitterly denounces the Supreme Court's recent Dred Scot II decision, which asserts that intelligent robots are only property. The Anti-Robot Militia, on the other hand, calls for solidarity against the robot hordes. ''It's not the color of your skin that's important,'' a poster proclaims, ''it's the flesh inside.''
Title: Tracking an Elusive Film Game Online

Paragraph: The patented software uses artificial intelligence intended to detect and expose viruses that have not been seen before, and then alert an I.B.M. data center, where the new virus is analyzed. Warnings, information to identify the virus, and antidotes are then sent across I.B.M.'s own network and the Internet. The patent uses artificial intelligence technology called neural networks, which mimic the way people learn, interpret information and apply lessons from experience. ''In the learning phase, we build neural network classifiers,'' Mr. Kephart said. ''We start from scratch. We present the computer with a whole bunch of viruses and nonviruses and say, O.K., you figure it out.

Paragraph: STEFFI GRAF trounced AI SUGIYAMA of Japan, 6-0, 6-1, in the third round Monday night. Graf, who is ranked 45th but seeded third based on the ranking she held when she left the circuit last year because of knee surgery, was visibly impressed, and relieved, after her rout of the 11th-seeded Sugiyama. ''It felt great that I was going for my shots, played very hard, very deep,'' said Graf, who needed just 43 minutes to advance to play NATASHA ZVEREVA. Graf, who had not won three successive matches since last May, said she was drawing no assumptions from her steady progress and was in no hurry to test herself against MARTINA HINGIS, the player who supplanted her at the top. ''I'm very much aware that I'm going to need time,'' Graf said. ''Hey, I'm just starting again. I don't see myself being able to be at that level right now.''
Title: The New and Improved Agassi Is Working Harder to Succeed

Paragraph: What does loom, then, on Burrows's space horizon? He raises tourism, mining and manned missions to Mars, only to knock them down as currently impractical. Approvingly he presents a proposal by the physicist Freeman Dyson for ''Astrochickens'' -- small, self-replicating, exploratory spacecraft combining ''21st-century genetic engineering, advanced artificial intelligence and solar electric propulsion.'' These craft also want development, but at least they conjure an imagined future that is truly original, rather than a tired repackaging of the first space age. Paragraph: This is true. Jay is on the edge, of windows, of ivy walls, a man who never graduated from high school but managed to make his way into M.I.T., where he was mentored by Marvin Minsky, the father of artificial intelligence. In 1968, Jay began an art project called Extended Credentials, for which he illegitimately obtained the birth certificates of babies born in the years 1943 to 1945 who soon died, used the birth certificates to get Social Security numbers and then set about creating passports, driver's licenses and assorted official documents for the deceased. It was all a brazen attempt to question the modern construction of identity. He turned the work into a performance piece, showing the birth certificates and other forged documents and acting out the dead babies' lives as he imagined them. The underlying message being, what makes us real? Is life essentially dramaturgic? How do we differentiate the phony from the authentic? He kept the project going until he was arrested by the F.B.I. in 1972 for fraud.
Title: Pills Will Keep Us Together

Paragraph: Reading a short story by Chekhov, a poem by Hart Crane, a novel by Jane Austen or a play by Shakespeare is an activity only minimally visual. The tyranny of the bodily eye is usurped by the inner ear, which is a metaphor for the mind exercising all its powers. I am not a Luddite, and am aware that there may prove to be -- even in my own remaining lifetime -- no clear limits to artificial intelligence. Computers may yet read, write, think, speak in ways transcending their programming. The epics and romances of artificial intelligence may inundate us and be no better or worse than the breaking wave of publish-your-own-manuscript e-books. But a screen remains a screen, and a printed book is something other than a container, if its content is Jane Austen or Shakespeare. Mr. Crichton does not contain the reader. Shakespeare paradoxically does. If what we read is ''Pride and Prejudice'' or ''Hamlet,'' we need to hold it rather more individually than a screen, by its very nature, can permit.
Title: On First Looking Into Gates's Crichton
Other (negative): inherent limitations of AI in arts AI is incapable of human artistry

Paragraph: Microsoft maintains that everything it is being asked to do is impractical. That is for the courts to decide. But Mr. Gates must know better than to assert that the Government's demands are the equivalent of asking Coca Cola to include cans of Pepsi in all its six-packs. Coca Cola is not a monopoly, but Microsoft's operating system is. It would be better if Mr. Gates recognized that reality and stopped behaving as if his company were still a struggling upstart. As he said yesterday, the world awaits an era of accelerating change in computers, with undreamed-of products in voice recognition, artificial intelligence and Internet commerce. Paragraph: From San Francisco to Japan, Web robots run the gamut, from the sublime (painting) to the mundane (toy trains). One allowed students to interact with robots at the site of the Titanic wreckage. Another was developed so NASA scientists could control the Pathfinder mission on Mars from around the world. In fact, the Web robot world is mature enough to have critical mass: in October, the first international conference in the field was held in Canada. If Webcams took the central nervous system of the Internet and gave it eyes, then Web robots have completed the body. With the increased sophistication of Internet programs like CGI, which is used to update Web page information rapidly, and Java, which can relay tiny packets of information between computers, it became easier for a home PC to issue complex commands to a machine somewhere else. By most accounts, the first two Web robots started up almost simultaneously (although independently) in 1994. One was a six-legged robot bearing a camera at the University of Western Australia, the other a robot arm with a camera that dug buried artifacts out of a sandbox at the University of California at Berkeley. Humanizing the Net with this sort of interactive art is also the ambition behind Puma Paint, the Web robot at Wilkes University. Mr. Stein, an associate professor of mechanical engineering, initiated the project after creating an on-line telerobotic exercise between his students and a group at the University of Wisconsin. Then, Mr. Stein said in a telephone interview, ''I became curious about what we as a community of Web surfers would do with a blank canvas and the ability to paint it.''
Title: Web Robots Offer Hands-On Experience From Afar

Paragraph: KNOWN to American television viewers as Astro Boy, Tetsuwan Atom was one of the earliest icons of cuteness in Japan, a country preoccupied with youthful paraphernalia. The wide-eyed robot with a nuclear-reactor heart and rockets in his feet launched Japan's first animated television show in the 1960's. Atom was created by the comic-book artist Osamu Tezuka, and he spent each episode battling evil robots and supernatural phenomena that threatened to wipe out the human race. Like Atom, Mr. Yanobe's sculptures are friendly, unthreatening beings. There's a babyishness to their tubby profiles. ''Atom was a robot who was trying to be more human, a sort of Pinocchio robot,'' says Frederik Schodt, author of ''Dreamland Japan: Writings on Modern Manga.''  ''He established the tradition in Japan of the robot-as-pal, or human friend, which remains a very big genre for children.''
Title: An Appreciation of Cute Finds a Niche in High Art
Other (positive): about Manga robots viewed as social companions

Paragraph: For instance, in a very simple, early mission, the robot has to touch a flag and return to home base. The task breaks down into two states: ''find flag'' and ''go home.'' In Duel Mode, for instance, the goal is to disable another robot before it disables you. The hardware options available include grenade- and tennis-ball launchers, lasers, a force-field generator, a crossbow, a cloaking device, pogo springs, hover pods and a banana gun, all of which consume varying amounts of energy and do varying amounts of short, medium and long-range damage. The options are virtually limitless. It boils down to personal style. These virtual machines aren't robots in the 1950's science-fiction sense. But in a way, they are the ultimate robots because they are pure programming. And programming is the only thing that distinguishes a robot from a run-of-the-mill machine. The reality of robots is factory work. But the robot of popular imagination is a machine that shows signs of intelligent life, not a machine that methodically sucks the air out of vacuum-packed grocery items. Things like Web crawlers, intelligent agents and artificial life forms -- automata that have shed their electromechanical coils -- are much closer to our idea of ''robot'' than the real robots. Virtual machines that do the tedious work of gathering data, updating files, tidying up our hard drives, fetching and carrying information, and catering to our whims -- these are the heirs of our sci-fi imagination.
Title: To Field a Fighting Robot, Learn to Program
Other (positive): military application

Paragraph: Yet what of that more common writer's madness that calls to mind a windup robot that hits the wall and keeps walking? In ''Middlemarch,'' George Eliot limned the futility of vast totalizing projects, and in Mr. Casaubon, with his emotional illiteracy and blinkered devotion to an impossible ''Key to All Mythologies,'' she created one of literature's first cases of Asperger's syndrome. Of course, all that distinguishes Eliot, who wrote many novels, from Mr. Casaubon, who never finished his ''Key,'' is the saving grace of the imagination.
Title: Writers on Writing; Comforting Lessons In Arranging Life's Details

Title: Meeting to Study New Facets of Microelectronic Industry

Paragraph: The project robot consists of a mobile platform equipped with infrared sensors and an ultrasonic ranging device that help it navigate. A rod fixed to the platform supports a mechanical device that serves as the robot's arm. The robot can adjust its arm level to the height of the shelf it needs to reach. Attached to the arm is a gripper designed to grasp a single book. A bar code scanner inside the gripper tells the robot whether it is retrieving the right book. Robots are already being used in a handful of libraries around the world, although none of them perform the complicated tasks for which the Johns Hopkins robot is being designed. At the main library of California State University at Northridge, an automated system retrieves boxes of books from a storage site and takes them to a processing station where a library worker picks out requested items. A robotic system manufactured by ABB, a Finnish automation company, and installed at a municipal library in Vaasa, Finland, takes items dropped off by users out of a bin and sorts them by subject.
Title: In Remote Library Stacks, an All-Seeing, Scanning Robot

Paragraph: Like all computer scientists, Wallace knew about a famous ''chat-bot'' experiment called Eliza. Back in 1966, an M.I.T. professor, Joseph Weizenbaum, created Eliza as a ''virtual therapist'' -- it would take a user's statement and turn it around as a question, emulating a psychiatrist's often-maddening circularity. (You: ''I'm mad at my mother.'' Eliza: ''Why are you mad at your mother?'') Eliza was quickly abandoned as a joke, even by its creator. It wasn't what scientists call ''strong'' A.I. -- able to learn on its own. It could only parrot lines Weizenbaum had fed it.
Title: Approximating Life
Other (positive): chat-bot

Paragraph: Because the composer is Tod Machover, who, perhaps more than anyone else, is identified with new computer-music possibilities, science-fiction opera, artificial intelligence manifested in sound. He is known for his 1988 opera, ''Valis,'' arguably the most famous achievement in operatic science fiction, which traces the story of a Philip K. Dick novel with rock beats and hallucinogenic synthesizer riffs. He is known for his ''hyperinstruments,'' like the computerized cello on which Yo-Yo Ma performed, each movement of his arm triggering great washes of sound rising through stacks of loudspeakers.
Title: An Opera Lures a Futurist Back to the Present

Paragraph: Photo: The Russian-made Zarya control module, top, and the American-made Unity module, along with a robot arm, successfully linked yesterday about 240 miles above the Earth. The modules are the first components of what will eventually be an international space station. Page A14. (Associated Press/NASA TV)
Title: A Historic Rendezvous in Space
Other (positive): space exploration

Paragraph: Three books on artificial intelligence say the age of machines smarter than people is nigh, but they differ on how pleasant it will be.  BOOK REVIEW
Title: INSIDE

Paragraph: H. Joseph Perrin, AI 11,866 1%
Title: The Races for the U.S. Senate

Paragraph: Between the sweatshop operators and the romantic poets, the meaning of Luddite became fixed as ''radical opponent of technological or scientific progress.'' The novelist Thomas Pynchon wrote in The New York Times in 1984, ''The word Luddite continues to be applied with contempt to anyone with doubts about technology, especially the nuclear kind.'' But he foresaw the day when ''artificial intelligence, molecular biology and robotics all converge'' and found what Microsoft lawyers claim to be government barbarians at their Gates as ''certainly something for all good Luddites to look forward to, if, God willing, we should live so long.''
Title: On Language; Return of The Luddites
Other (negative): references Luddites

Paragraph: The importance of machine vision goes beyond its commercial value, Mr. Molella said. ''What's more important is the path it has opened toward artificial intelligence and robotics in general,'' he said. ''It has fed the imagination as well as the assembly lines.'' A robot with a machine vision system can be built and programmed to perform a wide range tasks: picking up a single bolt from a jumble on a conveyor belt and screwing it into an engine block, automatically discarding a defective soda bottle in a production line or placing a needle on the hub of a speedometer moving down a conveyor belt and pointing it exactly to zero. Machine vision systems use video cameras and perceive objects by using mathematical approaches that look for patterns in pixelated video images. Many of the mathematical formulas were developed decades ago. Chart/Diagram: ''Digital Sentries on the Production Line''  Machine vision is useful in manufacturing and quality control because it can detect subtle defects in products in less time than human inspectors or direct robots in specific tasks. A bottling company, for example, may use machine vision to insure that containers are sound or that labels are affixed correctly. Here's how it works.    A sensor triggers a frame grabber, which grabs a picture of each bottle as it  moves in front of the video camera. Image data are transmitted to a computer where a reference image of what a bottle should look like is stored. Software on the computer then looks for differences in pixel patterns between the reference image and the image of the bottle being inspected. If variations are too extreme, a message is transmitted to the production line to reject the bottle.    Most machine-vision applications use a standard 640-by-480 pixel grid for comparing images. Each pixel is one of up to 256 shades of gray, allowing the computer to register more subtle variations between images than the human eye, which can typically distinguish only 64 shades of gray.    1. A CAMERA photographs a bottle with a defective label.    2. Moments later, the bottle travels by the REJECT MODULE and is removed.    DETECTING ERRORS    Inspecting Labels  In this case, the computer knows from the reference image that the pixels at or around row 210 should be darker than those in previous rows, indicating the top edge of the label.    To make sure that the label is straight, the computer identifies two points along the label edge. If they are separated by more than a predetermined number of pixel rows, the bottle is rejected.    Inspecting Bottles  Imperfections in a bottle are identified by matching brightness values in the reference image with those in the inspection image. The reference image establishes a pattern of dark and light pixels for the neck of the bottle, for example. Values for the bottle being inspected are subtracted from the values in the inspection image, revealing any defects.    Reference Image  An image of what the area being inspected (in this case, the neck of the bottle) should look like is stored in the computer's memory.    Inspection Image  The camera on the assembly line is trained at the same area as the inspection image.    Comparison  Mathematical formulas are used to compute pixel variations between the reference and inspection images. If there are too many differences, the bottle is discarded.    ANOTHER APPROACH: FINDING JUST THE RIGHT PART  More advanced applications can discern objects, enabling a robot arm to grab parts off a conveyor belt and assemble them. Software searches for patterns in pixels indicating lines and arcs, and notes their relationship. Lines and arcs are compared with the reference image for geometric similarities. Sophisticated mathematical formulas enable the computer to recognize a part and send a signal to pick it up even when it is obscured by shadow or an overlapping object.    The software looks for sharp differences in pixel values, which suggest edges.    An object can be recognized even if the lighting conditions change or half of it is hidden under another object.    Diagrams illustrate the technologies    (Source: Cognex)(Illustrations by Mika Grondahl and Tom Zeller/The New York Times)
Title: Machine Vision: Narrowing the Gap Between Human and Robot
Other (positive): science and technology development support AI  automates work, stimulates mind

Paragraph: The main objective was to install two, 100-pound communications antennas on opposite sides of the American-made Unity connecting module. The astronauts wrestled with the suitcase-size antennas as they pulled them through a narrow tunnel into the cargo bay. Then, with Colonel Ross riding the shuttle's robot arm and Dr. Newman moving up the side of the module on a tether line, they moved the antennas halfway up the 35-foot-tall module.
Title: 2 Astronauts Make 2d Space Walk to Install Antennas on Station

Paragraph: The spacewalkers will also assist Ms. Ivins as she uses the robot arm to attach the docking port to the end of Destiny, giving future shuttle missions another place to dock.
Title: NASA Set to Deliver Station's Scientific Core

Paragraph: If hypochondriacs at work make unrealistic demands, it is the stoics who pose the real challenge to management. At the International Truck and Engine Corporation plant in Indianapolis, Kenneth Jones's task was to lift a 15-pound oil pan, put an adapter on it for the dipstick and then place it on a table for a robot to pick up -- 300 times a shift.
Title: Battling Job-Related Aches and Pains

Paragraph: About six months ago, Dr. Adkins was asked to work on the robot by Dr. Ed Heller, another researcher at Sandia, in Albuquerque. In 1996, Dr. Heller helped build a self-contained robot known as the Mini Autonomous Robot Vehicle, or MARV, that was one cubic inch. That was about as small as robots could be built using conventional parts and fabricating technology. One of the breakthroughs in making something even smaller had more to do with careful shopping than engineering. The robot needed a microprocessor, which is not in itself heavy or bulky. But microprocessors have a protective shell and tiny wires that account for about 80 percent of the microprocessor's volume, Dr. Adkins said. To build the robot body, the researchers turned to a relatively new technique called stereolithography. It starts with a type of epoxy resin that cures only when zapped with a specific color of laser light. Once Dr. Adkins had a computer-generated design for the robot bodies, lasers in Sandia's stereolithography laboratory began building it up with layers of epoxy, each one six-thousandths of an inch thick. About a dozen bodies were made, but they are not much to look at. ''They're the color of natural epoxy, like the stuff you get at Home Depot,'' Dr. Adkins said. For now, that means the minirobot can  follow a simple programmed route over and around coins at a sedate 20 inches a minute. One of its performances can be viewed at www.sandia.gov/media/NewsRel/NR2001 /images/MicroRobotDemo2.MPG. (Much to Dr. Adkins' dismay, a nervous Dr. Heller repeatedly prods the robot with a pair of tweezers in that video.) Recently a heat sensor was added, so now the robot's array includes backing up when confronted by a heat gun.
Title: The Incredible Shrinking Robot, Self-Contained and Untethered

Paragraph: Dr. Geoffrey E. Hinton, researcher, artificial intelligence, University College, London
Title: Minds Meet Online to Offer New Perspectives on Old Questions

Paragraph: Dr. Shannon's later work on chess-playing machines and an electronic mouse that could run a maze helped create the field of artificial intelligence, the effort to make machines that think. And his ability to combine abstract thinking with a practical approach -- he had a penchant for building machines -- inspired a generation of computer scientists.
Title: Claude Shannon, Mathematician, Dies at 84

Paragraph: MILAN, Aug. 20                     Pirelli, one of Europe's leading tire companies, said yesterday that it had opened its first United States tire factory fitted with a robot system that cuts production time. Pirelli makes 18 percent of Europe's high-performance tires. Demand for top-of-the-line tires is growing as much as 15 percent a year, compared with 1 percent for the global tire market, the company said. Pirelli installed its first robot system two years ago in Milan.
Title: Georgia Tire Plant Opens
Other (positive): does work faster

Paragraph: Meanwhile, the police opened the trunk of Rosario Musca's car and discovered the cans of gasoline wrapped in plastic bags. Fearing they were linked to some trigger and might be a bomb, the police called in the arson-bomb squad, which brought a robot to the scene. The robot removed the gasoline, and no bomb was found.
Title: A Family Feud Erupts in Bullets and Flames in a Long Island Home
Other (positive): bomb disposal

Paragraph: ''Mind Catcher'' fully discharges its obligation to generate suspense. But after putting it down, the thoughtful reader might wonder: just what is the mind-catching process that the author is trying to evoke? Is it really a matter of the brain's software being uploaded into a computer? That's the fantasy of the real-life artificial intelligence theorists whose names crop up in the book, figures like Hans Moravec and Ray Kurzweil.
Title: A Boy's Essence Uploaded And Adrift in Cyberspace

Paragraph: But some nanotechnology experts consider that plea naïve and self-defeating. Because nanotechnology is gaining momentum from the convergence of advances in genetics, robotics and artificial intelligence, it has become an unstoppable force, said Douglas Mulhall, author of the recently published ''Our Molecular Future'' (Prometheus Books). ''A moratorium isn't going to happen,'' Mr. Mulhall said, ''so it's the wrong thing for environmentalists to focus on.''
Title: New Economy; Nanotechnology has arrived; a serious opposition is forming.

Paragraph: It takes relatively sophisticated vision for a robot to distinguish its owner's face from those of other humans, and recognizing a particular voice is a big jump from simply learning commands, said Douglas Thomas, an associate professor of communications at the University of Southern California.
Title: A Robotic Pet Gains an Independent Streak

Paragraph: Nomad, a car-size robot on wheels, is being judged as a form of intelligent life by how it searches for another form of life. Nomad's job is to identify meteorites by using its robot arms and a mounted spectrometer, distinguishing them from ordinary rocks. That is something no robot has previously accomplished. Nomad, which was created at the Robotics Institute at Carnegie Mellon University, began its mission on Jan. 17 and enjoyed success in its first week in the field. It has since identified five meteorites.
Title: Accompanying a Robot on an Antarctic Quest

Paragraph: ''BICENTENNIAL MAN,'' starring Robin Williams, Embeth Davidtz, Sam Neill and Oliver Platt. Directed by Chris Columbus (PG, 132 minutes). This year's gushy Christmas card from Robin Williams follows the 200-year quest of a household robot named Andrew to become human. Directed by the schmaltzmeister Chris Columbus, who steered this star through ''Mrs. Doubtfire,'' the movie is a joke-strewn sentimental man-machine allegory determined to make us feel good about being human that is punctuated by corny speeches exalting freedom, the joys of sex and the mystery of mortality. Except for Mr. Williams, the acting is strictly of sitcom caliber (Holden).
Title: MOVIE GUIDE

Paragraph: I part with my computer colleague, conceding that it has infinitely more artificial intelligence and agreeing that U.S.C. will have played the most difficult schedule in the nation by season's end -- Auburn, Colorado, Kansas State, Washington State and Notre Dame. Still, the Trojans have lost twice, and just as a two-loss Colorado team loudly lobbied to be in last season's title game and was wisely kept out, so Southern Cal will be.
Title: Sooners Are Rising as the Unbeaten Ranks Thin

Paragraph: It has indeed been an entertaining run for that nifty piece of artificial intelligence hidden somewhere in the Times building. But today the Times computer will join six of its 21st-century brethren, along with the often cranky humans that vote in the Associated Press media poll, as well as the mostly distracted coaches who vote in the USA Today/ESPN poll, to give us 2002's inaugural Bowl Championship Series ranking.
Title: Irish No. 1 in Times; Now Comes B.C.S.
