Along with arcane discussions of software technology and licensing schemes, the editors post gleeful critiques of Microsoft and its wares, and approving commentary on pop/nerd culture, including Natalie Portman, Aibo robot dogs, Lego projects and fun science projects.
Title: It's a Site for the Truly Geeky, And It Even Makes a Few Bucks

Paragraph: The writer is a scientist who works in artificial intelligence.
Title: Celebrity Scientists

Paragraph: And while chat is a major feature of There, the company's chief executive, Tom Melcher, said it offers much more, including avatars enlivened with artificial intelligence that look and act more realistically than typical game characters. They appear to breathe. Their eyes blink, and their body language -- controlled by the user or left to software to animate -- is meant to make conversations feel more natural.
Title: Now Playing: Reality Without the Downside

Paragraph: IT may lack the beeping charm of R2D2, but Shell's SmartPump has a more limited mission: it's just a robot that happens to be a gas jockey.
Title: Fill 'er Up, Mrs. Jetson?

Paragraph: But these researchers believe that disabled people will someday be able to control robot limbs by thinking about moving them. Who knows? It may someday be possible to do word processing without moving a muscle.
Title: Mind Over Matter: A Computer Makes It Work
Other (positive): someday disabled people will be able to control robots with their thoughts

Paragraph: Adrianne Wortzel, a New York artist, disagreed. For ''Camouflage Town'' she built Kiru, a four-foot-tall robot that will roam the Whitney's first floor. Online viewers anywhere  can control the robot's behavior and speech while Webcams transmit its movements back over the Internet. ''For me the right version is the online one,'' Ms. Wortzel said. ''Remotely manipulating the robot to walk and talk is thrilling.''
Title: O.K., It's Art. But Do You View It at Home or in Public?
Other (positive): artistic possibilities

Paragraph: Ada1852 is the creation of Christopher Fahey, a New York artist who rewrote an existing artificial-intelligence program so that its bland, computer-generated conversations with people would seem less mechanical. ''I did not want to build a person whose primary function was to be a nonperson,'' Mr. Fahey said. By giving Ada1852 a personality that verges on the disturbed, he is subverting many notions about artificial intelligence.
Title: Digital Artworks That Play Against Expectations
Other (positive): chatbot

Paragraph: The spacecraft has been orbiting Earth since it was launched on July 3, traveling in an elliptical path 140 miles high at its low point and 71,000 miles out at its peak. The 2,138-pound robot craft was 140 miles above the Indian Ocean and out of contact with ground control when the rocket firing was to occur.
Title: Comet-Exploring Spacecraft Has Disappeared, NASA Says

Paragraph: Because there has been a teeny little leak of research specimens into the atmosphere, Jack is summoned to the fab complex to troubleshoot. What he knows -- and what Mr. Crichton explains in clear and fascinating detail -- is the difference between artificial intelligence and artificial life. Jack's specialty is studying the latter by projecting the rogue behavior of known entities once they form groups.
Title: Extending Franchises: Alive! Dead!

Paragraph: A follow-up expedition to Lake Vida in 2004 sponsored by NASA and the National Science Foundation will use a robot originally designed to gather rock cores on Mars to drill through the ice into the liquid brine.
Title: From Lake's Depths, Frozen Bacteria Are Brought Back to Life
Other (positive): research

Paragraph: Later this year, Hoover plans to introduce a new machine based on Friendly Robotics technology: a robot that vacuums.
Title: Patents; A new way to make snow when nature will not oblige aims for the ideal, not too soppy or too dry.

Paragraph: I have wondered ever since whether a human conductor was aboard, or whether a robot train is still making its ghostly way up and down the No. 6 line, opening and closing its doors for no one. And was this train an example of the latest in subway technology, a gremlin in the system or the answer to complaints of overcrowding on the No. 6 line? I guess I'll never know.
Title: Metropolitan Diary

Paragraph: In hoop jargon, Kobe vs. A.I. was but a tuneup for the Land of Mutombo vs. O'Neal's Universe, for everything in the N.B.A. kitty.
Title: Centers Play Rough, and That's Just on an Off Day

Paragraph: But test a computer that has been taught to play bridge, and the result is different. Matt Ginsberg, a professor of artificial intelligence at the University of Oregon and an expert bridge player, has created GIB, which stands for Ginsberg's Intelligent Bridgeplayer. It proved itself the best of its kind when several programs competed against each other in Chicago in July.
Title: Computers' Play Improves, Especially in Tricky Hands

NYT section: Technology; Corrections; New York and Region
Paragraph: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the evolution of software-based robots, known as bots, misstated the given name of the inventor of what is now called the Turing test, which judges the sophistication of artificial intelligence programs. He was Alan M. Turing, not Joseph.
Title: Corrections

Paragraph: Americans know Dr. Penrose from his books on scientific questions, including ''The Emperor's New Mind'' (Oxford University Press, 1989), which criticizes the idea of artificial intelligence, and ''The Nature of Space and Time'' (Princeton University Press, 1986), which he wrote with his friend Stephen Hawking.
Title: A Mathematician at Play in the Fields of Space-Time
Other (positive): book review blurb

Paragraph: The prologue to EVOLUTION'S DARLING (Four Walls Eight Windows, paper, $15.95), by Scott Westerfeld, is breathtaking. Rathere, the 14-year-old daughter of a space-roving journalist, has trouble getting her father's attention. Her constant companion is an Artificial Intelligence (A.I.) with so much computing capacity that it can pilot a starship, baby-sit for Rathere and ponder the mysteries of the universe at the same time. The danger, for Rathere's financially strapped father, is that the A.I. will raise its ''Turing Quotient'' to 1.0, which would make it, in the eyes of the law, an independent person rather than a useful piece of property. Realizing that his daughter's relationship with the A.I. is driving the machine toward sentience, the father separates them. Rathere fights back in the only way she can. To nudge the A.I. over the threshold to personhood, she makes love to it -- in a scene of eerie beauty that begins with the words, ''It's me, darling.''
Title: Science Fiction

Paragraph: When the owner (Sam Neill) of an industrial robot named Andrew (Robin Williams) discovers that it has creative powers, he sets the machine up as a clockmaker. But Andrew longs to be a human and generations later, when robots possess the emotions to fall in love, he envisions marriage to his former employer's great-granddaughter (Embeth Davidtz). Free to employ all of Mr. Williams's moist, sad-clown expressions, Chris Columbus's film ''pours on the sentimentality in lumpy mawkish speeches about freedom, the joys of sex and the meaning of life'' (Stephen Holden).
Title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
Other (positive): AI is implied, but not specifically

Paragraph: VIOLENCE -- A robot acts up but none too scarily. ''Violence is only for those who have run out of good ideas,'' Doug says.
Title: A Monster in the Lake Or Just a Cuddly Blue Guy?

Paragraph: But she may be having digital dreams of grandeur. Chatterbots are not true examples of artificial intelligence. ''Chatterbots are all about the illusion of intelligence and the suspension of disbelief on the part of the user,'' said Dr. Walter Alden Tackett, chief executive of Neuromedia.
Title: Sons and Daughters of HAL Go on Line

Paragraph: Many advocates insist that the same thing is happening on the Internet. Each user is a neuron hooked into a worldwide organism that is gradually evolving; a living matrix is taking shape. There are programs that maneuver through the Internet guided by primitive forms of artificial intelligence, gathering information. Software aficionados speak of them, imagistically, as ''agents,'' quietly making their way across cyber-borders. That metaphor returns to its origins in ''The Matrix,'' where software ''agents'' protecting the matrix appear as hard-core beings equipped with suits and secret-agent-shades.
Title: A Hacker's Haunting Vision of a Reality Within Illusion
Other (negative): Unclear, but Orwellian

Paragraph: So far in this young campaign, the issues that Gore loves -- from his ''practical idealism'' to his ''electronic-privacy bill of rights'' -- have lacked a certain electricity. But that is not to say that the Gore 2000 effort is a listless one. To the contrary, the candidate may still seem like the robot caricature of a thousand late-night monologues, but his campaign's fund-raising calls to mind a dizzyingly effective machine. In the first three months of 1999 alone, Gore fund-raisers piled up $8.9million in contributions -- easily a record, and a sum that has scared off all challengers for the Democratic nomination except Bill Bradley.
Title: Al Gore's Money Problem

Paragraph: The Web site for ''A. I.,'' Steven Spielberg's forthcoming film about artificial intelligence, offers an on-screen greeting and invites a typed response on any subject. So, I asked the humanoid software lurking within, how good will the Web sites be for this year's summer movies? The chatbot, as these computerized conversationalists are known, replied, ''As good as most, better than some.'' Photo: The Web site for ''A. I.,'' Steven Spielberg's forthcoming film on artificial intelligence.
Title: The Movie Business Seeks Its Fortune on the Web

Paragraph: Some space scientists contend that NASA could do more exploration at lower cost and less risk to human life with unmanned robot craft like the vehicles that have explored Mars and other planets. But the space station needs its resupply trips.
Title: Future of the Shuttle Program Is Linked to the Space Station's

Paragraph: For characters who really think, who make manifest the complex processes of philosophical or mathematical or symbolic analysis, you need to turn to Richard Powers. Powers, the author of eight novels, the most recent being ''The Time of Our Singing,'' is a novelist of Ideas as well as of ideas. His concerns are general -- Art, Science, Capitalism and now Race -- and particular: the science of DNA, the manufacture of soap, artificial intelligence, virtual reality and, in this latest novel, physics, the lieder, and the social history of segregation. Not surprisingly, perhaps, he has been criticized for creating people who sound less like humans than like textbooks or computers (one of his best characters is a computer, in fact), and for doing so in a strained and lifeless prose.
Title: Real Thoughts and Fictional Thinking

Paragraph: When a news release arrived announcing that a company in Barcelona, Spain, had developed an artificial intelligence application that could analyze a song and determine its potential to become a hit, it seemed to be a practical joke poking fun at the desperation and cluelessness of the music business. Ms. Reed replied that the scientists at Grupo AIA were recognized as leaders in artificial intelligence.
Title: Antiwar Song, With Whimsy

Paragraph: They are competing in the high school division of the New York City regional Robotics Competition, presented by First (For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology). First gives each team mechanical parts, including motors, pneumatic controls and radio transmitters. Then students, working with science advisers, build a robot from any material, including plywood and extruded aluminum.
Title: FAMILY FARE

Paragraph: FLESH AND MACHINES: How Robots Will Change Us, by Rodney A. Brooks. (Vintage, $14.) The director of the M.I.T. artificial intelligence laboratory examines the history and current state of robotics as well as its short-term future. The result is a ''stimulating book written by one of the major players in the field,'' Dick Teresi wrote here in 2002, adding, ''It also offers surprisingly deep glimpses into what it is to be human.''
Title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

Paragraph: Despite advances in artificial intelligence, sensors and mechanical devices, researchers are still a long way from realizing the guiding vision of robotics: machines that can move and work like humans, learn new tasks with little or no training, and react with sensitivity to the changing moods of their mortal masters. But in its training, the robot moves beyond simple imitation. Once the robot has learned a task, it is able to perform it even under different circumstances.
Title: Getting to Know All About You
Other (positive): Once the robot has learned a task, it is able to perform it even under different circumstances

Paragraph: With all the dinosaurs, apes, robots, digital actors and artificial intelligence on screen, it's often hard to connect with anybody real. Not so during the Depression, when drama and the better screwball and romantic comedies had people to grab hold of.
Title: When It Helped To Be a Bit Nuts
Other (negative): criticism of modern moviemaking lack of human connection in art/movies hard to connect with anybody real

Paragraph: Sometimes the race goes to the slow and fragile. Helios, a solar-powered flying wing built for NASA, broke the altitude record for non-rocket aircraft set 25 years ago. Powered by 14 small electric motors each turning a propeller, Helios climbed above the skies of Hawaii at barely 25 miles per hour to reach 96,500 feet, topping the old mark by more than 11,000 feet. The robot plane, made of lightweight materials covered with a plastic film skin, is a forerunner to craft that one day may soar in the rarefied air of Mars.
Title: August 12-18; Higher

Paragraph: ''Computers are extremely stupid,'' he said. ''Talk to any computer scientists, not the marketing people. They'll tell you artificial intelligence cannot determine context.''
Title: Cracking the Code Of Online Filtering

Paragraph: Dr. Saul Amarel, who helped develop the field of artificial intelligence and founded the computer science department at Rutgers University, died on Wednesday in Princeton, N.J., where he lived. He was 74. Among his peers, Dr. Amarel was perhaps best known for a paper he wrote in 1968, which put him at the vanguard of the artificial intelligence movement. Later, Dr. Amarel joined artificial intelligence with other fields. He worked, for example, to develop a machine that could diagnose illness, and he envisioned a time when machines would be able to do things like customizing drugs.
Title: Saul Amarel, 74, an Innovator In the Artificial Intelligence Field

Paragraph: * ''A.I.,'' starring Haley Joel Osment, Jude Law, Frances O'Connor and Sam Robards. Written and directed by Steven Spielberg (PG-13, 140 minutes). Mr. Spielberg's new film, a project he inherited from Stanley Kubrick, to whom it is dedicated, is a work of brilliant artifice and profound intelligence. Mr. Osment plays a robot programmed with the capacity to love who is sent to live with a couple grieving for their comatose, gravely ill son. The movie's three distinct sections reveal an unsettlingly plausible vision of the future  and explore a rich, complex set of emotions and ideas. Mr. Spielberg accomplishes the improbable feat of melding Kubrick's chilly, analytical style with his own warmer, needier sensibility, and the result is an exquisitely layered, complex movie -- the riskiest, most ambiguous, most intellectually challenging fairy tale the director has made to date (A. O. Scott).
Title: MOVIE GUIDE

Paragraph: In Majestic, for example, fake company Web sites look like real ones. Some players communicating with others through instant messages may appear to be helpful, but some are bots, using artificial intelligence to deceive players.
Title: Game Designer Who Breaks the Mold
Other (negative): deception

Paragraph: An exception can be made for the Dow theory, however, because of a study three years ago by Stephen J. Brown of New York University, William N. Goetzmann of Yale and Alok Kumar of Cornell. Instead of trying by themselves to divine unambiguous rules from Mr. Hamilton's editorials, these researchers relied on neural networks -- artificial intelligence software that can be ''trained'' to detect patterns. Upon testing this version of the Dow theory from Sept. 1, 1930 through Dec. 1, 1997, they found that it beat the market by a significant margin. (Their study appeared in The Journal of Finance in August 1998.)
Title: A Venerable Market Theory Points to an Extended Slump
Other (positive): Can help predict stock markets and make predictions.

Paragraph: Indeed, applying the study of ants to complex engineering problems is something of an intellectual trend. The topic drew attention at a recent international conference on artificial intelligence in Seattle. It has been discussed in a variety of scientific journals. And a new book by Steven Johnson, ''Emergence: The Connected Lives of Ants, Brains, Cities and Software'' (Scribner), points to ant behavior as a way to further, among other things, understanding of the World Wide Web.
Title: Better Networks: Look to Nature

Paragraph: Meticulous in her artwork, methodical in her favorite subject of math, Cierra is as sharp as a new Crayola. She can't wait to learn something new. Zachariah Walker is just the same. He has enjoyed a summer spent building a robot from the hangers he has sneaked from his mother's closet, but he sprang up on his tiptoes thinking about the first school bell.
Title: Life Is More Than Tennis

Paragraph: Once Linda has exploded a few buxom demons, she can go through other doors, where her possessed sisters wait to do battle. The sisters are gigantic and unique: one is a robot and another is an ethereal figure with a worshipful cult of midgets whom she can transform into savage flying demons.
Title: Where All the Soldiers Have Six Legs

Paragraph: Once the story of running bases had been told, Robert pulled himself off the couch, fell to the floor and crawled, dragging his legs behind him as if they were paralyzed, to the toy cupboard. He pulled himself up and began to survey the toys. He found a silver robot and asked, ''Hey, is this new?'' I said no, it wasn't, but apparently it was to him. The robot had been in the toy cupboard awhile, but this was the first time in two years that he noticed it. (I later realized that the robot is the only silver toy and the tallest in my cupboard.) He also selected nine dinosaurs, lined them up and complained that they were outdated. Many of the details were wrong: ''This triceratops didn't have this kind of scales.'' He shook his head. ''This brachiosaurus is so wrong. His skull was much smaller.'' In the heat of battle, I didn't really comment. But at one point, I offered, ''That guy must have one heck of a headache.'' Robert replied without returning my gaze or interrupting the battle, ''You mean hell.'' I silently assented. Near the end of the battle, the robot began to weaken. His knees started to give way, his torso was twisted beyond its midline axis. He fought to maintain his balance, but he continued to fight. ''I am beginning to think that guy might be the most tired person on earth,'' I told Robert. He nodded. A lot of people are very tired today, I continued. Tired because they are afraid, and tired because they are fighting not to be afraid.
Title: War Game

Paragraph: The new Aibo, which can be preordered for $1,500 at www.us.aibo.com, is the second modular, programmable Aibo companion for people with money to spare, and Sony is hoping there will be many more. For robot lovers with less cash on hand, Sony recently released a line of Aibos for $850 each. These robots, named Latte and Macaron, can respond to 75 voice commands and move around on their own but are not modular.
Title: A Programmable Dog That Will Bite Back

Paragraph: On the afternoon of Sept. 12, a small robot called a MicroTrac crawler located a pocket of rooms that had remained largely intact under a pile of debris. Emergency workers then uncovered the rooms and a firefighter was sent down. Several bodies were found. This early deployment of the robots has alerted researchers to features that are needed but not yet developed. For one, temperature sensors are important when penetrating burning rubble. Dr. Murphy said that a robot that was sent into the depths of the rubble lost its rubber treads, probably because they were melted by the fires smoldering  under the debris.
Title: Agile in a Crisis, Robots Show Their Mettle
Other (positive): Robots to find people during recovery missions search & rescue drone

Paragraph: The robots in Dr. Balch's experiments are nothing more than a few lines of software code, gradually taught to play soccer on a computer screen. They are computer simulations of physical robots built by Dr. Balch -- shoe-box-size machines that he has entered in robot soccer tournaments. Dr. Balch is not rushing to extend his findings to human societies, and he acknowledges that human complexities -- including traits like motivation and jealousy -- are hard or impossible to reproduce in robotic systems. But he says the experiments show that robot studies can serve as a window for understanding human behavior. Dr. Ross Burkhart, a political science professor at Boise State University in Idaho, who has studied the relationship between economic freedom and democracy, says there are interesting parallels between the robot studies and the way economies work.
Title: Robots Learn Soccer (and the Game of Life)
Other (negative): inherent limitations of AI
Other (positive): Ai research enhances understanding of human behavior  robot studies can serve as a window for understanding human behavior.

Paragraph: While performing the operation, the team in New York could examine the Strasbourg patient's body by means of two digital camera ''eyes'' that zoomed into and panned out of the surgical zone. In New York, each surgeon stepped up to a console and slipped his hands around handles designed to resemble surgical instruments. As the surgeons moved their hands, their actions were translated into a data stream that traveled under the Atlantic via high-speed fiber-optic cable. When the data reached their remote location, a robot performed the doctors' bidding. The total time delay between the doctor and his robot? Eighty milliseconds. In the case of the gallbladder operation, a three-dimensional monitor helped make the experience of telesurgery feel almost like the real thing. And the technology is only going to get better. For example, future setups will likely include ''force feedback,'' a system that allows the surgeon to ''feel'' what the distant robot arms are encountering as they delve into a patient's body. As a robotic arm at the surgery site thrusts, say, a needle into denser tissue, electronic signals tracking the instrument's movements will immediately flash back to the handles being gripped by the doctor's distant hands -- allowing him to experience exactly the same degree of resistance as the instruments penetrating the body.
Title: Telesurgery

Paragraph: And yet, researchers in artificial intelligence and behavioral sciences often talk now about embodied intelligence. Dr. Antonio R. Damasio, a neurobiologist at the University of Iowa, who is the author of ''Descartes's Error'' and more recently ''Looking for Spinoza,'' has argued that the mind contains a model of the human body and that the actions of the body inform the brain. ''The mind exists,'' he writes in ''Spinoza,'' ''because there is a body to furnish it with contents.''
Title: Playing Music as a Toy, and a Toy as Music
Other (negative): Explains why we're inherently better at intelligence than machines

Paragraph: A group led by a university researcher has created a part mechanical, part biological robot that operates on the basis of the neural activity of rat brain cells grown in a dish. The neural signals are analyzed by a computer that looks for patterns emitted by the brain cells and then translates those patterns into robotic movement. If the neurons fire a certain way, for example, the robot's right wheel rotates once. As the robot moves, it functions as a sensory system, delivering feedback to the neurons through the electrodes. For example, Mr. DeMarse said, the robot has sensors for light and feeds electrical signals proportional to the light back to the electrodes. ''We return information to the dish on the intensity of light as the robot gets closer and the light gets brighter.''
Title: Wired to the Brain of a Rat, a Robot Takes On the World

Paragraph: A green wire that you stake into the ground forms a perimeter fence and emits an electromagnetic signal to make sure the mower stays on your property. And the latest RoboMower model talks to you, admonishing you to read the manual before you set it in motion and complaining in ''Lost in Space'' robot fashion (''Danger! Please remove the battery before lifting'') when you pick it up in the middle of its chores. It even warns you with an electronic ''Charge!'' bugle call when it's about to start mowing.
Title: It Mulches, Too? Robotic Mowers Win a Following

Paragraph: In the original, the men in town take revenge on the Betty Friedan ethos and notions about unshaved legs, burned bras and competing his-and-her careers by killing off their newly liberated wives and replacing them with shaplier and more submissive robot doppelg_nger in aprons who knit and coo. (The fembots with Farrah hair and blue eyeshadow sometimes go haywire and breathily repeat things like, ''I'll just die if I don't get that recipe.'')
Title: Hot Zombie Love

Paragraph: Army officials said India had shot down a robot Pakistani spy plane flying over Indian airspace in Kashmir. They said wreckage from the plane fell 400 yards inside the part of the region controlled by India. There was no immediate response from Pakistan. Last week, Pakistan said it had shot down an unpiloted Indian spy plane, an assertion India denied. Pakistan says it provides moral and political support to Kashmiris fighting for independence; India accuses Pakistan of sponsoring terrorism in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir.
Title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Army Says It Downed Pakistani Robot

Paragraph: Mr. Schlink studied constitutional law, and developed an abiding interest in the United States, when he studied artificial intelligence and the law at Stanford University in 1974. He remembers with great fondness a three-month trip by Greyhound bus across the country.
Title: Postwar German Writer a Bard of a Generation

Paragraph: AT first glance, it's obvious why ''BattleBots,'' the robot fighting show on Comedy Central, would draw television viewers like passers-by to a car crash. It is, after all, a series of staged battles between remote-controlled machines equipped with spinning blades, ramming spears and swinging maces. It has noise, wreckage, pseudo-sports commentary modeled on professional wrestling and the all-too-obvious d̩colletage of Carmen Electra, proffered to the camera as she asks a robot designer, after a bout, how it felt to have his weapon lopped off. Some robot competitions involve machines that are designed for specific tasks and include only transistors and diodes. Some of the machines are run by humans using remote control devices; others are true, autonomous robots, programmed for different tactics.
Title: When Nerds Collide: Bots in the Ring

Paragraph: What is the world going to be like in 2173? Just ask Woody Allen. He has already been there, and the hilarious answer is visible in his comedy SLEEPER (1973). Chosen by The New York Times as one of the year's 10 best films, ''Sleeper'' relates the wacky adventures of Miles Monroe (Mr. Allen), a Greenwich Village health food store owner who undergoes a supposedly minor operation at St. Vincent's Hospital and wakes up from a frozen state 200 years later. Amid 12-foot-tall chickens, robot servants, robot dogs and other oddities in a police state, Miles becomes the reluctant head of the anti-government underground, with a splendid comic ally in Diane Keaton - Saturday at 2 p.m. on TCM.
Title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE

Paragraph: There will be interactive digital challenges for visitors to try to penetrate espionage disguises and conspiracies. There will be real devices like an East German robot camera designed to peer through walls, plus fictitious offspring including James Bond's gadget-laden car from ''Goldfinger.''
Title: It's All Cloak and Dagger, but Hardly Classified

Paragraph: At Syrrx, a structural genomics company, a robot places a tiny drop of protein into 480 wells, each containing a different chemical combination. The machine can do 11,000 crystallization experiments in 24 hours. A robot being developed will be able to do 130,000 a day, with a computer vision system checking one million wells a day in search of the elusive crystals.
Title: Analyzing Proteins With X-Rays, Crystals and Some Luck

Paragraph: Around the country, several hundred such robot cameras have been installed, with more on the way. In New York City, there are 30, generating 200,000 tickets a year.
Title: Frown, You're on Red-Light Camera!

Paragraph: Once in a fight, you can attack a monster twice in one turn or choose to attack once and save the extra energy for a more devastating attack on your next turn. You can also take command of a giant killer robot that is far more powerful than the monster but that cannot be healed during battle. The original Zone of the Enders, released in 2001, centered on a boy named Leo who was swept up in an interplanetary war and found himself the unwilling pilot of a giant killer robot called Jehuty. Leo was a reluctant hero who got upset every time he had to kill for the greater good, and the game had an emotional complexity lacking in most action games.
Title: Interplanetary Warfare, On the Installment Plan

Paragraph: Once in a fight, you can attack a monster twice in one turn or choose to attack once and save the extra energy for a more devastating attack on your next turn. You can also take command of a giant killer robot that is far more powerful than the monster but that cannot be healed during battle. Paragraph: Ronald Brachman, a Darpa expert in artificial intelligence, said it was time to view computers in a dramatically different way. He expressed annoyance at his ''stupid PC,'' which cannot, in any real sense, learn.
Title: The Right and Wrong Stuff of Thinking Outside a Box

Paragraph: Puerto Rican rap artists and children wearing A.I. do-rags and 76ers jerseys -- the No. 2-selling N.B.A. jersey last season behind Kobe Bryant's -- cheered Allen Iverson on Friday afternoon in an arena in Caguas, 23 miles south of San Juan, even though the crowd of 500 had to wait more than two hours before their idol appeared at the three-on-three tournament that he helped create.
Title: Iverson's Injury Slows His Image Crossover

Paragraph: But given the way he looked after the game, unable to put on his socks and moving like a robot whose batteries were low, Camby will probably not be available for the Knicks' home game Sunday against the Miami Heat and most likely will not play in the other two games before next weekend's All-Star Game break.
Title: A Healthy Knicks Team Is Too Good to Be True

Paragraph: Now, three centuries later, a team of entrepreneurs and archaeologists working with the British government says it has probably discovered the  Sussex in the depths of the Mediterranean. A half mile down, the team's robot has examined a large mound rich in cannons, anchors and solidified masses of artifacts, and its mechanical arm has gingerly lifted a few to the surface.
Title: 'Eureka!' Off Gibraltar: A Trove From 1694?
Other (positive): underwater salvaging

Paragraph: Handspring, the No. 2 maker of personal digital assistants behind Palm, recently began testing an unusual software program by a company called TuVox. The program uses artificial intelligence and speech recognition to talk Handspring's callers through repairing errors, crashes, failed synchronizations and other troubles that afflict hand-held equipment.
Title: Need to Fix a Computer? Ask Another Computer
Other (positive): AI facilitates device fixes

Paragraph: In Germany, artificial intelligence experts have tried to get a computer to play Octi. So far, only humans have done well at the game. Dr. Green is ecstatic.
Title: Professor Sees a Toy, Then Invents Game

Paragraph: Witness the success of ''BattleBots,'' a bizarre televised contest in which robots operated by remote control try to destroy each other as a live audience cheers. Since its debut in August, this techie transmutation of cockfights and tractor pulls has become the second most popular program on Comedy Central after its Wednesday night lead-in, ''South Park,'' with an average audience of 1.6 million. (''BattleBots'' will move to Tuesdays beginning Dec. 5.) Cultural phenomena are fabricated quickly these days, so the robot contestants -- along with their human creators and operators -- almost instantly appeared on network television, giving demo matches on the ''Tonight'' show. The ''BattleBots'' ethos of violence without blood or sweat also fits into a cultural shift toward technological distancing, which became apparent during the Gulf War, a conflict that was conveyed on television as a video game. In ''BattleBots,'' the robots attack each other with a ferocity and assortment of weaponry -- including buzz saws and spikes -- that would be terrifying if flesh, rather than metal, were on the line. They battle for three minutes -- less if there's a knockout -- in an arena called the BattleBox. Its sides are made of shatterproof glass, to protect the audience from flying parts -- and to shield the meek-looking robot owners, who stand outside the box as they manipulate their proxies with hand-held controls. The floor contains 14 hazards, including sledgehammers, ramrods and more buzz saws, that pop up periodically and try to dismantle the robots before their opponents can. ''BattleBots'' grew out of live robot competitions begun in San Francisco in 1994 by Marc Thorpe, a former model maker at George Lucas's Industrial Light and Magic. Called Robot Wars, these gladiator-style contests celebrated engineering ingenuity and the weird obsessiveness of people willing to spend years and thousands of dollars developing a robot that could be destroyed in three minutes or less. Though an occasional cute, anthropomorphic robot showed up, most of the combatants looked like mischievous science fair projects, piles of junk containing clever destructive capabilities. A robot named Tentoumushi, designed by a 14-year-old girl, is one of the cute ones, resembling a ladybug until its red shell lifts and reveals a hook that can be lowered to trap its opponent. Others have names like Mauler and Toecrusher, which was named for its dominant feature, a dagger-like protrusion at the end of a metal arm that slams down on command.
Title: High Tech, High Camp And Battles To the Death
Other (positive): battle-bots

Paragraph: Photos: Oblong rock 30 feet long ''seen'' from the descending robot craft. (NASA)(pg. A1); The planned landing site for a NASA spacecraft on the asteroid Eros is indicated on this composite image created from pictures taken on Dec. 3. (NASA)(pg. A28)
Title: With a Skip and a Bounce, Spacecraft Lands on Asteroid

Paragraph: In ''Who Let the Robot Out'' (State of the Art, Jan. 25) David Pogue writes that Aibo, the robot dog from Sony, understands ''standard commands like 'Sit,' 'Shake,' and 'Lay down.' '' Mr. Pogue, did you (oh, horror) actually say, ''Lay down''? Doesn't Aibo distinguish between ''lie'' and ''lay''?
Title: Aibo's Lack of Education

Paragraph: First released in 1999 by the mod designer Minh Le and his Counter-Strike team as a free download for  owners of Sierra's Half-Life, Counter-Strike has become the most popular of all multiplayer action games. This popularity has moved Sierra to release a standalone version of the mod for people who don't own Half-Life. Besides Counter-Strike it contains other multiplayer mods like Team Fortress Classic and the western-theme Wanted, making it the ultimate package for those who consider battling monsters with artificial intelligence a hollow experience compared with battling real human minds.
Title: Where Death Is Final, and Caution Is a Must
Other (negative): video gaming AI fails to engage

Paragraph: Zeta, a government-designed robot labeled a menace to society, goes undercover in the year 2040 with his streetwise friend Ro to clear his name and elude his creators in ''The Zeta Project,'' a new animated series on Kids' WB! on Saturdays at 10:30 a.m.
Title: Robotic Fugitive Angel

Paragraph: Herbert A. Simon, an American polymath who won the Nobel in economics in 1978 with a new theory of decision making and who helped pioneer the idea that computers can exhibit artificial intelligence that mirrors human thinking, died yesterday. He was 84. People were asked for the general reasoning processes they went through as they solved logical problems and these were then converted into computer programs that Professor Simon and Mr. Newell thought equipped these machines with a kind of artificial intelligence that enabled them to simulate human thought rather than just perform stereotyped procedures. But in a much-cited 1957 paper Professor Simon seemed to allow his own enthusiasm for artificial intelligence to run too far ahead of its more realistic possibilities. Within 10 years, he predicted, ''a digital computer will be the world's chess champion unless the rules bar it from competition,'' while within the ''visible future,'' he said, ''machines that think, that learn and that create'' will be able to handle challenges ''coextensive with the range to which the human mind has been applied.'' Because artificial intelligence has not grown as quickly or as strongly as Professor Simon hoped, critics of his thinking argue that there are limits to what computers can achieve and that what they accomplish will always be a simulation of human thought, not creative thinking itself. As a result, Professor Simon's achievements have sparked a passionate and continuing debate about the differences between people and thinking machines.
Title: Herbert A. Simon Dies at 84; Won a Nobel for Economics
Other (negative): It will not really be thinking.  Just  simulation. inherent limitations of AI
Other (positive): obit    simulate human thought  This is probably part of an Obit for Herb Simon  a digital computer will be the world's chess champion

Paragraph: It might seem odd to say that neurological studies on how technology might be changing the way we use our hands or take in visual information have anything to do with that cyborgian dream, but it's not really such a stretch. Sadie Plant happens to be a cyberfeminist, with a hip cultural-studies background: her empirical research on mobile phones fits neatly into the visionary view of digital technology, in which it is seen as radical, emancipatory and really cool. The goal of making cyborgs more humanlike may still be beyond the grasp of robotics engineers -- Rodney Brooks, the head of the M.I.T. Artificial Intelligence Lab, told NPR recently that while we could make a robot play chess, we were still flummoxed by the challenge of creating one that like a human 2-year-old could ''come into a place they've never seen and point to things and say 'chair,' 'cup,' 'table.''' But the related dream of making humans a little more like cyborgs seems closer to reality. Cosmetic plastic surgery is more ambitious and more ubiquitous than ever, makeovers more extreme. Experiments with ''bionic technology,'' like brain implants that can restore vision to the blind or mobility to the paralyzed, are now proceeding with human subjects. And they have definitely got the cyber-groovies excited. Not long ago, according to The Guardian, Kevin Warwick, a professor of cybernetics at the University of Reading, ''underwent a two-hour operation to have a chip attached to nerves in his left arm,'' which he says he hopes will ''allow him eventually to communicate with his wife through thought alone.'' Superthumbs and Robocop-like visual scanning could be regarded as virtual implants, incorporating machine intelligence into human bodies without surgery.
Title: My Son, the Cyborg
Other (positive): brain implants that can restore vision to the blind or mobility to the paralyzed

Paragraph: JUDE LAW, a star of the STEVEN SPIELBERG film ''A.I.,'' said his part brought out his inner dancer. He spent three months in dance workshops, learning tap, ballet, kabuki, tango -- even break dancing. All to learn how to do a mechanized kind of swagger so he could play a robot who happened to be a kind of sex slave.
Title: BOLDFACE NAMES
Other (positive): movie blurb

Paragraph: While pilotless aircraft are not new, the idea that a robot plane could replace an Air Force fighter pilot was, until recently, the stuff of futurist science magazines.
Title: The Pilot, Gone. The Market, Huge.
Other (positive): drones

Paragraph: The little red robot that could has made it all the way to Orlando, Fla., from its humble birthplace on Flatbush Avenue. The question now is: can the underdog robot from Brooklyn conquer the world? The robot is red because the only available paint was left over from touching up a fire hydrant. But the 50 students in the project became a well-oiled robot-building and robot-hyping machine.
Title: Red Robot With Blue Collar Gets a Blue Ribbon
Other (positive): contest encourages AI advances, academia supports AI education

Paragraph: Elsewhere hangs a big photograph of a man cradling an antiquated robot -- a funny-sad, futuristic ''Piet'' about technological and, implicitly, human obsolescence. More hauntingly enigmatic is a 12-minute film called ''Mayday,'' a slow, stately, wordless narrative. An attractive couple drive to a beach in their BMW. There they strip down to black long johns, and each lies down on a log that's been wrapped in a fluffy blanket. Each also has a curious, futuristic blinking red lighting device wedged between the buttocks. As the camera draws back for an aerial view, we are left to wonder whether we have witnessed a ritual of suicide or, more hopefully, of spiritual transformation.   KEN JOHNSON
Title: Siobhan Hapaska

Paragraph: Some players of an ambitious Internet game that is part of the marketing push for the film ''A.I.'' say it is a more absorbing experience than watching the much-anticipated movie by Steven Spielberg, on the set above with the actors Haley Joel Osment and Jude Law. The core of the online game -- which has attracted several hundred thousand players, according to Elan Lee, a Microsoft game designer -- is an elaborate sprawl of Web sites for fictitious people and companies, peppered with clues to a murder. The game's obscurity, like that of a nightclub with no sign outside, seems only to increase its appeal. C1 Photo (David James/Warner Brothers and DreamWorks)
Title: Playing A.I. on the Internet

Paragraph: Some artificial intelligence researchers have shunned the Turing test altogether, calling it only the illusion of intelligence. Others, like Douglas B. Lenat, who has spent more than 16 years in the field of artificial intelligence, or A.I., say it has its place in research. ''It may not be an important end in itself, but the manner in which it has failed each year is a useful measure of A.I. progress,'' he said. ''It will amplify our minds.'' Mr. Loebner, who counts the legalization of prostitution and marijuana among his other causes, said that he, too, was puzzled by how to determine artificial intelligence.
Title: The Art of Virtual Chat Is Still a Work in Progress
Other (positive): turing test's value discussed

Paragraph: The illusory world depicted in the 1999 movie ''The Matrix'' could well stand for this shift in perception. Created by artificial intelligence, the illusion of normal life is produced by streams of 0's and 1's in a state of constant flux. The computer has reduced all information to this binary system. Suppose that human intelligence is artificial. 0 stands for unity, for a void undifferentiated in space and time. 1 stands for an initial act of differentiation: the division of light from darkness, for example, or of black from white, male from female, nature from culture, left from right. In working on the computer, we are always returning to unity and always stepping away from it. Whatever forms we create on the screen, we are always recreating and destroying the void.
Title: The Dionysian Drama of Today's Design
Other (negative): illusion of normal life

Paragraph: The long-term goal of the competition is to create a team of fully autonomous robots by 2050 that can defeat the human team that wins soccer's World Cup. But RoboCup has a more serious, and immediate, side as well: to advance research in robots and artificial intelligence. What is learned through robots working with one another on the soccer field may help foster the development of robot teams that could perform surgery, fight large fires or lead search and rescue missions after natural disasters, researchers said.
Title: Robot Competitors Meet on a Soccer Field of Dreams
Other (positive): AI can lead search and rescue missions  soccer, perform surgery, fight large fires, lead search and rescue missions after natural disasters

Paragraph: For a long time, Dr. Murphy said, autonomy was the main goal in creating search-and-rescue robots. But, Dr. Murphy said, it is most important for the robots to work with the rescue teams and supplement what rescue workers can do. One function, she said, is for a robot to go into a collapsed building and map the rubble and structural conditions, a job that can be highly dangerous and slow for a human rescue worker. ''Everyone has tried to make the robot like a person and what we really need is something more with the intelligence of a dog that you can tell where to go,'' she said. ''Add to that the advantage of a robot that can work everywhere, take all these camera pictures and send them back to the rescue league, which is something dogs and people can't do. They can't carry all that sensor equipment, people are too big, and dogs don't know to look in corners and look for structural details.
Title: Robots Tested in Mock Search for Urban Disaster Victims
Other (positive): does dangerous jobs work with the rescue teams and supplement what rescue workers can do, do a job that can be highly dangerous and slow for a human rescue worker    disaster recovery, robots go where people can't

Paragraph: In a few instances, video is intrinsic to the work of art. A clipboard is the support for Michael Oatman's flat monitor bearing an animated pair of mug shots of himself, front and side views, confessing to crimes. They include minor infractions, but his monologue turns into an impassioned critique of his life. The group with the imposing name Institute for Applied Autonomy found video appropriate for presenting a cunning robot that will hand out leaflets and write graffiti as a surrogate for a human who might get arrested doing the same.
Title: The Long Arm of the Law Reaches Into the Gallery

Paragraph: Picture this: The excitement builds as the audience waits to find out not only who's going to be the lucky bride or groom, but also . . . whether the sentient being behind that screen is a person, or an artificial intelligence program!
Title: Who Wants to Marry Some More Bad Ideas?

Paragraph: Theirs was an informal network that included people like John McCarthy, a pioneer in artificial intelligence, and Whitfield Diffie, an inventor of modern cryptography, who was then a Stanford graduate student and carried custom chopsticks. Bill Gosper, a mathematician and legendary computer hacker, ate at the restaurant every evening for a decade.
Title: Palo Alto Journal; Hackers Enjoy One Last Meal From the Master of .com Cuisine

Paragraph: Taking a page from science fiction, engineers at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Ames Research Center at Moffett Field, Calif., are developing small robot buddies that could tag along with astronauts and act as personal assistants. ''Then I saw 'Star Wars' and there was a scene in the movie when the characters used a remote robot object -- a fast-moving ball -- to practice with their light sabers,'' he said. ''And that gave me more ideas.''
Title: Building Robot Aides To Follow Astronauts

Paragraph: It is technology that defines his resume; he has spent 34 of his 51 years inventing ingenious uses for artificial intelligence. But like a priest caught playing in a physics lab, he keeps coming up with inventions inspired by aesthetics and social conscience.
Title: The Soul of the Next New Machine: Humans; How the Wedding of Brain and Computer Could Change the Universe

Paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO                     IN the latest ''Terminator'' movie, Arnold Schwarzenegger plays a robot who returns from the future to save a grand old civilization from chaos. In Tuesday's California recall election Mr. Schwarzenegger stands a chance of transforming a grand old political party, not just in California but possibly on the national stage as well. That prospect exhilarates national Republican leaders, even as some acknowledge that it carries risks as well.
Title: The Nation: Party Time; California's New Trend: Big-Tent Republicans

Paragraph: No one, that is, except for a piece of artificial intelligence called Hit Song Science, a program that tries to determine, with mathematical precision, whether a song is going to be a Top 40 hit. When the scientists fed Jones's album into that computer, alarm bells went off: the program predicted that eight tracks would hit the charts. ''We were like, whoa, that's funky,'' says Mike McCready, the C.E.O. of Polyphonic HMI, the Barcelona-based company that developed the software application. A few months later, Jones's album went multiplatinum -- and Hit Song Science had proved it could pick a hit as well as Clive Davis.
Title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Hit Song Science
Other (positive): music prediction predicts musical hits

Paragraph: The dizzying effects of too much information are nothing new to aficionados of cyberpunk, the variety of science fiction closely identified with Stephenson (and vice versa). Its practitioners like to throw their readers headlong into a dense, distracting future that makes Times Square look like a cloister. In their worlds it's impossible to know where bodies end and brains begin, or where brains end and computers begin. In Stephenson's ''Snow Crash,'' for example, a computer virus leaps the species boundary between silicon and flesh, infecting people. In ''The Diamond Age,'' a powerful artificial intelligence designed to program leaders falls into the hands of a girl from the wrong side of the modem.
Title: The Original Information Age

Paragraph: About 1 p.m., the police sent in a robot with a camera, but it was unclear if the effort yielded any information. By 2:33 p.m., after more than six hours of silence, the police closed in, entered the trailer and found the bodies of the woman and two men.
Title: 6-Hour Siege At Campsite Ends Fatally

Paragraph: It lay in darkness at the bottom of the Atlantic for more than a century, guarded only by the occasional shark. Now, the 150-year-old steamship has a visitor: a robot bristling with lights, cameras and mechanical arms that is picking its way through the wreckage, hauling up a fortune in gold and silver coins, eventually perhaps 30,000 of them. In icy darkness at the bottom of the Atlantic, the robot took thousands of photographs, which the team made into a detailed photo mosaic to guide recovery work. Early this month, the team had the robot vacuum away sand from where the cache was believed to lie. A few coins appeared, then more. ''They followed it like a trail of bread crumbs,'' Mr. Stemm said, ''and came upon a cascade of gold coins.'' Photos: Greg Stemm, left, and Ernie Tapanes of Odyssey Marine Exploration watched as a robot excavated the wreck of the Republic below the surface of the Atlantic, about 100 miles off the coast of Georgia. (Photo by Copyright 2003, Odyssey Marine Exploration); The Republic left New York in 1865, bound for New Orleans. It sank in a hurricane. Dozens survived, but a cargo of money was left behind. (Photo by Copyright, Peabody Essex Museum, Salem, Mass.); The wreck of the steamship Republic has yielded 1,600 gold and silver coins, and salvagers are hoping to find tens of thousands more. (Photo by Copyright 2003, Odyssey Marine Exploration)
Title: Salvagers Say a Shipwreck Trove Is Worth Millions
Other (positive): research      excavation  excavation

Paragraph: How wrong they were. Just as millions of users defied the first engineers' narrow visions of what a home computer could be, and figured out how to make PC's bend to their will, the cheapness and flexibility of commodity computer components are now enabling a new hobbyist revolution in home robotics. C.P.U.'s -- the brains of a PC -- are cheap like borscht, and the sensors that allow computers to see, hear, feel and smell have likewise plummeted in cost. (Pinhead digital cameras, for example, are so cheap these days that it's hard to find a pocket-size gizmo that doesn't have one built in.) All it takes to turn these pieces into a robot is packaging the brains and the senses atop a mobile platform and stirring in some clever code.
Title: Domesticating The (Electronic) Help

Paragraph: The house in which the gunmen made their last stand was pocked with bullet holes this morning, the bodies still inside. As some Israeli soldiers, looking exhausted, left the settlement, others were still detonating hand grenades that the attackers had left around the nearby houses. A yellow robot was used to handle unexploded ordnance.
Title: Palestinians Attack Israeli Settlement
Other (positive): bomb disposal

Paragraph: With the bodies and movements in place, artificial intelligence is used to program the brains of the players. Programmers build a database of skills for each athlete, including a level of speed, agility and awareness. Players' positions impose their own attributes, too, like a quarterback's passing and running abilities.
Title: Sports Fantasy Is Catching Up With Reality
Other (positive): sports?

Paragraph: For instance, Dante II was created by NASA as a model for extraterrestrial exploration. Looking like a giant arachnid (it has eight legs), Dante hasn't been to outer space yet, but it has been where no human dares go: deep inside a volcanic crater. Children can push buttons to move his -- I mean its -- legs up and down. They can also operate a backhoe and see why it's only a machine, not a robot (no artificial intelligence).
Title: FAMILY FARE

Paragraph: The robot searching ice fields in Antarctica for meteorites has found its first one, researchers said yesterday. The four-wheeled robot called Nomad, built by the Robotics Institute at Carnegie Mellon University, made its find Friday after about a week of test runs near Elephant Moraine, about 180 miles from the main American base at McMurdo Station. Dr. Dimitrios Apostolopoulos, project manager for Nomad, said reports sent by e-mail from the field team said the 1,600-pound robot picked out the meteorite on an ice field during its third day of searches. Using its camera system, the robot correctly classified the meteorite. Dr. Apostolopoulos said the robot would continue its field test for another week.
Title: 'Nomad' Finds Its First Meteorite
Other (positive): classified the meteorite

Paragraph: She professed to be deeply offended, taking the remark as a reference to a scene in ''Terminator 3'' in which Mr. Schwarzenegger's character dips a woman (albeit an evil robot woman) head-first into a toilet. Mr. Schwarzenegger said after the debate that his aides had suggested that if this political thing did not work out, he and Ms. Huffington could take their routine on the road.
Title: Page Two: Sept. 21-27 -- California Watch; Adventures in Democracy: Huffington vs. Schwarzenegger

Paragraph: Cierge club members get first pick of Sony items that may be in limited supply, like its latest Aibo robot or its highest-end digital camera. Other perks include free  technical support and invitations to screenings and product previews.
Title: Wear Me, Use Me, Flaunt Me: Hitching a Product to the Stars

Paragraph: ''Jet Lag'' was a collaboration between Diller and Scofidio and the Builders Association, a performance group directed by Marianne Weems. The work was originally commissioned by MASS MoCA, a sprawling arts complex in North Adams, Mass., where it was staged as one of the center's inaugural events. The play starts out with a line that some will recall as the opening sentence from ''The Medium Is the Massage,'' Marshall McLuhan's 1966 cult classic: ''Good Morning!'' In the performance that follows, video, radio (broadcast and short-wave), in-flight movies, telephone and other media are the major characters. The human actors speak a language that derives almost entirely from media cliches. As in the recent film ''The Matrix,'' they are playthings of the artificial intelligence that has evolved beyond human control.
Title: Exploring Space and Time, Here and Now

Paragraph: ''BICENTENNIAL MAN,'' starring Robin Williams, Embeth Davidtz, Sam Neill and Oliver Platt. Directed by Chris Columbus (PG, 132 minutes). This gushy Robin Williams star vehicle follows the 200-year quest of a household robot named Andrew to become human. Directed by the schmaltzmeister Chris Columbus, who steered this star through ''Mrs. Doubtfire,'' the movie is a joke-strewn, sentimental man-machine allegory determined to make us feel good about being human. Corny speeches exalting freedom, the joys of sex and the mystery of mortality punctuate the tale. Except for Mr. Williams, the acting is strictly of sitcom caliber (Holden).
Title: MOVIE GUIDE

Paragraph: I was surprised to read in ''It's Not Big Brother, It's Customer Service''  (Jan. 27) that customers found solutions, on the spot, to the classical problem of distinguishing between sophisticated artificial intelligence programs and real people speaking in real time -- by quizzing the online customer service representatives. Without realizing it, the customers had improvised Turing tests, a method of distinguishing between the responses of human beings and computer programs. The Turing test may in fact be intuitive.
Title: Sales Help at Your Elbow
Other (positive): People can improvise the Turing test on the phone

Paragraph: ''BICENTENNIAL MAN,'' starring Robin Williams, Embeth Davidtz, Sam Neill and Oliver Platt. Directed by Chris Columbus (PG, 132 minutes). This gushy Robin Williams star vehicle follows the 200-year quest of a household robot named Andrew to become human.
