Paragraph: So when she and Rodney A. Brooks, director of the M.I.T. computer science and artificial intelligence laboratory, were offered a Segway Human Transporter to serve as Cardea's mode of mobility, they took it. Cardea, named for the Roman goddess of thresholds and hinges, can now roll up to a door, recognize it and open it with its robotic arm. Most important to the M.I.T. researchers, the Segway's gyroscopic balance system allows Cardea to stand as tall as Dr. O'Reilly without the need for an awkwardly wide base to insure stability. M.I.T.'s goal is to create a robot that can act as a kind of personal assistant, and Cardea's height and maneuverability should help it interact with humans at their level. ''A dynamically stabilized robot can fall down,'' Mr. Morrell said. ''To some extent, that's a new problem to think about.'' Meanwhile, M.I.T. has a long way to go before Cardea can act as a true personal assistant. The robot spends much of its time in pieces as 11 researchers work on its various systems. (Facing the first deadline to show Darpa a functioning robot, the M.I.T. team rushed a bit and now has to clean up some of its mess.) Photo: CREATIVE -- Una-May O'Reilly, an M.I.T. scientist, with Cardea, a robot built on the frame of a Segway scooter. (Photo by Jodi Hilton for The New York Times)
Title: With an Urban Scooter, a Humanoid Robot Hits Its Stride
Other (positive): science supporting AI is progressing  personal assistant        information lacking

Paragraph: Special black ink on the cover of the new monograph ''Extra Spatial'' by Kim Colin temporarily disappears when warmed, right. The effect is magical -- and surprisingly low-tech. ''It's not the technology, but what you do with it,'' said Tim Brown, the chief executive of IDEO, a design consultant that has created products for Palm and BMW. ''Extra Spatial'' presents some whimsical IDEO projects like the digital mirrors at the Prada store in SoHo and Spyfish STV, an 18-inch robot submarine that probes underwater landscapes with video cameras. ''Go diving without having to get wet,'' Mr. Brown said. Spyfish is $15,000 at www.spyfish.com, and the monograph (Chronicle Books, $35) is available at www.ideo.com.   CRAIG KELLOGG
Title: Harnessing the Power of Whimsy
Other (positive): Spyfish STV, an 18-inch robot submarine that probes underwater landscapes with video cameras

Paragraph: The robot will also seek the airplane's flight recorders, which investigators hope will throw light on why the Flash airlines Boeing 737 crashed almost immediately after takeoff. Egyptian and French officials have said the accident was a result of a technical malfunction, but the exact cause remains unclear.
Title: 4 Americans Were on Plane That Crashed In the Red Sea
Other (positive): searching

Paragraph: But something is new this time around. There seems to be more chatter than usual among paranoids enraged that other paranoids are making stupid arguments. A commentator named ''doubting Thomas'' tossed out this proof: ''We've got friggin' surveillance cameras here in banks that take nothing but blurry photos -- we're supposed to believe that this robot ship flew to Mars and somehow took this high-resolution picture of itself? PUH-LEEZ!''
Title: Ideas & Trends: Conspiracy Alert; Sure, It May Look Like Mars

Paragraph: As a future old person, I'm sure I would prefer the company of a robot pet to the canned companionship of a human do-gooder. But there's a better alternative. Those who want to alleviate the loneliness of the elderly should try teaching old people how to use computers and surf the Internet. This will enable the elderly to find people who will interact with them out of shared interests.
Title: Helping the Elderly Connect
Other (positive): AI could provide companionship to humans

Paragraph: Diane is an Aibo, a computer-controlled robot made by Sony, and D.H.S. is Droopy Head Syndrome, which is caused when a clutch wears out (it's repairable by replacing the head). Mr. Brattin was grieving over a broken machine.
Title: Silicon Pets, but the Pride Is Real

Paragraph: Back in the real world, we humans have problems of our own. The Smart House is already big business, far from the computer-science laboratories -- a growth industry not waiting for the emergence of advanced artificial intelligence. Home remodelers nationwide have become systems integrators. Here in 2003, the core home technologies are still light switches and coffeepots and DVD players and burglar alarms. Make connections with wires and radio waves, allow a bit of programming and funny things can happen.
Title: When the House Starts Talking to Itself

Paragraph: Which should be good news for the novel's rabid fans. ''High Fidelity'' isn't exactly a cult novel -- there's no shape-shifting, no artificial intelligences, no pages-long hallucinogenic spiels -- but it does seem to be something of a cultural hallmark. ''I think it has become one of those books that people of a certain age have all read,'' says Wendy Carlton, Mr. Hornby's editor at Riverhead Books. ''It was the kind of book that everybody in my summer house just had to read. There's a lot of us -- aging teenagers, thirtysomething teenagers -- who are a lot like Rob: not married, not settled, career in the air. We love the freedom of it, but at the same time we feel this nagging guilt. You know, that 'By the time they were my age, my parents already had me' kind of thing.''
Title: Film; Keeping Faith With 'High Fidelity'

NYT section: Technology; Corrections; New York and Region
Paragraph: An article in Business Day on July 17 about Microsoft's plans for new software technologies to manage information overload misstated the company's relationship to an artificial intelligence company, Knowledge Industries. While Microsoft bought parts of it in 1993, the company remains independent; it was not wholly acquired.
Title: Corrections

Paragraph: Old toys need not be expensive. Skinner has given many lots $200 estimates, though not the star ones. These include rare robots like the Robby Space Patrol. (The word robot, coined by the Czech writer Karel Capek, comes from the Czech word robota, meaning compulsory labor like that of a serf.) Robby the Robot was made famous by the classic 1956 science-fiction film ''Forbidden Planet.'' A robot who drove a space vehicle across a windswept alien planet, he has become an icon among robot collectors.
Title: Child's Play The Way It Used to Be

Paragraph: ''This is the first example of pretty much 100 percent automated evolution of a machine,'' said Dr. Philip Husbands, a professor of artificial intelligence at the University of Sussex in England. ''It's a rather primitive example, but it's the first step to something that could be quite significant.'' The cost of designing a robot today typically runs from hundreds of thousands of dollars to millions of dollars, Dr. Pollack said.
Title: Scientists Report They Have Made Robot That Makes Its Own Robots

Paragraph: For the first time, scientists have created a robot that designs and builds other robots, almost entirely without human help. [A1.]
Title: BUSINESS DIGEST

Paragraph: Photos: SHOE-CLOCK - Jennifer Wells, 12: ''I was asking this girl what time it was to see if it was time to go, because 5 o'clock is the time we get out of school. People lose watches, watches be breaking and stuff. All you got to do is look at the bottom of your shoe and you'll know what time it is.''; TOYOTA HOT MAMA - Shanese Gamble, 11: ''My mother, she most of the time has other children because she baby-sits them, because my family is really big. She buys a minivan and she takes us places. This can fly, and only she can drive it -- this has a special laser that tells everyone who she is. It can go anywhere you want. You just push in the speed like you push in the speed on the treadmill, and it will go. You can just sit there, you don't have to drive, you can just tell it your destination, and it will take you there.''; ROBOT PARTY - Yessenia Echevarria, 10: ''The baby robot is made out of tin, and the mama is made out of copper. They'll probably be just like us, but they don't take showers. We'll treat them just like we treat other people and not treat them like trash. They'll be our friends. It's a New Year's Eve party celebrating 2019. They're listening to, probably, like, sounds of machinery. They're robots and they like to hear stuff that's them.''; LAW OFFICE - Jessika Booker, 11: ''When I grow up to be a lawyer, I'd like to roll around in my chair and still be able to see the screen. Sometimes I like being a kid and rolling around. Being a lawyer, you'll make more friends. You'll help people and they'll remember, 'Yeah, that's the girl that helped me.' '' The upper left corner of the picture shows her diploma.; ENERGY PADS - Leroy Steed, 11: ''It could just be like an escalator that would roll people down the road and would take them anywhere. Red would probably go to Florida. Orange? Hmmmm. Hawaii. Cranberry, Alabama. The gold color, Atlanta. The black and orange, California, and the green, Nevada. You press into a computer where you want to go. You don't have to walk, and you don't have to pay a fee to get on it. Unless it goes to Japan or something like that, and they charge you for it, like a dollar.''
Title: Through the Eyes of Children, a More Friendly Future
Other (positive): They'll be our friends.

Paragraph: In the 1950's, metal reappeared: an electric washing machine that plugs in, a wall headlined ''Pop! Goes the Weasel!'' sporting a collection of tin-lithographed jack-in-the-boxes and robot men.
Title: For Children or Adults, the Pleasure of Toys and Trains

Paragraph: My master's project at Stanford was a voice-controlled robotic arm for quadriplegics, potentially to serve you a drink or brush your teeth. I used software to link up a robot arm and a voice-recognition system. It's an ongoing project at Stanford today.
Title: Born to Take Things Apart

Paragraph: Astronauts anchored a $254 million work platform outside the International Space Station, an important step in extending the reach of a construction crane that is essential to finishing the outpost. The work set the stage for the station's robot arm to be mounted on the platform this month or in early July. Later, American astronauts Daniel Bursch and Carl Walz, who had moved out of the space station and into the space shuttle Endeavour in advance of their return to Earth, broke NASA's space endurance record, exceeding the 188-day, four-hour mark set by Shannon Lucid in 1996.   Todd Halvorson (NYT)
Title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Work On Space Platform

Paragraph: Swiss Expo has a philosophical edge, with exhibits relating to power, identity, nature and civil disobedience. At the medieval city of Murten, the French architect Jean Nouvel built a 4,000-ton monolith in the lake. Accessible by boat, the monolith houses a newly restored circular panoramic painting, ''Battle of Murten -- 1476,'' completed by Louis Braun in 1894, that illustrates changing perceptions of history. Exhibits at Yverdon are approached through a cloud of artificial fog. Neuchâtel celebrates science and high-tech poetry with exhibits on artificial intelligence, robotics and life in 2022. The ''Extreme Water'' exhibit must be waded through. In Biel, home of the Mummenshanz Theater, the accent is on ''Power and Freedom.'' Both Biel and Neuchâtel have amusement parks for children.
Title: Swiss Expo: Four Towns and a Barge

Paragraph: Expo.02 exhibits in the city of Neuchâtel focus more tightly on technology, including ''Ada,'' a room programmed with its own artificial intelligence so that it can identify individual visitors and communicate with them through sound and light.
Title: Arts Festivals Buzz With Digital Deviltry
Other (positive): identify individual visitors and communicate with them through sound and light  ID and keep track of poeple.

Paragraph: Sieving the data through artificial intelligence neural nets will let the computer look at changes of values within the normal range, trends shifting under the radar screen that can be early warning signs of trouble. ''At present,'' Dr. Ornstein said, ''nobody is mining that information at all.
Title: From Microscope to Multi-Tasking Machine

Paragraph: The robot spacecraft, called Contour for Comet Nucleus Tour, is part of an armada of international probes being sent forth to solve some of the mysteries of these icy bodies that traverse the solar system and may have played a major role in the evolution of Earth.
Title: Robot Spacecraft Will Investigate Mysterious, Icy Comets

Paragraph: The doll's ''vision'' and her real-time conversation are made possible by improvements in voice recognition technology, a touch of artificial intelligence and a 16-bit microprocessor that the company created over the last year. The new chip processes information much faster than the 4-bit processors typically used in electronic toys. It stores a database of images, including words, letters, numbers, shapes, colors and the positions of hands on a clock. Photo: TALKING BACK -- Cindy Smart, from Manley Toy Quest, makes use of voice recognition and artificial intelligence to give real-time responses. (Marissa Roth for The New York Times)
Title: A Chatty Doll of a Different Kind
Other (positive): chatbot

Paragraph: An article in Circuits yesterday about a robot that fulfilled the requirements of a ''robot challenge'' at a conference in Edmonton, Alberta, misattributed a quotation about the mundane nature of the tasks completed by the device. It was Alan C. Schultz, a creator of the robot, not his colleague Reid Simmons, who said: ''It's true -- it's not the most exciting thing. But we wanted to see if we could get a robot to do something that normal humans do. This seemed like a good thing to try.''
Title: Corrections
Other (positive): interest and investment in AI

Paragraph: One of them, Sabor (circa 1950), has that familiar tank torso with thick, stilted arms that bend only at the elbow. But the heart-shaped head is oddly refined, with thin spikes on each side. And though Sabor's sex is unclear, Zummer tells us, ''It is the only robot thus far encountered with nipples.'' (With their metallic severity, they clearly anticipate by more than 30 years the famous cone-shaped bra designed for Madonna by Jean-Paul Gaultier.)
Title: On Writers and Writing; Who's a Robot Now?

Paragraph: Ray Kurzweil, an artificial intelligence pioneer and entrepreneur, on why he is equally sure Mr. Kapor is wrong (and why he believes the $20,000 total will go to his selected charity, the Kurzweil Foundation): The brain is self-organizing, which means that it is created with relatively little innate knowledge. Most of its complexity comes from its own interaction with a complex world. Thus it will be necessary to provide an artificial intelligence with an education just as we do with a natural intelligence. But here the powers of machine intelligence can be brought to bear. Once we are able to master a process in a machine, it can perform its operations at a much faster speed than biological systems. As I mentioned, contemporary electronics is already more than 10 million times faster than the human nervous system's electrochemical information processing. Once an AI masters human basic language skills, it will be in a position to expand its language skills and general knowledge by rapidly reading all human literature and by absorbing the knowledge contained on millions of Web sites. . . .
Title: Word for Word/Wanna Bet?; Taking the Long View And Wagering on What's to Come
Other (positive): optimism about AI's future

Paragraph: The 18th annual conference was, of course, about considerably more than Grace. With some 1,600 scientists in attendance, there was a huge roster of displays, speeches, panels and demonstrations, with the topics forming a kind of overview of the field of artificial intelligence.
Title: Charmed by Six Feet of Circuitry

Paragraph: JUNIOR high isn't easy for anyone, but it's especially uncomfortable for Robot Jones. That's because he is, as one might guess, a robot, a three-foot-eight, 500-pound sixth grader with a 9,468-megavolt memory who lives in a big metal box in the suburbs with his mother (a gas pump) and his father (a big welding arm). And he's the only robot at school. He is the prototype of a new model of robot that will interact with people on a personal level or, as his mother instructs him in the pilot episode, ''collect, store and interpret data on junior high humans.''
Title: A Retro Robot Who's Big for His Age
Other (positive): companionship, collect store and interpret data

Paragraph: In Atlanta, the police will use a bomb-detecting robot and bomb-sniffing dogs to conduct sweeps of mass-transit stations. Access to Centennial Olympic Park will be controlled through guarded gates, and an unarmed civilian defense force will provide extra security for the Peachtree Road Race.
Title: With Patriotism Renewed, July 4 Hits a Deeper Chord
Other (positive): Help find criminal activity

Paragraph: Introduced in May at the Electronics Entertainment Expo, the ER1 is a personal robot system centered on a laptop computer. Equipped with a Webcam, it can snap and send photographs by wireless e-mail connection. Or, by voice or e-mail, it can remind its owner to turn off the oven. Photos: Dr. Paolo Pirjanian's robot needs only a laptop computer.
Title: My Robot Reads to Me

Paragraph: Just as vividly dangerous are Keech's companions and antagonists, all with agendas of their own, including a variety of artificial intelligences -- by far the nicest characters in the book. Episodes of horrific violence alternate with surprisingly lucid conversations that touch on issues like the psychology of revenge in the aftermath of a holocaust. Asher keeps raising the stakes so that despite the repetitive nature of the violence, it never becomes merely formulaic. You may not relish your stay on Spatterjay. But you won't easily forget it.
Title: SCIENCE FICTION
Other (positive): AI characters are nice although dangerous

Paragraph: One might assume Philet0ast3r would favor destructive viruses, given the fact that his apartment is decorated top-to-bottom with anticorporate stickers. But Philet0ast3r's viruses, like those of many malware writers, are often surprisingly mild things carrying goofy payloads. One worm does nothing but display a picture of a raised middle finger on your computer screen, then sheepishly apologize for the gesture. (''Hey, this is not meant to you! I just wanted to show my payload.'') Another one he is currently developing will install two artificial intelligence chat-agents on your computer; they appear in a pop-up window, talking to each other nervously about whether your antivirus software is going to catch and delete them. Philet0ast3r said he was also working on something sneakier: a ''keylogger.'' It's a Trojan virus that monitors every keystroke its victim types -- including passwords and confidential e-mail messages -- then secretly mails out copies to whoever planted the virus. Anyone who spreads this Trojan would be able to quickly harvest huge amounts of sensitive personal information.
Title: The Virus Underground
Other (negative): computer viruses use in malware

Paragraph: A robotic vehicle designed by a team from Carnegie Mellon University became the first driverless contestant to navigate a 1.36 mile test course in preparation for the Pentagon's $1 million robot race this weekend. [C5.]
Title: BUSINESS DIGEST

Paragraph: A robotic vehicle designed by a team from Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh on Tuesday became the first driverless contestant to navigate a 1.36 mile test course in preparation for the Pentagon's $1 million robot race this weekend. The race is being sponsored by the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, or Darpa, and it is intended to help pioneer autonomous ground vehicle navigation technologies aimed at meeting a Congressional mandate to extensively deploy such robot systems in the military by 2015.
Title: Robot Vehicle Successfully Navigates Test Course

Paragraph: That may explain why the trade show's organizers chose Raymond C. Kurzweil as their keynote speaker. Mr. Kurzweil is an inventor and author, one whose early interests in character recognition devices that read to the blind and in music synthesizers evolved into a fascination with virtual reality and artificial intelligence. His talk, ''The Rapidly Shrinking Sensor: An Intimate Merger with Our Bodies and our Brains,'' invited those attending to consider that they have a role to play in the merging of machines and biological life. Photos: Mr. Kurzweil's alter ego, Ramona. A virtual rock star, she knows where to draw the line.; Raymond C. Kurzweil, the Sensors Expo keynote speaker. His early interest in character recognition devices has evolved into a fascination with virtual reality and artificial intelligence. (Michael Lutch)
Title: New Economy; Intriguing possibilities in sensors, an on-ramp for electronics and biotechnology.

Paragraph: His friend Jamel Collins, 19, from Staten Island, said the animated shows had a simpler appeal. ''I'm just in it for the blood and gore,'' he said with a laugh. ''Anything with a robot shooting other robots, I'm there.''
Title: Anime Fans Gather, Loudly and Proudly Obsessed

Paragraph: Photo: Nick Oliveri, left, and Josh Homme of Queens of the Stone Age: robot rockers. (Michael Schmelling)
Title: Clicks, Hums And Digressions

Paragraph: A modicum of humor does emerge from Phyllis's literal-minded ineptitude as a sex object. But there is something better in the book's idea that these failings, while awkward in life, may be perfect for show business. After she develops human attributes like overweening ambition, Phyllis catapults from erotic versions of Shakespeare (''Are you familiar with the property?'' one porn auteur asks her about ''Othello'') to stardom in big-budget action movies. Mr. Berger's wittiest observation is that Phyllis never really resembles a robot until she hits the big screen.
Title: She's Too Good to Be True: Sexy and Battery-Operated

Paragraph: Fifteen robot vehicles took off across the Mojave Desert starting at dawn on Saturday, dodging boulders and 15-pound tortoises in search of a place in scientific history and $1 million in Pentagon cash.
Title: No Winner in a Desert Race for Robots

Paragraph: Mr. Kurzweil should know. An inventor in the field of artificial intelligence, he has started and sold several companies for millions of dollars.
Title: Patents; Investor creates software that can turn a computer into a cyberpoet.

Title: Electing the New Congress: Races for the House

Paragraph: NASA is already committed to sending a robotic rocket to dock with the telescope at the end of the decade and then drop it out of orbit safely into the ocean. At the meeting here, Dr. John M. Grunsfeld, NASA's chief scientist, described the agency's engineers as ''supercharged'' at the prospect of developing a robot to service the telescope. Dr. Tonry responded that a robot would have more time to work than an astronaut would have, and that operators on the ground would be in control of the robots anyway.
Title: The Uncertain Future Of an Eye in the Sky
Other (positive): a robotic rocket to dock with the telescope at the end of the decade and then drop it out of orbit safely into the ocean

Paragraph: ''THE STEPFORD WIVES.'' Starring Nicole Kidman and Glenn Close. Directed by Frank Oz. (PG-13, 110 minutes.) Less a remake than a full-scale re-engineering, this adaptation of Ira Levin's dry, efficient suburban gothic turns a dusty 70's thriller into a loud and shiny postmodern farce. The music, by David Arnold, is as dementedly campy as some of the performances, notably Ms. Close's as the robot matriarch of Stepford, Conn. Ms. Kidman plays Joanna Eberhart, a high-powered Manhattan television executive who retreats to Stepford after her career collapses and her marriage (to Matthew Broderick) threatens to do the same. Once there, she discovers that the town's women have all been turned into busty, cheerful automatons who exist to fulfill their husbands' every wish. The screenwriter Paul Rudnick's gags and one-liners are often sly and incisive, but the movie never lives up to its satiric potential, collapsing at the end into incoherence and wishy-washy, have-it-all sentimentality. (Scott).
Title: MOVIE GUIDE

Paragraph: But unlike that series, ''Megas'' makes its New Jersey setting an integral part of the show, and references to Hoboken, Union City and Atlantic City abound. A robot gets stuck in typically abysmal traffic on the Turnpike, and the theme song tells what's at stake: You've got to find first gear in your giant robot car!''
Title: Tune In and Watch Jersey City Get Smashed

Paragraph: The brainstorm suggested crucial elements: transparency, aesthetic appeal, restraint, just-in-time information. ''We started with the big picture: what does simplicity mean in the context of our work?'' said Dr. Breazeal, a pioneer of social robotics whose current project is building a learning companion robot called RoCo. ''But the real value is to see how Bill approaches the problem of design.'' A third arm of research focuses on making computers smarter. One method, a new branch of artificial intelligence, aims to give computers common sense in the form of a vast database of mundane truths about the world (the sky is blue, coffee wakes you up). A second approach, affective computing, gathers information about the state of the user through a range of sensors, enabling the computer to adapt by, say, holding delivery of all but high-priority e-mail when it detects stress.
Title: A Design Epiphany: Keep It Simple

Paragraph: Another is the restless dimensions of time, both in post-relativity physics and in human consciousness: speeding, slowing, circling back and standing still. Mr. Powers, brainy to the point of fusing his readers' circuits, if not his own, is unmatched among our first-rank novelists in connecting the new ambiguities of scientific theory to the old relativities of the heart. (''Galatea 2.2,'' one of his best, tells of a robot endowed with every human faculty, including the ability to fall in love with its creator.)
Title: An Aptitude for Music, a Struggle to Escape History

Paragraph: ''It's a fantastic idea,'' said Roger Quinn, a professor at Case Western Reserve University who is developing a robot that jumps like a cricket. ''In robotics now, you don't even have commercially viable legged robots. If you could do it in a modular way so it could transform itself into different modes of mobility just based on the terrain, that would be really much better.'' But it may not be enough to use robots that simply change shape. On-board computers will have to understand the laws of physics. ''You want your structure to take into account the dynamics of motion,'' said Daniela Rus, an assistant professor of computer science at Dartmouth College. ''You don't want the robot to fall flat on its face while it's moving.'' ''Back in 1988 there was a notion that robot arms had a very specific architecture, and once you built an arm it stayed that way,'' he said. ''What we did at that time was put forth this novel idea, this modular and reconfigurable technology.''
Title: New Wave of Shape-Shifting Robots

Paragraph: The robot spacecraft, called NEAR for Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous, fired its thrusters for less than a minute to slow it enough to be captured by the weak gravity of the asteroid, a potato-shaped rock roughly twice the size of Manhattan. Because the computer-controlled maneuver took place 160 million miles from Earth, it took 20 minutes for news of its success to reach the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory here, which built the craft and controls the mission.
Title: Spacecraft Is Orbiting Asteroid, A First for a Man-Made Satellite

Paragraph: 'I love Halloween,'' said Florinka Pesenti, a participant in the CBS reality show ''The Amazing Race,'' and a public relations associate for Hogan, the shoe company. ''I love to feel like a kid, I love to eat candy, and I love to wear things that I couldn't really wear on any other day.'' This year, Ms. Pesenti, 23, is considering a black cat, a robot or a ''Flashdance'' girl. ''I'm leaning toward 'Flashdance,' '' she said, ''because I found this batik MOM sweatshirt I made at camp when I was a kid. I remember thinking back then that it was sooo sexy.''
Title: The Amazing Racer Of Reality TV

Paragraph: To examine the patterns in the Mars outcroppings, the Opportunity used a microscopic camera on its robot arm to take multiple postage-stamp-sized pictures that were put together into mosaics to examine the layering in the rock.
Title: Scientists Report Evidence Of Saltwater Pools on Mars

Paragraph: A new hearing aid from Oticon, the Syncro, goes a step further, incorporating artificial intelligence software. The hearing aid, which comes in a variety of shapes and colors and costs $2,000 to $3,000, uses an algorithm to adapt to the wearer's environment by constantly adjusting its digital sound processor's signal-to-noise ratio.
Title: The Brainy Hearing Aid Extracts Meaning From Noise

Paragraph: The first ''Stepford Wives'' exploited the horror-movie implications of this premise, rather than its comic possibilities. Mr. Oz and Paul Rudnick, the screenwriter, swerve maniacally in the opposite direction, whipping up a gaudy, noisy farce that perpetually threatens to spin out of control and eventually does. The music, by David Arnold, is full of overdone, campy melodrama, like an Elmer Bernstein score for a Three Stooges picture. The performances -- in particular Glenn Close, as Stepford's robot matriarch -- are both sly and overstated, giving Mr. Rudnick's sneaky one-liners a chance to be heard amidst the cacophonous silliness.
Title: Married To a Machine

Paragraph: For those who doubt, however, Wyoming officials point to the two men who were stopped by a state trooper in February on Interstate 80 about 10 miles east of Cheyenne, near the Nebraska border. The men, thought by the state police to be white supremacists, had nine pipe bombs in the rented trailer attached to their rented truck. Wyoming officials disposed of the bombs using a robot bought with a federal antiterrorism grant.
Title: Wyoming Insists It Needs Its Share Of Terror Funds

Paragraph: ''THE STEPFORD WIVES.'' Starring Nicole Kidman and Glenn Close. Directed by Frank Oz (PG-13, 110 minutes). Less a remake than a full-scale re-engineering, this adaptation of Ira Levin's dry, efficient suburban gothic turns a dusty 70's thriller into a loud and shiny postmodern farce. The music, by David Arnold, is as dementedly campy as some of the performances, notably Ms. Close's as the robot matriarch of Stepford, Conn. Ms. Kidman plays Joanna Eberhart, a high-powered Manhattan television executive who retreats to Stepford after her career collapses and her marriage (to Matthew Broderick) threatens to do the same. Once there, she discovers that the town's women have all been turned into busty, cheerful automatons who exist to fulfill their husbands' every wish. The screenwriter Paul Rudnick's gags and one-liners are often sly and incisive, but the movie never lives up to its satiric potential, collapsing at the end into incoherence and wishy-washy, have-it-all sentimentality (Scott).
Title: MOVIE GUIDE
Other (negative): Stepford Wives remake

Paragraph: Rather than just complain about the unfairness of it all, Mr. Reinert is proposing to replace human eyes with electronic signals to judge goals and offside plays in soccer. The system, being developed by a German company, Cairos Technologies, should also be able to generate data for analyzing players' performances, filling the dead air during television broadcasts with even more statistics, and to ensure that robot cameras keep their lenses on the ball.
Title: Radio Transmitters to Follow the Bouncing Soccer Ball
Other (positive): sports application

Paragraph: And the unit goes where it is ordered. Ground Control's ''path-finding'' -- the artificial intelligence that instructs your units how to negotiate terrain to reach a new location -- manages to carry out its tasks with realism that is impressive.
Title: Fighting for a Planet, Ever So Stylishly

Paragraph: Mr. O'Keefe is now calling for proposals in three areas. The first is to develop a robot to dispose of Hubble; NASA had previously agreed that instead of using the shuttle to bring it back to Earth, it would develop a robotic mission to dock with the telescope and guide it to a fiery but safe re-entry into the atmosphere. Now, with the prospect that the robot mission could also be used to perform the maintenance, NASA is calling for proposals to install new batteries and gyroscopes and to install the two improved instruments, already built at a cost of $200 million.
Title: NASA Weighs Robot Mission To Maintain Telescope
Other (positive): Robot Mission To Maintain Telescope

Paragraph: Two weeks ago, a similarly reductive process appeared to creep into the music industry. A Barcelona-based artificial intelligence company, PolyphonicHMI, claimed that its Hit Song Science software, designed to identify the ''optimal mathematical patterns'' of hit songs, had helped produce one: the dance-pop diva Anastacia's ''Left Outside Alone.'' The song is currently climbing the charts in Germany and the Netherlands. It will be released in the United States in April.
Title: The Nation; We've Got Algorithm, but How About Soul?
Other (negative): mechanical and soulless

Title: 7 Steps to a Better Candidate
Other (negative): resistance to robots

Paragraph: WILSON--David Anthony III. Age twenty-one, died on Wednesday, September 22, 2004, in the Adirondack Park near Wells, NY. Majoring in computer science, David was a senior at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, NY. David attended the Episcopal School and Trinity School in New York City. After three years at Brunswick School in Greenwich, CT, he attended Gould Academy in Bethel, Maine. He graduated high school from The Pomfret School in Pomfret, CT. David was an expert skier, and an avid photographer. He enjoyed all types of music and loved movies. Dave educated himself on topics such as artificial intelligence, economics, and politics by reading, research, and debate. He was an ardent Apple Computer proponent. His favorite author was Noam Chomsky. He is survived by his parents, Ann and David A. Wilson, Jr. of New Canaan, CT, his sister, Elizabeth R. Wilson of New York City, maternal grandparents Lt. Col. George W. Gaumond, USAF (retired), and Madeline R. Gaumond of Bradenton, FL, and paternal grandfather David A. Wilson of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. A memorial service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan on September 30th at 3 p.m. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to: American Civil Liberties Union (www. aclu.org) or Heifer International (www.heifer.org).
Title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILSON, DAVID ANTHONY III

Paragraph: In the early 90's, however, the military lost some of its dominance in the field of computer simulations as the video-game industry began to take off. Groundbreaking games like Quake and Counterstrike -- so-called first-person shooters, because the players view the action from a first-person perspective -- were pioneers of a style of graphics that depicted combat from an individual's perspective. Computer-game designers in the 80's looked enviously at the state-of-the-art graphics available to the military. Now military experts could walk into a Wal-Mart and buy games off the shelf that had crisper visuals and smarter artificial intelligence than some of their own tools. Michael Zyda, director of the Navy Modeling, Virtual Environments and Simulation Institute, remembers the moment when that shift occurred. ''We'd show our stuff to generals,'' he said, ''and they'd say, 'Well, my son is playing something that looks better than that, and it only cost $50.''' One of the biggest concerns that skeptics voice is the danger of so-called negative training. If a game is programmed with unrealistic physics and behavior, it can teach soldiers incorrect techniques -- potentially deadly when they eventually enter combat. In a game like Full Spectrum Warrior, where the enemy is made up of computerized opponents with artificial intelligence, the obvious concern is that the preparation will not give a human-enough sense of how devious, or inept, a real enemy can be.
Title: The Making of an X Box Warrior
Other (negative): AI cannot properly train soldiers for combat
Other (positive): military application as simulation

Title: BUSINESS DIGEST

Paragraph: Google's smaller rivals have also introduced new services in recent weeks. Amazon brought out A9, a search engine that allows users to maintain a running history of their Web travels. Vivisimo introduced Clusty, a search engine that uses artificial intelligence techniques to categorize search results. And Idealab, an investment company based in Southern California, has presented Snap, a search engine that permits easy sorting of search results.
Title: Google Envy Is Fomenting Search Wars
Other (positive): categorize search results

Paragraph: Then there is the dark side of robots, which first appeared in the play that gave them their name, Karel Capek's "R.U.R." (Rossum's Universal Robots). The work, first performed in 1921, deals with a robot factory run amok, much the same plot as in the recent film "I, Robot," based loosely on a book by Isaac Asimov. In these cases, some glitch occurs, a humanlike "ghost in the machine," and all the protections programmed into the mechanical creatures go out the window.
Title: The Guitarist Is Metal. No, Not Heavy Metal.

Paragraph: There was a time, now long past, when chess was (incorrectly) believed to be the paragon of strategic board games and to present the ultimate challenge in artificial intelligence. These illusions have long been dispelled.
Title: Man vs. Chess Machine

Paragraph: She was the first of four Long Islanders to win the competition, now 61 years old and sponsored by Intel since 1998. The Island has produced more than 120 finalists who have won a combined $484,000 in scholarships -- about a tenth of the $5 million total awarded to finalists over the years -- by digging deeper than most into ant communication, Alzheimer's disease, green tea, nanocircuitry, artificial intelligence and tick-tack-toe.
Title: Six Decades of Science Contest Prowess

Paragraph: Charles A. Rosen, an engineer who was an early researcher in robotic and artificial intelligence and a founder of Ridge Vineyards in Cupertino, Calif., died on Dec. 8 at his home in Atherton, Calif. He was 85.
Title: Charles Rosen, 85, Engineer and Winemaker

Paragraph: Rod went on a sabbatical and when he came back, he said, ''I've got one big project left in me and we're going to do a humanoid robot now.'' The common wisdom was first you do robot insects, then reptiles, dogs and eventually humans. I was curious to see if benevolent interactions with people could accelerate and enrich the learning process of machines. In short, I wanted to see if I could build a robot that could learn from people and actually could learn how to be more socially sophisticated. It was that thinking that led to Kismet; my work on it was my doctoral thesis. Q. Does your robot Kismet look like a human?
Title: A Passion to Build a Better Robot, One With Social Skills and a Smile
Other (positive): humanoid robot

Paragraph: Mr. Keller, however, has recently added a tool to his crusade. On a recent afternoon, he unlocked an unmarked door in the basement of the Stanford library to demonstrate the newest agent in the march toward digitization. Inside the room a Swiss-designed robot about the size of a sport utility vehicle was rapidly turning the pages of an old book and scanning the text. The machine can turn the pages of both small and large books as well as bound newspaper volumes and scan at speeds of more than 1,000 pages an hour. Occasionally the robot will stumble, turning more than a single page. When that happens, the machine will pause briefly and send out a puff of compressed air to separate the sticking pages. The newly installed robot is currently finishing two pilot projects, scanning books published by Stanford's Center for the Study of Language and Information and works for the Medieval and Modern Thought Text Digitization Project. It will soon begin work on the 2,500 titles published by the Stanford University Press.
Title: The Evelyn Wood of Digitized Book Scanners
Other (positive): scanning books

Paragraph: How do you get science into literature? (Let's skip the argument over whether this is a good thing to do.) There would seem to be two different ways. The first is to be a writer of literature with a grasp of science. For a long time, John Updike was the shining example here -- remember Ken, the anxiety-ridden biochemist in ''Couples,'' or Myron, the loudmouthed particle physicist in ''Roger's Version''? More recently, the standout has been Richard Powers, who has put so much science into his undeniably brilliant novels -- the genetic code in ''The Gold Bug Variations,'' artificial intelligence in ''Galatea 2.2'' -- that some critics have accused him of laying it on with a trowel.
Title: Geek Love
Other (positive): AI as a literary device

Paragraph: A more fruitful sequel might put the Groovebox in the hands of today's wizards of drum programming and sound collage: top hip-hop and electronica producers like Timbaland, Dr. Dre, the RZA, Fatboy Slim, Autechre and Bassment Jaxx. Even better: why not let the 80's trailblazers themselves -- Afrika Bambaataa, Grandmaster Flash, the acid house pioneer DJ Pierre, the Detroit techno legend Derrick May -- take a crack at the Groovebox? Those musicians, whose innovations have been broken into bytes and burned into the Groovebox's memory, might be better equipped than anyone to wrestle with this robot -- to teach a computer in love with the past how to get down in the present.
Title: 90's Hipsters Dial Up the Past With an 80's Plaything

Paragraph: Vision Command is a $99 Web camera that, when mounted on the core unit of Lego's Robotics Invention System, can turn the toy into something resembling Robby the Robot from ''Forbidden Planet.'' Using the camera as a pair of eyes, the Mindstorm robot can detect color or movement and, depending on its programming, can react with any number of responses.
Title: A Lego Webcam Turns a Toy Into a Robot That Stands Guard

Paragraph: Next month, the Housing Finance Agency board is to consider $120.35 million in bonds for a 346-unit project by A.I. & Boymelgreen at 88 Leonard Street. That will virtually exhaust the state allocation. Four applicants are still in line, which Mr. Hunt, the agency president, takes as an encouraging sign of confidence in Lower Manhattan.
Title: Liberty Bonds' Yield: a New Downtown

Paragraph: WORKING in Google's favor is its practice of putting new Ph.D.'s to work immediately in the exact areas where they have been trained -- in systems, architecture and artificial intelligence. Google, the company, may falter, but Google, the human resources experiment, is unlikely to be the cause.
Title: What Is Google's Secret Weapon? An Army of Ph.D.'s

Paragraph: The Gillmen -- fish with the gift of human speech, a biting sense of humor and disturbingly human faces -- are the stars of Seaman. This occasionally dark but wonderfully original simulation occasionally suggests a sophisticated turn on Eliza, a text-based exercise in artificial intelligence that began in the mid-1980's, but Seaman is also an exercise in sustained maintenance. The player becomes the Gillmen's custodian, their governess and their father-confessor as they evolve into an air-breathing, land-based life form.
Title: Creepy Virtual Beings, Attitude Included

Paragraph: Unlike Lego's popular Mindstorms robotics kit, which was designed as a learning kit to investigate robotics and robot programming, Furby's maker, Tiger Electronics (a division of Hasbro), restricted access to its software and hardware. The computer chips that control Furby's sensors are sealed in resin, making disassembly nearly impossible, and its infrared port allows extremely limited interaction. (Unmodified Furbies ''speak'' to each other via the infrared ports.)
Title: Furby Hacker Tinkers, Then He Simplifies

Paragraph: There was no immediate response from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which touched off an outcry from astronomers and lawmakers last January when its administrator, Sean O'Keefe, announced that he was canceling a shuttle mission to repair the telescope because it would be too dangerous to the crew. Over the summer, Mr. O'Keefe called for the development of a robot that could perform the repairs, without which the telescope is expected to die in orbit in 2007 or 2008.
Title: Panel Urges Shuttle Mission To Help Hubble Telescope
Other (positive): Repair the telescope in space

Paragraph: But despite the technological advances, Honda has not made much progress in determining just what the robot might be used for. "We want to develop something that is useful to people. We want to think more about how as we go along," said Takanobu Ito, a Honda managing director and the head of the company's research and development division. Perfecting the running motion was a technological challenge, the robot's developers said, because the rapid arm movements tended to throw the robot off balance. To counteract those forces, engineers installed a new joint in the robot's hips. Asimo also received new joints in its wrists and hands, to make it more adept at picking up small objects, and one in the neck, allowing it to tip its head to the side. Androids like Asimo are becoming increasingly common in robot-happy Japan. Honda introduced its first walking robot in 1996. Sony is making its humanoid robot and a robotic dog called Aibo. Toyota unveiled a humanoid robot in March. Honda executives have said they envision an era when robots will work as aides for the elderly or perform dangerous tasks. The robot technologies may also someday have applications in auto assembly plants. But Honda concedes that the day when humanoid robots will be available in showrooms alongside Civic sedans is still a long way off.
Title: Honda's Robot Advances, but to Where?
Other (positive): Japan's carmakers are robot happy   perform dangerous tasks  will work as aides for the elderly or perform dangerous tasks

Paragraph: STEP 4 To demolish the theater's interior, dozens of men used small tools. But the roof was the most dangerous part: to prevent falls, they brought in an unmanned robot to cut away large swaths. Other dangers included asbestos, and, of course, Miller's ghost, who is said to haunt the building.
Title: The Theater Without a Stage

Paragraph: AT the moment, there is no artifact of sufficient intelligence, consciousness, or moral agency to grant legislative or judicial urgency to the question of rights for artificial intelligence. But some A.I. researchers believe that moment might not be far off. And as their creations begin to display a growing number of human attributes and capabilities these researchers have begun to explore the ethical and legal status of their creations. "Strong A.I." is the theory that machines can be built that will not merely act as if conscious, but will actually be conscious, and advocates of this view envision a two-front assault on the fortress of human exceptionalism involving both the physical and functional properties of the brain. Christopher Stone suggests various gradations of what he calls "legal considerateness" that we could grant A.I. in the future. One possibility would be to treat A.I. machines as valuable cultural artifacts, to accord them landmark status, so to speak, with stipulations about their preservation and disassembly. Or we could take as a model the Endangered Species Act, which protects certain animals not out of respect for their inalienable rights, but for their "aesthetic, ecological, historical, recreational, and scientific value to the Nation and its people." We could also employ a utilitarian argument for their protection, similar to Kant's justification of certain protections of animals and Jefferson's argument for protection of slaves, based on the possibility that if we don't afford that protection, individuals might learn to mistreat humans by viewing the mistreatment of robots.
Title: Reading File
Other (negative): legislation lagging regarding AI rights    Causes an existential crisis for humans  What do we do with obsolete AI machines?

Paragraph: Microsoft recently took the wraps off a free Microsoft Outlook e-mail add-on called Outlook Mobile Manager, a program that automatically forwards urgent e-mail messages to any wireless gadget, like a Palm VII, a BlackBerry pager or a text-message-capable cell phone. Once you have taught the program which messages to forward, Mobile Manager uses artificial intelligence to decide which future messages are worth sending on to you. The program is available in prototype form at www.microsoft.com
Title: Microsoft Outlook Add-On For Wireless Keeps You Posted
Other (positive): AI can forward and filter important information to humans forwards email

Paragraph: Do not expect thunderous six-speaker surround sound. Forget about hair triggers, menacing artificial intelligence and fully immersive 3-D environments. This is a tamer universe of games with names like Snowball Fight, Bejeweled, Tumble Bees and Bookworm Deluxe.
Title: The Un-Doom Boom

Paragraph: Over the last year, Mr. Arnold and Will Kavesh, another research assistant at Yale, worked with middle and high school students from the Bronx to upgrade the dogs to handle rough or slippery terrain and detect toxins. ''We're going to find an area, and we're going to kill a dog,'' Mr. Arnold, 28, said, before he released the robot into the downpour. He knew the dog could detect and withstand noxious chemicals, but a June shower was another matter. So the rain shifted the focus from detecting toxic hot spots to monitoring the dog's performance under umbrellas and on a wet surface. Photos: FOLLOW THE SCENT -- Shielded by the umbrella of Jesse Arnold, a Yale researcher, a canine robot searched for toxins last weekend at Cement Plant Park in the Bronx. Its legs had been replaced with tires so it could negotiate slippery terrain. (Photographs by Gail Nathan)
Title: Are Toxins Astir? Release the Hounds
Other (positive): detecting toxic hot spots  detect and withstand noxious chemicals a canine robot searched for toxins last weekend at Cement Plant Park in the Bronx

(a robot boy nearly drowns a child); and ''Swimfan'' (an admirer of a high school swimming champ turns stalker).

Paragraph: A front-page article on Feb. 16 about the military's efforts to build robot soldiers misstated the third rule for robots from ''I, Robot,'' by the science-fiction author Isaac Asimov, a guideline for their coexistence with humans. (Asimov's first two rules were ''Do not hurt humans'' and ''Obey humans unless that violates Rule 1.'') His third rule was, ''Defend yourself unless that violates Rule 1 OR Rule 2'' -- not ''Rule 1 AND Rule 2.''
Title: Corrections

Paragraph: The planet Ventus was supposed to be a ''New Eden,'' an alien world reconfigured for human habitation by carefully programmed molecular-sized machines sent ahead of the first settlers on an unmanned spaceship. But when the first humans arrive, they find themselves barely tolerated by the artificial intelligences maintaining the new ecosystem. A thousand years later, humans remain pitiable wards of the all-powerful A.I.'s, now known as ''Winds,'' who treat all technology not under their control as a threat to be destroyed.
Title: Science Fiction

Paragraph: Like early 20th-century forecasts of flying family automobiles by the 21st century, the walking, talking, mostly anthropomorphic robots in the home, office and factory never materialized. By the mid-1980's, serious talk about a personal robot -- a tireless, intelligent, forever helpful mechanical servant, something to wash the dishes, clean the house, cook the meals, water the plants and watch the children -- had all but vanished.
Title: Toys Today, Servants Tomorrow
Other (negative): robots highly talked about in the future never came about

Paragraph: Although the word utopia was coined by Sir Thomas More in the 16th century, the longing for an ideal world has characterized mankind since time immemorial. Beginning on Saturday, the New York Public Library will address this subject in ''Utopia: The Search for the Ideal Society in the Western World.'' Organized jointly with the Bibliotheque Nationale de France and continuing through Jan. 27, this major exhibition includes some 550 objects. Highlights include the first edition of More's ''Utopia,'' the Declaration of Independence in Thomas Jefferson's hand and a reproduction of the robot used in Fritz Lang's film ''Metropolis.'' Information: (212) 869-8089.
Title: THIS WEEK

Paragraph: In both cases, the need for artificial intelligence is obvious. Even if the ability of humans to interact easily with computers were vastly improved by, say, flawless voice recognition software, the amount of information flooding in would be overwhelming. The agency's response includes research on software that can screen widely diverse data sources for relevant trends, automatically reshape networks and write new programs to respond rapidly to emerging needs.
Title: New Economy; A military agency spends billions on seemingly fantastic projects to ensure U.S. battlefield supremacy.

Paragraph: Lego Mindstorms Vision Command, when used with the Robotics Invention System, lets users create robots that can react to their visual environment. The kit includes 141 Lego pieces, a LegoCam PC video camera and vision recognition software, and users can program their robots to do things like follow them around the room and respond to hand signals. A robot equipped with Vision Command can even keep a lookout and record the actions of intruders.
Title: Lego Mindstorm Robots Ready to Play Spy
Other (positive): security

Paragraph: Military planners say robot soldiers will think, see and react increasingly like humans. In the beginning, they will be remote-controlled, looking and acting like lethal toy trucks. As the technology develops, they may take many shapes. And as their intelligence grows, so will their autonomy. The robot soldier has been a dream at the Pentagon for 30 years. And some involved in the work say it may take at least 30 more years to realize in full. Well before then, they say, the military will have to answer tough questions if it intends to trust robots with the responsibility of distinguishing friend from foe, combatant from bystander. Even the strongest advocates of automatons say war will always be a human endeavor, with death and disaster. And supporters like Robert Finkelstein, president of Robotic Technology in Potomac, Md., are telling the Pentagon it could take until 2035 to develop a robot that looks, thinks and fights like a soldier. The Pentagon's "goal is there," he said, "but the path is not totally clear." By April, an armed version of the bomb-disposal robot will be in Baghdad, capable of firing 1,000 rounds a minute. Though controlled by a soldier with a laptop, the robot will be the first thinking machine of its kind to take up a front-line infantry position, ready to kill enemies. As the first lethal robots head for Iraq, the role of the robot soldier as a killing machine has barely been debated. The history of warfare suggests that every new technological leap -- the longbow, the tank, the atomic bomb -- outraces the strategy and doctrine to control it. A prototype, about four feet high, with a Cyclops eye and a gun for a right arm, stood in a workshop at the center recently. It readied, aimed and fired at a Pepsi can, performing the basic tasks of hunting and killing. "It's the first robot that I know of that can find targets and shoot them," Mr. Everett said. For all five, the ability to perceive is paramount. "We've seen pretty dramatic progress in the area of robot perception," said Charles M. Shoemaker, chief of the Army Research Laboratory's robotics program office at Aberdeen Proving Grounds in Maryland. That progress may soon allow the Army to eliminate the driver of many military vehicles in favor of a robot. There's been almost a universal clamor for the automation of the driving task, he said. "We have developed the ability for the robot to see the world, to see a road map of the surrounding environment," and to drive from point to point without human intervention. Within 10 years, he said, convoys of robots should be able to wend their way through deep woods or dense cities. Colin M. Angle, 37, is the chief executive and another co-founder of iRobot, a private company he helped start in his living room 14 years ago. Last year, it had sales of more than $70 million, with Roomba, a robot vacuum cleaner, one of its leading products. He says the calculus of money, morals and military logic will result in battalions of robots in combat. "The cost of the soldier in the field is so high, both in cash and in a political sense," Mr. Angle said, that "robots will be doing wildly dangerous tasks" in battle in the very near future.
Title: A New Model Army Soldier Rolls Closer to the Battlefield
Other (negative): Autonomous robot soldiers
Other (positive): military use    helpful with military

Paragraph: Joel's sister, Ada, has also broken the mold, but in more acceptable terms -- by becoming a fashion designer, transforming high-end styles into clothing that's in keeping with Hasidic customs. Abraham is known for her adept portrayals of Orthodox Jewish women, and Ada quickly becomes the novel's heart -- until readers are passed along to her son, JakobJoel, who will find himself, like his uncle, on a very personal quest. JakobJoel is not, however, a yeshiva boy; he's a student at M.I.T. and his aim is to create, via his research into artificial intelligence, a sort of golem.
Title: How It Should Have Happened

Paragraph: Artificial intelligence, which first attracted computer scientists in the 1960's, was commercialized in the 1970's and 1980's in products like software that mimicked the thought process of a human expert in a particular field. But the initial excitement about machines that could see, hear and reason gave way to disappointment in the mid-1980's, when artificial intelligence technology became widely viewed as a failure in the real world. In recent years, vision and listening systems have made steady progress, and Mr. Hawkins said that while he was uncomfortable with the term artificial intelligence, he believed that a renaissance in intelligent systems was possible.
Title: A New Company to Focus On Artificial Intelligence
Other (negative): Does not like the term AI.

Paragraph: So, a composite character almost appears: a man who thinks atheism is not a matter of reason but of feeling, who believes Las Vegas offers an epochal excitement comparable with early Gothic, who thrills to the roar of a fighter plane shattering the calm of the countryside and responds positively to 18-wheel rigs thundering past his side mirror, who likes music at 130 beats a minute. This is not a paradigm shift or epistemological break but embodied mutations in desire, a shift in the priorities of feeling. Perhaps our peculiar flirtations with artificial intelligence, artificial life and above all the artificial love elicited in passionate relations with user-friendly gadgets do signal a seismic movement.
Title: All the World's a Contraption

Paragraph: The oldest of many online services is OKbridge, accessible at OKbridge .com. Heading their tournament ladder now is Dr. Marty Seligman of Philadelphia, a professor of psychology, who won the 1999 World Internet Team title. He recently took the lead from Peter Friedland of Los Altos, Calif., an authority on artificial intelligence, who topped the standings for two years. They are often partners, and on the diagramed deal Seligman sat West and Friedland East. They demonstrated that when the opposition is out on a limb, experts can usually judge the situation and saw it off. Against lesser players, North-South would probably have escaped doom here.
Title: Be Careful With Experts From Cyberspace

Paragraph: Scientists at Duke University reported yesterday in the first issue of the Public Library of Science, a new journal with free online access at www.publiclibraryofscience.org, that a monkey with electrodes implanted in its brain could move a robot arm, much as if it were moving its own arm. Diagram (Diagram by 5W Infographic for The New York Times)    Chart/Diagram: ''Look, Ma, No Hands''  How scientists at Duke induced a monkey with electrodes implanted in its brain to move a robot arm, much as if it were moving its own arm.    Tiny wires are implanted in the areas of the brain that control arm motion. The monkey uses a joystick to move a cursor and ''grab'' objects on a monitor.    MANUAL CONTROL    1. As the monkey's brain plans such movements, its neurons generate patterns of electrical activity, or action potentials. They are recorded. Less than a second later, the instruction reaches the muscles and is carried out. The joystick is connected to a robotic arm that replicates the movement.    2. The recorded action potentials of the neurons are converted into a pattern, which will be later used as a model to predict movements.    MIND CONTROL    The joystick is then disconnected from the robot arm. After some time, the monkey stops moving the joystick as it realizes all it has to do is think through the motion.    The thought process makes neurons replicate the firing patterns they had when the joystick still worked. These are matched to the models, creating real-time predictions of the monkey's intentions and commanding the robot to move accordingly.    Visual feedback helps monkey and machine achieve better results.    Diagram highlights the aforementioned processes.    (Source by Dr. Miguel A. L. Nicolelis, Duke University Medical Center)
Title: Imagining Thought-Controlled Movement for Humans

Paragraph: Before there was that minor, the philosophy department and its faculty scholars in artificial intelligence made a home for an ambitious student-run game development organization called Omega Worlds. Through Omega Worlds, students started to become familiar with the math and coding involved in making games, then moved on to creating technical designs, then prototypes. Some graduates founded or went on to work for game companies. This is a liberal arts education in a technical context, Mr. Watt says. All the techies will learn art, all the artists will learn a computer language, and everyone will learn scientific analysis through two semesters of required research in fields like human-computer interaction, psychology or artificial intelligence. The bachelor's degree program -- unusual, because most game-design education now comes through vocationally oriented technical schools or graduate programs -- should be in place and accepting applicants by fall 2006.
Title: Much Fun, for Credit

Paragraph: Another toy designer, Colan Ho, says he hopes that his robot and spaceman figures will generate interest in the characters in his sci-fi graphic novels. Simon Wong, who has designed fashion collections for Esprit and CK jeanswear, is producing 12-inch figures that sport bead-laced string purses and leather-faced down coats. (Recently he obtained ''original 1970's polyester'' to line a denim outfit.) ''The goal is to attract fashion companies that would want to collaborate with me to do something -- a promotion item to put in the window or give away as premium gifts,'' he says. He says he dreams of eventually having his own fashion line. Meanwhile, pursuing a better-trod path to fortune, the brother-and-sister team of Wendy and Kevin Mak -- children of a manufacturer of plastic water guns -- have concluded that their toys, known as 2da6, are priced too aggressively. They produced their first toy, a teahouse waiter, in late 2001, as an adjunct to an online game. The game collapsed, but the toys persist, despite anemic sales. ''The cost of all these figures is too high,'' Wendy Mak says. ''Our future plan is to go for mass production, to Toys 'R' Us or Kmart.''
Title: Cult Figures

Paragraph: MARTINA NAVRATILOVA brought down the curtain on her Wimbledon career Saturday, 31 years after first competing at the All England Club. At 47, her dreams of a record 21st Wimbledon title ended when she and LISA RAYMOND bowed, 7-6 (4), 7-5, to LIEZEL HUBER and AI SUGIYAMA in the women's doubles semifinals.
Title: Sharapova Conquers Wimbledon

Paragraph: THE VELVET TEEN -- There are arguments against the proliferation of digital home recording gear. You don't have to listen for long to hear how a band making its own records can go horribly wrong. But an inspiring example of putting the technology in the right hands is the new Velvet Teen album, ''Elysium'' (Slowdance Records). It is ambitious and cinematic. The album starts with processed, cut-up sounds, like a robot dropping its keys and fumbling around in the dark to find them. The band then melds them into beautiful songs with piano and strings. The singer Judah Nagler must be one of those talented people who doesn't need to think about what he's doing. The vocal passages on ''Penicillin (Doesn't Mean Much)'' are effortlessly fluid.
Title: Guided By Voices Into Retirement

Paragraph: This is the future of video games. In their modern riff on "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" Walter was the only human. Grace and Trip were virtual characters powered by advanced artificial intelligence techniques, which allowed them to change their emotional state in fairly complicated ways in response to the conversational English being typed in by the human player. As we try to create more immersive experiences, these artificial intelligence techniques are helping drive games forward and this is one of the areas that could really explode, Bing Gordon, chief creative officer at Electronic Arts, the No. 1 video game company, said after his talk Wednesday night. "We hope that the folks here start thinking about artificial intelligence as a feature, like graphics is a feature or sound is a feature." At the same time, he added, "players are demanding a lot more freedom. Often they don't want to be put on a roller coaster track that just takes them along one path, no matter how entertaining that one path may be. They want a range of choices and they want those choices to matter in creating the overall experience. You put together all of these demands, and that's why you're seeing all of this attention now on artificial intelligence in games." Outside the game world, the term artificial intelligence is used to label technologies as disparate as air traffic control systems and automated vacuum cleaners. At the conference, much of the discussion was about specific game activities that, to a human, would seem more intuitive than rational, like using conversational language. But one of the broadest and most powerful approaches to artificial intelligence may be one that does not focus on determining specific behaviors. ("Does the computer general know that it should use tanks and artillery together?") The problem now is that the worlds are so complex and the variety of potential actions so vast that trying to direct the environments and the behaviors of computer-controlled agents through traditional scripting can become unmanageable, Jeff Orkin, an artificial intelligence programmer at Monolith Productions, said between sessions. But perhaps that bridge will run in unexpected directions. Until now, artificial intelligence has often involved making computers accessible to humans. With his new project, "Spore," Will Wright of "The Sims" fame means to invert that concept. Until now, artificial intelligence has usually meant that the human creates or perceives a model of how the computer makes decisions, Mr. Wright said. "But what if the computer is instead analyzing the player, and the program is customizing the experience based on the internal model it has created of the human?"
Title: Redefining the Power of the Gamer
Other (negative): Programming video game AI has become unmanageable and complex

Paragraph: DAY 2 -- The crew attaches a 50-foot robot arm to a new 50-foot sensor-tipped boom and conducts an inch-by-inch survey of the wing-leading edges and nose cap, which are made of the brittle reinforced carbon-carbon material that was damaged during the Columbia flight and led to the destruction of shuttle. The sensor pack at the end of the boom, containing a camera and laser scanner, moves at maximum rate of two and a half inches per second, causing the task to take about seven hours. Afterward, astronauts stow the boom and use the robot arm alone to survey Discovery's upper surfaces and crew cabin.
Title: Discovery's Day-by-Day To-Do List
Other (positive): does dangerous jobs

When the order to stand down was issued shortly after 1:30 p.m., the shuttle's seven astronauts were already strapped into their seats, after a morning in which they had been sent off to the launching pad to thunderous applause from employees of the space agency. Title: A CONVERSATION WITH: James McKerrow; A Lab Builds Better Barriers Against Invading Parasites

Paragraph: The problem is, the Sims 2 has turned out to be incredibly difficult to shoot with. When the Rooster Teeth gang uses Halo for machinima, the characters are mere puppets and can be posed any way the creators want. But in the Sims 2, the little virtual characters have artificial intelligence and free will. When you're playing, you do not control all the action: the fun is in putting your Sims in interesting social situations, then standing back and watching what they'll do. When Rooster Teeth's Matt Hullum builds a virtual set and puts the "Strangerhood" characters in place for a shoot, he's never quite sure what will happen. To shoot a scene in which two men wake up in bed together, Hullum had to spend hours playing with the two characters -- who are nominally heterosexual -- forcing them into repeated conversations until they eventually became such good friends they were willing to share a bed. Shooting machinima with Sims is thus maddeningly like using actual, human stars: they're stubborn; they stage hissy fits and stomp off to their trailers.
Title: The Xbox Auteurs
Other (negative): limitations due to unpredictability of AI characters in video games

Paragraph: Thus, of the morning commute: ''Headlines try to get under your skin and cheap ink on top of it. Wrassle and grapple newspapers. If only he knew the proper way to fold a newspaper on public transportation. If only my robot double were working, I'd send him to the office in my place. They like him better anyway. Over that stranger's shoulder, a writer of horoscopes is an intimate friend. He looks like an idiot in this suit, but it's the only one he owns and he can mask his too short sleeves by magic-show posture.'' These seven sentences, a fair sampling, represent between four and six separate viewpoints, none of them necessarily the author's, but all of them probably his to some degree, in the same way that writers often populate their fiction with a host of partial versions of themselves. Every sentence here dips momentarily into the pockets of a potential character, whose past, issues and aspirations lie about an inch away from being discernible.
Title: Eight Million Reasons

Paragraph: The report also called for building a robot for deep exploration that could dive 4.3 miles deep. A new piloted craft could be built by 2006, it said, and the robot by 2004 or 2005.
Title: Report Urges U.S. To Upgrade Its Fleet Of Deep-Diving Craft
Other (positive): deep exploration investment in AI, robots go where humans can't, AI advances science exploration

Paragraph: Monkeys that can move a robot arm with thoughts alone have brought the merger of mind and machine one step closer. The study is being published today in the inaugural issue of The Public Library of Science, a peer-reviewed scientific journal that makes articles available free of charge. The research team was led by Dr. Miguel A. L. Nicolelis, a neurobiology professor and co-director of the Center for Neuroengineering at Duke, in North Carolina. Dr. Nicolelis also did the earlier research on monkeys and robot arms at Duke. ''For nearly completely paralyzed people, this promises to be a fantastic boon,'' said Dr. Jon Kaas, a psychology professor at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, who is familiar with Dr. Nicolelis's research. ''A person could control a computer or robot to do anything in real time, as fast as they can think.'' The final step was to divert brain signals to a computer model that controlled the movements of a robot. The monkey continued to think the movements but in doing so it now moved the robot arm directly, without a joystick, which in turn directed movements of the cursor. Controlling a shaky, jerky robot with thought is not easy, Dr. Nicolelis said. When the robot is first added, the monkey's performance degrades. It takes two days for the animal to learn the mechanical properties of the arm and to incorporate its delays into motor planning areas.
Title: In Pioneering Duke Study, Monkey Think, Robot Do
Other (positive): AI enhances understanding of brain and neurology, academia supports AI advances    assist people with disabilities

Paragraph: Mr. de Grey's ideas were not completely new to people who have been pondering cyborgs and artificial intelligence for years. ''I think, and I've thought this for a long time, that we live, roughly speaking, in the last generation of human beings,'' said Whitfield Diffie, chief of security for Sun Microsystems, a pioneer in encryption, and a freewheeling thinker often sought after for such conferences as a speaker. He was just visiting this year and said he was fascinated by the grand claims for the biological century, which he views as probably too conservative.
Title: High-Tech Daydreamers Investing In Immortality

Paragraph: Vivisimo's co-founder and chief executive, Raul Valdes-Perez, was a protégé of Herbert A. Simon, a Nobel laureate who was a pioneer in artificial intelligence research. Before co-founding Vivisimo, Mr. Valdes-Perez was a computer scientist at Carnegie Mellon University. He professes that the way to deal with information overload is with information "overlook" -- techniques that strip away extraneous information.

Paragraph: In the Arctic, every living thing craves the fleeting rays of sunshine during the short summer. Next month, a robot will traverse a cold, rocky wasteland in the far North driven by its own determination to bask in the sun. The robot takes its name from Greek mythology. Hyperion was a titan, a predecessor to the gods, who supposedly fathered the Sun, the Moon and the dawn. The word ''Hyperion'' roughly translates as ''he who follows the Sun.'' The robot is designed to operate autonomously, computing its own pathways and guiding itself around obstacles. However, it also can be operated remotely by human controllers if problems arise. Photos: The Hyperion, a solar-powered robot, is put through field tests in Pittsburgh. In two weeks, the robot will be tested in a cold, rocky area above the Arctic Circle. (Photographs by Debra Tobin)
Title: Designed for Other Worlds, Robot Is to Follow the Sun
Other (positive): robots go where humans can't, AI advances scientific exploration        operate autonomously Solar powered robot

Paragraph: Vassar College's stately buildings are in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., but the leafy, gated campus might as well be another planet to many of the poorer teenagers who live in the city. In September, Vassar will admit three Poughkeepsie High School seniors as freshmen as a result of a Vassar science scholars program in which selected city students take Saturday classes with college professors and use the school's equipment to study artificial intelligence and other science topics. The seniors are CHRISTINE GAVIN, JOSUE FLORES and STEPHEN PELUSE. ''It's two blocks from my house, but it'll be a whole new world,'' Mr. Peluse said.
Title: BULLETIN BOARD

Paragraph: Dr. Kenneth Mark Colby, a psychiatrist known for his work with artificial intelligence, died on April 20 at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 81. At 31, Dr. Colby published ''A Primer for Psychotherapists.'' He wrote or contributed to nine more books and over 100 articles on psychiatry, psychology, psychotherapy and artificial intelligence.
Title: Kenneth Colby, 81, Psychiatrist Expert in Artificial Intelligence

Paragraph: ''A.I.?'' a professor of English queries, unabashed, in Lodge's latest novel, ''Thinks. . . .'' Her scientist companion dutifully provides an explanation of artificial intelligence, which presumably he wouldn't have to do once the Steven Spielberg film ''A.I.'' comes out this summer. Well, why should she know? She's really just a novelist -- although one has to wonder about a middle-aged, putatively worldly woman who needs to ask, later, ''What's a colonoscopy?'' She's a respected writer, but it has never occurred to her to communicate by e-mail. However, let us note the year -- 1997 -- so perhaps we can forgive her awe as she watches her future lover set up her modem. She is, no doubt, the kind of woman who would proclaim herself a Luddite, as if she'd invented the notion of using that term for computer illiteracy.
Title: Very Artificial Intelligence

Paragraph: The robot should be able to do everything a nurse can, Dr. Treat said. And because she is a computer, he said, she can even do some things better. How do you program a robot to do a human's job? "The devil is in the details," Mr. Brady said. Paragraph: Foreign visitors will want to join the Japanese spectators as they take photos on cellphone cameras of box-shaped robots sweeping the streets, and child-care robots with camera eyes announcing roll calls of nursery school students. The best and most sought robot spot is the Toyota pavilion, where visitors are greeted by a robot jazz trio playing trumpets. (On preview days, tickets for the Toyota pavilion were gone by 11 a.m.) Offering a new take on mobility, Toyota showcases the "I-foot," a walking robot where a passenger sits in a clam-shell seat above two lumbering legs.

Paragraph: The show is a sociological argument made with visual evidence, but because this evidence comes from one of the world's most aesthetically sophisticated and refined cultures, it packs a tremendous visual punch. At times one can do nothing more than hang on for the ride. The first gallery is dominated by a tank-size head of the robot Gundam. Behind it is an imposing phalanx of Hello Kitty ephemera, including wallpaper. To one side are Aya Takano's drawings and paintings of wide-eyed prepubescent, but sexually knowing, waifs. To the other side, cute goes monstrous in five plush, big-headed puppetlike costumes for yuru chara, regional mascots that represent nearly every local government in Japan. They suggest cuteness as public policy.
Title: From a Mushroom Cloud, a Burst of Art Reflecting Japan's Psyche
