Paragraph: Extension Activities:1. Peru has experienced many tragedies in recent times.  Write the script of a television documentary titled “Peru: Scandals and Sadness,” and cover the events such as government corruption, human rights violations, terrorism, and natural disasters that have plagued this nation.    2. The incident involving Montesinos is the second high-profile spy story to attract media attention in 2001, after the well-publicized Hanssen case in the United States.  Write a “Tale of Two Spies” — a comparative analysis of these two figures.  3. Conduct your own investigative research and trace the connection between the C.I.A. and Vladimiro Montesinos over the years, starting with the Peruvian antidrug operation of the 1970’s.  4. Explore what “artificial intelligence” means. Create a collage or guide exploring how artificial intelligence impacts government intelligence agencies. Extension Activities:1. Peru has experienced many tragedies in recent times.  Write the script of a television documentary titled “Peru: Scandals and Sadness,” and cover the events such as government corruption, human rights violations, terrorism, and natural disasters that have plagued this nation.    2. The incident involving Montesinos is the second high-profile spy story to attract media attention in 2001, after the well-publicized Hanssen case in the United States.  Write a “Tale of Two Spies” — a comparative analysis of these two figures.  3. Conduct your own investigative research and trace the connection between the C.I.A. and Vladimiro Montesinos over the years, starting with the Peruvian antidrug operation of the 1970’s.  4. Explore what “artificial intelligence” means. Create a collage or guide exploring how artificial intelligence impacts government intelligence agencies.
Title: Secret Agent Men

Paragraph: Overview of Lesson Plan: In this lesson, students learn about how robots are programmed to play games. They then construct robot applications (basic computer codes) for playing tic-tac-toe comprised of if-then۪ logic sequences and compete in teams using their application codes to determine the effectiveness of their robot applications۪ for the game. Further Questions for Discussion:What is a computer language? What computer languages can you name?  Why is important that the robotic soccer players mentioned in the article be autonomous۝? What would a semi-autonomous robot be?  What did Brett Nadler mean when he stated, You can۪t just be a good electrical engineers and do well at this competition۝? What different scientific disciplines are needed for building good robots?  What other demonstrations will be held at the RoboCup 2001 in Seattle? How are these demonstrations related to robotic soccer? Extension Activities:1. Research Web robots. What is a Web robot? What is an agent? Can a search engine be classified as a robot? Why or why not? Search for examples of Web robots, agents, and spiders, and write a brief description of each one. How do they differ from each other, and how are they similar? 2. Explore “The Tech” Web site (http://sizzle.thetech.org/hyper/robots/overview/) and learn about the five parts every robot must have. Then, design a robot with these five parts that can perform a basic soccer move (“head in” the ball, dribble the ball, score a goal), and draw a set of blueprints describing each part. Include specifications and descriptions of the materials needed to build your robot. 3. Research how robots are used in space at NASA’s Robotic Vehicles page (http://robotics.jpl.nasa.gov/groups/rv/). Choose one robot and write a report or create a “How It Works” poster. For what was this robot designed? Has it been used in a space mission? What scientific instruments does it carry? How does it move? How is it controlled? What has it allowed us to learn about space? 4. Create an illustrated timeline of the development of robots and artificial intelligence. When was the term “robot” first coined, and what does it mean? When was the term first used in fiction? What was the first company to produce robots? Include mechanical and robotic toys and automata, as well the uses of robots in space, in medicine, and in industry. 5. Conduct a search for robots in your environment. What is the basic definition of a robot, and what parts must every robot have? What could be classified as a robot in your school? At home? Make a list and describe why each item qualifies as a robot. Other Information on the Web:RoboCup: The Robot World Cup Initiative (http://www.robocup.org/) is the official site of the international research and education initiative to foster AI and intelligent robotics research. Get A Grip On Robotics (http://www.thetech.org/exhibits_events/online/robots/teaser/), an online exhibit from the Tech Museum of Innovation, will help you understand how robots work and their potential abilities in the future. Robotics: Sensing, Thinking, Acting (http://www.thetech.org/robotics) from the Tech Museum of Innovation lets you discover the history of robots and listen to discussion of ethical issues, or explore a gallery of modern artists and their work. Activities / Procedures:1. WARM-UP/ DO-NOW: Prior to class, arrange desks in pairs. Upon entering class, students respond to the following as a pair (written on the board prior to class): Play a game of tic-tac-toe with your partner. Then, think about these questions together, and write down your answers: What are the rules of tic-tac-toe? What decisions does a player need to make before taking a turn? How would you verbally describe each of those decisions?۝ After a few minutes, ask the students to share with the class some of their responses. What kinds of statements are used to describe the rules and moves of the game? 2. As a class, read and discuss Robot Competitors Meet on a Soccer Field of Dreams,۝ focusing on the following questions:  a. What makes the international soccer tournament described in this article unusual?  b. According to the article, what are the short-term and long-term goals of this competition?  c. Who founded this competition, and why?  d. What other robot teams will the knowledge gained in this competition help foster, according to the article?  e. What are the four different leagues in the RoboCup?  f. What does Manuela M. Veloso mean when she says, We can۪t pre-program everything۝? g. How did the teams practice before the competition? For what were the teams practicing?  h. How long does it take to build a team of robotic soccer players? What is involved in doing this?  i. What are teams required to share after each year۪s competition? 3. Explain to students that they will be working in pairs to write an application (a string of basic computer code) for robots to enable them to play tic-tac-toe. They will then be competing in the first annual RoboTic-Tac-Toe Tournament.۝ Begin by returning to the earlier discussion of the rules of tic-tac-toe. What goals does each player have? Who starts the game? Is there a best place۝ to put the first X? What are some winning strategies for the next move? For example, If the X is in the center, then where should I put an 0?۝ Why is if-then۝ logic a good way to explain strategy for a simple game like tic-tac-toe? Now, further consider the if-then۝ statement. Ask students to share some if-then۝ statements about everyday situations, and write a few on the board (such as if I stay up late, then I am tired the next day۝ or if I jump in the mud, then I get my shoes dirty.۝) How do the terms if۝ and then۝ govern a logical sequence? Does an if-then statement need to be true? (Technically, no. The words if-then۝ define a cause and effect sequence, not a truth. It might be possible to state If I stay up late, then my shoes get muddy.۝ However, this is not a true or logical statement.) What, then, makes an if-then statement for tic-tac-toe true? (In tic-tac-toe, the rules of the game determine whether the if-then statement is true. For example, it would not be possible to truthfully state, If there is an X in the center, then place four O۪s in each corner.۝) To show how an if-then statement can be applied to tic-tac-toe, demonstrate the opening move for a game of tic-tac-toe on the board. Draw a nine-space grid and label the squares one through nine. Then ask the students where to place the first X. Depending on where it is placed, have students create an if-then statement that determines the next move. For example, If the first X is in the center, place an O in a corner square.۝ This is the first command in an application for the robot. What would the next line of code be? Ask students to work in pairs to complete the application. Each line of code in the entire sequence will cover every possible combination of moves the students can think of until a game is completed. Students need to remember that there are multiple options for each move (including the beginning move, which could be the placement of an X in the center, a corner, or in the middle of one of the outer perimeters of the grid.) They should consider all of the possibilities in developing their code. 4. WRAP-UP/HOMEWORK: Students complete their application and practice playing tic-tac-toe following only the commands they have written. They should debug۝ their program in preparation for the RoboTic-Tac-Toe Tournament۝ to be held in a future class. During the tournament, each team۝ (pair of students) will be acting as a single robot programmed by the application they developed; one student will read a command from their application, and the other student will execute the command. Teams play against each other, testing how successful their code is. Each game should be observed by the rest of the class and monitored to ensure the teams only execute the commands read. Which team wins the tournament, and why? What have students learned from this exercise about these types of applications? Extension Activities:1. Research Web robots. What is a Web robot? What is an agent? Can a search engine be classified as a robot? Why or why not? Search for examples of Web robots, agents, and spiders, and write a brief description of each one. How do they differ from each other, and how are they similar? 2. Explore “The Tech” Web site (http://sizzle.thetech.org/hyper/robots/overview/) and learn about the five parts every robot must have. Then, design a robot with these five parts that can perform a basic soccer move (“head in” the ball, dribble the ball, score a goal), and draw a set of blueprints describing each part. Include specifications and descriptions of the materials needed to build your robot. 3. Research how robots are used in space at NASA’s Robotic Vehicles page (http://robotics.jpl.nasa.gov/groups/rv/). Choose one robot and write a report or create a “How It Works” poster. For what was this robot designed? Has it been used in a space mission? What scientific instruments does it carry? How does it move? How is it controlled? What has it allowed us to learn about space? 4. Create an illustrated timeline of the development of robots and artificial intelligence. When was the term “robot” first coined, and what does it mean? When was the term first used in fiction? What was the first company to produce robots? Include mechanical and robotic toys and automata, as well the uses of robots in space, in medicine, and in industry. 5. Conduct a search for robots in your environment. What is the basic definition of a robot, and what parts must every robot have? What could be classified as a robot in your school? At home? Make a list and describe why each item qualifies as a robot. Other Information on the Web:RoboCup: The Robot World Cup Initiative (http://www.robocup.org/) is the official site of the international research and education initiative to foster AI and intelligent robotics research. Get A Grip On Robotics (http://www.thetech.org/exhibits_events/online/robots/teaser/), an online exhibit from the Tech Museum of Innovation, will help you understand how robots work and their potential abilities in the future. Robotics: Sensing, Thinking, Acting (http://www.thetech.org/robotics) from the Tech Museum of Innovation lets you discover the history of robots and listen to discussion of ethical issues, or explore a gallery of modern artists and their work.
Title: The Games Robots Play
Other (positive): search engines This is some sort of CompSci quiz

Paragraph: Activities / Procedures:1. WARM-UP/DO NOW: Students respond to the following prompt in their journals (written on the board prior to class): Think about the following items: a cheese grater, a vacuum cleaner, a CD disc changer, a battery-operated car, a regular car, and a desktop computer. Which of these items would you consider to be a robot? Why do you think each item is or is not a robot?۝ After a few minutes, allow students to share their answers, and tally student responses on the board for each item. Is there a consensus on what qualifies as a robot? What is a robot? What characteristics and features do robots have that other machines do not? 2. As a class, read and discuss When Nerds Collide: Robots at War,۝ focusing on the following questions:  a. According to the author, what draws viewers to BattleBots۝? b. What does the show۪s creator, Trey Roski, say this show is about?  c. What are some of the other shows and competitions that feature battling robots?  d. What types of machines are involved in the competitions?  e. According to the article, how much money might Japanese competitors spend on a sumo robot?  f. What is the maximum weight of a sumo robot? What device allows such light machines to hold them to the surface?  g. What does the author suggest might be the real source۝ of the appeal of robot battles? Do you agree? Why or why not? 3. Explain to students that they will be working in groups, acting as teams of engineers to design robots that will complete everyday tasks or household chores (tying a shoe, emptying the trash, etc.) Divide students into small groups of three or four, and have each group spend five minutes determining the answers to the following questions (one student should act as the group۪s secretary۝): What task will the robot accomplish? How is this task currently done without the robot? How will the robot do it better? After five minutes, have each group share their ideas. Then, organize each group around a computer with Internet access, and have them explore The Tech۪s online robot exhibit, which describes the five main parts usually found in a robot (http://www.thetech.org/exhibits_events/online/robots/5main/). After they have toured the exhibit and feel that they understand these components, groups should discuss how these five parts will function in their robots, focusing on the following questions (written on the board for easier student reference):  -Sensor: What will the robot sense? What information about the environment will it gather and feed back to the controller?  -End effector: What specific tasks will the robot perform?  What tools will it manipulate?  -Drive: How will the robot move? What power source will drive the robot functions?  -Arm: How will the robot۪s end effector and sensor be positioned? What degree of freedom will the robot arm(s) need to perform the task?  -Controller: How will the other four parts be controlled? Create a schematic that accounts for the signal pathways that control each part of the robot. What type of program might direct these signals? After these engineering aspects have been determined, each team creates a presentation poster that illustrates and explains the function of the five essential parts of their robot. Groups should also include a summary statement that explains what the robot will do and why it will do it better than conventional technology. 4. WRAP-UP/HOMEWORK: Allow students to finish their presentation posters. They should also create a model (working or non-working) of their robot to better explain its functions. In a future class, teams should present their designs and models. Allow students to question other design teams about their concepts and to offer constructive suggestions. As homework, each student revisits the six items they considered at the beginning of the lesson  a cheese grater, a vacuum cleaner, a CD disc changer, a battery-operated car, a regular car, and a desktop computer  and respond in writing to the following prompt (written on the board or copied for easier student access):  Based on what you have learned about the five essential parts of a robot, which of these items qualifies as a robot, and which do not? Explain your answer for each by noting which of the five components it has and how each part works.۝ Evaluation / Assessment:Students will be evaluated based on written journal entries, participation in class and group discussions, thoughtful annotated group poster and model of robot design, group presentation, and thoughtful completion of a final writing assignment. Extension Activities:1. Using cardboard, foam core, wire, and other materials, create a more detailed model of the robot designed in class. How does a static model differ from a functional prototype? What would be required to create a functional prototype of your robot? Investigate ways to make your robot work, and try to create a functional prototype. 2. Explore the many robots on NASA۪s Cool Robot of the Week۝ page (http://ranier.hq.nasa.gov/telerobotics_page/coolrobots00.html). Choose one and create an annotated diagram that explains what this robot does and how it works. 3. Research robot competitions. What different types of robot competitions can you find? Are these competitions only for entertainment? Choose several examples and write an editorial that describes their value (educational, scientific, entertainment, etc.) and argues for or against a school supporting such competitions. Other Information on the Web:Learn more about the robot competitions described in the article: BattleBots (http://www.battlebots.com>), Robot Wars (http://www.robotwars.com/) and Robotica (http://tlc.discovery.com/fansites/robotica/robotica.html). Robotics: Sensing, Thinking, Acting (http://www.thetech.org/robotics/) from the Tech Museum of Innovation lets you discover the history of robots and listen to discussion of ethical issues, or explore a gallery of modern artists and their work. Robot World (http://robotworld.knex.com/) includes robot models and online building plans.
Title: Popular Mechanics
Other (positive): about web based robot resources

Paragraph: Activities / Procedures:1. WARM-UP/DO NOW: In this initial classroom activity, students will respond to the production quality of recorded music played on two different types and qualities of music devices. Play the same piece of music for students  once on a cassette player and once on a CD player (try to use as old and inexpensive a tape player, and as new and advanced CD player, as possible). Keep the two music players hidden beneath a cloth or thin blanket so that the students cannot see what devices are being used. Then, in their journals, students respond to the following prompt (written on the board prior to class): Can you hear a difference between the two recordings? How would you describe the difference? What do you think accounts for the differences you perceive?۝ After a few minutes, allow students to share their responses. Then, reveal the two players and discuss the following: Who guessed the different technologies correctly? When do you think each device was first invented? How much money do you think each device cost when it was first introduced to the public? Are the differences between new products and their most recent versions always discernible? Why or why not? 2. As a class, read and discuss Year of Living Geekily: Even the Dogs Evolved,۝ focusing on the following questions:  a. According to the article, what is a geek?  b. Reflecting on the technology industry over this last year, what does the author mean by from a stockholder۪s perspective, this was the year the high-technology bubble burst with a definitive pop۝? c. What fundamental truths۝ does the author observe about new technology?  d. What one net appliance۝ is still being produced, according to the article? Why is the price of this device surprising? What does the author mean by the big companies had it all wrong۝? e. How much does the new robot dog cost? Does this sound like a toy۝? f. Windows XP and Mac OS X are examples of computer operating systems What is an operating system? [According to WhatIs?com (http://whatis.techtarget.com/), an operating system is the program that manages all the other programs in a computer, performing functions such as allocating the sharing of memory; handling input and output to hard drives, printers, and dial-up ports; and sending messages about the status of operation and any errors that have occurred.۝)According to the article, what makes the new Mac operating system better? Does the author give you enough information about these improvements? Why or why not?  g. What is the chief virtue of the latest ViaVoice speech-recognition program? Is it clear why this feature is an improvement? Why or why not?  h. What are some of the features of the remaining products that the article mentions? Which of these features are easy to understand, and which ones do you not understand?  i. Do you think a geek۝ is someone who understands all these terms? 3. Divide the class into five groups, and explain that each group will be working as a team of product managers helping to develop a new personal electronic device. Explain that product managers typically serve as the liaisons between engineering teams, who design the products, and sales teams, who are directly responsible for selling the products. Product managers must be savvy about both the technology and the features that will make the most difference to consumers. Assign each group a different product category: digital cameras, handheld devices (PDAs), portable music devices, speech recognition programs and home robotic devices (such as robo-pets, yard bots, or roving house monitors). Each group begins by visiting an online electronics catalog, such as Cnet (http://www.cnet.com), and identifying three specific products in their category  one inexpensive, one moderately priced, and one top-of-the-line.۝ Next, students should examine the basic specs۝ (specifications) for the individual products (as well as the what to look for۝ descriptions for their category on CNet), and create a list of product specifications common to all three products in the category. (For example, while the number may vary, all the digital cameras include a specification for megapixels.۝) After creating a specification list, divide it among the students in the groups so that each student will research and write the definitions for one or more specifications. In each definition, students should describe the technology behind the feature (how does it work?), as well as explain why a consumer would want more (or less) in the product (what is its value?). 4. WRAP-UP/HOMEWORK: Each group writes a category assessment plan۝ for the product category they researched in class, responding to the following (written on the board to be copied): As a product management team for an electronics company, write a report that summarizes what is considered to be state-of-the-art۪ in your product category. What minimum requirements would a new product in this category have to meet? What are your personal recommendations for positioning a new product in this category? Include references to all of the different basic specs in your report and a glossary as an appendix.۝
Title: What's New?

Paragraph: Other Information on the Web:The Institute for the Learning Sciences at Northwestern University (http://www.ils.nwu.edu/) is an interdisciplinary research and development lab dedicated to applying principles of cognitive science, computer science, artificial intelligence, and educational theory to improving the way people learn.  The site includes a column by Roger Schank.  Cognitive Arts (http://www.cognitivearts.com/) is Roger Schank’s company.  For the latest in technology news and trends, visit The New York Times on the Web’s Technology section (http://www.nytimes.com/yr/mo/day/tech/).  The weekly Circuits section (http://www.nytimes.com/library/tech/yr/mo/circuits/index.html) offers articles from the current Circuits, as well as a free archive of past articles. Title: Computer Versus Tutor

Paragraph: Objectives:Students will:  1. Identify everyday devices that are robotic; define what a robot is.  2. Learn about the latest autonomous vehicles participating in the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency۪s Grand Challenge by reading and discussing the article Robotic Vehicles Race, but Innovation Wins.۝  3. Propose ideas that would make directly controlled robotic devices more antonymous.  4. Create and present posters illustrating their ideas. Activities / Procedures:1.WARM-UP/DO-NOW: Prior to class, arrange an area in the front of the room to display several robotic and non-robotic items, or photographs of such items. Upon entering class, students should respond to the following prompt in their journals (written on the board prior to class): Fold a piece of paper in your journal in half. Label the left column Robots۪ and the right column Non-Robots.۪ Think carefully about the everyday items in the front of the room, and write their names in the appropriate columns. Add three other everyday items to each column. Then, answer the following questions: What is a robot? What qualities do all robots share?۝ After a few minutes, ask students to share their ideas and record them on the board for use later in the class period. Explain that a robot is essentially a smart۝ machine, or, more precisely a device that automatically performs complicated and often repetitive tasks۝ (http://www.webster.com) after programmed by humans. Explain that these everyday machines are examples of directly-controlled robotic devices۝; although they seem smarter۝ than ordinary machines, they cannot think or act on their own. Inform students that they will now read an article about a more sophisticated robot, a fully autonomous robotic device.۝ 2. As a class, read and discuss the article Robotic Vehicles Race, but Innovation Wins۝ (http://www.nytimes.com/learning/teachers/featured_articles/20050915thursday.html), focusing on the following questions:  a. What kind of car is Stanley?  b. What is the name of the Pentagon۪s research arm?  c. What course did the Pentagon set up for robots to complete nearly 18 months ago?  d. What was the prize for the completion of this course?  e. How many miles did the most successful robot complete?  f. When will the second race take place?  g. How many groups will take part, and what to they stand to gain?  h. What company produced Stanley?  i. What is the race called?  j. What is the purpose of the race?  k. What is the broader goal۝ of Sebastian Thrun, director of the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory?  l. What kind of mobile robotic companion۝ did Mr. Thrun and Michael Montemerlo develop?  m. What are possible applications of their software?  n. What robot will Mitsubishi Heavy Industries begin selling in September?  o. What about the course do the participants already know?  p. Why caused Stanley to swerve off the road?  q. How successful was Stanley in completing the entire test course?  r. How will Stanley and the other competing vehicles operate without passengers during the race?  s. What companies are sponsoring the race?  t. What team is the favorite to win, and why?  u. What high school team is also participating?  v. What did William L. Whittaker mean when he said that he didn۪t know whether this year۪s race would be more like Lindbergh landing in Paris or more like Woodstock۝? 3. Explain to students that according to Tom Sugar, a robot maker and assistant professor of Mechanical Engineering at Arizona State University, There are three aspects to robots. Robots need to do sensing, just as we need to sense our environment. They must be able to make decisions based on that sensing information. And they must be able to take action based on those decisions۝ (http://researchmag.asu.edu/stories/robots.html). Write these three components on the board: Sense the Environment, Make Decisions Based on Sensing, Take Actions Based on Decisions. Ask students to think back to the article. What did the automated car need to sense? What decisions did it make in response to sensory information? What action did the car take based on each decision? Make sure students understand what differentiates the robotic devices listed during the Warm-Up activity from the robotic vehicles read about in the aritcle: the vehicles are fully automated robotic devices that require limited to no human input. Remind students that, during the final course, the programmers will have no communication with their racing vehicles. Explain to students that they will be developing design improvements for everyday robots to increase their autonomy and usefulness. Ask students to form pairs and instruct each pair to choose one of the robotic devices listed on the board from the Warm-Up activity. Each pair should then answer the following questions about their robot (copied on a handout or written on the board for easier student access:  -What does the robot do?  -What basic steps must the robot complete in order to perform the task?  -What information in the environment must the robot sense?  -What decisions does the robot make upon processing the sensory information?  -What action or actions does the robot then carry out?  -Think of three new tasks that you would like your robot to perform. For each one, identify what information in the environment it must sense, what decisions it must then make, and what actions it must then take.  -Given these ideas, would this robot as a fully automated robot provide better service than the original version? Why or why not? Who, in particular, might it help? It may be useful to provide this example for students: At the same time each night, a fully-automated microwave might sense the presence of food, automatically turn on, heat the food to the desired degree. stop, open its door automatically, close it again if the food had not been retrieved within five minutes, and keep the food warm until it is finally removed. This device might benefit people who work late and want to have dinner ready the minute they return. 4. WRAP-UP/HOMEWORK: Each pair creates an informational poster in which they sketch the original robot and the redesigned device, using arrows and text to describe features, abilities and improvements. Students should present their ideas to the class. Evaluation / Assessment:Students will be evaluated based on initial journal response, participation in class discussions, contribution to the robot improvement project, and thoughtful completion and presentation of their ideas.
Title: Automated Intelligence
Other (positive): student innovation designing robots contest, students learn about robots,     concept of AI provides teachable topics

Paragraph: Interdisciplinary Connections:Civics- The use of technology in immigration and homeland security in the United States has become a controversial topic. As technological advances have allowed new practices  such as retinal scanning, fingerprinting, and accessible digital passport photos  to increase border protection, some people feel that their civil liberties are being taken away. Research what other countries are doing in terms of technology and border protection, and write an opinion piece about what the technological advances mean to policy makers and citizens. Health- Many different types of robotic technology are currently used in medical procedures. Examples include artificial hearts and limbs, as well as actual robotic assistance in surgical procedures. Write a research paper about current trends in robotics as they relate to medical advances. Media Studies- Watch and write a film review of a movie that focuses on robots as characters, such as I, Robot۝ (2004), Artificial Intelligence: AI۝ (2001) or Star Wars۝ (1977). Are the messages in the film consistent with Dr. Wilson۪s assessment of robot stereotypes? How do you feel about the way robots are portrayed in this film? What is human and inhuman about the robots in this film? How is this juxtaposition a central theme of the film? Teaching with The Times- Clip articles from The New York Times that present new types of technology. Choose a recent technological invention and become an expert on it. Write an article about how it might be utilized at your school or in your home. To order The New York Times for your classroom, click here. Other Information on the Web:Daniel H. Wilson۪s Web site (http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~dwilson/) includes a blog and publications. Robot Uprising (http://www.robotuprising.com) is the book۪s Web site, with lots of excerpts from the book and information on how to survive such an attack. The Carnegie Mellon University۪s Robotics Institute (http://www.ri.cmu.edu/) provides useful information about the Robot Hall of Fame, robot camp programs, academic degree programs for students interested in studying robotics, and various links to  information related to robots. Objectives:Students will: 1. Design their ideal personal robots and identify their potential functions; consider what defines a robot and how they are often portrayed in science fiction.  2. Learn about current trends in robotics by reading and discussing the article If Robots Ever Get too Smart, He۪ll Know How to Stop Them.۝  3. Develop and propose ideas for creating smart۝ spaces in schools.  4. Reflect on the pros and cons of relying more heavily on technology to improve school resources. Extension Activities:1. Go on a robotics hunt۝ in your home, identifying all of the different robots that are used in different rooms. Then, research and create a guide that illustrates all of the ways in which robotics technology is being used in your home on a daily basis. 2. Go to Dr. Wilson۪s Web site, http://www.robotuprising.com, and read the two excerpts he has published there from his new book, How to Survive a Robot Uprising.۝ After you have read the excerpts, write a third that might be added to the site. 3. Imagine that you are a robot and have been given to someone your age to act as a personal assistant. From the point of view of the robot, describe what your life۝ is like. Interdisciplinary Connections:Civics- The use of technology in immigration and homeland security in the United States has become a controversial topic. As technological advances have allowed new practices  such as retinal scanning, fingerprinting, and accessible digital passport photos  to increase border protection, some people feel that their civil liberties are being taken away. Research what other countries are doing in terms of technology and border protection, and write an opinion piece about what the technological advances mean to policy makers and citizens. Health- Many different types of robotic technology are currently used in medical procedures. Examples include artificial hearts and limbs, as well as actual robotic assistance in surgical procedures. Write a research paper about current trends in robotics as they relate to medical advances. Media Studies- Watch and write a film review of a movie that focuses on robots as characters, such as I, Robot۝ (2004), Artificial Intelligence: AI۝ (2001) or Star Wars۝ (1977). Are the messages in the film consistent with Dr. Wilson۪s assessment of robot stereotypes? How do you feel about the way robots are portrayed in this film? What is human and inhuman about the robots in this film? How is this juxtaposition a central theme of the film? Teaching with The Times- Clip articles from The New York Times that present new types of technology. Choose a recent technological invention and become an expert on it. Write an article about how it might be utilized at your school or in your home. To order The New York Times for your classroom, click here. Other Information on the Web:Daniel H. Wilson۪s Web site (http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~dwilson/) includes a blog and publications. Robot Uprising (http://www.robotuprising.com) is the book۪s Web site, with lots of excerpts from the book and information on how to survive such an attack. The Carnegie Mellon University۪s Robotics Institute (http://www.ri.cmu.edu/) provides useful information about the Robot Hall of Fame, robot camp programs, academic degree programs for students interested in studying robotics, and various links to  information related to robots.

Paragraph: Overview of Lesson Plan: In this lesson, students investigate current research in artificial intelligence and imagine the ways in which those technologies can be developed for use in daily life. Objectives:Students will:  1. Imagine how they might use a robot in their daily lives. 2. Learn about advancements in artificial intelligence by reading and discussing the article “Brainy Robots Start Stepping Into Daily Life.” 3. Investigate a current robotic technology under development. 4. Prepare posters and present ideas that consider how a robotic technology might be implemented in daily life in the near and distant future. Resources / Materials:-pens/pencils -classroom board -student journals -copies of the article “Brainy Robots Start Stepping Into Daily Life,” found online at  http://www.nytimes.com/learning/teachers/featured_articles/20060720thursday.html (one per student) -poster board (one or two per student group) -markers, glue and scissors (one set per student group) -resources for researching artificial intelligence such as science and/or technology magazines, encyclopedia, library resources and computers with Internet access Activities / Procedures:1. WARM-UP/DO-NOW: Before class, write the following prompt on the board for students to respond to in their journals: “If you had a robot, what would you want it to do?”  After a few minutes, have students share their responses.  Do they believe they might have a robot in their lives someday?  How soon might that technology become a part of daily life? 2. Have the class read the article “Brainy Robots Start Stepping Into Daily Life”  http://www.nytimes.com/learning/teachers/featured_articles/20060720thursday.html. Select questions from the following list to enhance your class discussion:  a. What robotic technologies are currently in use? b. How is the reality catching up with the fantasy? c. In what ways are the projects becoming more ambitious? d. Why might assembling an Ikea bookcase be beyond the reach of many humans? e. What might an electronic butler be able to do? f. How is current research in artificial intelligence distinguishable from that of an earlier generation? g. What is meant by cognitive computing? h. Why is it considered a research discipline rather than an industry? i. How is success currently measured in the field? j. To what degree might it be significant that cars with robotics technologies are mid-priced? k. How are underwater vision systems being used, and where? l. What organization is funding the design of a robot car, and why might members be interested in this technology? m. What is the “urban challenge?” n. How might the research project Microsoft is currently working on be used in daily life? o. What is TellMe Networks and what technology are they developing? p. When was this technology first introduced to the marketplace, and how has it improved since then? q. Where is the Ecole Polytechnique Federale de Lausanne and how is it advancing research in artificial intelligence? r. What fundamental insights do researchers hope to gain through the Blue Brain project? s. How might an electronic butler be used and how soon might one be available? t. Who is Robert Hecht-Nielsen and why might he have some credibility in the field? u. What is his theory of “confabulation” and how did he demonstrate it? v. In what way does the robot’s third sentence represent a coherent thought? w. Who originated artificial intelligence and when? x. What was the first demonstration of Mr. Turing’s theory? y. What were the early applications of the technology? z. From what corresponding advancements has robotics research benefitted? aa. What are the implications and how might daily life be affected? bb. Who is Andrew Ng and what is his goal? cc. How close is his dream to becoming reality? 3. Explain to the class that they will work in groups to consider the question, “How might artificial intelligence change the way we live?” by investigating an area of research discussed in the article or in the Warm-Up. To begin, arrange the class into small groups and assign each an area of research from the list below or from those discussed in the Warm-Up. Provide the list of questions as a handout along with the presentation supplies (poster board, markers, scissors and glue) and instruct groups to work together to create a brief presentation about the technology they are investigating.  Students should collect images and details about their subject, as well as prepare a well-considered analysis of the impact the technology might have on daily life. AREAS OF RESEARCH -Voice control systems -Advanced artificial reason techniques -Underwater vision systems -Robot cars -Systems of predestination -Voice recognition services -Electronic butlers -Models of confabulation -Mobile robotics QUESTIONS FOR CONSIDERATION BASICS -What is it? -What does it do? -How is it currently being used? -What are all of the possible ways it might be used in the future? THE TECHNOLOGY -What human behavior does it simulate? -How does it assist and/or replace humans? -In what way does it improve on a human capability? LIFESTYLE ANALYSIS -In what areas of life might the technology be used: home, work, school and/or the public sphere? -What types of experiences might it affect: work, learning, entertainment, health, transportation, everyday tasks, etc.? -How might this technology affect your life positively and/or negatively? -How might it alter the way people behave, think and/or interact with one another? Have students present their findings to the class. 4. WRAP-UP/HOMEWORK: How might a technology you or your classmates investigated in class be further developed for use in daily life at home, in school, in the workplace or for a public purpose? Choose any robotic technology presented in class to investigate further and consider how you or future generations might use it.  Prepare a poster presentation that explores one specific application for the technology in daily life.  Proposals should address both the technical and personal aspects of life with the technology.  Some questions to consider include : -What will it do and what will it be called? -What areas of daily life will it affect? -How will it supplement or replace a human activity? -What interaction will humans have with it (either directly or indirectly)? -How will it change the way people experience daily life at home, school and/or work? -How will it affect the way people behave, think or interact? -To what degree might it improve safety and/or efficiency for people? -How far in the future might this technology actually be available for use in daily life? Present posters to the class. Be sure to include illustrations, photographs and any additional details that will showcase your robot and demonstrate how it might be used in daily life. Extension Activities:1. Create an illustrated timeline of advancements in artificial intelligence.  What are some of the earliest examples of this technology? Choose one to investigate further. How has its form and function changed over time? What were some milestones in its development and what were the inspirations for those innovations? Present your findings to the class. 2. How might robots be used to assist people with special needs, those who are infirm and/or the elderly?  Investigate a specific special need, infirmity or age-related disability to determine what needs or activities might benefit from a robotic technology.  How might a robot assist people in that group?  How might life change with the introduction of a robot?  Be creative in imaging the form and function of the robotic technology. Present both the best possible scenario and the potential flaws.  How far in the future do you think your robot might be available for use? Prepare a poster presentation that demonstrates your investigation of the technology and the potential user. 3. Invite a robotics specialist to your class to demonstrate a robotic technology in development.  If possible, have the specialist bring tools to allow students to build their own robot. 4. Write a short science fiction story that features an artificial intelligence machine or system.  Is the robot the protagonist or antagonist?  What is the main theme? What are the conflicts and how are they resolved?  Are there human characters?  If so, what is the nature of their interactions with the robots?  When and where does the story take place?  Submit stories to the school literary journal for publication. 5. List all of the technologies you use on a daily basis.  Write a short story in which you imagine that these technologies are no longer available to you. Be creative in establishing your scenario. Where and when does your story take place? Why are the technologies not available? How will you communicate, play and work without them? Is life better, worse or just different without them? Share stories with the class. Interdisciplinary Connections:Fine Arts – How might artificial intelligence affect art-making practices?  Can an intelligently designed robot create art?  Is creativity something you can simulate?  Work with a robotics specialist to create a robot that can simulate the act of painting.  Can the robot be programmed to create different outcomes each time?  Discuss whether the finished products qualify as art and/or how an artist might use artificial intelligence to create an original work of art.  Display works created by the robot and/or the robot and humans in an exhibition for the school with an essay that explains your process. Math – Compare early computing machines of the 1950’s and 60’s with those in use today.  How do they compare in terms of processing power, memory, speed, accuracy, flexibility, adaptability and size?  Create a series of charts and graphs that demonstrate the changes in each area over time. Media Studies – Watch a film or television program in which artificial intelligence is featured, such as “2001: A Space Odyssey” (1968), “Star Wars” (1977, etc.), “Artificial Intelligence” (2001), “I, Robot” (2004),”The Incredibles” (2004), “Robots” (2005),  or “The Jetsons,” “Lost in Space,” “Battlebots” or “Futurama.” How are the robots portrayed?  What purpose do they serve? Do they take the place of humans? Do they create conflict or calm?  What are the robots’ assets and/or shortcomings? What is the power relationship between the humans and robots?  How do they interact with humans?  What positive and negative experiences or feelings do the humans have in relation to the robots? How might the portrayal of the robots in the film or television show reflect something about human society in reality?  Write a critical analysis that addresses these issues. Science – What is a neural network?  How does it affect cognition?  Investigate current students in human brain research as it relates to artificial intelligence.  What brain functions can currently be simulated by a computer or robot?  Could that function be automated?  Create a How It Works poster that explains that brain function and how it can be simulated by a robot. Teaching with The Times – Read The New York Times every week for one month and clip stories about people who you think might benefit from robotic technologies (such as those with disabilities, involved in search and rescue missions or in combat zones).  Propose a use for robotics in one of those examples.  Is there a current technology under development that might serve them? At the end of the month, write a reflection that summarizes how the lives of those explored might change with the introduction of a robot into their daily lives. To order The New York Times for your classroom, click here. THE TECHNOLOGY -What human behavior does it simulate? -How does it assist and/or replace humans? -In what way does it improve on a human capability? LIFESTYLE ANALYSIS -In what areas of life might the technology be used: home, work, school and/or the public sphere? -What types of experiences might it affect: work, learning, entertainment, health, transportation, everyday tasks, etc.? -How might this technology affect your life positively and/or negatively? -How might it alter the way people behave, think and/or interact with one another? Have students present their findings to the class. 4. WRAP-UP/HOMEWORK: How might a technology you or your classmates investigated in class be further developed for use in daily life at home, in school, in the workplace or for a public purpose? Choose any robotic technology presented in class to investigate further and consider how you or future generations might use it.  Prepare a poster presentation that explores one specific application for the technology in daily life.  Proposals should address both the technical and personal aspects of life with the technology.  Some questions to consider include : -What will it do and what will it be called? -What areas of daily life will it affect? -How will it supplement or replace a human activity? -What interaction will humans have with it (either directly or indirectly)? -How will it change the way people experience daily life at home, school and/or work? -How will it affect the way people behave, think or interact? -To what degree might it improve safety and/or efficiency for people? -How far in the future might this technology actually be available for use in daily life? Present posters to the class. Be sure to include illustrations, photographs and any additional details that will showcase your robot and demonstrate how it might be used in daily life. Extension Activities:1. Create an illustrated timeline of advancements in artificial intelligence.  What are some of the earliest examples of this technology? Choose one to investigate further. How has its form and function changed over time? What were some milestones in its development and what were the inspirations for those innovations? Present your findings to the class. 2. How might robots be used to assist people with special needs, those who are infirm and/or the elderly?  Investigate a specific special need, infirmity or age-related disability to determine what needs or activities might benefit from a robotic technology.  How might a robot assist people in that group?  How might life change with the introduction of a robot?  Be creative in imaging the form and function of the robotic technology. Present both the best possible scenario and the potential flaws.  How far in the future do you think your robot might be available for use? Prepare a poster presentation that demonstrates your investigation of the technology and the potential user. 3. Invite a robotics specialist to your class to demonstrate a robotic technology in development.  If possible, have the specialist bring tools to allow students to build their own robot. 4. Write a short science fiction story that features an artificial intelligence machine or system.  Is the robot the protagonist or antagonist?  What is the main theme? What are the conflicts and how are they resolved?  Are there human characters?  If so, what is the nature of their interactions with the robots?  When and where does the story take place?  Submit stories to the school literary journal for publication. 5. List all of the technologies you use on a daily basis.  Write a short story in which you imagine that these technologies are no longer available to you. Be creative in establishing your scenario. Where and when does your story take place? Why are the technologies not available? How will you communicate, play and work without them? Is life better, worse or just different without them? Share stories with the class. Interdisciplinary Connections:Fine Arts – How might artificial intelligence affect art-making practices?  Can an intelligently designed robot create art?  Is creativity something you can simulate?  Work with a robotics specialist to create a robot that can simulate the act of painting.  Can the robot be programmed to create different outcomes each time?  Discuss whether the finished products qualify as art and/or how an artist might use artificial intelligence to create an original work of art.  Display works created by the robot and/or the robot and humans in an exhibition for the school with an essay that explains your process. Math – Compare early computing machines of the 1950’s and 60’s with those in use today.  How do they compare in terms of processing power, memory, speed, accuracy, flexibility, adaptability and size?  Create a series of charts and graphs that demonstrate the changes in each area over time. Media Studies – Watch a film or television program in which artificial intelligence is featured, such as “2001: A Space Odyssey” (1968), “Star Wars” (1977, etc.), “Artificial Intelligence” (2001), “I, Robot” (2004),”The Incredibles” (2004), “Robots” (2005),  or “The Jetsons,” “Lost in Space,” “Battlebots” or “Futurama.” How are the robots portrayed?  What purpose do they serve? Do they take the place of humans? Do they create conflict or calm?  What are the robots’ assets and/or shortcomings? What is the power relationship between the humans and robots?  How do they interact with humans?  What positive and negative experiences or feelings do the humans have in relation to the robots? How might the portrayal of the robots in the film or television show reflect something about human society in reality?  Write a critical analysis that addresses these issues. Science – What is a neural network?  How does it affect cognition?  Investigate current students in human brain research as it relates to artificial intelligence.  What brain functions can currently be simulated by a computer or robot?  Could that function be automated?  Create a How It Works poster that explains that brain function and how it can be simulated by a robot. Teaching with The Times – Read The New York Times every week for one month and clip stories about people who you think might benefit from robotic technologies (such as those with disabilities, involved in search and rescue missions or in combat zones).  Propose a use for robotics in one of those examples.  Is there a current technology under development that might serve them? At the end of the month, write a reflection that summarizes how the lives of those explored might change with the introduction of a robot into their daily lives. To order The New York Times for your classroom, click here.
Title: Our Robots, Ourselves
Other (positive): concept of AI provides teachable topics              improving things in daily life; AI as teaching subject use in average daily life syllabus

Paragraph: Microsoft‘s drive into the health care market is just getting under way, but the company signaled Monday that one important ingredient in its plan will be a specialized search engine tailored to deliver useful medical information to consumers. Paragraph: When the cosmic game between humans and computers is complete, here’s how the sequence of moves will read. In the opening, humans evolved through engagement with nature. In the middle game, we projected our intelligence onto computers and co-evolved through engagement with them. In the endgame, we merged computers with our minds and bodies, bringing that projected intelligence back into ourselves. The distinction between human and artificial intelligence turns out to have been artificial. When the cosmic game between humans and computers is complete, here’s how the sequence of moves will read. The distinction between human and artificial intelligence turns out to have been artificial.
Title: Is the Only Winning Move Not to Play?

Paragraph: It’s also possible that posthuman scientists could find a way around the ethical problems of running a simulation on unwilling subjects. Peter Jenkins, an attorney, has reviewed current ethical guidelines for experiments and concluded that anecestor simulations could meet them. He cleverly suggests in this paper that posthuman scientists could recruit volunteers among the posthuman population – the AIs, as Mr. Jenkins calls these beings with artificial intelligence. When asked to give consent, the AI would not be informed what sort of life it would lead in the simulation; otherwise most AIs would not give consent unless the proposed life was somehow exceptional, e.g., Albert Einstein, Elvis Presley, Queen Elizabeth, etc. However, it would be necessary to inform the AI that it would be guaranteed not to be put into a life of extreme pain, suffering or hardship, e.g., a peasant living in grinding poverty. These sorts of roles in the simulation could be played by automated programs (“bots”) that are not self-aware. This implies that if you are a conscious individual who is experiencing extreme distress, then you probably exist in the real world of the early 21st century rather than in a simulation run by a future society. Conversely, if you are an individual whose life generally involves happiness, freedom and self-fulfillment, then you probably exist in a simulation (although there is one real version of you in the early 21st century). It’s also possible that posthuman scientists could find a way around the ethical problems of running a simulation on unwilling subjects. When asked to give consent, the AI would not be informed what sort of life it would lead in the simulation; otherwise most AIs would not give consent unless the proposed life was somehow exceptional, e.g., Albert Einstein, Elvis Presley, Queen Elizabeth, etc. However, it would be necessary to inform the AI that it would be guaranteed not to be put into a life of extreme pain, suffering or hardship, e.g., a peasant living in grinding poverty. These sorts of roles in the simulation could be played by automated programs (“bots”) that are not self-aware. This implies that if you are a conscious individual who is experiencing extreme distress, then you probably exist in the real world of the early 21st century rather than in a simulation run by a future society. Conversely, if you are an individual whose life generally involves happiness, freedom and self-fulfillment, then you probably exist in a simulation (although there is one real version of you in the early 21st century).
Title: To Sim or Not to Sim: Simulated Happiness versus Real Misery
Other (positive): AI could be studied as human beings are without violating ethical guidelines         AI can be experimented on to learn about humans without violating ethical standards

Paragraph: Bloomingdale۪s phantasmal windows are the most out there۝ of its department store peers this year, derived less from holiday imagery than than raw imagination of children. In collaboration with the Children۪s Museum of Manhattan and the Children۪s Museum of the Arts this summer, Bloomingdale۪s invited children to create collages, paintings and sculptures which were then converted into life-size scenes. The plots may not make so much sense by traditional standards, but the visual impact of the scenes are intense, featuring characters like an alien queen with five eyes and two mouths, a robot with a candy heart and a glowing purple snowflake with oracle-like qualities.

Paragraph: Activities / Procedures:1. WARM-UP/DO NOW: Before class, write the following prompt on the board (and, if possible, cover it up to reveal it after the initial activity): Was this activity difficult and why? What signals was your brain receiving during the activity? How did your brain interpret and translate the signals into an action? Did the game get easier with practice and why?۝ Begin by playing a short action game in which the visual clue and the oral clue given to students do not match. For example, you might tell students to pat their knee۝ at the same time you pat the top of your head. Or you might tell students to touch their nose۝ while you touch your ear. Instruct students to only do the action that you say aloud. After a few rounds of the game, have students respond to the prompt in their journals. Discuss students۪ reactions and prior knowledge they have about how the brain sends and receives messages. What do you know about how the brain and nervous system work? 2. As a class, read and discuss the article Monkey۪s Thoughts Propel Robot, a Step That May Help Humans۝ (http://www.nytimes.com/learning/teachers/featured_articles/20080115tuesday.html), focusing on the following questions:  a. Why is this experiment a significant advancement in the field of brain research and robotics? b. What would a brain machine interface۝ do?  c. What are the potential applications of the research conducted with Idoya?  d. What steps are necessary before this kind of interface is usable in humans?  e. What is implied by Dr. Nicolelis۪s statement, That۪s one small step for a robot and one giant leap for a primate۝?  f. What parts of Idoya۪s brain were responsible for motion?  g. How did Idoya demonstrate the ability to create new neural connections in her brain?  h. How did Idoya۪s brain activity show that she was controlling the robot۪s motion? 3. Have students work in small groups to make a quick sketch diagramming the set up and implementation of the experiment as detailed in the article. Encourage groups to visualize how the thoughts of the monkey in North Carolina caused the robot in Japan to move. How was the brain machine interface used to translate the brain activity of the monkey to control the movements of the robot? Then, have students compare their sketches to the New York Times Image Moving by Thought,۝ found online at http://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2008/01/14/science/20080115_monkey.html. Discuss the steps in the diagram to further clarify the innovation described in the article. Then tell students that they will research how the brain controls the movement of the body by sending and receiving messages, focusing on the brain activity and muscle movements in humans that cause motion. These are similar to the brain activity and movement of the monkey that scientists monitored and recorded in the experiment. In their small groups, have students begin by brainstorming a list of voluntary actions they use on a daily basis, such as walking, chewing, running, jumping, writing, turning their head, driving or picking up a book. Then, the group should choose one motion and work together to create a diagram mapping how the brain and nervous system are responsible for this motion. Diagrams should include the brain and the parts of the central and peripheral nervous systems, including the structure and function of neurons and sensory receptors. Instruct students to use labels, numbers and text boxes to describe clearly the sequence of events necessary for the voluntary action to occur. Next, explain that they should apply what they learn about the brain and nervous system in the research phase of the activity to make and add details to their diagram. Provide the following general questions to guide students۪ research, and remind students consider how the brain initiates motion, reacts to sensory stimuli and causes continuous fluid actions. GUIDING QUESTIONS -What parts of the body are involved in the action?  -What are the different parts of the brain and nervous system? -What specific parts of the brain are activated during a voluntary movement? How do they coordinate to produce voluntary motions? -What are the parts of a neuron? How do neurons transmit messages to and from the brain?  -How is sensory information collected by the body and transmitted to the brain during motion? Why is this information necessary for movement?  -If a brain machine interface were used, where in the brain would electrodes most likely be implanted to control the desired motion? The level of detail required in the diagrams should depend on the students۪ ability level. For example, beginning students might state that a signal is transmitted from the motor cortex of the brain, through the spinal cord and peripheral nervous system to the muscles of the arm,۝ while advanced students might also describe the electrochemical activity responsible for transmitting signals across the synapses between neurons. When small groups are ready, have students present their diagrams to the class. Have students from other groups do the action in slow motion while the group explains the brain activity involved in the fractions of a second it takes the brain to chew, take a step, pick up a pencil or throw a ball. Could the classmates act out the motion using the description? Does anything need to be added, deleted, clarified, or otherwise changed in the diagram? Before the end of class, have students imagine what it might be like to have a disability, such as paralysis or a mobility-limiting injury or affliction. Have students how the brain interface technology described by the article might help people with these disabilities in the future, such as helping a stroke victim regain clear speech. Then, in preparation for the homework, have students brainstorm other possible uses for this technology, such as eliminating the need for workers such as miners or astronauts to physically enter potentially dangerous situations or enhancing a virtual۝ video game to a new level. 4. WRAP-UP/HOMEWORK: Individually, students should respond to the following prompt (provided before students leave class): Dr. Nicolelis said, We have shown that you can take signals across the planet in the same time scale that a biological system works. Here the target happens to be a robot. It could be a crane. Or any tool of any size or magnitude. The body does not have a monopoly for enacting the desires of the brain.۪ Using this quote, your imagination, and what you learned about the physiology of movement in class, write a one-page proposal outlining an idea for a science fiction story, comic book series or screenplay. Describe the characters, include a plot summary and hypothesize potential problems that characters might encounter. Include a detailed account of how you will explain the science behind the brain motion interface to give the story a realistic element and make it seem plausible.۝ Extension Activities:1. Test your knowledge of the human brain and neuroscience with the New York Times Learning Network’s crossword puzzle, found online at http://www.nytimes.com/learning/teachers/xwords/20070717.html. 2. Build a model of the brain. Include a description of the structure and function of each part of the brain. How does the brain control all the other systems of the body? Present your model to the class. 3. Invite a robotics specialist to your class to demonstrate a robotic technology in development. 4. Read a science fiction book that incorporates artificial intelligence or robotic advancements into the story, such as “Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?” by Philip K. Dick or “2001: A Space Odyssey” by Arthur C. Clarke. Write a book report describing the plot of the story. Extension Activities:1. Test your knowledge of the human brain and neuroscience with the New York Times Learning Network’s crossword puzzle, found online at http://www.nytimes.com/learning/teachers/xwords/20070717.html. 2. Build a model of the brain. Include a description of the structure and function of each part of the brain. How does the brain control all the other systems of the body? Present your model to the class. 3. Invite a robotics specialist to your class to demonstrate a robotic technology in development. 4. Read a science fiction book that incorporates artificial intelligence or robotic advancements into the story, such as “Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?” by Philip K. Dick or “2001: A Space Odyssey” by Arthur C. Clarke. Write a book report describing the plot of the story.
Title: We Think, Therefore We Move
Other (positive): Monkey۪s Thoughts Propel Robot

Paragraph: Robert Pearlman of the space history news site Collectspace.com jokes that the robot, with its enormous arms, reminds him of the scene from the movie Dave۝ when Kevin Kline, using a pair of robotic arms, cracks up a crowd by intoning, I once caught a fish this big,۝ and spread the robot arms wide, wide, wide. Of course, for those of a fussy bent, what۪s being assembled is not actually a robot (which is a device with a degree of autonomy), but is more precisely a waldo,۝ or an extension of the user۪s hands. That term comes from a science fiction story by Robert Heinlein. But the space program uses the term robot broadly  and the humor has been a little broad, too. Pierre Jean, the acting head of the station program for the Canadian Space Agency, said that it was natural to joke a bit about Dextre; after working on the program for ten years, he said, the Canadian team had come to feel that while the Canadian robot arm, called Canadarm, was an it,۝ Dextre was a he,'۝ he said. And we started treating it as one of the gang.۝
Title: Space: Also a Frontier for Corny Jokes

Paragraph: While propulsion and life-support technology are improving, it seems fair to predict that the development of near-human-intelligence Artificial Intelligence will precede the advent of interplanetary human spaceflight. This development will greatly diminish the importance of humans to space exploration, since space probes will be freed from the chains of Earthly control, able instead to “phone home” once in awhile like dutiful offspring. And by the time that interstellar spaceflight becomes feasible for humans, it is likely that AI technology will have become fantastically advanced, giving rise to brilliant, possibly self-replicating probes which will scour the galaxy for the benefit of their builders. Paragraph: It is a modest-sized purchase for IBM, but Ilog, based in Paris and founded 21 years ago, is an intriguing company. Ilog traces its heritage to the LISP programming language and artificial intelligence research. It is a leader in the growing niche called “business rules” software, which enables ordinary users to build rules into software by themselves without the assistance of a professional programmer. Rules, in this sense, are essentially if-then statements. They are used for everything from vetting customer credit-risk at banks to helping to guide search-and-rescue robots. Paragraph: What۪s remarkable about this robot is that it learned some previously impossible maneuvers (for a robot helicopter) by essentially observing a human. The Stanford researchers had tried the traditional approach  writing a program instructing the robot what to do  but failed because the aerodynamic problems were so complicated. So they relied instead on apprenticeship learning۝ and turned for help to a non-electronic brain: a human expert who had already figured out how to do these stunts with a radio-controlled helicopter.The researchers couldn۪t tell the robot simply to copy the signals sent by the human pilot operating the remote controls, because these signals vary from flight to flight as the human pilot reacts to changes in the wind. But by using a learning algorithm to analyze the signals sent in a series of flights, the computer was able to figure out a strategy for performing the stunts without crashing the helicopter. After this apprenticeship, the robot performed an airshow that included by far the most difficult aerobatic maneuvers flown by any computer-controlled helicopter,۝ said Andrew Ng, a professor of computer science at Stanford, who directed the helicopter project of graduate students Pieter Abbeel, Adam Coates, Timothy Hunter and Morgan Quigley. The researchers say this sort of apprenticeship could produce robot helicopters capable of performing tasks like gathering data in the middle of forest fires or searching for land mines.
Title: The Flying Robot Apprentice
Other (positive): robot learned from human, the computer was able to perform the stunts without crashing the helicopter. gathering data in the middle of forest fires, searching for land mines. disaster application, bomb detection, robots go where humans can't

The Halcyon Company, which owns the rights to the Terminator۝ series, announced the fifth film at the Dubai International Film Festival; no title or start date was given, but the movie is expected to be released in 2011.

Paragraph: Fast & Furious۝ may have also benefited from a boom in moviegoing that many experts have tied to a need for affordable entertainment during the recession. Total ticket sales for the year are $2.73 billion, a 15 percent increase over the same period last year, according to Media By Numbers, a box office tracking firm. Attendance is up 13 percent.DreamWorks Animation LLC Ginormica flees alien robot in Monsters vs. Aliens.۝Last weekend۪s top movie, Monsters vs. Aliens۝ from DreamWorks Animation, was in second place this weekend. The 3-D movie sold an estimated $33.5 million in tickets, according to Box Office Mojo, for a new domestic total of $105.7 million.Rounding out the top five were the horror film The Haunting in Connecticut۝ from Lionsgate with an estimated $9.6 million ($37.2 million); the thriller Knowing۝ from Summit Entertainment with an estimated $8.1 million ($58.2 million); and the buddy comedy I Love You, Man۝ from Paramount Pictures and DreamWorks Studios with an estimated $7.9 million ($49.3 million).The only other movie of note to open over the weekend was Adventureland,۝ a dramatic comedy from Miramax. The low-budget, R-rated picture sold an estimated $6 million in tickets in a medium-sized run in theaters. A tuned up Fast & Furious۝ zoomed to No. 1 at the weekend box office, selling an unexpectedly strong $72.5 million in tickets in North American theaters.Eli Reed/Universal Studios Some of the cars in 2 Fast 2 Furious.۝The result  more summer than spring, which is typically a quiet moviegoing period  reignites a film franchise that had been dismissed by Hollywood, if not Universal Pictures, following a disappointing third installment in 2006. That movie, The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift,۝ stalled after selling just $62.5 million at domestic theaters, less than half the total of each of its two predecessors, The Fast and the Furious۝ and 2 Fast 2 Furious.۝But Universal and its financing partner, Relativity Media, decided to place another bet on the street-racing franchise. Research showed that audiences were still keenly interested in Vin Diesel, who moved on after headlining the original The Fast and the Furious.۝ If it could get other members of the original cast to return, Universal figured the audience would turn out for a fourth movie  and bring their kids.Sidney Balwin/Universal Pictures Lucas Black in The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift.۝I۪m euphoric that our production team had the foresight to do this even though people snickered,۝ said Nikki Rocco, president of Universal Pictures distribution. We saw an opening for a big action movie in April and decided to bite the bullet.۝Ms. Rocco said interest across ethnicities helped fuel ticket sales, validating the studio۪s decision to aggressively pitch the movie to Hispanic audiences. In Fast & Furious,۝ a fugitive ex-con (Mr. Diesel) reluctantly teams up with an FBI agent (Paul Walker) to infiltrate a heroin-importing operation in Mexico and Los Angeles.Universal۪s creative team is starting to become known for spotting life in ideas that other industry experts feel have burned out. Last summer, the studio turned Hellboy II: The Golden Army۝ into a hit after Sony Pictures Entertainment passed on making a sequel.Fast & Furious۝ may have also benefited from a boom in moviegoing that many experts have tied to a need for affordable entertainment during the recession. Total ticket sales for the year are $2.73 billion, a 15 percent increase over the same period last year, according to Media By Numbers, a box office tracking firm. Attendance is up 13 percent.DreamWorks Animation LLC Ginormica flees alien robot in Monsters vs. Aliens.۝Last weekend۪s top movie, Monsters vs. Aliens۝ from DreamWorks Animation, was in second place this weekend. The 3-D movie sold an estimated $33.5 million in tickets, according to Box Office Mojo, for a new domestic total of $105.7 million.Rounding out the top five were the horror film The Haunting in Connecticut۝ from Lionsgate with an estimated $9.6 million ($37.2 million); the thriller Knowing۝ from Summit Entertainment with an estimated $8.1 million ($58.2 million); and the buddy comedy I Love You, Man۝ from Paramount Pictures and DreamWorks Studios with an estimated $7.9 million ($49.3 million).The only other movie of note to open over the weekend was Adventureland,۝ a dramatic comedy from Miramax. The low-budget, R-rated picture sold an estimated $6 million in tickets in a medium-sized run in theaters.
Title: Summer Comes Early for Hollywood (and Christmas Comes Early for Vin Diesel)

Paragraph: Technology | Promoters of artificial intelligence regularly describe the mind and brain as the “software and hardware” of thinking, writes Ari N. Schulman, an editor of the technology-and-ethics journal The New Atlantis. Also, they describe senses as “inputs” and behaviors as “outputs,” neurons as “processing units” and synapses as “circuitry.” But this brain-as-computer metaphor doesn’t hold up when you examine the actual workings of computers, Schulman says. So proponents thus may be engaging in wishful thinking or misleading people about the possibilities of artificial intelligence — from computer therapy programs that replace your real-life shrink to robotic pets. [New Atlantis]More Recommended Reading: Technology | Promoters of artificial intelligence regularly describe the mind and brain as the “software and hardware” of thinking, writes Ari N. So proponents thus may be engaging in wishful thinking or misleading people about the possibilities of artificial intelligence — from computer therapy programs that replace your real-life shrink to robotic pets. [New Atlantis]More Recommended Reading:
Title: Are Minds Really Like Computers?

Title: Honda Develops a Robot Controlled by Human Thought. Or Is That a Joke?
